headline: Investigators in Reuters Case Met With Computer Consultant Months Ago
abstract: Executive with Cyberspace Research was confronted several months ago by Federal law enforcement officials investigating whether company was commissioned by subsidiary of Reuters Holdings PLC to steal information electronically from rival, Bloomberg LP; contact between Government and Cyberspace executive suggests that at least some people working with company could have been cooperating with Federal investigators of Reuters Analytics Inc, before it was disclosed last week; prosecutors have been investigating for as long as a year to determine whether Reuters took part in scheme to steal proprietary information maintained in Bloomberg's central computers; they are examining whether that information was later improperly incorporated into products like Reuters 3000, which as been widely viewed in financial data industry as product most likely to compete with Bloomberg terminal (L)

headline: Israelis Lining Up for Gas Masks as Officials Warn Iraq
abstract: Israelis, edgy after local press reports about Iraq's arsenal, are lining up for gas-masks; Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai warns that Israel will defend itself if attacked by Iraq in retaliation for US military strike (M)

headline: Yeltsin Tells Parliament to Fix Economy, and Win I.M.F. Aid
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin scores proposed budget and renews threat to form new Government if Cabinet does not quickly resolve nation's economic problems, annual speech to Parliament; scores neglect of debt obligations (M)

headline: Benjamin Bowden, 91, Auto and Bicycle Designer
abstract: Benjamin Bowden, industrial designer who created futuristic bicycle that became expensive collector's item, dies at age 91 (M)

headline: INDONESIAN RUPIAH REBOUNDS.
abstract: Indonesian rupiah recovers after sharp plunge; graphs; table (S)8

headline: Turks Clash Over Defense of Virginity Tests
abstract: Turkish feminists demand resignation of Isilay Saygin, Cabinet minister in charge of women's affairs, after she defends traditional practice of subjecting women to virginity tests (M)

headline: 2 Corporate Cultures Meet in MCI-Worldcom Merger
abstract: Challenge of integrating differing corporate cultures of MCI Communications Corp and Worldcom Inc--one a brash newcomer to upper echelons of telecommunications world, the other onetime rebel that joined establishment--is just one of potential hurdles in pending merger; analysts say those hurdles are not likely to block merger altogether; two companies will propose directors of the new company; photo of MCI chairman Bert C Roberts Jr and Worldcom head Bernard J Ebbers (L)

headline: 3 Acquisitions By Sunbeam in Separate Deals
abstract: Sunbeam Corp, which discharged half its 12,000 workers and closed dozens of plants since Albert J Dunlap took over as chairman 18 months ago, announces three separate acquisitions worth total of $1.8 billion that will more than double Sunbeam's size; company will pay $1.6 billion for Coleman Co Inc and assume $440 million in debt; Coleman is controlled by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, which will become one of Sunbeam's largest shareholders; Sunbeam will also purchase Signature Brands USA Inc, maker of Mr Coffee coffee makers, for $279 million and assume $165 million in debt; third company is First Alert Inc, for which Sunbeam will pay $133 million plus assumption of $43 million in debt; chart (M)

headline: FIRSTBANK OF ILLINOIS TO BE ACQUIRED BY RIVAL
abstract: Mercantile Bancorp agrees to acquire Firstbank of Illinois Co for $697 million in stock (S)

headline: Senate Urges U.N. to Try Iraqi as a War Criminal
abstract: Senate votes 93-0 to urge creation of United Nations tribunal to try Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein as war criminal; Sen Arlen Specter, resolution's main sponsor, comments; House approved similar resolution in Nov (M)

headline: Razorfish Teams Up With Avalanche
abstract: Razorfish advertising agency acquires Avalanche ad agency; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Need for Information
abstract: Arthur Westneat letter requests Circuits section run articles on updating home-built computers (S)m

headline: Those Hidden, Sometimes Hefty Transaction Costs Can Be a Drag
abstract: Warning about variety of sometimes hefty, often hidden, transaction-related costs that can drag down performance of certain mutual funds (S)

headline: Love Affair With Mutual Funds Shows No Evidence of Weakening
abstract: Mutual fund industry just finished its biggest year ever; even after three straight years of torrid growth, Americans show few signs of slowing down in their drive to accumulate assets for retirement; chart (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Lay Out Concerns About Lockheed-Northrop Deal
abstract: Pentagon and Justice Department raises serious concerns about Lockheed Martin Corp's plan to buy Northrop Grumman Corp because deal would all but eliminate competition in manufacturing of certain radar and electronic warfare systems (L)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKASHOK, LILLIAN G.
abstract: LUKASHOK-Lillian G. The Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Lillian G. Lukashok. A longtime supporter of UJA-Federation, she dedicated her life to philanthropy and leadership in many communal organizations. She was a friend of the entire Jewish community. Our condolences go to her son, Martin; her sister, Frances Horowitz; her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and her entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Susan K. Stern, Vice Chair, Campaign & Chair, Women's Campaign Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

headline: Edmund Asbury Gullion, 85, Wide-Ranging Career Envoy
abstract: Edmund Asbury Gullion, one of country's most accomplished career ambassadors and former dean of Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, dies at age 85 (M)

headline: Archives Yield Aid for Claims On Holocaust
abstract: Holocaust survivors and relatives of victims after World War II pressed insurance claims against German and Italian companies, which denied many of them because claimants lacked death certificates or other documentation; researchers have recovered from government and private archives documents that strengthen those claims and show how top executives of biggest German insurance company, Allianz AG, worked closely with Third Reich to seize policies owned by Jews; experts say most significant document is copy of Austrian State Police report that directs Italian subsidiary of Allianz to turn over funds to Nazis; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Mark falls on surprising declines in German business confidence and money supply growth (S)

headline: It seems there's no fail-safe way of protecting children on the Internet.
abstract: Thomas Morgan, president of Nvolve Inc, company that develops on-line communities, is promoting Safe Playgrounds initiative; his proposed set of laws, guidelines and coding systems is aimed at protecting children from pornography and sexual and commercial predators on the Internet; drawing (Technology column) (M)

headline: A Number of Deals Are Made in Europe
abstract: Zenith Media Services is named to handle worldwide media buying for Alcatel Alsthom SA; duties on the account, with billings estimated at $150 million, had been handled by various agencies, including Optimum Media, part of Omnicom Group; McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising expands operations in former Soviet Union; McCann also expands its relationship with Adam Opel AG, unit of General Motors Corp as Opel Southeast Europe Ltd in Budapest names McCann as first agency to handle advertising for Opel vehicles in nine countries; J Walter Thompson Frankfurt is named to handle pan-European advertising for Minolta's business equipment operations (M)

headline: Alumni of 2 Colleges Bestride World of Fashion : London:the Runway to Success
abstract: LONDON—  To outsiders, it might seem like a conspiracy — two London fashion colleges intent on world domination infiltrate their students into the prime jobs in international fashion.

headline: SIEMENS DEAL COULD BRING MCI $2.1 BILLION IN BUSINESS
abstract: Siemens AG unit and MCI Communications Corp sign five-year agreement that could bring $2.1 billion in business to MCI, No. 2 United States long-distance company (S)

headline: Life Magazine, Struggling for Niche, Dismisses a Third of Staff
abstract: Life magazine dismisses 15 editorial employees, or 33 percent of staff, on orders of Isolde Motley, who became managing editor on Jan 1 (M)

headline: High-Stakes Face-Off Begins for Columbia/HCA
abstract: The decision by the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation to try to settle possible Federal charges signals what could be the start of a high-stakes face-off in the sprawling fraud investigation of the company.     For Columbia, the world's largest health care company, the stakes are obvious. To limit its business troubles, it must put the investigation behind it quickly without paying more in penalties than it can afford. It must also avoid being barred from Federal programs like Medicare, as a fraud conviction could require.

headline: Amid Blame, United Artists Sale Collapses
abstract: United Artists and its controlling investor, Merrill Lynch & Co, and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst offer conflicting accounts of collapse of deal for leveraged-buyout firm to acquire nation's third-largest theater chain; collapse slows Hicks, Muse's joint effort with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co to gain savings by building dominant company in fragmented industry (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Robert E. Torray; Torray Fund
abstract: Torray Fund portfolio manager Robert E Torray discusses investment strategy, interview; graphs; table; photo (M)

headline: Under the Hood
abstract: List of program files loaded by Microsoft's Internet Explorer and, for few key files, description of what they do; Microsoft contends that without Explorer, its Windows 95 operating system and features of other software will not work; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Fines Weimar Bond Dealer $60,500
abstract: Michigan brokerage firm J W Korth & Co that sold investors some defaulted Weimer Republic bonds has been ordered by Federal Judge Ursula Ungaro-Benages to pay $60,500 for failing to cooperate with Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the bonds; firm refused to give regulators serial numbers for about $145,000 in bonds, which it says were probably stolen from Jewish bondholders by Nazis years after their issuance (S)

headline: U.S. Ties Unaffected, Russian Tells Albright
abstract: Foreign Min Yevgeny M Primakov tells Sec of State Madeline K Albright in Moscow that Russia's foreign policy will remain unchanged despite political turmoil; photo (M)

headline: The Art of Swimming Against the Tide
abstract: Question-and-answer article with Anthony M Gallea, senior portfolio manager at Smith Barney office in Rochester, NY, where he oversees $600 million in client assets; Gallea is a contrarian who studies psycholgy of possible investment; describers his approach to investing; chart outlines his suggestions on buying and selling stocks; photo (M)

headline: David C. Masket, 67, Ex-Apparel Executive
abstract: David C Masket, former president of Maidenform Worldwide, dies at 67 (S)

headline: West Fears Bosnia Funds Aid Hard-Line Serbs
abstract: Western Governments, preparing to spend some $130 million on new aid projects in Bosnian Serb areas, are concerned that some of aid will bolster or enrich leaders who oppose Western efforts to promote peace and ethnic tolerance; aid officials say money is tool for gaining influence and spurring political change, even if much of it goes to authorities who routinely renege on commitments; map (M)

headline: AXA's Profit Soared In 2d Half of '97
abstract: AXA SA, French insurer, says its second-half profit almost quadrupled amid gains in foreign operations and turnaround at French insurer it acquired last year; says profit rose to 3.7 billion francs ($607 million) in half from 1 billion francs year earlier (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shares of the high-flying LHS Group may be getting some help from hype in Germany
abstract: Market Place column on some reasons for rapid rise in stock of LHS Group; says American company, which develops software for telecommunications industry and was founded in Germany, is being touted in German newsletters and on television; holds while LHS is listed on Nasdaq it is also listed on Neuer Markt, a new stock exchange in Frankfurt modeled on Nasdaq that trades four times daily average of Nasdaq (M)

headline: Suharto's New Cabinet Expected to Set Back Hopes for Indonesian Reform
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto names Cabinet marked by loyalty and family ties, not economic expertise; lineup suggests Indonesia plans to resist International Monetary Fund demands for more open economy that would reduce role of Suharto family, favoritism and cartels; Cabinet includes Suharto's daughter, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, as Social Affairs Minister and his close friend, Mohammad Hasan, as Trade and Industry Minister; Finance Min Fuad Bawazier is seen as close to Suharto family and supportive of its economic interests; photo (M)

headline: Italy's Hard Right Sheds Neo-Fascist Past for Respectability
abstract: Italy's National Alliance, hard right-wing political party, held three-day conference in Verona, where it shed last loyalties to lingering Fascist tradition, and emerged as stable, indispensable and increasingly respectable member of country's center-right opposition (M)

headline: Clifford and Altman Settle With Fed Over B.C.C.I.
abstract: Clark M Clifford and his law partner, Robert A Altman, have reached $5 million settlement with Federal Reserve, resolving one of last actions against them stemming from 1991 collapse of Bank of Credit and Commerce International; Clifford and Altman do not admit to any of Federal Reserve's allegations; Altman agrees not to participate in banking industry without approval of Federal Reserve; Fed dismissed similar prohibition against Clifford, who is elderly and in poor health; two men face only legal action from liquidators of BCCI and holding company of First American Bankshares Inc, banking group based in Washington that was secretly owned by BCCI (L)

headline: Trade Deficit For 1997 Hit 9-Year High
abstract: US trade deficit in 1997 reaches its highest level in nine years, and jump in December suggests deficit will surge again this year because of Asia's financial crisis; imports exceed exports by $10.8 billion in December, increase in deficit of $2.1 billion compared with November's figures; economists expected December's deficit to be about $9 billion; monthly figures show first tentative signs of Asia's effect on trade patterns; trade deficit with South Korea expands by $300 million in December, to $343 million; overall deficit in 1997 is $113.7 billion, up from $111 billion in 1996; deficit in trade of goods alone sets new record of $198.9 billion in 1997 but is offset by surplus in services trade of record $85.2 billion (M)

headline: A Little English Goes Far in Seoul
abstract: SEOUL—  From 7 A.M. to well into the evening, in hundreds of small classrooms across the country, young Koreans are struggling to learn English conversation.

headline: Clinton Urges Irish to Grab 'The Chance of a Lifetime'
abstract: Pres Clinton meets at White House with Ireland Prime Min Bertie Ahern and Northern Ireland political leaders David Trimble, John Hume, Gary McMichael and Lord Alderdice in what Clinton calls '30-hour marathon effort'; he admonishes them not to squander 'chance of a lifetime for peace'; photo (M)

headline: Rene de Epelbaum, 77, Argentine Protester
abstract: Rene de Epelbaum, founder of Argentina's Plaza de Mayo human rights group, dies at age 77 (S)

headline: INVESTING IT; Baseball and Beyond
abstract: Rawlings Sporting Goods prepares to expand behond its historical stronghold, baseball, having acquired Victoriaville line of hockey equipment and entered alliance with Host Communications, nation's leanding sports marketer, which will push Rawlings name and products through joint promotions with corporations; Bull Run Corp, which recently acquired 10 percent of Rawlings stock, may also help company exploit its powerful brand name; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Sanofi Profit Fell 18.9% in 2d Half of '97
abstract: Sanofi SA's profit fell 18.9 percent in second half of 1997; posts profit of $860 million French francs ($142.8 milion); profit for full year rose 10 percent, to 1.92 billion francs from 1.74 billion francs; sales rose 9 percent in 1997, to 25.7 billion francs (S)

headline: ST. PAUL BANCORP TO BUY RIVAL IN ILLINOIS
abstract: St Paul Bancorp agrees to buy rival Beverly Bancorporation for $170 million in stock (S)

headline: People
abstract: Listing of recent appointments and promotions in advertising industry (S)

headline: Italy's New Fiscal Rigor Fails to Reassure Europe
abstract: Doubts persist among Italy's partners in European Union despite success of center-left Government in more than halving budget deficit to 2.7 percent of gross domestic product--below limit set by Maastricht Treaty for members to join planned single currency in 1999; politicians in Netherlands and Germany are questioning Italy's ability to sustain new-found fiscal rectitude; key concern is country's public debt ratio, which at approximately 122.7 percent of gross domestic product is more than twice 60 percent goal set by Maastricht Treaty guidelines (M)

headline: Battling Junk E-Mail May Become Easier
abstract: Sendmail, the most popular software used to deliver E-mail on the Internet, is getting a powerful set of tools to fight the junk mail known as spam, which is increasingly clogging cyberspace and filling mailboxes of Internet users with unwanted promotions on subjects as diverse as get-rich-quick schemes and pornography.

headline: Some not-so-nostalgic memories of the old times with computers.
abstract: Edward Rothstein article, recalling frustrating time he had programming computer for scientific experiment years ago, cites ease with which researcher in same lab today is able to collect data on far smaller computer with few lines of simple computer code; holds computer advances have changed nature of detail and premises, allowing more to be imagined as more is taken for granted (M)

headline: Business World
abstract: Business Day's annual survey of the economy, markets and industry examines whether the prosperity enjoyed by Wall Street and Main Street in 1997 can continue for another year, and whether problems like the Asian financial crisis will endanger economic growth.     Section D (2 parts).

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  None reported

headline: People
abstract: * Patricia Doyle was named to the new position of executive vice president for worldwide accounts and strategic services on the Compaq Computer Corp. account at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. She had been senior vice president and executive group director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of WPP Group.

headline: Federal Express Now FDX
abstract: Federal Express Corp changes its name to FDX Corp, after completing its $2.25 billion purchase of trucking company Caliber System Inc on Jan 27 (S)

headline: A Safety Net, An Extension
abstract: Advice on requesting extra time to complete Federal income tax return; drawing (S)

headline: Clinton Likely to Win Over Senate on Expanding NATO
abstract: Clinton Administration's campaign to sell Senate on expansion of NATO appears near successful conclusion; Senate Foreign Relations Committee chmn Jesse Helms says expansion will make NATO stronger and make Europe more peaceful and united; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, Defense Sec William S Cohen and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chmn Henry H Shelton support NATO's expansion at committee's final hearing on issue before Senate vote (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises nearly 4 percent, to highest level since November, on news that warehouse stockpiles are declining; May delivery contracts settle at 83.70 cents a pound; graphs; table (S)

headline: Chief of Gtech Quits in Wake Of Libel Case
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp chairman Guy B Snowden resigns one day after British jury finds that he committed libel in connection with effort to win contract to operate Britain's national lottery;; Snowden's resignation comes after libel case in London involving Virgin Group PLC head Richard Branson; Branson publicly accused Snowden of trying to bribe him into withdrawing from competition for lucrative contract to operate Britain's lottery; Snowden denied accusation; Branson contended that Snowden committed libel by calling him a liar; jury also awards $164,700 to Branson; Snowden is replaced by William Y O'Connor, who will continue as president and chief executive officer (M)

headline: 3 Agencies Form Specialized Divisions
abstract: Three agencies form new divisions in health care advertising, product development and strategic consulting; they are Gillespie in Princeton, NJ, Northlich Stolley LaWarre, and Bates USA (S)

headline: Study Questions The Usual View Of Downsizing
abstract: Study by Educational Testing Service shows more jobs are being created for business managers and professionals than high-technology workers; study challenges two widely held views about the work force; one is that corporate downsizing has decimated middle-level management; study finds downsizing has been widespread, but hiring has outpaced layoffs; other challenge is to concept that corporate America is starved for people highly skilled in technology; real draw for college graduate is upper-level office job, not a job that requires education in science and technology; that specialty work does not pay as much; study shows thirty-seven percent of all jobs created since 1989 have been for 'business professionals and managers'; that is up from 20 percent of new jobs in 1970's; graph (L)

headline: San Francisco Tries to Retain Its 'Multimedia Gulch'
abstract: San Francisco has overtaken Silicon Valley as more popular home of interactive media, catchall label describing Internet service companies, Web site developers, interactive game makers and CD-ROM publishers; despite many amenities of having headquarters in city, executives of interactive media start-ups are grumbling about increasingly high rents, lack of parking and city bureaucracy that makes it difficult to expand; Mayor Willie L Brown, eager to keep these businesses in his city, has met with several hundred industry executives, and already city has responded to some of their complaints; photo (M)

headline: Israel Calls British Aide's Visit To Disputed Site Unacceptable
abstract: Israeli Government criticizes as unacceptable intention of British Foreign Sec Robin Cook to visit site of disputed new Jewish settlement in eastern Jerusalem; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu may refuse to meet him; planned visit is part of Cook's three-day visit to Middle East as representative of European Union (M)

headline: Antitrust Scrutiny Ends Plan To Merge Accounting Firms
abstract: Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick abandon merger plans in face of growing opposition from foreign antitrust regulators; regulators are concerned that merger would further reduce the number of accounting firms that public companies have to choose from; abandonment of merger by these two firms might reduce regulatory opposition to another planned accounting merger, that between Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand (M)

headline: Staying With the Pitch; Stalwarts of Face-to-Face Sales Reluctant to Peddle on Line
abstract: Number of major direct-sale businesses, including Tupperware, Amway and Mary Kay, continue to shun idea of selling directly to consumers on line, although each has built Web presence for educating consumers, enhancing brands and recruiting salespeople; others, including Avon Products and Fuller Brush unit of CPAC Inc, are offering products on line to appeal to wired generation, but continue to stress face-to-face selling; drawing; table (M)

headline: Japanese Auto Exports To U.S. Fell in December
abstract: Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association says Japanese auto exports to US fell in December 1997 for first time in 16 months; says exports fell 2.4 percent, to 90,239 vehicles; even with December's decline, exports to US increased 15.7 percent for 1997, first rise in three years; Japan's global exports in 1997 increased, by 22.7 percent, to 4.5 million vehicles, first rise in 12 years (S)

headline: Senators Ask Microsoft to Ease Data Release
abstract: Senate Judiciary Committee formally asks Microsoft Corp to allow business partners to provide information to committee without notifying software maker; committee makes request in letter signed by Sen Orrin G Hatch, chairman, and three other committee members; similar letters are sent to Netscape Communications Corp and Sun Microsystems Inc (S)

headline: India's Confident Leader Faces a Key Vote Today
abstract: Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India strengthens his week-old Hindu nationalist coalition by assuring Indians that policies will not depart from those of previous governments; nationalists are expected to have trouble holding coalition together over longer term; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Consolidates Marketing Roster
abstract: IBM consolidates its agency roster for worldwide direct and interactive marketing at 4 shops from 30; combined billings estimated at $100 million; shops are Barry Blau & Partners, unit of Bronner Slosberg Humphrey, unit of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and Wunderman Cato Johnson (S)

headline: Worsening Financial Flu in Asia Lowers Immunity to U.S. Business
abstract: Experts say Asia's financial crisis may result in greatly expanded American business presence in region, particularly in markets that have historically been sensitive and often closed; market pressures, principally desperation for cash, and some arm-twisting by US and International Monetary Fund could give US businesses new leverage; while some American companies are hurting because of turbulence, banks, insurance companies and others could eventually emerge as beneficiaries; central question is whether increasing American presence will spark antagonism toward US, which is seen as pushing its commercial interests as price for throwing lifeline to Asian economies; photos (M)

headline: Getting the Right Beat:The Behind-the-Runway Music Masters
abstract: PARIS—  Runway music is a savvy mix of old and new but never quite what you heard on the radio, thanks to fashion's sound wizards — whether it is Catherine Deneuve, to the tune of Erik Satie, explaining her craft for Martin Margiela's at Hermes, or whether it is a mix of the greatest hits from the group Stereolab for Marc Jacobs's modernism at Louis Vuitton.

headline: Filling a Technology Need
abstract: Prof John Chapin letter on inaugural Feb 26 edition of New York Times Circuits section (S)2

headline: Societe Generale Unit To Buy Yamaichi Stake
abstract: Societe Generale Asset Management, unit of Societe Generale, says it agreed to buy 85 percent interest in Yamaichi International Capital Management, unit of failed Yamaichi Securities; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Juggling Goals, F.C.C. to Hold Wireless Sale
abstract: Federal Communications Commission, hoping to dodge parade of problems that plagued its last major auction of wireless licenses, is set to conduct latest auction with new guidelines; auction is for local multipoint distribution services, or LMDS, high-speed, non-mobile wireless technology that works only between fixed points; small companies fear being shut out of process, and Webcel Communications Inc has petitioned FCC to have auction delayed (M)

headline: How the New York Media Cover the New York Media: Intently
abstract: One of hottest topics for media in New York is the media; both of city's general-interest tabloids have bolstered their media business coverage over last year with daily sections focused on industry; John Polich, newspaper consultant and professor of media business management at Fordham University, disapproves of this media self-absorption in New York City; Peter Bart, editor of Variety, acknowledges 'degree of narcissism' about way papers cover each other (M)

headline: True North is working to regain momentum after a legal battle with Publicis over Bozell, Jacobs.
abstract: True North Communications is working to regain momentum after legal battle with former partner Publicis SA over True North's acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt (L)

headline: U S West Media Reduces Loss
abstract: US West Media Group says its loss in fourth quarter narrowed to $133 million from $174 milion a year earlier; revenue rise 5.3 percent, to $1.29 billion (S)

headline: Threats Worry 3 Who Tied Croatian Army to Atrocities
abstract: Three former Croatian soldiers who testified before war crimes tribunal say they have been repeatedly subjected to beatings and death threats; Zdenko Bando, Milan Levar and Zdenko Ropac say that hundreds of ethnic Serbs, as well as Croats who opposed the nationalist movement, were executed and buried in mass graves around town of Gospic by the Croation Army, paramilitary groups and police; say documents they turned over to The Hague implicate senior Croatian officals, including Defense Min Gojko Susak; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, promoted Joseph G. Sponholz, now the executive vice president and chief administrative officer, to vice chairman.

headline: Perot's Return to Business: The Vote's Not In
abstract: Ross Perot, in three months since taking over as interim chief executive of Perot Systems Inc, has adopted numerous changes in response to sharp drop in earnings in 1997 first half; has campaigned around nation to rally employees and sign new accounts; discusses plans to stay on while he trains and tests successor, interview; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Patents; It's spring, and some inventions are aimed at helping baseball players improve their form.
abstract: Several patents are awarded to help younger players with their baseball game; Joseph Prunckle's device helps infielders get into habit of keeping their glove on ground as batter steps up to plate; Robert Socci's device lets batter known whether his chin is tucked appropriately; Timothy Bengtson gets patent for two-tone ball for use during practice; Joseph DaSilva gets patent for combination organizer and baseball cap shaper (M)

headline: Peugeot Citroen Reports Big Loss in 1997
abstract: PSA Peugeot Citroen SA says it lost 2.5 billion francs ($417 million) in 1997 as it took charges to pay for jobs cuts and foreign exchange losses (S)

headline: Handyman Seeks a Financial Blueprint
abstract: Fresh Start, periodic series that looks at crossroads of personal finance, focuses on Darrin Schoen, 27-year-old handyman who, until recently, had money only in his checking account; Schoen has no benefits or pension and slim after-tax resources from his paycheck; Maury Zanoff, financial planner and friend of Schoen, laid out plan to improve his financial future, which leaves Schoen $1 after investments are made and bills paid; Schoen says he is determined to adopt Zanoff's plan; photo (M)

headline: DECAUX OF FRANCE UNIT OFFERS HIGHER BID FOR MORE GROUP
abstract: Unit of Decaux SA offers $799 million in cash for More Group PLC; bid is 8 percent higher than bid of Clear Channel Communications Inc; Clear Channel suggests it might make another bid (S)

headline: And Don't Forget . . .
abstract: Robert Hercz brief assessments of some World Wide Web sites on wine (S)

headline: James O'Brien, 88, Ex-Financial Executive
abstract: James J O'Brien Sr, former executive at Chase Manhattan Bank and on Wall Street, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Mark falls after senior Bundesbank officials question stability of Europe's planned single currency; graph (S)

headline: Some U.S. Rabbis Hope for a Backlash
abstract: American Jewish religious figures say they fully expected decision by Israel's Chief Rabbinate rejecting compromise on religious conversions; agree, that in response to ruling, Reform and Conservative movements could win some of legal recognition in Israel that they have sought all along (M)

headline: Armenians Turn Out To Elect New Leader
abstract: Armenians turn out in large numbers to vote in presidential election that Western political analysts say could profoundly affect stability in oil-producing Caucasus region; 12 candidates are competing in contest (S)

headline: Who Will Profit by Covering The Cards?
abstract: Insurance to pay off credit card and finance company loan balances if policyholder dies or becomes disabled or unemployed discussed in light of furious battle between American International Group and Cendant Corp for control of industry leader, American Bankers Insurance Group; consumer advocates say hardly anyone should buy such insurance, which is extremely profitable; photo (M)0

headline: Dialing for Dollars in Brazil's Telephone Privatization
abstract: Outlook discussed for investments in Brazil's inefficient telephone industry, now that Government has moved to completely privatize huge Telebras company; stock price graph (S)

headline: A New Battle in Belgrade: The Big Buses That Can't
abstract: Comment on decrepit bus and streetcar system in Belgrade, Serbia, where doors fall off moving vehicles and maintenance crews cannibalize buses to keep diminishing fleet of 800 vehicles on the road; transit authorities decided this month that finances of system might improve if passengers paid for service, but passengers have not proved compliant, and there is war on city streets that transport system appears to be losing (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Dazzling Returns Bring a Cash Surge to Junk Bonds
abstract: Junk bond funds were among best-performing bond funds in 1997; AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows, says in last three months of 1997, junk funds received most cash of any investment category; in December, more than $5 billion a week flowed into high-yield bond funds; Morningstar Inc says these funds posted return of 12.17 percent on average last year (M)

headline: Volkswagen and Arnold Communications pitch a Beetle with 'more power' and 'less flower.'
abstract: Volkswagen AG is spending $35 million to promote updated version of Volkswagen Beetle automobile; campaign has been developed by Arnold Communications (L)

headline: Four A's Council Nominates Officers
abstract: American Assn of Advertising Agencies nominates executives to serve as top officers for 1998-99 year; they are Patrick J McGrath, Shelly Lazarus and Sally Minard (S)

headline: Here's Your Winner, If Heft Alone Counts
abstract: Brief assessment of Encyclopedia Britannica 98 on CD-ROM; photo (S)

headline: Yes, I'll Take a Seat, And the Job Offer, Too
abstract: Question of applying for job while obviously pregnant discussed; Federal law forbids discrimination against pregnant women, and data show vast majority do remain on the job, but discrimination by interviewers is hard to prove; photo (S)

headline: Jakarta Dissident Questions U.S. Military Aid
abstract: Indonesian opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri, in March 18 letter to Pres Clinton, challenges him to explain why US special-operations soldiers are training members of Indonesian military (S)

headline: Perfecting His Word; Corel's Feisty Founder Promises the Company Will Rebound
abstract: Michael C J Cowpland, chief executive of Corel Corp, is confident that his company will rebound from its worst year ever after its futile, all-out battle with Microsoft for word-processing software market; Corel sales force did not have expertise or deployment to sell Wordperfect, which Corel bought from Novell Inc in 1996, and 26 million existing users of Wordperfect refused to spend money for Corel version of aging software; analysts say Corel made mistake of producing 'bloatware,' programs packed with more features than majority of users ever care to have; Cowpland's new goal is to make Microsoft's Windows operating system obsolete, with basic software for new generation of low-cost computers connected to and fed by Internet; many analysts doubt that Corel can reinvent itself; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Reuters Unit Puts 3 Executives on Paid Leave
abstract: Three executives with American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings PLC are placed on paid leave by company following disclosure of investigation into possible theft of confidential information from corporate computers of competitor Bloomberg LP; Reuters hires Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, prominent Manhattan law firm, to conduct independent investigation for Reuters (S)

headline: Jardine Matheson Profits Tumbled 21% in 1997
abstract: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd says its profits fell 21 percent in 1997, to $292 million; collapse of Asian currencies cited (S)

headline: Challenge Is Raised to Plan for a Holocaust Monument in Berlin
abstract: Nineteen prominent German intellectuals, historians and authors, including writer Gunter Grass, urge Germany to abandon plans for gigantic Holocaust memorial in heart of Berlin, letter to Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other supporters of project; hold huge abstract installation would be inappropriate (M)

headline: Investments in Long-Term Mutual Funds at Peak
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports Americans made more new investments in long-term mutual funds last year than ever before; says resurgent market for bond funds spurred further growth in an industry whose expansion over most of the last four years has been driven by the popularity of funds that invest in stocks; says through end of November, stock and bond funds received combined $252.5 billion in new net investments, surpassing previous record for net cash flows in full year, set in 1993, of $243.4 billion (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.44   5.47   5.17        3-month T-bills   4.96   5.08   4.98        6-month T-bills   5.00   5.05   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.66   3.32        10-yr. T-note   5.54   5.55   6.45        30-yr. T-bond   5.85   5.86   6.75        Telephone bd.   7.28   7.28   7.78        Municipal bds.   5.19   5.19   5.77          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Comedy in the Conference Room
abstract: Accounts solicited for article on comic moments in the corporate conference room

headline: Appealing for Asylum, 12 Crash Into UN's Offices in Malaysia
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  In a desperate attempt to avoid being sent back to Indonesia, 12 asylum seekers crashed a truck through the gates of a United Nations office here Monday as Malaysia deported nearly 1,500 more illegal immigrants.

headline: Students at Key School Rally Against Suharto : '60s-Style Campus Protesters
abstract: BANDUNG, Indonesia—  Every day last week, hundreds of students of an elite university here assembled on an outdoor basketball court and demanded that the man who has ruled their country for more than 30 years step down.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Prospects of American and Japanese intervention in foreign exchange market to support Japanese yen prompts dollar selling for yen and German marks; graph (S)

headline: Korean Banks Said to Be in Technical Default
abstract: Moody's Investor Service says South Korea's banks are technically in default on billions of dollars of loans that have been twice extended by international lenders; Korean stocks surge 6.4 percent on Jan 11, as investors show growing optimism that nation's economy may rebound faster than others in Asia from financial crisis (M)

headline: Ex-Chase Official Joins Equitable
abstract: Equitable Companies names Michael Hegarty, former vice chairman of Chase Manhattan Corp, president of its life insurance subsidiary; Hegarty will become president of Equitable Life Assurance Society of US; he will also serve as chief operating officer for Equitable and for its life insurance unit; Equitable's board names Edward D Miller chairman of Equitable Life, replacing Joseph J Melone, who is retiring (S)

headline: HOUSE OF GRAFT: Tracing the Bhutto Millions -- A special report.; Bhutto Clan Leaves Trail of Corruption
abstract: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is at heart of widening corruption inquiry that Pakistani investigators say has traced over $100 million to foreign bank accounts and properties controlled by her family; investigators have detailed pattern of secret payments by foreign companies that sought favors when Bhutto was in power; documents leave uncertain degree of involvement by Bhutto, but they trace pervasive role by her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, who turned his marriage into source of virtually unchallengeable power; Middle East gold bullion dealer, Abdul Razzak Yaqub, has been shown to have deposited at least $10 million into account controlled by Zardari after Bhutto Government gave him monopoly on gold imports that sustained Pakistan's jewelry industry; Bhutto and Zardari dismiss Pakistani inquiry as political vendetta by her successor as Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif; Zardari has been in prison for 14 months on charges of murdering Bhutto's brother, Murtaza; map; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Aid to Indonesia Delayed, But U.S. Sends In Food  The United States and the I.M.F. have reportedly agreed to further delay in the payment of billions of dollars in emergency aid to Indonesia until President Suharto begins to act on a new plan for economic reform being negotiated in Jakarta.    But seeking to stop the food riots that some Indonesians attribute to the austerity measures, the United States announced that it would send more than $70 million in emergency food and medical aid. [Page A6.]

headline: Investigators in Reuters Case Met With Computer Consultant Months Ago
abstract: Executive with Cyberspace Research was confronted several months ago by Federal law enforcement officials investigating whether company was commissioned by subsidiary of Reuters Holdings PLC to steal information electronically from rival, Bloomberg LP; contact between Government and Cyberspace executive suggests that at least some people working with company could have been cooperating with Federal investigators of Reuters Analytics Inc, before it was disclosed last week; prosecutors have been investigating for as long as a year to determine whether Reuters took part in scheme to steal proprietary information maintained in Bloomberg's central computers; they are examining whether that information was later improperly incorporated into products like Reuters 3000, which as been widely viewed in financial data industry as product most likely to compete with Bloomberg terminal (L)

headline: Israelis Lining Up for Gas Masks as Officials Warn Iraq
abstract: Israelis, edgy after local press reports about Iraq's arsenal, are lining up for gas-masks; Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai warns that Israel will defend itself if attacked by Iraq in retaliation for US military strike (M)

headline: Yeltsin Tells Parliament to Fix Economy, and Win I.M.F. Aid
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin scores proposed budget and renews threat to form new Government if Cabinet does not quickly resolve nation's economic problems, annual speech to Parliament; scores neglect of debt obligations (M)

headline: Benjamin Bowden, 91, Auto and Bicycle Designer
abstract: Benjamin Bowden, industrial designer who created futuristic bicycle that became expensive collector's item, dies at age 91 (M)

headline: INDONESIAN RUPIAH REBOUNDS.
abstract: Indonesian rupiah recovers after sharp plunge; graphs; table (S)8

headline: Turks Clash Over Defense of Virginity Tests
abstract: Turkish feminists demand resignation of Isilay Saygin, Cabinet minister in charge of women's affairs, after she defends traditional practice of subjecting women to virginity tests (M)

headline: 2 Corporate Cultures Meet in MCI-Worldcom Merger
abstract: Challenge of integrating differing corporate cultures of MCI Communications Corp and Worldcom Inc--one a brash newcomer to upper echelons of telecommunications world, the other onetime rebel that joined establishment--is just one of potential hurdles in pending merger; analysts say those hurdles are not likely to block merger altogether; two companies will propose directors of the new company; photo of MCI chairman Bert C Roberts Jr and Worldcom head Bernard J Ebbers (L)

headline: 3 Acquisitions By Sunbeam in Separate Deals
abstract: Sunbeam Corp, which discharged half its 12,000 workers and closed dozens of plants since Albert J Dunlap took over as chairman 18 months ago, announces three separate acquisitions worth total of $1.8 billion that will more than double Sunbeam's size; company will pay $1.6 billion for Coleman Co Inc and assume $440 million in debt; Coleman is controlled by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, which will become one of Sunbeam's largest shareholders; Sunbeam will also purchase Signature Brands USA Inc, maker of Mr Coffee coffee makers, for $279 million and assume $165 million in debt; third company is First Alert Inc, for which Sunbeam will pay $133 million plus assumption of $43 million in debt; chart (M)

headline: FIRSTBANK OF ILLINOIS TO BE ACQUIRED BY RIVAL
abstract: Mercantile Bancorp agrees to acquire Firstbank of Illinois Co for $697 million in stock (S)

headline: Senate Urges U.N. to Try Iraqi as a War Criminal
abstract: Senate votes 93-0 to urge creation of United Nations tribunal to try Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein as war criminal; Sen Arlen Specter, resolution's main sponsor, comments; House approved similar resolution in Nov (M)

headline: Holders Left Holding the Bag
abstract: Alliance Global Environment Fund's conversion from closed- to open-end status last year brought profits for most shareholders, but left others with huge tax bills; those affected were stockholders who failed to cash out at net asset value quickly, and few others who bought shares after fund was converted but before distribution was paid; stock price graph (M)

headline: Dow Up 115 As It Reaches Newest High
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 115.09 points, or 1.41 percent, to close at record 8,295; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 8.27 points, to 1,019.01; Nasdaq composite index rises 18.61 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,709.04; charts; graphs (L)

headline: Israel Sets Tight Limits for Any West Bank Pullback
abstract: Israeli Government adopts sweeping guidelines defining its vital interests in any future talks on West Bank; cites security zones, Jerusalem and environs, military bases, Jewish settlements, roads and sacred sites; agrees on general principles, avoiding Cabinet showdown on specifics and giving Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu more room to maneuver in talks with Pres Clinton; photo (M)

headline: $319.5 Billion in Securities Offerings Sets a Record
abstract: Wall Street completes record year for underwriting financial secuirities, raising $319.5 billion despite concerns about spreading financial crisis in Asia; volume of securities issued in American financial markets during three months ended yesterday represents 22 percent increase from $261.7 billion raised through stock and bond offerings in final three months of 1996, but is is decline of 14 percent from levels for three months ended Sept 30, when underwritings raised $371.8 billion; during last three months, Merrill Lynch & Co retained its position as leading manager of new US issues, with 16.7 percent market share; chart of leading underwriters (M)

headline: With Goto.com's Search Engine, the Highest Bidder Shall Be Ranked First
abstract: Yahoo and other sites devoted to navigating Web are trying to turn their sites into destinations in themselves, featuring such services as E-mail or chat rooms; different approach is being taken by start-up Goto.com, which will focus entirely on searching and on making money by encouraging Web sites to pay for more prominent placement in search results; Goto.com ranks results according to how much sites are willing to pay, rather than to where and how often certain key words appear; service posts per-word pricing in open auction, allowing Web sites to continually bid for higher placements on given topic; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: British pound strengthens to its best level against dollar this year; in New York, pound costs $1.6692, up from $1.6686; graph; chart (S)

headline: Students Who Make the Grade and Make Money
abstract: Twelve seniors who take popular investment course at University of Northern Colorado each semester are given opportunity to manage more than $500,000 of school's $37 million endowment, within certain conservative parameters; classes in recent years have equaled or surpassed S&P 500 results in recent years; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Japanese Car Makers Set Cuts in Production
abstract: Japanese auto makers Nissan Motor Co, Mitsubishi Motors Corp, Mazda Motor, Nissan Diesel and Isuzu Motor Corp say they will cut domestic output in March because of weak sales in Japan, their biggest market (S)

headline: In Cameras' Glare, A Man About Town
abstract: Surveillance cameras abound in Manhattan, for security, traffic monitoring and just fun; map; photos; drawings (M)

headline: People
abstract: Donald R Allman, executive vice president and general manager at TDI, New York, is named to new position of chief operating officer (S)

headline: HINDU PARTY HAS A STRONG SHOWING IN INDIAN ELECTION
abstract: India's Hindu nationalist party, Bharatiya Janata, demands right to form Government after nearly complete election returns show party and its allies have won about 251 of 545 seats in lower house of Parliament, at least 80 more than rival Congress Party and its allies; Congress leaders meet with those of third major political bloc to discuss forming coalition to keep nationalists from power; two groups together would have 264 seats, 9 short of clear majority; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, HOWARD P.
abstract: PECK-Howard P. On March 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Nikki Peck. Loving father of James M., Andrew J. and Theodore S. Peck. Adoring grandfather of Alissa D. and Adam R. Peck. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, March 24, at 11:30 AM. Interment private.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  A surge in bond issuances by nonprofit groups is broadening the tax-exempt market, but with some risks. By Sana Siwolop.

headline: Chinese Face Uncertainties From Asia's Financial Chaos
abstract: China's economy is still bustling along at high speed, but economy has gritty underside: morass of dilapidated industry left over from state-planning days, tens of millions of grumpy, underemployed workers and insolvent banks trying to wean Chinese companies from irrational system of 'loans' that are still effectively state handouts (M)

headline: Kosovo Leader Urges Resistance, but to Violence
abstract: Ibrahim Rugova, President of self-declared Republic of Kosovo, who comes close to being revered among ethnic Albanian majority in Pristina, Serbia, comments on situation; says he is passionately committed to nonviolence; map (M)

headline: Name-Change Survey's Results
abstract: Annual name-change survey by Anspach Grossman Enterprise lists 1,625 corporate name changes in 1997, up 10.5 percent from 1,471 in 1996; name changes increased primarily because of corporate revampings (S)

headline: Growth Rate Slowing Sharply in Korea
abstract: South Korea says high interest rates and plunge in its currency will cause its economy to grow much more slowly than forecast a month ago; Government plans to announce that economy may grow as little as 1 percent in 1998, not 3 percent predicted in December; graph (S)

headline: Boeing to Overhaul Executive Pay
abstract: Boeing Co announces plans to overhaul management pay, tying it more closely to company's stock performance to make top executives more accountable for Boeing's performance; Boeing also expects to miss, by one, its target of making 43 planes a month in second quarter but is on track to achieve that goal in third quarter (S)

headline: Lehman Reports Rise in Earnings
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc says earnings rose 30 percent in quarter ended Feb 28; net income rose to $187 million from $144 million a year earlier (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; No Pain, No Gain? Forget It, Doc
abstract: Comment by J Philip Lathrop on minimum standards for dignified inpatient hospital experience; holds as managed care continues to drive down hospital occupancy rates, forward-looking medical centers will succeed by trumpeting their private rooms and new amenities, in addition to high-quality clinical care; says as competition transforms health care, industry must learn that unpleasant customer experiences may mean no customers at all; drawing (L)

headline: German Social Democrat Triumphs in Key State Election
abstract: Gerhard Schroeder, Premier of northern German state of Lower Saxony, triumphs in closely watched state elections, sealing bid to challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl in national elections in September; says Kohl era is over; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Case May Be Prelude to a Wider Antitrust Battle
abstract: Justice Dept ponders whether to broaden its antitrust battle with Microsoft Corp by filing Sherman Act case against computer giant; sweeping case against Microsoft would be landmark test of how smokestack-era doctrine of antitrust applies to high-technology industry; but Washington would prefer to avoid long-running, high-profile Sherman Act case; policy makers and economists say issue is to try to insure that Microsoft's near-monopoly of PC operating-system software is not used to exercise 'chokehold control' over new markets of Internet software and Internet commerce; Sen Orrin G Hatch warns that antitrust scrutiny of Microsoft is preferable to more heavy-handed Government intervention such as an 'Internet Commerce Commission'; there is similar sentiment within Justice Dept; senior official there says 'dialogue' element of Government's dealings with Microsoft would be reopened if only company agreed to discuss ground rules of competition (M)

headline: Japanese Executive and Wife Found Dead
abstract: Yasuo Nakajima, president of small picture frame manufacturer in Japan, and his wife, Akiko, committed suicide because of bad business conditions; it is second time in a week that suicides are attributed to financial travail, and experts fear morbid statistics will increase as Japan's economy sputters and obtaining credit remains difficult (S)

headline: Cohen Is Heading for Gulf To Tell Arabs of War Plans
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen is traveling to Europe and Persian Gulf to explain US plans for striking Iraq if Saddam Hussein continues to defy United Nations inspections of Iraq's biological and chemical weapons programs; signs orders sending 2,200 marines and four more warships to join the already formidable forces in region; map (M)

headline: U.S. and Allies Set Sanctions on Yugoslavia
abstract: United States and its Western allies in so-called contact group monitoring Yugoslavia and republics that seceeded from it, agree to impose modest diplomatic and economic sanctions on Yugoslavia for Pres Slobodan Milosevic's 'unacceptable use of force' against ethnic Albanian majority in Serbia's Kosovo province of; State Sec Madeleine K Albright calls decision 'satisfactory;' group agrees to press United Nations Security Council to impose comprehensive arms embargo on Serbia; Russia refuses to agree to ban on export credits by foreign governments (M)

headline: EDUCATION SOFTWARE RIVALS PLAN $131 MILLION MERGER
abstract: CBT Group PLC agrees to aquire smaller rival, Forefront Group, for $131 million in stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROWAN COS., Houston, an oilfield services company, terminated its 49 percent interest in KLM ERA Helicopters.    CANDIES INC., Purchase, N.Y., a shoe manufacturer, agreed to acquire New Retail Concepts Inc., also based in Purchase, N.Y., for $11.5 million in stock.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: YEN UNDER PRESSURE***Japanese yen weakens against dollar as Japanese stocks slide; graphs; table (S)

headline: Cheaper Oil Propels Import Price Drop
abstract: Prices of imported goods dropped six-tenths of 1 percent in December and 4.9 percent in all of 1997, largest decline since Government began collecting such data in 1983; economists seek to gauge how much Asian currency devaluations and strengthening dollar might restrain inflation in United States; prices have already fallen on some goods, but discussion has expanded to possibility of more general price decline that could be disruptive to economy, in part by cutting corporate earnings while wage levels remain fixed; drop in price of petroleum imports--5.4 percent in December and 25.5 percent in 1997--could be stimulus to economy, should it hold; economists view drops in oil prices as being like tax cuts because they can directly put money into consumers' pockets; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft, Accused of Trademark Violations, Is Sued in Europe
abstract: Palm Computing Inc, 3Com unit and pioneering Silicon Valley maker of hand-held electronic organizer called Palm Pilot, sues Microsoft Corp in Europe, accusing it of patent violations; dispute arose as result of Microsoft's decision last year to enter market for shirt-pocket-sized computers with new version of its CE operating system that it named Palm PC; new Microsoft-based machines borrow number of Palm Pilot's features; Donna Dubinsky, 3Com vice president and president of Palm Computing division, says Europe was selected for suit for reasons relating to trademark law (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, ALLEN
abstract: CAMERON-Allen. Of Essex, CT., March 20, age 86. Husband of Ruth I. Cameron, Father of Suzanne Schutz of Greenwich, CT., and Laurie Larkin of Claremont, CA; Brother of F. Morton Cameron and Sister Donalda Cameron both of San Diego, California, and Grandfather of 3. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Friends of the Valley Railroad Co of Connecticut Valley, P.O. Box 452, Essex, Connecticut 06426.

headline: SUMMIT CARE IN NEGOTIATIONS TO SELL COMPANY
abstract: Summit Care Corp says it is in talks to be acquired by unnamed company (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  Presidents' Day holiday. Financial markets and institutions in the United States are closed.

headline: Peace Languishes as Another Angola Deadline Passes
abstract: Jonas Savimbi, leader of Unita rebels in Angola, fails to attend scheduled peace talks with Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos in capital of Luanda; series of such missed deadlines have left officials involved in negotiations on both sides wondering whether Angola is moving closer to peace or war; South African military analysts say both sides seem poised for aggression; map (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PITTSTON BURLINGTON GROUP, Richmond, agreed to acquire the privately held Air Transport International L.L.C., a freight and passenger airline, for as much as $30 million in cash.

headline: British Brewer Will Buy Big Hotel Chain
abstract: Bass PLC, British brewer, agrees to buy 187 Inter-Continental Hotels from Saison Group of Japan for $1.4 billion; deal follows six-week auction among five hotel companies, including Marriott and Patriot American; Bass owns Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza chain, but wants to expand into higher-priced hotels; Inter-Continental also includes Forum and Global Partner hotels (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: G. Kenneth Heebner; CGM Realty Fund
abstract: Investing With profile of G Kenneth Heebner, who over 25 years has compiled one of mutual fund's best records; Heebner's CGM Capital Development Fund, closed to new investors for 29 years, has 15-year average annual return of twenty percent; his newer fund, CGM Realty, no-load fund investing in real estate investment trusts, has earned Morningstar's highest rating; Heebner comments on fast-growing REIT market, interview; photo; graph of prices for three REIT's favored by Keebner (M)

headline: Ulster Faction Issues Threat Of Attacks On Catholics
abstract: Loyalist Volunteer Force, Protestant paramilitary splinter group that has slain at least four Roman Catholics since Christmas, threatens to kill more Catholics in 'unholy war'; threat is taken seriously by officials involved in Northern Ireland peace talks, which resume in Belfast on Feb 2 after sessions in London (M)

headline: LYCOS BUYS WEB SITE WITH A MILLION CUSTOMERS
abstract: Lycos Inc acquires closely held Tripod Inc for $58 million in stock, adding an on-line community of one million members to its Internet directory service (S)

headline: Microsoft Shifts Web Unit to Windows Group
abstract: Microsoft Corp moves group that develops its Internet Explorer World Wide Web browser into business unit that develops and markets its Windows operating system; issue of whether Internet Explorer is separate application or integrated part of Windows 95 is at heart of lawsuit filed by Justice Dept charging that Microsoft violated 1994 antitrust agreement; reorganization is likely to raise eyebrows in light of suit (M)

headline: Solid Corporate Profit Reports Help Push Share Prices Higher
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 102.14 points, or 1.32 percent, at 7,815.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 12.07 points, or 1.26 percent, to 969.02; Nasdaq composite index rises 17.44 points, or 1.12 percent, to 1,578.90; graph; chart (L)

headline: Second Chance at Defiance For a British Newspaper
abstract: The Independent, lone British newspaper to offer bias-free coverage of news, is being given second chance after falling on hard times; Anthony J F O'Reilly, Irish industrialist, says his Independent Newspapers chain is taking full control of Independent, and promises to establish United States-style division between news and editorial departments to reinforce notion of coverage free of bias; most papers in Britain reflect news of their owners in news pages as well as on editorial pages; Andrew Marr is named Independent's editor in chief and Rosie Boycott is editor for news and features; photos (M)

headline: Indonesian Stocks Rise as Rupiah Falls
abstract: Indonesian stocks rise on January 26 as investors take advantage of difference between value of shares in Jakarta and New York as value of rupiah continues to plunge (S)

headline: Asia Hurts Gucci Profit, But Less Than Expected
abstract: Gucci Group, Italian designer of luxury goods, says its fourth-quarter profit fell 20 percent, to $42.1 million, as Asia's economic and currency problems hurt sales less than expected (S)

headline: New Searle Drug Goes to Burnett
abstract: G D Searle pharmaceutical business unit of Monsanto Co names Leo Burnett Co to handle new worldwide assignment, introduction of Celebra, an arthritis therapy now under clinical study; billings are estimated at $20 million to $30 million or more (S)

headline: People
abstract: -- Andrea MacDonald, former senior partner and director for nontraditional media at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of WPP Group, left to open MacDonald Media, New York, where she is president and chief executive.

headline: Ex-Chief Quits Post At Mercury Finance
abstract: Mercury Finance Co's former chief executive, John N Brincat, resigns from its board and agrees to repay part of his bonuses for 1994, 1995 and 1996; Brincat resigned as chief executive on Feb 3, 1997, four days after Mercury said it overstated 1996 earnings (S)

headline: Ecuadoreans Want Texaco to Clear Toxic Residue
abstract: Residents of Shushufindi, Ecuador, seeks more than $1 billion from Texaco Inc in compensation for health and environmental damage and for clean-up of hundreds of waste pits with toxic chemicals, which were left behind after company ceased operations there after two decades; class-action suit, dismissed in US court in 1997 but currently under appeal, is being closely watched by oil and mining industries; suggests that pliable governments, which may have been possible advantage for foreign investors in past, could actually prove liability, as citizens take on companies directly; Texaco vehemently defends its actions; map; photo (M)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Desktop Coaches for the Final Four
abstract: World Wide Web has many sites for college basketball fans who cannot attend NCAA tournaments' semifinal and championship rounds (M)

headline: Kofi Annan and Washington Smooth Some Rough Edges
abstract: Pres Clinton assures United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan that US will consult with Security Council before taking any military action against Iraq; Clinton's remarks are slight shift from earlier Administration argument that Security Council resolution warning Iraq of serious consequences if it interfered with arms inspections gave US authority it needed to use force; UN officials say Clinton sought assurance that UN will not put obstacles in path of US policy; Annan says there are no outstanding disagreements between him and Administration; photo (M)

headline: OMNIAMERICA ACQUIRES 30 MEDIA TOWERS IN FLORIDA
abstract: OmniAmerica Inc., a venture involving Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., acquired 30 wireless-communications towers in Florida yesterday for $20 million. The company, based in West Palm Beach, bought 3 towers in Palm Beach County and 2 towers in Fort Pierce from the Ardman Broadcasting Corporation and 25 towers serving the Tampa-St. Petersburg area and western Florida from HSW Associates Inc. OmniAmerica was formed in September by Hicks, Muse, the Dallas-based leveraged buyout firm; Carl Hirsch, OmniAmerica's chief executive, and Anthony Ocepek, its senior vice president and chief operating officer. OmniAmerica buys media towers for the radio and television broadcasting and wireless communications markets.

headline: New Proposal By Netanyahu For West Bank
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, after months of stalemate and under increasing pressure from Clinton Administration, sends Pres Clinton compromise offer on Israeli withdrawal from West Bank; withdrawal Netanyahu proposes is smaller than one US is suggesting, but Israel would cede more land than it has been willing to give up in past; proposal offers Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat more adjacent land, answering major complaint of Palestinians, who have said Israel was offering them isolated patches of land; Pres Clinton thinks enough of Netanyahu's proposal to send US envoy Dennis B Ross back to Middle East (M)

headline: Adobe Profit Falls More Than Expected
abstract: Adobe Systems Inc says first-quarter earnings ended Feb 27 fell 50 percent, bigger decline than analysts expected; profit was $22.9 million compared with $45.4 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Shopping at Asia's Fire Sale: Can Managers Avoid Getting Burned?
abstract: Portfolio managers who sought bargains after collapse of Asian stock markets, before stocks reached lowest levels, may be positioned to reap gains, even if they are lagging behind in current market rebound; table (M)d

headline: Jerusalem Journal; An Unusual Snow Day Brings On a City's Thaw
abstract: Rare snowstorm strikes Jerusalem, leaving city under eight inches of heavy, wet snow; photo (M)

headline: Palestinians Hold March in Bethlehem to Show Support for Iraq
abstract: Several hundred Palestinians march in Bethlehem in support of Iraq, but without the popular support that accompanied Persian Gulf war of 1991; most demonstrators stress that they are marching in solidarity with Iraqi people, not Saddam Hussein; photo (S)

headline: Four Business Groups In Japan Urge Tax Cuts
abstract: Heads of Japan's four leading business organizations call on Government to approve further tax cuts for individuals as way to increase consumer confidence; groups are Japan Federation of Economic Organizations, Japan Federation of Employers Associations, Japan Association of Corporate Executives and Chamber of Commerce and Industry (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.63   5.63   5.37        3-month T-bills   5.04   5.04   5.00        6-month T-bills   5.01   5.02   5.06        10-yr. T-infl.   3.64   3.64   3.34        10-yr. T-note   5.50   5.55   6.49        30-yr. T-bond   5.80   5.83   6.78        Telephone bd.   7.22   7.24   7.82        Municipal bds.   5.19   5.20   5.82          (Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones Markets; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Treasury Prices Rally on Inflation Outlook
abstract: US Treasury securities rally sharply and push long-term yields to lowest level this month; 30-year bond surges 1 3/32, to price of 103 30/32, while yield falls to 5.84 percent, from 5.92 percent on Feb 10; graph (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  New-Home Sales Feb.  Prices of New Homes Feb.

headline: Partners & Shevack Is in Joint Venture
abstract: Partners & Shevack is expanding Partners & Frankfurt by forming joint venture with Belk Mignogna Associates (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls to two-and-a-half-week low against German mark after tentative agreement is reached to defuse crisis with Iraq; in New York, dollar costs 1.7933 marks, down from 1.8214; graph; chart (S)

headline: DEPUY TO BUY ACROMED, SPINAL IMPLANT MAKER
abstract: DePuy Inc says it agreed to purchase privately held Acromed Corp, Cleveland spinal implant company, in transaction valued at $325 million (S)

headline: Indonesian Currency Continues Slide Despite I.M.F. Deal
abstract: Indonesia's weakened currency resumes sliding, only one day after Pres Suharto reluctantly agrees to major restructuring of Indonesia's economy, as demanded by IMF; international marketplace, which has become de facto arbiter of Indonesia's economic policies, still seems dissatisfied; several financial analysts say that risks and uncertainties remain too great; currency ends day at 8,450 rupiah to dollar--6.5 percent lower than when economic package was announced (M)

headline: Profit Up at Dayton Hudson and Federated
abstract: Dayton Hudson Corp and Federated Department Stores Inc report that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose, beating analysts' expectations; Dayton Hudson's net income rose 66 percent, to $356 million from $214 million a year earlier; revenue for quarter ended Jan 31 rose 9.5 percent, to $8.95 billion from $8.17 billion; Federated's income rose 31 percent, to $379.1 million from $289.2 million; revenue rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to $5.06 billion from $5.04 billion (S)

headline: BREED TECHNOLOGIES TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 25%
abstract: Breed Technologies Inc will dismiss 4,500 workers, or 25 percent of its work force, and close 47 of its 103 factories and offices by mid-1999 (S)

headline: For Fanatics, Sports Webcasts
abstract: Internet simulcast allows sports fans to follow games via computer at sites where television coverage is not available; services use animation or text updates fed from sidelines to simulate games as they happen; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Prudential Policyholders May Become Shareholders  Prudential Insurance, the nation's largest life insurer, said it wanted to reorganize in a way that would convert policyholders to shareholders and that might distribute as much as $12 billion among them.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 11 Countries Are Cleared To Join Euro Currency  The European Commission officially recommended that 11 countries, including Italy, which has made significant progress in taming its deficit and inflation, be allowed to join Europe's new single currency plan next year.

headline: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY 68% OF ESSEX INVESTMENT
abstract: Affiliated Managers Group Inc agrees to acquire 68 percent of Essex Investment Management Co for $69.6 million in cash and 1.75 million shares of newly issued nonvoting convertible Affiliated Managers stock, valued at $51.6 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas futures prices fall 3.5 percent; Mar contract drops 8 cents, to $2.208 per 1,000 cubic feet; graphs; table (S)9

headline: Profit at Thomson-CSF Soars as Exports Surge
abstract: Thomson-CSF, Europe's largest military electronics company, reports second-half profit rose to 1.66 billion francs ($276 million), from 349 million francs, while full-year net almost tripled, to 2.12 billion francs (S)

headline: Shift in Assignments By 3 Marketers
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co names Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide to handle various brands in US and Europe; billings estimated at $65 million to $70 million; brands had been handled by Wells BDDP; Aamco Transmissions Inc names Partners & Shevack to handle to handle advertising for more than 700 franchised automotive repair stores; those duties had been handled by Publicis/Bloom; Sprint Corp names Grey Advertising to handle consolidated creative duties for local business markets and local brand creative for its local division, which had been handled by various agencies (M)

headline: Employment Declined In Germany in 1997
abstract: German Statistics Office says 34 million workers were employed in Germany in 1997, down 463,000, or 1.3 percent; number of registered jobless rose 10.6 percent, to 4.4 million, during year; that means 11.4 percent of work force was jobless, up from 10.3 percent in 1996 (S)

headline: Progress on Health Costs, But Nagging Woes Persist
abstract: Health care economy has undergone sweeping changes since 1993, when double-digit spurts helped push health care to top of national political agenda; but system is so big, accounting for one-seventh of gross domestic product, and so varied that even experts are cautious about making predictions; costs are headed up again, after two-year hiatus, and even with booming economy, number of uninsured Americans, largely children of low-income parents, rose to 41 million in 1997 from 37 million in 1993; graph (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DOREL INDUSTRIES, Montreal, a manufacturer of ready-to-assemble and metal folding furniture, will purchase Ameriwood Industries International Corp., Grand Rapids, Mich., also a furniture maker, for $9.625 a share, or $41.1 million.    LEXINGTON CORPORATE PROPERTIES TRUST, New York, a real estate investment trust, will acquire four properties for about $37 million. Two of the properties are in Livonia, Mich.; one is in Hebron, Ky., and one is in Bristol Township, Pa.

headline: Court Orders F.C.C. To Obey Its Ruling
abstract: Federal appeals court orders Federal Communications Commission to stop circumventing ruling by court that leaves pricing decisions on local phone service to states; decision is victory for Bell companies spun off from AT&T, which say FCC does not have authority to impose tough pricing rules on local phone companies; at issue are prices that local phone companies charge their rivals for use of their phone networks (M)

headline: Seinfeld Meets a Really 'Super' Salesman
abstract: American Express Co will soon introduce television commercial in which Jerry Seinfeld is paired with Superman; it is being described as first time that animated Superman character will appear with a celebrity for advertising purposes; commercial is being developed by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide (S)

headline: Digging Up an Old Return
abstract: Advice for divorced people on getting copies of past joint tax returns from Internal Revenue Service; drawing (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDOLSKY, MILTON
abstract: PEDOLSKY-Milton. Formerly of Port Washington, NY. Loving to, and dearly loved by, his late wife, Beverly; son, Richard; daughter-inlaw, Cecillia; grandson, Isak; daughter, Andrea; Nicholas; and many wonderful friends. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service April 7, 4 PM, at Cooper Union, Peter Cooper Suite, 7 E. 7th St., NYC. Should friends desire, memorial contributions may be made to Friends and Relatives of Institutionalized Aged.

headline: Market Place; A small company with big ideas is paying a lot to promote its stock at the expense of its holders.
abstract: Market Place column on Semiconductor Laser International Corp, which has begun to make some sales of high-powered lasers but is losing money at a fast pace; says Semiconductor Laser in October hired Marketing Direct Concepts to promote its stock; adds Marketing Direct got $75,000 in cash up front, plus $10,000 a month; it also got 150,000 shares of Semiconductor Laser plus warrants to buy 750,000 shares (L)

headline: Is the Explosion-Noisy Base a C.I.A. Spy School? What Base?
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency maintains base called Harvey Point Defense Testing Activity, outside town of Hertford, NC, where it runs secret paramilitary and counter-terrorism courses for thousands of its officers and select foreigners; established weeks after 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, school for spies has been shielded by secrecy, security fences and cypress tress festooned with Spanish moss ever since; Harvey Point sets off powerful explosions to recreate terrorist acts, distressing some residents of Hertford; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Teligent Inc., Vienna, Va., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, as the first agency to handle brand marketing and direct marketing for the company, which provides telecommunications and Internet products and services. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

headline: Acts That Failed
abstract: Presentations: They're showtime for some people, the bane of many others. How have they gone for you? And what moments next to the overhead projector would you most like to forget? Or remember? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Havas Buys SFM, Big Media Agency
abstract: Havas Advertising SA acquires SFM Media Corp, which will become unit of Havas (S)

headline: World Bank Lends $1 Billion to Manila
abstract: World Bank president, James D Wolfensohn, pledges additional $1 billion in loans to Philippines, adding to another $1.16 billion in unspent loans already allocated to country (S)

headline: Electrolux Net Off 33%; Problems Abroad Cited
abstract: Electrolux AB says its fourth-quarter net income fell 33 percent to 286 million kronor ($36.2 million) after company paid more tax than expected and took charge to cut jobs in Brazil and Asia (S)

headline: Drug Distributors to Fight Foe of Deal
