abstract: McKesson Corp and Amerisource Health Corp decide to fight FTC's attempt to block their merger, which would combine nation's No. 1 and No. 4 drug wholesalers; on March 17, Cardinal Health Inc, No. 2 company, says it would fight regulators' efforts to stop its acquisition of No. 3, Bergen Brunswig Corp (S)

headline: Regulators Oppose End to Session if Dow Plunges
abstract: Nation's top financial regulators tell Congress they support raising limits on amount that stocks can fall before trading is interrupted, but oppose plan to close markets for rest of day as too restrictive; Arthur Levitt Jr, chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, says closed markets create panic among investors (M)

headline: VODAFONE TO SELL STAKE IN PACIFIC LINK COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Vodafone Group PLC says that it would sell stake it holds in Pacific Link Communications Ltd to two companies for total of $160 million; companies are Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd and First Pacific Co (S)

headline: Korean Stocks Fall After Panic Selling
abstract: Korean stocks tumble by their largest margin so far this year, underscoring economic uncertainties facing new Pres Kim Dae Jung as he tries to reorganize nation's economy; Korea Composite Stock Index falls 6.5 percent (S)

headline: Big Changes Expected in the Sale of Mutual Funds
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to adopt sweeping changes next week in way that mutual fund companies sell their shares to investors; new procedure would allow sales based on two-page profile of a fund; using this streamlined disclosure requireement, fund companies may be able to include enough detail in newspaper advertising to make a sale; and they would probably reap great cost savings (L)

headline: Indonesia's New Cabinet Takes Office
abstract: New nationalist-oriented Cabinet takes office in Indonesia; faces tough negotiations with international lenders over how best to solve deepening economic crisis (S)

headline: NEWELL SELLS 8% BLACK & DECKER STAKE FOR $395 MILLION
abstract: Newell Co sells its 7.862 million-share stake in Black & Decker Corp to investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Co for $395 million (S)

headline: Video World Is Smitten by a Gun-Toting, Tomb-Raiding Sex Symbol
abstract: Lara Croft, digitized female image from one of hottest-selling video games of year, Tomb Raider 2, has fans all over world who say she is virtually real; Eidos Interactive, which publishes game, says Lara Croft receives fan mail and gifts; every game and computer magazine wants to reprint her sexy image; drawing (M)

headline: Intel hires extra help, part of a whirl of account activity with billings in the many millions.
abstract: Flurry of advertising account activity has rippled through Madison Avenue, affecting assignments with billings estimated at $275 million to $305 million; biggest change involves Intel Corp, which unexpected added second ad agency to its roster to handle North American advertising, with billings estimated at more than $100 million; newcomer, Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, will share Intel North American assignment with Euro RSCG DSW Partners (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: British pound rises for third day on speculation that Bank of England might soon raise interest rates to limit inflation; graph; chart (S)

headline: Internet Helps to Keep Silicon Valley in a Boom
abstract: Silicon Valley's booming economy continued at near-record growth rate in 1997, adding 53,000 jobs and showing surprising strength in manufacturing sector; biggest job gains are reported in software, where there are 8,300 new jobs, outpacing computers-communications, which added 7,500 jobs (M)

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Maker of I.B.M. Clones Teams With Microsoft
abstract: Amdahl Corp, maker of clones of IBM's biggest mainframe computers, will announce wide-ranging partnership with Microsoft Corp to help sell Windows NT to large corporations (S)

headline: Economic Scene; The tax credit for research and development: free lunch.
abstract: Economic Scene column on business tax credit for research and development; says Clinton Administration is proposing only temporary extension of credit; holds that undermines long-term incentives the tax break is designed to generate; says if tax credit were permanent the budget rules would obligate Congress to find five years' worth of revenues to offset the cost, rather than just one; drawing (L)

headline: Hot Market For Initial Offerings Tapers Off
abstract: Market for initial public stock offerings ended 1997 with few of price explosions of previous few years (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: West Africa's New Oil Barons; Equatorial Guinea Joins the Region's Bonanza
abstract: Many officials in Equatorial Guinea's mining ministry are still having hard time coming to terms with country's fantastic oil windfall; last year alone, offshore petroleum production, which was begun only recently by Mobil Oil Corp, earned poverty-stricken country estimated $100 million, effectively doubling gross domestic product overnight; Mobil and other companies are already scrambling for rights to explore for many more deposits on deep-water blocks nearby; map; photos (L)

headline: Cincinnati Fund Looks No Farther Than Its Backyard
abstract: Gateway Group's Cincinnati Fund, set up in late 1994 and managed by J Patrick Rogers, is restricted to about 100 public companies based in Cincinnati area or with significant operations there; photo; annualized return was 29.3 percent over last three years (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: France Meshes Old and New to Create a Super-School
abstract: PARIS—  The days when budding designers in France learned their trade picking up pins in the couture house atelier are over. Faced with increasingly stiff European and international competition, French schools are beefing up their curriculums. Internationalization, multi-disciplinary study and fashion business are the new mantras.

headline: Hindu Still Proud of Role In Killing the Father of India
abstract: Interview with Gopal Godse, Hindu nationalist who recounts his role in plotting assassination of Mohandas K Gandhi in 1948 because of his evenhandad attitude toward Muslims; says he is proud of his role and feels vidicated by current elections returns, which point to best showing by Hindus ever in Indian national elections; map; photo (M)

headline: Assisted-Living Stocks Begin to Fulfill Promise
abstract: 1997 may go down as year when winners finally outnumbered losers in assisted-living industry; revenues for $12 billion industry are growing 15 to 20 percent annually; companies, which furnish residences for frail but healthy elderly, are trying to distinguish themselves in crowded field; photo (M)

headline: SYCAMORE PARTNERS AGREES TO ADD MEGO FINANCIAL
abstract: Sycamore Partners LLC to acquire Mego Financial Corp for about $120 million; Sycamore is newly formed entity to be financed by Blackacre Capital Group LP (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices fall nearly 4 percent, to lowest level in four months, amid expected big crop in Brazil and weak demand; May contract falls 5.8 cents, to $1.525 a pound, on Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; graph; chart (S)

headline: Surge in Asian Stocks Buoys Markets in Europe and U.S.
abstract: Global stock markets rally after Japanese Govt backs plan that many investors believe will stimulate its economy and help ease concerns about Asian crisis; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 7,753.55, up 67.78 for day; graph (M)

headline: E-Mail Alerts Show Growing Potential
abstract: Philip Greenspun, computer scientist and creator of E-mail alert service called Remind Me, is working with colleagues at Massachusetts Institute of Technology to push frontier of E-mail alerts, not for profit but for science; their premise is that most alerts run backwards, centered on sender rather than recipient; they plan free Web service that will allow people to put in basic facts about their pets, then receive E-mail alerts when shots are due; animal's medical history would be on Web for veterinarian if pet is ill or injured while traveling; photo (M)

headline: China Is Said to Suspect a Bomb in Bus Blast
abstract: Chinese police reportedly suspect bus blast, Wuhan, that killed at least 16 people was caused by bomb; terrorists bombings are rare in China (M)

headline: A Welcome Explanation
abstract: Shirley Harrison letter lauds Feb 26 article explaining meaning of megahertz in personal computers (S)n

headline: Ex-Nazi Is Seized; Accused of Gunning Down 500 at Maidanek
abstract: German prosecutors arrest suspected Nazi war criminal accused of killing 500 people at Maidanek death camp in Poland in 1943; refuse to identify suspect and decline to confirm news reports that his name is Alfons Goetzfried (S)

headline: An On-Line Lesson in Thin Mints and Lemon Pastry Cremes
abstract: More than a third of the country's 319 Girl Scout councils have gone on line in the last two years and some councils are selling cookies on the Web; photo (M)

headline: Corning to Sell Most of Its Cookware Unit
abstract: Corning Inc says it agreed to sell most of its Corning cookware business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co for $583 million and assumption of $10 million in debt; accord comes after Corning's agreement with AEA Investors Inc fell through (S)

headline: Publisher Apologizes to Hong Kong Chief for Canceled Book
abstract: HarperCollins, in highly unusual move, apologizes for suggesting its decision to cancel publication of book East and West, by Chris Patten, former Hong Kong Governor, was spurred by book's shortcomings; agrees to pay Patten unspecified sum; apology is public embarrasment for Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corp owns publisher; he ordered cancellation out of concern book would jeopardize his relationship with Chinese leaders; backs Eddie Bell, HarperCollins executive chairman (M)

headline: After Clinton's Trek: Fear of a Crushing Embrace?
abstract: News analysis of Pres Clinton's visit to South Africa as part of African visit; even though one of Clinton's central themes is partnership, which is widely welcomed as break with paternalism of past, he left behind major question over terms of potential partnership; US could crush comparatively small nations and economies of continent in its embrace because of its overwhelming economic and political power (M)

headline: U.S. Military Draws Up Battle Plans on How to Win an 'Info War'
abstract: PARIS—  Information warfare was born with hackers, anarchistic whiz-kids who got so bored waiting for their turn running a big IBM mainframe at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that they turned to pranks such as taking a piano apart, then reassembling it atop the chapel spire.

headline: Colgate-Palmolive Sweeps Awards
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive Co is awarded Grand Edison New Product Marketer of the Year award at 12th annual presentation of Edison Best New Products Awards, sponsored by American Marketing Assn (S)

headline: U.S. Mediator Seeking to Get Mideast Talks Restarted
abstract: Dennis Ross, US mediator for Middle East, shuttles between Israeli and Palestinian politicians for third day in search of new formula to bridge widening gap between them and enable negotiations to resume; central question among Israelis is whether Government of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu can survive any decision following resignation of Foreign Min David Levy (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: THE SUHARTO BILLIONS -- A special report.; For Asian Nation's First Family, Financial Empire Is in Peril
abstract: Special report, The Suharto Billions, describes huge fortune amassed by Indonesian Pres Suharto and his six children in 32 years of his rule over far-flung nation of 200 million people; IMF, demanding wide reforms as price of financial rescue package, confronts entrenched 'king' whose authority has never been questioned, and whose children believe their wealth is God-given; youngest Suharto son, Hutomo Mandala Putra, will lose lucrative tax breaks for his automobile company, as well as monopoly on cloves, used in Indonesian cigarettes; $1.6-billion power plant sponsored by his sister, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, is canceled and bank owned by middle son, Bambang Trihatmodjo, is closed down; paper, cement and plywood cartels run by family and friends are to be dissolved under IMF terms; unclear is whether family of ailing 76-year-old leader will give up operations that amount to 'crony capitalism' that has stunted country's development by killing off competition, driving out foreign investment and keeping prices high; family also owns television and radio networks, chemical factories, pharmaceutical companies, shopping malls, hotels, shipping lines and taxi companies; Hutomo runs airline, brother Bambang Trihatmodjo controls communications satellite industry and sister Siti Hardiyanti Rukamana built major toll roads; photos; map (L)

headline: Blair Puts His Weight Behind Dome Of Millennium
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair says Millennium Dome, Britain's ambitious monument to next century which is scheduled to open on Dec 31, 1999, will be built on time and on budget; dome has been derided as extravagant irrelevancy, a political vanity project and colossal waste of $1.24 billion; it was designed by architect Richard Rogers and will be built in Greenwich to mark place where Greenwich Mean Time was introduced in 1884 and where new century will officially dawn (M)

headline: Computer Services Company Vows Fight on Hostile Offer
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp will fight $9.8 billion hostile takeover offer made by Computer Associates International Inc; Computer Sciences says $108-a-share offer is far too low and merger would pose problems for its customers, employees and business projects (M)

headline: Turkey Jails A Dissident Who Praised Rebel Kurds
abstract: Turkish dissident Haluk Gerger begins serving 10-month sentence linked to his 1993 article praising Kurdish rebels and charging army bombs villages and burns farms in Kurdish region; jailing is sign of Turkey's determination to limit public praise for rebels (M)

headline: For $19.95, Slate Sees Who Its Friends Are
abstract: Slate, Microsoft's on-line magazine, will charge its readers a subscription fee, in radical step for Internet; venture is being watched closely as test of potential profitability of Internet; Slate, created and edited by Michael Kinsley, seeks to help define category that did not exist, product straddling several worlds; it arguably has depth and analysis of print, immediacy of radio and television, and bells and whistles of Web sites; Slate's decision to go to paid circulation is calculated risk, with so much else on Web free; several webzines have folded before even trying paid subscriptions; Microsoft feels move is financially necessary, because revenue from advertisers is low, given Slate's relatively small number of readers; Slate will have to spend money on advertising to win new readers; photo (M)

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN TO BUY THERMADYNE HOLDINGS
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc's Merchant Banking Partners II says it will buy 82 percent of Thermadyne Holdings Corp for $790 million in stock and debt (S)

headline: Big Hospital Chain To Report Huge Loss
abstract: The nation's largest chain of hospitals, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, said yesterday that it expected to report a loss of between $1.25 billion and $1.35 billion for the last three months of 1997 because of the costs of a reorganization and an extensive Federal investigation into its business practices.    Wall Street analysts had expected the company to post a small profit for the last quarter of the year, excluding the effects of any extraordinary losses. But the company said it would report a loss of $375 million to $425 million on operations, even before accounting for the costs of reorganizing and the Federal inquiry.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Chart on key United States interest rates

headline: For book clubs, the big increase in sales is coming in smaller niches.
abstract: Major trade publishers are struggling with downturn in hardcover and mass-market paperback sales, but book clubs are faring much better, reporting 5 percent rise in sales in 1997, and 50 percent rise from 1990 to 1996; club executives credit much of their success to their strategy of focusing on niche markets; there are book clubs devoted to crafts, cooking, home decorating, religious themes and many other subjects (M)

headline: The Many New Shades of Gray
abstract: Roundup of what personal-finance magazines are offering this month; photo (M)

headline: Overseas Crisis Takes a Toll On Earnings Of 3 Big Banks
abstract: Crisis in overseas financial markets is again felt in US, as J P Morgan & Co, Chase Manhattan Corp and Citicorp say fourth-quarter earnings were hurt by sharp economic downturns in Asia and Latin America; J P Morgan says profit plunged 35.3 percent; Chase Manhattan's earnings rose 5 percent and Citicorp's gained 7.4 percent, but both companies were battered abroad; J P Morgan reports net income of $271 million on revenue of $1.68 billion, compared with $419 million on revenue of $1.8 billion a year ago; for the year, bank earned $1.465 billion on revenue of $7.22 billion, compared with $1.57 billion on revenue of $6.85 billion in 1996; Citicorp had profits of $1.06 billion on revenue of $6 billion, compared with $987 million on revenue of $5.74 billion in year-earlier quarter; Citicorp earned $3.6 billion on revenue of $23.3 billion, compared with profits of $3.8 billion on revenue of $21.5 billion in 1996; Chase reports profits of $874 million on revenue of $4.29 billion, compared with $836 million on revenue of $4.1 billion in last year's quarter; Chase earned $3.53 billion on revenue of $17.67 billion, compared with profits of $2.24 billion on revenue of $16.43 billion in 1996; chart (L)

headline: Despite Carnage, Algeria Shuns Aid Offers
abstract: Algeria rejects all outside interference in its internal affairs as reports mount that Islamic militants are committing atrocities against Algerian civilians; Foreign Min Klaus Kinkel of Germany has called for dispatch of European Union mission to Algeria to help Government in dealing with crisis; Algerian newspaper La Tribune reports that 'several hundred people' were burned alive on Jan 4 in Relizane Province in western Algeria, where 412 people were reportedly slaughtered by Islamic rebels opposed to military-backed Government; map; photo (M)

headline: Solemn Words Offered by the Vatican: A Call to Penitence
abstract: Text of Vatican document acknowledging blame for failure of Roman Catholics to deter slaughter of Europe's Jews during Holocaust; photo (L)

headline: Rules Could Change At Troubled H.M.O.
abstract: Members of Oxford Health Plans may eventually face fewer choices, higher costs or both under a shake-up aimed at reversing heavy losses at the big managed-care company.

headline: Southern to Buy Generator
abstract: Southern Co acquires coal-fired State Line Generating Station in Hammond, Ind, from Commonwealth Edison for $68 million (S)

headline: Auto Dealers Make Changes in Accounts
abstract: Ford Motor Co and Mitsubishi Motor Co dealers make changes on their advertising accounts; specifics noted (S)

headline: Another Year Of the Bull; Dow Up 22%
abstract: For the first time in its 100-year history, Dow Jones industrial average registers three consecutive superb years; all major stock market indexes show strong returns, adding $2.6 trillion worth of wealth to the market; even with decline of 7.72 points yesterday, Dow average closes at 7,908.25--a gain of 22.6 percent for the year and first time Dow had ever gained 20 percent or more for three consecutive years; graphs on 3-year gains on Dow Jones industrial average; chart of other periods of three-year gains (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CPC International, maker of Hellman's mayonnaise and Knorr soups, changes its name to Bestfoods and spins off Corn Products International, business it has owned since 1906 (S)

headline: European Commission May Revoke Exemption for U.S. Movie Studios
abstract: European Commission antitrust official moves to break up United International Pictures, joint distribution company in Frankfurt, Ger, owned by three big American movie studios; studios, Paramount, MCA and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer-United Artists, together account for 20 percent of box-office sales in Europe, reflecting Europe's soaring demand for Hollywood output; until now, underlying direction of policy at European Commission has been to force more open competition on every part of economy, including media, rather than promoting national cultures (M)

headline: Antalaha Journal; Vanilla Farming? Not as Bland as You Might Think
abstract: Increasing use of artificial chemical flavorings and foreign competition has hurt Madagascar's vanilla industry, but most harm has resulted from years of Government price-fixing, high taxation and over-regulation; cash crop that once brought prices of nearly $40 per pound was for long time island's second biggest export crop after coffee; map; photo (M)

headline: Bozell Resigns From Merrill Account
abstract: Bozell Worldwide declines to take part in review called by Merrill Lynch & Co, resigning from worldwide advertising account after 12 years (S)

headline: TRANSWORLD ENDS ACQUISITION TALKS WITH HEALTHCALL
abstract: Transworld Healthcare Inc ends talks on possible acquisition of Healthcall Group PLC valued at about $96.5 million (US) (S)

headline: Why Microsoft Is Taking a Hard Line With the Government
abstract: Microsoft Corp's combative stance against Justice Department can be traced to 1994 consent decree that slightly altered Microsoft's licensing practices; settlement prohibited Microsoft from tying use of one of its products to another, but not from developing integrated products; Microsoft sees its current crusade as defense of principle that Microsoft alone should be arbiter of what goes into its products and how it defines integrated product; Microsoft contends that what is at stake is who will control innovation in economy--entrepreneurial companies like Microsoft or Washington and the courts; Justice Department sees case as abuse of market power on part of Microsoft; says Microsoft is using its near-monopoly in operating-system software to restrict competition in market for Internet browsing software, where its main competitor is Netscape Communications Corp; photos; chronology of events in Microsoft's march onto Internet since 1993 (L)

headline: Diminishing Draw For Olympic Games
abstract: Viewers of Olympic Winter Games in Nagano, Japan, watched on average one full day less of coverage than viewers watched of 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta; about 43 percent of viewers in study rated commercials they saw as 'outstanding' or 'better than usual'; 50 percent say CBS's coverage was good (S)

headline: British Officer Said to Give NATO Plans to Bosnian Serbs
abstract: British Government is expected to charge Army Maj Milos Stankovic with providing classified NATO information and documents to Bosnian Serb leadership during last two years of Balkan war; senior Western diplomats say he seriously undermined effectiveness of United Nations peacekeeping effort in Bosnia (M)

headline: The Other Battle Over Browsers; Barnes & Noble and Other On-Line Booksellers Are Poised to Challenge Amazon.com
abstract: Leading Internet booksellers are locked in battle for dominance, market share, strategic alliances and customer loyalty; sales are expected to rise to $400 million this year, or 3 percent of $13 billion retail market; Borders Group and Bertelsmann AG are expected to enter field, and Barnes & Noble plans to significantly increase its advertising; current leader in field, Amazon.com, will start selling music and expand into Europe while searching for distribution sites there; Jeffrey P Bezos, 34-year-old founder of Amazon.com, says he fears Barnes & Noble's purchasing power and Bertelsmann's marketing skills, but is confident that Amazon.com knows more about E-commerce than anybody else; says company is not yet making profit, but is meeting its immediate goal of getting big fast; its customer accounts grew to 1.51 million by end of 1997, with 58 percent of orders from repeat customers; best evidence of growing effect of electronic bookstores comes from top publishers who over last few months made quiet pilgrimages to Amazon.com's offices; photos; graph (L)

headline: AT&T to Pay $11.3 Billion For Teleport
abstract: AT&T Corp agrees to acquire Teleport Communications Group Inc, one of nation's largest alternative local telephone companies, for $11.3 billion in stock; if deal goes through, it would give AT&T significant presence in local telephone markets for first time since company was forced to spin off its local operations as part of antitrust settlement in 1984; chart (L)

headline: Information Potholes
abstract: Question and answer column on why connection to Internet service provider may occur at slower speed than users modem is capable of (S)9

headline: Will Iran Now Let a U.S. Congressman Visit? Yes and No
abstract: Rep Tom Lantos asks to visit Iran in order to improve its relations with US; offer elicits conflicting reactions from Iranian Government on whether such a visit would be cultural, which would be acceptable under Pres Mohammad Khatami's recent overture, or political, which would not be acceptable (M)

headline: Pope Carries His Message to the 'Rome' of an Afro-Cuban Faith
abstract: Pope John Paul II celebrates Mass in Santiago de Cuba, where many Catholics also practice African-derived faith of Santeria, much to displeasure of Catholic Church; estimated three-quarters of Cubans were Catholics before revolution in 1959, but majority of country's 11 million people--including many who consider themselves good Catholics--are believed to follow Santeria and to regard it as essential part of nation's identity; Catholic hierarchy regards Santeria's enhanced status under Castro and encouragement it has enjoyed since Communist Party abandoned atheism in 1992 as part of organized campaign against Catholicism; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Can't Find Buyer for Jets Thailand Can No Longer Afford
abstract: Thailand is trying to back out of a contract to buy eight F/A-18 fighter jets, whose $392 million cost is now beyond its means; US is in a bind because planes are incompatible with its arsenal and it cannot find another buyer in time for Thailand to keep its contract with plane's manufacturer, Boeing; Boeing, noting that Thailand technically purchased planes directly from US, not from it, regards matter as one between the two governments (M)

headline: For a Shaky Japanese Economy, The Premier Is a Hesitant Steward
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's uncertain stewardship of his country's economy discussed; officials in Washington and Asian capitals are increasingly alarmed and angered by Hashimoto's reluctance to stimulate fragile Japanese economy; they fear that his inaction could worsen Asian financial crisis and provoke global slowdown; they foresee economic confrontation about international repercussions of Japan's domestic economic policy, rather than about trade barriers; photo (M)

headline: Unlike Microsoft, Intel Opts to Speak Softly on Antitrust Issues
abstract: Intel Corp has same commanding position in personal computer industry as Microsoft Corp, and has come under same scrutiny from Government antitrust authorities, but unlike Microsoft, Intel has mostly kept matter out of Federal court, Congress and headlines; antitrust experts note Intel takes more cautious and painstaking approach to antitrust issue than Microsoft; every manager and member of sales force at Intel attends antitrust training seminars, and every annual performance evaluation for managers includes person's work on antitrust compliance program; Intel officials have not shown belligerence of Microsoft officials, who have been quoted as calling Justice Dept staff 'poorly informed lawyers' and 'unwitting dupes'; nevertheless, none of Intel's compliance efforts will help if Federal Trade Commission finds that Intel was tying purchase of one product to another in licensing deals, or giving price discounts for buying only Intel chips (M)

headline: SHARES OF CMC PLUNGE 45% ON LOSS OF MICRON BUSINESS
abstract: Stock of CMC Industries declines more than 45 percent after company says it is losing its contract manufacturing services for its biggest customer, Micron Electronics Inc; shares close at $5.875 (S)

headline: BUSINESS AIR FARES CLIMB, PROMPTING CALLS FOR REMEDY
abstract: Business travelers are continuing to pay increasingly higher air fares, with price of a domestic round-trip coach ticket on at least one route surpassing $2,000 for first time; American Express Travel says air fares for business travelers have climbed nearly 40 percent in last two years; increases have prompted some members of Congress to take new look at reining in airline industry; Business Travel Contractors Corp, group supported by 58 companies that was most potent force pressing airlines to hold down ticket prices, recently suspended operations in frustration after four years; rising business fares have led to growing chorus of complaints about airline deregulation and have increased pressure on Clinton Administration and Congress to take action (M)

headline: PSA Peugeot Shares Rise On Outlook for Profit
abstract: Shares of PSA Peugeot Citroen climb after company says it will report profit this year and pay dividend after losing 2.77 billion francs ($454 million) in 1997; graph (S)

headline: Drug Merger Studied, With New Partners
abstract: Smithkline Beecham PLC is in talks with Glaxo Wellcome PLC on possible merger that would be largest corporate deal in history and would create world's biggest pharmaceutical maker; in pursuing combination with another British drug giant, Smithkline has spurred American Home Products, with which it had held merger discussions for last two months (L)

headline: A $2.8 Billion Deal by Alcoa For Alumax
abstract: Aluminum Co of America, nation's largest aluminum producer, says it is buying Alumax Inc, No 3 aluminum maker, for $2.8 billion in cash and stock; acquisition would expand capability of Alcoa in aluminum extrusion business as well as providing it with Alumax's low-cost aluminum smelters; merger, if approved, will increase Alcoa's annual revenue to $17 billion from $13 billion, add 100,000 employees and increase estimated annual output of aluminum to nearly four million tons; it will leave Reynolds Metals Co as No 2 domestic producer; merger is not expected to have regulatory problems, because companies are merging different lines of business; graph (M)

headline: Disney Profits Up 18%, Aided by Theme Parks
abstract: Walt Disney Co says profit rose 18 percent in its fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31; net income increased to $755 million from $641 million a year earlier; revenue increased 5.9 percent, to $6.34 billion from $5.98 billion (M)

headline: FORD SETS DISTRIBUTION FOR ASSOCIATES FIRST SPINOFF
abstract: Ford Motor Co sets distribution for its spin off of its 80.7 percent stake in Associates First Capital Corp (S)9

headline: Already Accountable
abstract: Stuart Kessler letter opposes legislation offered by Repr Richard H Baker that calls for SEC to approve pronouncements of Financial Accounting Standards Board (S)

headline: Copenhagen Journal; Unsolved in Denmark: Little Mermaid Caper
abstract: Bronze statue of Little Mermaid in Copenhagen harbor, since 1913 Denmark's best-known national emblem, has its head reattached after having been decapitated by vandal; chronology of vandalism against Little Mermaid through decades; tourists once again are posing by mermaid; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY

headline: Loss at Micron Technology Much Steeper Than Expected
abstract: Micron Technology Inc reports steeper-than-expected loss for its second fiscal quarter, citing pricing pressure from Asian competitors; for quarter ended Feb 26, Micron reports net loss of $48.1 million, compared with earnings of $142.7 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue in latest quarter dropped 14 percent, to $755.4 million (M)

headline: Signs of Recovery, but the Hard-Hit Brace for 'Ugly' Year
abstract: Thailand is emerging from crippling stage of national denial, and other hardest-hit nations of Southeast Asia have also begun grappling with economic downturn that over last six months ended decade of sky-high growth; Indonesia and Malaysia have already begun scaling back their growth plans; recovery will take time, will cause economic pain and social disruptions and will call for still-untested political will among region's leaders; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EVEREN CAPITAL CORP., Chicago, is laying off 250 workers, or about 30 percent of the 900 employees, at its Dallas-based Principal Financial Securities unit, which it bought in December for $75 million.

headline: Where Microsoft Wants to Go Today
abstract: Microsoft Corp, with $9 billion in cash and no debt, can go anywhere it wants, unless Government stops it; chances that Government might get in Microsoft's way increased lately as antitrust officials at Justice Dept aggressively pursued company in court; still, Microsoft has three goals: to go further into industrial-strength heart of corporate computing with Windows NT operating system and server software, to extend its reach further into American households using new frontier of television or some future variant of television, and to retool its media strategy; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rough Road for Motorola As Wireless Goes Digital  As the wireless communications industry has transformed itself from analog to digital technology, Motorola, whose reputation for innovation, quality and smart strategic thinking flourished in the early 1990's, has looked surprisingly clumsy at times.

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN UNIT TO PAY $437 MILLION FOR INSILCO
abstract: Insilco Corp agrees to be acquired by buyout fund run by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc for about $437 million including assumed debt; under deal, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II will acquire about 90 percent of Insilco's common shares (S)

headline: Senate Struggles to Pay Attention to the Remapping of NATO
abstract: Senate takes up issue of NATO expansion as afterthought, debating it for second day in row only after chaotic scheduling short-circuits debate on education; Sen John Warner, who is leading opposition to expansion, criticizes Senate for its lack of interest in foreign policy (M)

headline: 7-Up Adopts New Formula And New Ads
abstract: Reformulated 7-Up that is intended to revive long-slumbering soda brand is being introduced around country; new formula, with additional lemon-lime flavoring, is first change in soda since it was introduced in 1929; its parent company, Cadbury Schweppes PLC of Britain, hopes new 7-Up, which is expected to be on sale nationwide by late January, will budge brand from its perennial low spot on soft-drink totem pole; chart (M)

headline: AT&T Is Seeking Cable-TV Alliances
abstract: AT&T Corp's chief financial officer Daniel E Somers says company is talking to number of cable-television companies about alliances, which could help it offer local telephone and high-speed Internet access using cable wires (S)

headline: BRANDYWINE REALTY BUYS 23 PROPERTIES FOR $229 MILLION
abstract: Brandywine Realty Trust agrees to acquire 23-office property portfolio from GMH Associates Inc and other partners for $229 million; other partners include Whitehall Street Real Estate LLP VII and General Electric GE Capital unit (S)

headline: KPMG Settling Suit by Teachers In California
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick agrees to settle class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of some 20,000 California teachers who contended that accounting firm was not independent when it audited financial books of real estate partnerships that teachers had invested in; KPMG and another defendant in case, Comerica Inc, a banking company, agree to pay teachers $14 million; KPMG will pay something less than $10 million; neither firm nor bank admit any fault; teachers estimate their losses at $100 million (L)

headline: 1998 SPOTLIGHT
abstract: NOV. 1 By this day, the broadcast television networks have pledged to begin broadcasting digital television, much of it in high-definition. But some of them will probably start months earlier, with the start of the fall season. Television manufacturers intend to put the first high-definition television sets on sale starting in August or September.

headline: Chicago Archbishop Represents A Vital Center of U.S. Catholicism
abstract: Biographical profile of Archbishop Francis Eugene George of Chicago, who has been named a cardinal by Pope John Paul II; like all of Pope's recent appointments, he is conservative who can be counted on to defend traditional teachings; appointment continues long tradition of Vatican recognition that Chicago's spiritual head speaks for vital center in American Catholicism; photo (S)

headline: Ethnic Chinese in Malaysia Can Buy Big Equity Stakes
abstract: Malaysia, forced by Asian economic crisis to ease policy of promoting indigenous Malays over Chinese, will let overseas Chinese who live in Malaysia buy big equity stakes to bail out top Malay-controlled conglomerates; move contravenes central feature of economic plan, adopted in 1971, to create wealthy Malay elite to challenge pre-eminence of overseas Chinese; Daim Zainuddin, nation's top economic adviser, rules out sales to foreign companies (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.38   5.29   5.25        3-month T-bills   4.96   5.07   4.97        6-month T-bills   4.96   5.06   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.73   3.77   N.A.        10-yr. T-note   5.46   5.52   6.49        30-yr. T-bond   5.75   5.78   6.75        Telephone bd.   7.06   7.06   7.80        Municipal bds.   5.16   5.19   5.80          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Bowling's Fast Lane Of Slang
abstract: World Wide Web has at least two glossaries of bowling slang and one site describing how to keep score; diagram (S)

headline: Iraq Threatens to Stop Work Of a U.N. Inspection Team
abstract: Iraq again threatens to block new UN arms inspection team because it has nine Americans and because it is led by Scott Ritter, former Marine captain who served in Persian Guf war (M)

headline: AT&T Chief Said to Plan Big Job Cuts
abstract: AT&T said to plan cut in work force of about 15,000 employees, or roughly 12 percent; job cuts would be biggest step yet by company's new chairman, C Michael Armstrong, as he tries to remake AT&T into slim, fast-moving operator after decades of relative sluggishness; there may also be shakeup of senior management; Jeffrey Weitzen, who heads AT&T's unit serving business customers, says he will leave to become president of Gateway 2000 Inc; it is unclear whether most of cuts will come through attrition, voluntary buyouts or layoffs; Wall Street will probably be skeptical of any job elimination announcement from AT&T, given fact that AT&T now has more employees than it did two years ago, when it last announced that it would cut jobs (M)

headline: Texaco-Chevron Venture
abstract: Texaco Inc and Chevron Corp will spend $185 million to develop natural-gas site nearly two-thirds of mile below surface of Gulf of Mexico; Texaco owns 60 percent and Chevron 40 percent of reserve; drilling to begin later this year (S)

headline: Write-Offs Result in a Loss At Dow Jones in 4th Quarter
abstract: Dow Jones & Co reports fourth-quarter net loss of $889.3 million compared with profit of $59.6 million in 1996 fourth quarter; excluding one-time items, profits fell 24 percent, to $38.7 million; revenues rose 2.7 percent, to $689.5 million; chart (L)

headline: Clinton Will Insist Netanyahu Stick to Palestinian Issues
abstract: Clinton Administration, signaling that it will not be diverted from pressing for Israeli withdrawal from West Bank, has made it clear to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that his meeting with Pres Clinton should focus on Israeli-Palestinian negotiations; US officials, planning meeting, say they consider Netanyahu serious about peace, but that Israeli Cabinet's new list of conditions is not helpful (S)

headline: Oil Service Companies Surge; Dow Hits 8th Recent High
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 32.89 points, to 8,490.67, eighth new high in last 12 trading days; Nasdaq composite index is up 10.63 points, to record 1,777.11, and Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is up 5.77 points, to record 1,048.67; graph; chart (L)

headline: The Japanese Embrace Hip-Hop, and Parappa Is Born
abstract: Parappa the Rapper, released as Sony Playstation title in Japan, is selling well in United States, despite fact that it has no explosions, acrobatic combat or anything in way of cinematic violence; rap, which in US is seen as glorifying gangsta high life, is in this game distinctly Japanese: an animated playground filled with whimsical cartoon characters playing game of Simon Says; the background, a cartoon candyland, is kind of universal suburbia that Japanese children recognize from countless American sitcoms; photo (M)

headline: Can You Spare a Dime? Click Yes.
abstract: Rich Schmidt's Amazing 'Send Me a Dollar' Website is example of very old profession of begging updated for Web; Amazing site is entertaining and even endearing, and Schmidt claims to have received total of $300, by far most sent to any on-line beggar on Web; photo (M)

headline: Serbs Claim Victory Over a Separatist Militia
abstract: Senior Serbian officials and Western diplomats say that sweep in central Kosovo province by hundreds of Serbian police and paramilitary units appears to have failed to capture or kill most of ethnic Albanian rebels operating in area; action, which threatens to ignite another major conflict in Balkans, has left scores of people dead and dozens of houses burned (M)

headline: Help Is Ahead for Middle-Class Families Planning for College
abstract: Advice on new tax breaks for parents saving for their children's college costs; most of benefits take effect in 1998; photo (M)

headline: Starwood Says It Has Arranged Financing for ITT Acquisition
abstract: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust has obtained more than $7 billion in financing that will allow it to complete its $10.2 billion acquisition of the ITT Corporation, a hotel and casino company, Starwood's chairman and chief executive, Barry S. Sternlicht, said yesterday.     ''The deal will not unravel,'' Mr. Sternlicht said in an interview, calling the financing ''the largest of its type ever done for a real estate transaction.''

headline: U.S. General Says Conflict With Iraqis Is Still Possible
abstract: Gen Anthony C Zinni, commander of American forces in Persian Gulf, says American military buildup probably thwarted threat of hostilities by Iraq, but warns that military confrontation remains possible; says he does not know when US will be able to withdraw additional forces sent to region last month during lastest showdown with Iraq (M)

headline: Technology Earning Reports Finally Drive Down Markets
abstract: Major stock market indexes finish lower following warnings of disappointing earnings from some of largest technology companies late last week; Dow Jones industrial average slips 2.25 points, closing at 8,567.14; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index falls 3.38 points, to 1,052.31; graph (M)

headline: For ABC, the Academy Awards show means a badly needed big audience.
abstract: ABC-TV, which is broadcasting Academy Awards show, is hoping for huge one-night rating to help its overall yearly prime-time rating figure significantly; graph (M)

headline: CERTAINTEED TO ACQUIRE BIRD CORPORATION
abstract: Bird Corp agrees to be acquired by Certainteed Corp for $40 million (S)

headline: Dreamworks' lackluster start is putting pressure on the company to perform.
abstract: Prince of Egypt, $60 million animated story of Moses, is key release for Dreamworks SKG; if successful, it can generate cash and reassure investors and Hollywood community of company's ability to stake out its turf in lucrative animation industry; photo (M)

headline: Archer Daniels Informant Repudiates His Allegations
abstract: Mark E Whitacre, chief informant in sweeping antitrust investigation of Archer Daniels Midland Co, repudiates allegations he made last year that Federal Bureau of Investigation agent ordered him to destroy evidence favorable to potential defendants in case; Whitacre, former Archer Daniels executive, secretly recorded conversations that Government contends were part of conspiracy to fix prices of Lysine, feed additive; those tapes are now in dispute; Archer Daniels executives who were indicted in case asked judge to throw out much of Government's evidence, based in part on Whitacre's earlier allegations against FBI agent; Whitacre's new statement is latest in series of twists in investigation; his relationship with Government collapsed in 1995 after prosecutors learned he diverted millions of dollars from Archer Daniels to his own foreign bank accounts (M)

headline: Sports magazines are stepping up branding and promotion efforts.
abstract: Advertising column examines competition under way in crowded field of sports magazines; two mainstays of field, Sports Illustrated and Sport, have already been redesigned in anticipation of challenge from Walt Disney Co's entry, ESPN; third magazine, Inside Sports, has made editorial changes and increased its frequency; most ambitious revamping is being undertaken by oldest sports publication, The Sporting News, which has changed from newsprint tabloid into glossy magazine; photo (M)

headline: Foundation Health Systems Will Sell an Insurance Subsidiary
abstract: Foundation Health Systems Inc plans to sell its workers' compensation insurance unit and has hired Salomon Smith Barney as financial adviser for sale (S)

headline: Britain Takes Step Toward Ousting I.R.A. Ally at Ulster Talks
abstract: British Government moves closer to temporarily expelling Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, from Northern Ireland peace talks because of involvement in killing of civilian week ago in Belfast (M)

headline: Intel Offers Software to Cut Web Delays
abstract: The Intel Corporation introduced software yesterday to help Internet service providers eliminate some of the delays that plague users of the worldwide computer network.    Intel will sell the software, Quick Web, for an undisclosed price to Internet service providers, which connect users to the World Wide Web. Intel said it was negotiating with the 30 largest Internet service providers and had already signed up three of them.

headline: SUMMIT BANK TO TAKE OVER CALIFORNIA SECURITY BANK
abstract: Summit Bank Corp to acquire California Security Bank of San Jose in all-cash deal (S)

headline: Spyglass, a Pioneer, Learns Hard Lessons About Microsoft
abstract: Spyglass Inc has provided software for Microsoft Inc's Internet Explorer browser and also sought for a time to compete with Microsoft in browser market, and those endeavors offer lesson in complexities of software competition and software innovation and what it means to go up against giant such as Microsoft; Douglas P Colbeth, chief executive of Spyglass, has sanguine attitude about Microsoft's dominance; says while innovation in software business may be lost because companies fear competing with Microsoft, effect may be to drive innovation into other parts of information technology business; Colbeth will testify at Senate hearing in midst of persistent industry debate about Microsoft's practices; photo (M)

headline: Not So Jolly Now, a Giant Agency Retools
abstract: Leo Burnett Co, which enjoyed highly successful run of product promotions through 1990's, was knocked down to earth when some major advertisers withdrew their accounts starting in 1996; for long time, Burnett saw itself as special, holding confidently to status quo even as advertising world was changing around it; Burnett has now embarked on mission to remake itself, aiming to be quicker and smarter; is transforming itself into seven small business units, sending more than half of its roughly 2,000 workers in Chicago to new offices, and grouping creative and business people together according to brand; people in industry say it is too soon to say if Burnett's overhaul will succeed; photos (L)

headline: President Should Tell His Story, Stephanopoulos Says : Former Aide Calls on Clinton To Dispel Cloud of Questions
abstract: WASHINGTON—  George Stephanopoulos, once one of President Bill Clinton's closest advisers, called Wednesday on Mr. Clinton to clear the air of the lingering cloud of questions about his relationship to a former intern.

headline: Amplifying Voices For Human Rights
abstract: Hundreds of human rights organizations can be found in cyberspace; Djibril Diallo of United Nations Development Program says Internet is natural tool for human rights struggle, because it allows people around world to learn of rights violations immediately; however, no one seems able to measure in hard numbers just how much influence human rights activisim on line has actually had on government officials; photos (M)

headline: Cold War of the Soul: Siberian Ice Fishing
abstract: Perilous and often deadly sport of ice fishing in Siberia, where winter temperatures can fall to 32 degrees below zero, is favorite and popular pastime among millions of Russian men, not unlike American male's seemingly bottomless love of golf; its popularity and importance seems to express two immutable Russian traits, namely, love of suffering and a mystical soul; map; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buffett Says Cheap Stocks Were Tough to Find in '97  Warren Buffett, who built his reputation by buying stocks that were destined to soar, says he is having a hard time finding new investments that look cheap. So last year, he began selling some of the stocks his company, Berkshire Hathaway, had acquired over the decades.    In Berkshire Hathaway's annual report, Mr. Buffett wrote that the company cut back on three of its largest holdings: Walt Disney, Wells Fargo and Freddie Mac. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page D2.]

headline: Interpublic Group continues its shopping spree by buying Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.
abstract: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos advertising agency agrees to be acquired by Interpublic Group of Companies in pooling-of-interests stock deal; Jack Connors Jr, Hill's sole stockholder and co-founder, says group of 12 executives will share in proceeds; plans to remain chairman and chief executive (M)

headline: Barclays Sees Big Loss From Shedding Unit
abstract: Barclays PLC discloses that it would report large 1997 pretax loss of 688 million pounds ($1.1 billion) resulting from disposal of its BZW investment banking arm (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, MAXINE L. (MCKETTRICK)
abstract: WILSON-Maxine L. (McKettrick). Age 89, on March 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Isaiah Herbert ''Bud'' Wilson. Lovingly remembered by daughter Lynda Mae Wilson Laurence; grandson Matthew James Wilson Laurence and son-in-law Judge Kenneth Laurence, all of Lexington, MA. Private burial with interment at Westview Cemetery in Lexington. Visitors welcome at the Laurence home, 11 John Poulter Road, Lexington, evenings during the coming week. Contributions in Maxine's memory may be made to the Schepens Eye Research Institute for Macular Degeneration, 20 Staniford Street, Boston, MA 02114-2500, Tel: 617-723-6078.

headline: A New Palm Pilot By 3Com Today
abstract: The 3Com Corp will introduce enhanced version of its Palm Pilot hand-held electronic organizer as it prepares for Microsoft's entry into market for such devices later this year; new Palm Pilot will include infrared beaming capability to exchange information with similarly equipped devices and several other new or improved features; it will cost $399, up from current versions which sell from $250 to $370 (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           Feb. 27   Feb. 20   Feb. 28       1998   1998   1997       Gasoline production, daily   7.4   7.6   7.4       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.3   3.3       Gasoline stocks   219.0   218.0   201.8       Distillate stocks   126.1   126.6   106.7       Crude imports, daily   7.6   6.2   7.1       Product imports, daily   1.4   1.9   2.4       Crude stocks   326.7   328.7   297.8       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   89.0   88.7   88.6          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Another Rebuff to Iraq
abstract: Pres Clinton and top aides begin preparing nation for war in Iraq and for grim prospect of civilian casualties on the ground and of American pilots shot down from the skies; Clinton says he would not be deterred by Russia's opposition to an attack on Iraq if Pres Saddam Hussein does not allow United Nations weapons inspectors unfettered access; photo of memorial in Baghdad to people killed by American bombs in an attack on suburb of Amiriya on Feb 13, 1991 (M)

headline: Mondale to Visit Jakarta to Press Suharto on I.M.F. Reform Plan
abstract: Pres Clinton asks former Vice Pres Walter F Mondale to be special envoy to Indonesia; Mondale will tell Pres Suharto that US will help Indonesia through its economic crisis, but Suharto must carry out reform plan he signed with International Monetary Fund; photo (M)

headline: 300,000 FIND WORK
abstract: Labor Department reports employers added over 300,000 jobs in Feb; unemployment rate fell to 4.6 percent, down from 4.7 percent; proportion of Americans working remained at record 64.2 percent; average hourly earnings rose 8 cents, to $12.60; Federal Reserve reports consumer borrowing rose at 2.8 percent annual rate in Jan, down from 4.7 percent in Dec; graph (M)

headline: Color Ink-Jet Printers: Looking Beyond Price
abstract: Q.  When I bought my printer, the salesman showed me three different color ink-jet printers in my price range. Although they were drastically different in price, they seemed to have the same features. Is there really any difference in printers for home PC's?    A.  Desktop printers that appear to do roughly the same thing -- produce text, graphics and photographs in glorious living color -- range from about $200 to $500 these days. The whopping price discrepancy among products that are all classified as color ink-jet printers is curious, but as with many things in life, one must look closely at the fine print.

headline: He Accuses Special Prosecutor of 'Trying to Torture' His Daughter : Lewinsky's Father Rips Into Starr
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Monica Lewinsky's father vented anger and frustration Monday over the way that the investigation of his daughter's relationship to President Bill Clinton has dominated and disrupted the lives of his family and her friends.

headline: Flirtation Between Movies and Magazines Starts to Get Serious
abstract: Buzz magazine to announce deal with Paramount Pictures under which studio will provide Buzz with discretionary fund to pay for in-depth articles with movie potential, and Buzz will give Paramount first choice to buy options on articles, even before they are published; deal seen as striking testament to Hollywood's heightened interest in turning nonfiction magazine articles into film scripts; Buzz has also contracted with Crosby/Levy Co, management production company, to shop articles around to other motion picture and television studios if Paramount declines; increasingly intimate relationship between magazines and movies is disturbing to some editors, writers and even producers, who express concern about prospect of too close an alliance between magazines, which report facts, and studios, which create escapist fantasy; people in magazine business wonder if writers and editors will pursue articles based on their big-screen potential rather than their news value; photo (M)

headline: Consortium May Abandon Rail Contract
abstract: London and Continental Railways consortium to abandon its $8.3 billion contract to build high-speed link to Channel Tunnel and to run Eurostar passenger train service after failing to raise more money; consortium executives say decision was made after British Government rejected its request for additional 1.2 billion pound ($1.9 billion) subsidy; Government has already pledged 1.8 billion pounds for rail link, 68-mile track from London to Britain's south coast; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VALVOLINE CO., Lexington, Ky., agreed to acquire privately held Eagle One Industries, of Carlsbad, Calif., a maker of premium car-care products, for undisclosed terms.    N.V. KONINKLIJKE KNP BT, Amsterdam, a paper and packing company, offered to buy the 30 percent of BT Office Products International Inc. of Buffalo Grove, Ill., that it does not already own for $10.50 a share cash.

headline: VACANT CUBICLES -- A special report.; Software Jobs Go Begging, Threatening Technology Boom
abstract: American demand for computer programmers vastly outsrips existing supply, and shortage is expected to get much worse as estimated one million new programming jobs become available in next nine years; Clinton Administration has announced investment of $28 million in new initiatives to encourage training of more programmers; under plan, Labor Department will offer $3 million in grants to schools, businesses and local governments to retrain laid-off workers as programmers, and will spend additional $8 million to build World Wide Web site where employers can post job offerings and workers can place resumes; Commerce Department will spend $17 million to bring technology resources, including training, to poor people; programmer shortfall is attributed to opening of hundreds of new companies in Silicon Valley in last two years, as well as failure of software industry to recover from downturn in late 1980's, when downsizing by large high-technology companies threw computer scientists out of work and discouraged college students from pursuing computer careers; from peak of 50,000 in 1986, number of bachelor's and graduate degrees in computer science plummeted to 36,000 in 1995; photos; graphs; charts (L)

headline: Stability in Technology Stocks Seems to Bolster Markets
abstract: Technology stocks begin to show signs of stability after months of drifting lower; Dow Jones industrial average rises for third consecutive session, gaining 52.56 points to close at 7,784.69 (M)

headline: The High-Return Evangelist of Valueland
abstract: Robert A Olstein, manager of Olstein Financial Alert fund, attributes fund's success to its unwavering focus on value, for which his primary gauge is a company's per-share free cash flow; photo; table (M)

headline: Chess Rivals That Coach as They Vanquish
abstract: Dylan Loeb McClain reviews computer chess programs; photos (L)

headline: Asian Markets Rebound, Some Up 10% or More
abstract: Sustained market rallies raise hopes that Asian financial crisis may have reached end of its panic-stricken beginnings; stock markets in Hong Kong, Jakarta and Singapore all rise by 14 percent, Thailand gains 12 percent and Philippines, 10 percent; stocks in Tokyo are up just under 1 percent; in Malaysia, stocks rise 22 percent; South Korean stocks defy trend, falling more than 4 percent; markets are bolstered by strength in local currencies; shares in many Asian companies are trading at fraction of their levels year ago, and are attractive to foreign investors; broad advance in Asian markets contributes to global rally that pushes stocks to record highs in Frankfurt and London and helps Dow Jones industrial average gain 201.28 points; photos; graphs (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Palladium futures prices drop on optimism that Russia will soon resume exports; palladium for June delivery falls $12 an ounce, to $258.70; graphs; table (S)

headline: Talk of British Bid Spurs Credit Lyonnais Stock
abstract: Stock price of Credit Lyonnais soars to three-year high on speculation that company will attract buyers when French Government puts up its majority stake for sale; shares close at 445 francs ($74.16), up 47 francs (S)

headline: Drug Makers at Threshold of a New Therapy; With a Dose of Biotechnology, Big Change Is Ahead in the Treatment of Diabetes
abstract: Drug makers are seen at threshold of new therapy for diabetes; diabetes and its complications remain huge health problem; host of biotechnology companies are racing to develop new therapies that ultimately aim to go beyond merely treating symptoms to attacking cause of disease, in which pancreas shuts down or fails to produce correct amount of insulin hormone, causing dangerously high blood-sugar levels; many diabetes patients could have option within two or three years of inhaling insulin rather than giving themselves injections; but not long after that, if all goes well, new oral drugs could postpone or even prevent need for some to use insulin; charts; photos (L)

headline: French Jobless Find the World Is Harsher
abstract: First of two articles, Help Unwanted, on unemployment in France and the pressure on Government to reverse the escalation in jobless benefits; pattern of worker entitlement, protest and Government capitulation is deep-rooted in France and has swollen welfare state into one of most comprehensive and costly in Europe, with much of the burden borne by employers; employers say payroll taxes and benefits are main reasons why the are not creating jobs; French economy is expected to post healthy 3 percent gain in 1998, but it will not produce many new jobs; graph; photo (M)

headline: Fears of Higher Premiums and Perhaps Less Choice
abstract: Doctors, hospitals and employers that deal with Oxford Health Plans give it mixed reviews; experts fear its financial problems could undermine open approach to health care that spurred its rapid growth; warn of higher premiums and loss of choices (M)

headline: Turk-Kurd War Begins to Spill Refugees Into Europe
abstract: Surge of Kurdish refugees fleeing aboard rusty boats from Turkey to Italy again focuses European attention on 13-year-old war between Kurdish rebels and Turkish Army, one of world's longest and most intractable civil conflicts; officials in Italy and several other European countries have made renewed calls on Turkey to change its approach to conflict, but Turkey has rejected them (M)

headline: John A. Blum, 82, Ex-Executive at Macy's
abstract: John A Blum, former advertising and public relations executive with R H Macy & Co, dies at age 82 (S)

headline: Japan Air System Reports Weak Demand
abstract: Japan Air System Co, third-largest airline in Japan, acknowledges that it had weak demand for domestic flights but declines to comment on report that its operating loss for year to March will be a third higher than forecast (S)

headline: South Korea's New President Appeals to North to End Decades of Division
abstract: Kim Dae Jung, one of Asia's most vigorous voices for democracy and political tolerance, is inaugurated as South Korea's President and immediately calls for reconciliation and cooperation with North Korea; he also calls for far-reaching changes in South Korea's economy and political structure to pull nation out of its financial crisis; photo (M)

headline: Western Wireless Gets Ownership Waiver
abstract: Federal Communications Commission grants Western Wireless Corp's application to exceed 25 percent cap on foreign ownership, clearing way for Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, Hong Kong, to buy, indirectly, 19.9 percent stake in Western Wireless unit, Western PCS Corp; acquisition will put foreign ownership of unit at about 35.6 percent, above the legal limit (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: ASSAULT ON 9000 /Page 4/  The relentlessly bullish market has some strategists revising their 1998 projections for the Dow. By Kenneth N. Gilpin.

headline: Oxford Health Announces Plans to Revamp Its Management
abstract: Oxford Health Plans announces series of moves intended to bolster depth of its top management; company says it will hire new chief executive and appoint Albert A Koch, well-regarded turnaround specialist, as its temporary chief financial officer; Oxford has asked executive search firm of Spencer Stuart to conduct search for new chief executive; decision to replace William Sullivan, who became chief executive in August 1997, and hiring of Koch signal fundamental shift of priorities for the company (L)

headline: Spate of Killings Puts Cloud Over Talks on Ulster Peace
abstract: Protestant paramilitaries attack pub in Catholic area of Belfast, killing one man and wounding five others and threatening fragile Northern Ireland peace talks; slaying is third sectarian killing in province in week; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buffett Amasses Silver, Signaling He Sees Inflation  Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, one of the most widely known and followed investors, has accumulated a large chunk of the global silver supply, helping drive the price to the highest level in nine years.     The company's disclosure of the stake, about 130 million ounces, seems to suggest Mr. Buffett is betting on a resumption in inflation, which many investors have concluded is highly unlikely. But the investment could pay off if industrial demand for the metal continues to outstrip available supply. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page A1.]

headline: Columbia/HCA Is Target Of U.S. Search in El Paso
abstract: Law-enforcement officials serve new search warrant at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp's corporate offices in El Paso, Tex, obtaining hard drive of specific computer, which was used by only one Columbia employee; it is not immediately clear what is on computer hard drive, or why Government wants access to it; legal experts with no ties to case say serving of search warrant could be sign of strain in relationship between Government and Columbia; Columbia spokesman says search in no way affects company's relationship with investigators; prosecutors are investigating whether local hospitals defrauded Federal health programs by misreporting costs and submitting fraudulent bills (M)

headline: Indonesia Will Repay Deposits at Closed Banks
abstract: Indonesia will repay all deposits stored at 16 banks that were closed in November 1997 under initial IMF reform package (S)

headline: Nokia Net Rises More Than Expected
abstract: Nokia says fourth-quarter net income rose 23 percent, to 2.018 billion markkaa ($367 million) (S)

headline: Italian Insurer Backs Fund
abstract: Assicurazioni Generali, Italian insurance giant that was dominant underwriter of policies sold to Jews in Eastern Europe before World War II, says that it will cooperate with an independent panel to investigate unpaid claims by Holocaust victims and heirs; Sen Alfonse M D'Amato proposes panel at hearing in Washington (S)

headline: Bridge to Pay $510 Million For Dow Jones Data Business
abstract: Dow Jones & Co agrees to sell its troubled financial information business to Bridge Information Systems for $360 million in cash and $150 million in Bridge preferred stock; sale to Bridge, competitor of data business, Dow Jones Markets, will be far less than $1.6 billion that Dow Jones invested in operations when it bought it in 1980's (L)

headline: MULTIPLE $500 MILLION BIDS SEEN FOR BANKAMERICA UNIT
abstract: BankAmerica Corp receives several bids that top $500 million for its mobile-home financing unit; investment bankers familiar with sale say bids may change when potential buyers examine unit's books in second round of bidding (S)

headline: Tommy Hilfiger to Buy 2 Affiliates in Deal Worth $1.15 Billion
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger Corp will acquire Pepe Jeans USA, its Canadian distributor and women's wear licensee, for approximately $1.5 billion in cash and stock (M)

headline: $100 MILLION MERGER BY MAKERS OF PRIVATE-LABEL FOODS
abstract: International Home Foods Inc acquires Grist Mill Company for about $100 million and assumption of $5 million of Grist Mill's debt (S)

headline: Greenspan's Comments and Scuttled Merger Dampen Market
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 40.10 points, to 8,370.10; tables; graph (M)

headline: Germany Says Economy Grew Slightly in Quarter
abstract: Germany reports its economy grew slightly in 1997 fourth quarter (S)8

headline: Uh-Oh: A Bullish Consensus On Bonds
abstract: Market Watch column on reasons to be bullish on Treasury bond market (S)

headline: Israel to Set No Pullback Goal Before Talks With Clinton
abstract: Israeli Cabinet decides against setting figure for percentage of land to be included in next Israeli withdrawal from West Bank in advance of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's January 20 meeting with Pres Clinton in Washington; says it will later consider pullback up to unspecified ceiling; decision appears to be effort to free Netanyahu from trying to close gap between withdrawal that right-wing Cabinet would accept and pullback that US and Palestinians would consider satisfactory (M)

headline: Palestinian Census Dwarfs Old Tally; So Who's Right?
abstract: Results of first Palestinian census are announced, showing 2.9 million Palestinians in West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem (S)

headline: Uganda Could Be Model For 'New' Africa's Goals
abstract: Uganda has achieved most stunning transformation of six countries Pres Clinton is visiting during his African trip; Uganda's economy is fastest growing in Africa; security has been re-established in most of country after years of lawlessness; framework for democracy has been created (M)

headline: Rap Empire Unraveling As Stars Flee
abstract: Death Row Records, one of music industry's most profitable and controversial labels, may be coming to end; Death Row's empire of gangsta rap has been unraveling since Tupac Shakur was gunned down in 1996 and label's chief executive, Suge Knight, began serving nine-year sentence for parole violations in 1997; Death Row has lost most of its remaining successful acts, including Snoop Doggy Dogg, and is on verge of losing its distribution deal with Interscope Records; in addition, some Death Row executives have been under investigation in last year by Federal authorities for weapons trafficking, drug dealing, tax evasion and money laundering; photos (M)

headline: Power Deregulated. Consumers Yawn.; California's Effort to Promote Plan For Electricity Is Off to a Slow Start
abstract: California officials have not been able to get consumers excited about deregulation of electricity industry; on March 31, after three-month delay due to computer glitches, California will become first state in nation to throw market open to something close to full competition--and for last five months, marketers have inundated homes and businesses with pitches for cheaper and more efficient power delivery; so far, minuscule 25,000 customers out of 9.9 million have switched providers; most Californians remain confused about purposes of program and doubtful about payoff, if any, for them; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Nehru Spoke It, but It's Still 'Foreign'
abstract: Resentment of English, language of India's colonial past, is issue in current election campaign, with leading members of ruling coalition urging English no longer be used in conducting business or as language of instruction in public schools; English, spoken by less than 5 percent of Indians, is language of Government and educated elite in nation with 18 official languages and hundreds of languages and dialects; Hindi, possible alternative, is spoken by 45 percent of Indians, but is associated with poorer northern regions and with Hindu religion; photo (M)

headline: Suit Charges Ford Profited By Nazi-Era Forced Labor
abstract: Melvyn L Weiss, New York lawyer, files lawsuit, Federal court, Newark, NJ, accusing Ford Motor Co of having profited from forced labor of thousands of civilians at truck factory of its Cologne, Germany, subsidiary during World War II; suit was filed on behalf of Belgian woman named Elsa Iwanowa, who Weiss is representing; Elan Steinberg, executive director of World Jewish Congress, says suit is first to accuse an American corporation of profiting from forced labor in Germany during World War II; Ford issues statement saying that over the years it reviewed what happened at Cologne factory and concluded that it was under Nazi control and out of touch with corporate headquarters during war; also says it has started another investigation; suit contends Ford's management in the US was aware of forced labor at its German factory and that factory's board of directors urged German Government before war not to confiscate factory in event of hostilities (M)

headline: Francisco Rodrigo, 83, Filipino Who Defied Marcos Dictatorship
abstract: Francisco Rodrigo, former Filipino politician who defied Marcos dictatorship, dies at age 83 (S)

headline: TIDEWATER PLANNING A BUYBACK OF ITS STOCK
abstract: Tidewater Inc to buy back up to $200 million of its stock, which has fallen over 30 percent from Nov 1997 high (S)

headline: AMYLIN PHARMACEUTICALS SHARES OFF 44% ON FAILED DEAL
abstract: Shares of Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc lose 44 percent of their value after company announces that Johnson & Johnson is withdrawing from collaborative agreement to develop new diabetes drug, Pramlintide (S)

headline: LOMAK PETROLEUM IN DEALS TO SELL AND BUY PROPERTIES
abstract: Lomak Petroleum Inc is selling oil and gas properties valued at $54 million and has bought three oil properties for about $39 million in cash and stock, increasing its oil reserves by more than 30 percent; sales to several purchasers include interests in 526 oil wells in San Juan and Appalachian basins and will eliminate its interests in San Juan Basin; company also sells minority interest in Appalachian gas field (S)

headline: Canadian Power Deal
abstract: TransCanada Power Services Ltd will spend $83.7 million to buy power plant in northern Ontario and expand two plants (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: PG&E Wins Huge Contract, A Harbinger of Competition  In a sign of looming competitive changes in a deregulated electric power industry, PG&E, parent of the nation's largest utility, landed a $2 billion contract to manage most of the energy needs of Ultramar Diamond Shamrock, a big independent refiner.    The contract reflects an effort by big utilities such as PG&E and Enron to secure long-term deals with big companies to manage their energy requirements. [Page D2.]

headline: Despite Threat of Missiles, the Iraqi Capital's People Take a Crisis in Stride
abstract: Residents of Iraq's capital of Baghdad seem placid, cool and almost nonchalant despite possibility of military action by US because of Government's refusal to allow UN inspectors unfettered access to suspected weapons sites; photo (M)

headline: Turkish Ban of Islamic Party Won't Deter It, Leader Says
abstract: Turkey's highest court bans Islamic-oriented Welfare Party and rules that its leader, former Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan, cannot participate in politics for next five years; Erbakan tells his followers that he will not abide by ruling, but younger members of party want to push him aside (M)

headline: Licensed Goods See Sales Increase
abstract: Annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter shows retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America rose 1 percent in 1997 to $73.2 billion (S)

headline: Law Firms Are Turning to Technology to Manage Information Explosion
abstract: Computerization and Internet have reduced grunt work in legal firms, while changes in way information is collected, organized and retrieved are transforming practice of law itself; explosion of E-mail and sheer storage space that computerization provides is making computers virtual necessity to sift, retrieve and process massive quantities of documents; Davis Polk & Wardwell is in forefront in developing state-of-the-art technology infrastructure; Michael Mills, who directs that effort, has assembled full-text index of all firm's internal memos and work-product spanning last 18 years, so that all of firm's intellectual capital is available on line on its intranet; photo (M)

headline: A 'Better' Theme For Burger King
abstract: Burger King Corp unit of Diageo PLC is changing themes in its advertising for first time since awarding its account to Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of Interpublic Group of Companies in New York; new theme is 'it just tastes better' (S)

headline: Problems at DFS Cause Shares of LVMH to Fall
abstract: Shares of LVMH fall after its duty-free unit, DFS Group Ltd, says it is negotiating two-month delay in payments to its 5,000 suppliers to offset slowing sales in Asia (S)

headline: Chirac Wary of Quick Attack If Iraq Breaks Inspection Deal
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac, his popularity soaring in public opinion polls because of credit given to French diplomacy in avoiding an attack on Iraq, says in interview that France would not support calls for automatic military response if Iraq fails to live up to its latest agreement on weapons inspections (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Making Asia Fit for Survival
abstract: Comment by Teresa Wyszomierski on whether 'economic Darwinism'--strategy that only strong business enterprises should survive and that the weak, requiring subsidies or protection, must be allowed to fail so that rationality can return to global capital markets--can work in Asia; holds while healthy dose of market discipline is needed, Asia's structural and cultural landscape may negate usual effects of the strategy; suggests 'economic Darwinism' should be gradual process in region (L)

headline: U.N. Tells Iraq Of Inspections At Key Sites
abstract: Richard Butler, chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq, tells Saddam Hussein's Government that inspections of eight previously forbidden presidential properties will begin on March 26 under direction of Charles Duelfer, US expert who has been called spy by Iraqis (M)

headline: Airbus Expects Big Latin Orders
abstract: Airbus Industrie expects accord to to sell 100 narrow-body planes worth about $4 billion to Latin American airlines Lan Chile, Transportes Aereos Centro Americanos and TAM Transportes Aereos Regionais SA; deals would be breakthrough for Airbus in region long dominated by Boeing Co (S)a

headline: It Turns Out That James Bond Isn't Working for MI-6 After All
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment, battling suit by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to keep it from making James Bond movies with producer Kevin McClory, holds McClory helped author Ian Fleming develop movie ideas and co-owns Bond character; holds McClory has right to some of billions of dollars in revenues generated by character (S)

headline: Missed the Bus? Personal '800' Numbers to the Rescue
