abstract: Personal use of '800' toll-free numbers, started 30 years ago primarily for business use, has increased in last several years, with hundreds of thousands of families nationwide using them; photo (M)

headline: HUTCHINSON TECHNOLOGY SHARES FALL AFTER LOSS IS CITED
abstract: Hutchinson Technology Inc shares fall after company reports it lost money in first eight weeks of its second quarter ended Mar 29 (S)

headline: German Lawmakers Defeat Bill to Protect Nonsmokers at Work
abstract: German Parliament rejects bill to establish principle protecting nonsmokers at work and in public buildings and require all companies to establish smoke-free areas and set aside rooms where smoking is permitted (M)

headline: Prudential's Leader Knows His Way Around New Jersey
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co chief executive, Arthur F Ryan, must win approval of New Jersey Legislature for company's plan to go public; Prudential is based in Newark and is third-largest employer in state; company also needs approval from state's Department of Banking and Insurance; Ryan encouraged New Jersey officials to lead nationwide probe into company's sales practices four years ago; after inquiry was completed, many critics said that New Jersey regulators had been too soft on the insurer; Ryan will go before many of the same state officials with proposal that some consumer advocates say could hurt company's policyholders, while likely enriching Ryan and other company executives through stock options; photo (L)

headline: Microsoft Offers To Change Deals
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it offered to revise business deals with 40 Internet service providers in United States and Europe; denies move is reaction to continuing United States and European Union investigations into its business practices; company offers to amend business agreement language so service providers in contracts with Microsoft would be allowed to promote Internet browsing software from rival concerns (S)

headline: 2 Big Korea Investors in Debt to Morgan
abstract: Daehan Investment Trust Co and Daehan Life Insurance, two of South Korea's biggest institutional investors, say they owe J P Morgan & Co more than $12 million on Asian currency derivatives, type of contract at core of intensifying dispute between American investment bank and other Korean companies (S)

headline: Lose 1 to and Gain 1 From Thompson
abstract: Chris Hall is named president and chief executive of BBDOSouth (S)

headline: Ready, and at Ease
abstract: American soldiers heading for the Middle East from Fort Stewart, Ga., are expressing little concern about the dangers they may face. Page A8.

headline: DuPont Earnings Rose 10% in 4th Quarter
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 10 percent; profit rose to $946 million from $858 million in year-earlier period; revenue fell slightly to $11.33 billion from $11.41 billion; figures for all of 1997 noted (S)

headline: At W.H.O., 2 Physicians Lead the Race For Top Job
abstract: World Health Organization, in most important election to take place in United Nations system since choice of new Secretary General in 1996, will replace its Director General in late Jan; Gro Harlem Brundtland, former Prime Minister of Norway, and Nafis Sadik of Pakistan, head of United Nations Population Fund, are among seven candidates for post; US has been critical of departing Dir Gen Hiroshi Nakajima for his personnel policies and his setting of priorities in health programs; he has led organization for 10 years (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 2 Top S.&L.'s Will Merge, Creating Formidable Giant  The nation's two largest savings and loan companies, once intense rivals in the takeover game, agreed to merge in a $9.9 billion stock swap that would create a West Coast behemoth capable of competing with the new giants of consumer banking.    The deal, in which Washington Mutual of Seattle agreed to buy H. F. Ahmanson of Los Angeles, would make the new company triple the size of the nearest competitor among savings and loans. [Page A1.]

headline: Samsung Weighing A Foreign Alliance
abstract: Samsung Group of South Korea weighs strategic alliance with foreign partner to bolster competitiveness of its new auto subsidiary; reportedly is under Government pressure to sell unit (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Stephen McDonald was named client service director at Jeff St. Onge & Friends, New York, succeeding Eileen Schneidman, who will serve as a consultant to the agency. Mr. McDonald had been vice president and account service director at YAR Communications, New York, owned by Leap Group.    * Deborah Nichols Cavanagh, marketing director at Men's Health magazine, New York, published by Rodale Press, was promoted to the new position of associate publisher for marketing.

headline: VALUEVISION PLANS TO MERGE WITH DIRECT MARKETER
abstract: Valuevision International Inc, television home-shopping service operator, to merge with the National Media Corporation, direct-marketing company based in Philadelphia; Valuevision will own 55 percent of the new company (S)

headline: BMW Earnings Climb; Stock Payout Is Set
abstract: BMW AG says it will sell new shares to raise 2.1 billion marks ($1.15 billion) and pay share dividend after second-half profit rose 67 percent, to 811 million marks (S)

headline: Goree Island Journal; The Evil That Was Done Senegal: A Guided Tour
abstract: Joseph Ndiaye's slavery tour has made him one of best-known people in Senegal, former French colony that was one of key poles in Europe's trans-Atlantic slave trade; every day Ndiaye leads average of 200 visitors through horrors of past, beginning at former slave-trading house on Goree Island; tour rarely leaves visitors unmoved; photo; map (M)

headline: Comdisco Officers Buy Company's Stock
abstract: Comdisco Inc says 106 executive officers and managers bought more than 4 percent of company's shares outstanding for $109 million; purchases are part of plan to align managers' goals more closely with those of shareholders (S)

headline: From Capstar And a Rival, A New-Breed Hotel REIT
abstract: Capstar Hotel Co and American General Hospitality Corp agree to merge in transaction valued around $530 million, combining fast-growing companies with premium hotels in big cities including Los Angeles and Dallas; Capstar will spin off its business that operates hotels; shares of real estate investment trust that would be created by merger would trade separately from shares in spun-off hotel operating company; REIT would own 110 hotels; merger and spinoff plans are aimed at helping company carry out acquisitions; new company would have tax advantage of REIT, while bigger entity would have more buying and earning power; combined company will be called Meristar Hospitality Corp (M)

headline: Revenue for Euro Disney Up by 17% in Quarter
abstract: Euro Disney SCA says first-quarter revenue rose 17 percent, to 1.3 billion francs ($213 million) (S)

headline: Japan Banks to Increase Loan Write-Offs
abstract: Fuji Bank Ltd and six other Japanese lenders will increase their write-offs for bad loans by more than 950 billion yen, or $7.3 billion, in first wave of banks taking advantage of Government measures to increase capital; Fuji, Sakura Bank Ltd and most of Japan's 17 other biggest banks win final approval to sell Government more than 1.8 trillion yen in preferred shares and subordinated loans (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/  If the managers of the Kaufmann Fund sell out, they'll only be following investors disappointed by lackluster performance. By Edward Wyatt.

headline: Intrigue Swirls Around Korean Debt Talks
abstract: Rancor and backbiting swirl around South Korean debt negotiations involving J P Morgan & Co, Goldman, Sachs & Co and others; it reflects how much investment banks value winning lucrative role of leading multibillion-dollar bond offering by South Korea; major international banks agreed to swap $24 billion in short-term loans owed by South Korea's banks for new debt that does not come due for one to three years; agreement requires signatures from more than 100 banks, and leading industrial countries that have pledged $8 billion in aid will not release funds until all banks have signed on and South Korea has demonstrated it can raise fresh funds; South Korea hopes to raise its foreign currency reserves, probably through one, or series, of bond offerings; getting that business is prize most Wall Street firms have been angling for since December (M)

headline: Chimfunshi Journal; Humans Answer Call to Be Their Cousins' Keepers
abstract: Chimfunshi Ranch, former cattle ranch run by Dave and Sheila Siddle in Congo jungle in Zambia, has become chimpanzee orphanage, where 67 chimpanzees rescued from smugglers are being taught jungle skills; photo; map (M)

headline: Scientists Use Radar to Chart Cambodia's Ancient Ruins
abstract: Archeologists, with highly detailed radar maps as their guide, explore jungle beyond ancient ruins of Angkor in Cambodia and uncover remnants of previously unknown temples and new evidence of an earlier culture that occupied famous site; archeologists say discoveries could profoundly change thinking about history of ancient city, founded in ninth century AD as capital of Khmer empire; in Angkor's heyday, its 1,000 temples spread over 100 square miles, larger than Washington, DC; best-known of temples, Angkor Wat, has been described as largest religious monument ever built; map (M)

headline: Untying Cellular Phones From Those Annual Contracts
abstract: Increased competition in cellular telephone business is forcing companies to move away from requiring subscribers to sign one-year contracts, which helped cover cost of the heavily subsidized telephones they supplied; subscribers are now paying more for the phones, particularly digital ones, and contracting for service on a month-to-month basis; price of air time is also down sharply (M)

headline: German Bank Acts to Shield Itself on Asia
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG, Germany's biggest bank, announces that it has set aside $777 million to cover potentially soured loans in Asian region; announcement marks largest amount yet set aside by Western bank as cushion against possible defaults; cushion is nearly twice the size of bank's loss provisions for all loans in 1996 (L)

headline: IRAQIS COULD FACE HEAVY U.S. ATTACK, CONGRESS IS TOLD
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen tells Congress that US plans 'significant' military campaign against Iraq if diplomacy fails to persuade Iraq to allow international weapons inspections; Cohen, Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman, Gen Henry H Shelton, and Pres Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R Berger, meet with lawmakers and rally support for possible air strikes at suspected arms manufacturing and storage sites; war fever grips Congress, with Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and House majority leader, Repr Dick Armey, backing attack; Cohen warns air strikes alone will not defang Pres Saddam Hussein; does not plan to send ground troops to region; map; table (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: CERIDIAN CORP., Minneapolis, an information-services company, said it would purchase the payroll operations of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Toronto, and Toronto-Dominion Bank. Ceridian will also acquire Toronto-Dominion's human resources services business.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The National Association of Realtors reports on existing home sales for December; analysts expect an annual rate of 4,370,000, down 10,000 from November.

headline: FORT JAMES TO CUT 2,500 JOBS IN STREAMLINING
abstract: Fort James Corp will eliminate 2,500 positions, or 8 percent of its work force, in effort to streamline its operations in North America and Europe (S)

headline: Ultramar in Venture With Petro-Canada
abstract: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corp and Petro-Canada will form refining and marketing joint venture for Canada and Northern US (S)

headline: Chicago Tower Is Sold
abstract: Cambridge Shopping Centres Ltd sells 35-story office tower in Chicago to joint venture of Lincoln Property Co and Goldman Sachs Whitehall Fund; companies paid $93 million (Canadian), or more than $64 million (US) (S)

headline: WARNER BOOKS AND GATES REACH A TENTATIVE BOOK DEAL
abstract: Warner Books, Time Warner Inc unit, reaches tentative deal to publish book by Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates on how company applies its technology to running its business (S)

headline: Zions to Buy Sumitomo California Bank
abstract: Zions Bancorporation will buy Sumitomo Bank Ltd's California bank for about $546 million in cash to expand into state's growing Asian immigrant banking market (S)

headline: Fort George Journal; Wherein Is Revealed the Answer to an Old Inquiry About Kilts
abstract: Black Watch soldiers at Fort George in Scottish Highlands remain fiercely proud of their history and traditions even though Tony Blair's Government in London regards wearing of kilts and playing of bagpipes as inconsistent with the image of Britain as a beacon for the future; Pipes and Drums of the Black Watch and the London-based Regimental Band of Scots Guard are set to tour of 60 cities in US and Canada; photo; map (M)

headline: French Church and Volkswagen Settle Suit
abstract: Volkswagen and Roman Catholic Church of France settle unusual dispute about car advertisements; dispute involves what church considers offensive use of religious images in ads; Volkswagen and its advertising agency, DDB-Needham, agree to pay $50,000 to Catholic charity, and bishops drop their suit (S)

headline: Hong Kong Developer May Sell Some Hotels
abstract: The Lai Sun Development Company, the Hong Kong owner of the Four Seasons Hotel in New York and the Regent Beverly Wilshire in Los Angeles, plans to sell some of its hotels after a surge in its borrowing costs cast doubt over its ability to repay its debt. The property developer plans to sell hotels outside Hong Kong and would not rule out selling trophies like the Four Seasons, it said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Western region dealer association of BMW of North America, Los Angeles, is keeping Mendelsohn/Zien, Los Angeles, as its creative agency after a review. Billings on the account, which the agency has handled for six years, were estimated at $18.5 million.

headline: Kodak Profits Slid 37.7% in 4th Quarter
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says operating profits in fourth quarter plunged 37.7 percent, to $246 million; this is fifth straight quarterly profit decline for company; Kodak announced in late 1997 that it would take $1.5 billion charge in fourth quarter to cut more than 16,000 jobs, or 20 percent of work force, write down assets and restructure its business; revenue in fourth quarter fell 13.3 percent, to $3.83 billion (M)

headline: Not Alpha or Omega: Risk, Small Caps and Beta
abstract: Advice on limiting risk of investing in small cap stocks by choosing stocks that have historically been less volatile than others; measure is called beta, or regression analysis; graph (S)

headline: Vienna Journal; Homeless, but My Dance Card Is Full
abstract: New Homeless Ball is held in Vienna, Austria, as part of city's annual dance season--counterpoint to glittering, century-old Opera Ball staged by social elite; Viennese sympathizers, as well as homeless themselves, showed up in parkas, sneakers and baseball caps; photos (M)

headline: Richard S. West, 72, a Member of Lloyd's
abstract: Richard S West, former Lloyd's of London member, dies at age 72 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.M.F. Acknowledges Misjudgment in Indonesia  A confidential report by the International Monetary Fund concedes that an important element of its rescue strategy for Indonesia backfired and helped cause a bank panic that contributed to other financial market declines in Asia.    Though the report cites failures by the Indonesian Government, it acknowledges a misjudgment over how the Indonesian public would react to bank closings. [Page A1.]

headline: I.R.A. Ally Asks Irish Court to Block Ouster From Peace Talks
abstract: Sinn Fein, Irish Republican Army's political wing, says it will ask Irish Republic court to block any move to expel it from Northern Ireland peace talks; Irish Prime Min Bertie Ahern rejects Sinn Fein appeal to break with British on expulsion issue, holding there is reason to believe IRA was involved in two recent killings (M)

headline: British Bookseller to Buy Operator of Newsstands
abstract: W H Smith Group says it agreed to acquire John Menzies PLC for $68 million pounds ($112 million) (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/  Funds investing in mortgage-backed securities may not suffer their usual rout in the latest round of refinancings. By Sana Siwolop.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.56   5.52   5.21        3-month T-bills   4.94   4.94   5.08        6-month T-bills   4.97   5.01   5.19        10-yr. T-infl.   3.67   3.68   3.43        10-yr. T-note   5.55   5.62   6.69        30-yr. T-bond   5.86   5.94   6.95        Telephone bd.   6.97   7.02   7.98        Municipal bds.   5.27   5.30   5.84          (Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones; Markets; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Key Rates

headline: Rivalry Grows at Low End of Dial
abstract: Rise of Public Radio International as challenger to National Public Radio's programmming dominance has brought fierce competition to nonprofit radio arena; Steve Behrens, editor of Current, magazine about public broadcasting, points out that public broadcasting is ruled by same iron law as commercial broadcasting--be heard or be gone; efforts to have NPR and PRI merge foundered over turf issues that arose from dissimilarities between corporations; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * N2K Inc., New York, to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, as the first integrated communications agency of record for Music Boulevard, the company's on-line retail music service. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. Iballs, New York, will continue handling N2K's Internet ad placement.    * Dial-A-Mattress, Long Island City, Queens, to Dweck & Campbell, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

headline: A Nation's Identity Debated / Monument to the Millennium : What's in a Dome?That Is Britain's Question
abstract: LONDON—  The ring of giant steel masts soars above the banks of the River Thames like the superstructure of a futuristic building, or a massive theme-park attraction. Just which it will turn out to be, or whether the project is merely Britain's biggest white elephant, is a matter of increasingly fevered debate here.

headline: Prudential's Policy Sales Off By 27% in U.S.
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, still feeling effects of several years of criticism from millions of customers who contend they were deceptively sold insurance they did not need, saw sales of new policies in US plunge 27 percent in 1997; Prudential, still largest life insurer in US, sold 296,222 new life insurance policies, down from 405,800 in 1996; life insurance sales outside US increased, with 154,000 policies sold compared with 132,000 in 1996; worldwide sales were down 16 percent in 1997 (L)

headline: Memphis Grocer Purchase
abstract: Albertson's Inc, operator of 865 food and drug stores in West, Midwest and South, acquires Seessel Holdings, second-largest grocer in Memphis, Tenn, from Bruno's Inc; price is $88 million (S)

headline: How Companies Make the Boss Buy Stock, but Soften the Pinch
abstract: More than 200 companies have disclosed stock-ownership requirements for their top executives, but definitions of ownership vary; besides counting direct purchases of shares, most give credit for shares that executives have not purchases; some alternative stock plans include 401(k)'s, indirect ownership, restricted stock, deferred payment, stock options and phantom stock; charts (L)

headline: Stocks Romp Smartly On; Will Nothing Stop the Bull?
abstract: Performance of American stock market in 1990's has been amazing, particularly in last three years, when investors in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index saw their money more than double; much of outstanding performance came from demographics, as baby boom generation began investing for retirement; also important was that corporate earnings rose, with consistency and magnitude not seen in nearly half century; photo; graph (M)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Internet Can Help Sort Out Economic Turmoil in Asia
abstract: World Wide Web contains many sites explaining and discussing economic crisis in Asia; sampling of helpful and informative sites (M)

headline: CAMPBELL DIRECTORS SET SHARE RATIO FOR VLASIC SPINOFF
abstract: Campbell Soup Co says directors set share ratio for spinoff of its Vlasic pickles, Swanson frozen dinners and Swift meat businesses as Vlasic Foods International; Campbell says its shareholders will receive on March 30 one share of Vlasic Foods International for every 10 Campbell shares they own as of March 9 (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.44   5.55   5.52        3-month T-bills   5.05   5.05   5.22        6-month T-bills   4.97   4.97   5.34        10-yr. headline: GOTHIC ENERGY COMPLETES AMOCO PROPERTY PURCHASE
abstract: Gothic Energy Corp completes its acquisition of producing natural gas properties from Amoco Production Co unit of Amoco Corp for $237.5 million; Amoco also receives warrant to buy 1.5 million Gothic shares for $3 a share (S)

headline: Scudder Kemper Narrows Review
abstract: Scudder Kemper Investments Inc says it narrowed review on its account to four agencies from eight; billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Several Big Deals Near for Sun's Java Language
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc's Java programming language is suddenly enjoying new momentum outside personal computer industry, and company is planning to announce several new deals with consumer electronics manufacturers over next few weeks; Sun will announce that Ericsson will license Java for use in cellular telephones; it is also close to licensing agreement with Sony Corp; this is first year that Java language will be widely available for consumer devices other than computers (L)

headline: A Human Face for Swiss Banks; Unlikely Mediator for Dispute Over Jewish Assets
abstract: Profile of Hans J Baer who is representing Swiss banks in their bitter struggle with Jewish organizations over recovery of assets belonging to Holocaust victims; Baer is Jewish Swiss banker and elder statesman of only important Zurich founded by Jewish family, the Julius Baer Group; he also lived in Riverdale, NYC, as teen-ager for several years, and, as a result, speaks fluent English and has understanding of American culture and American character; his background gives in big advantage with American Jews and their sympathizers in Congress and courts, who are among Swiss banking industry's severest critics; photo; chronology of dispute from 1940's to 1997 (M)

headline: Time Warner in South Africa TV Venture
abstract: Consortium backed by Time Warner Inc wins license to build new television network in Johannesburg, South Africa; Midi Television will create first privately owned free channel; it has promised Independent Broadcasting Authority that third of its programming will be of local origin (M)

headline: Soweto Journal; Horseplay It's Not: Blacks Dream of Finishing First
abstract: Enos Mafokate, 52, barred by apartheid from becoming show jumper, runs only riding academy for young blacks in South Africa, Soweto; photos (M)

headline: Investor Optimism Over Earnings Sends Market Higher
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 52.57 points, to 8,160.35; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 4.73 points, closing at record 1,006.00; Nasdaq composite index climbs 13.45 points, to 1,666.34; graph (L)

headline: Paris Turns to the East for Ethnic Mix and Youthful Hip
abstract: PARIS—  The French have a phrase for it: "Ca bouge" — things are on the move. In the urgent, angry new-generation music, in the multiethnic restaurants and bars and in quirky new shops, a fresh energy is bursting out in a city where people had been claiming that the cultural lights were out.

headline: Program Soft-Pedals Hindu Supremacy
abstract: National Agenda for Governance issued by India's new Hindu Government appears to have been designed to draw wide support from groups that have traditionally opposed nationalists; makes commitments on defense, social policy, economic policy, foreign policy and other measures (M)

headline: Aiming for Business Readers This Time, Gates Plans 2d Book
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates intends to write new book in effort to showcase his talents as technologist and burnish image tarnished by Government lawsuit charging his company with monopolistic practices (L)

headline: Thousands Across France Stage Marches For the Jobless
abstract: Thousands of jobless workers demonstrate in Paris and other cities across France, demanding that Government do more for country's three million unemployed people or be thrown out of office (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMTER, FLORENCE (JILL) F.
abstract: SAMTER-Florence (Jill) F. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Thomas, Stephen and Hilary. Adored and cherished grandmother of Todd, Jonathan, Alison and Alexis. Services private.

headline: Thousands Said to Have Been Killed in Afghan Quake
abstract: February 4 earthquake and its aftershocks kill several thousand people in northeatern Afghanistan and leave thousands more injured and homeless; relief teams are hampered by harsh winter snows, isolated topography and effects of protracted civil war; map (M)

headline: Prices End Higher in a Shortened Session
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise in shortened session; 30-year bond rises 1/4, to 103 30/32, to yield 5.84%; table (S)8

headline: UAL's Profit Surged by 57% in 4th Quarter, Topping Expectations
abstract: UAL Corp says net income rose 57 percent in fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations; net income was $222 million, up from $141 million in year-earlier period; operating revenue rose 6.5 percent, to $4.24 billion from $3.97 billion (S)

headline: Layoffs Set at Apple Unit
abstract: Apple Computer Inc will lay off 300 workers from its Claris software subsidiary in latest in series of job cuts by computer maker (S)

headline: Priorities on Health Care
abstract: Letter by Felicia Ackerman on Dec 28, 1997, article on millions of Americans aged 55 to 64 who are finding it hard or impossible to get health insurance (S)

headline: Turkey Sentences 5 Officers in Journalist's Death
abstract: Provincial court in Turkey sentences five police officers to seven-and-half-year jail terms for beating journalist Metin Goktepe to death in January 1996; human rights activists say that sentences are far too light (S)

headline: Sometimes, Safeguards Protect Nobody
abstract: Profile of National Auto Credit Co, whose stock recently traded for $1.94 a share, down from about $10, after auditors warned last year that internal accounting controls were indaequate, although that problem was supposedly rectified; company says it is being investigated for how big reserve it should have maintained for bad loans as well as whether it understated its liabilities left over from former business of renting cars; stock price graph (M)

headline: U.S. Effort Fails To End Impasse In the Mideast
abstract: US envoy Dennis B Ross concludes four-day round of shuttle diplomacy in Middle East after apparently failing to break year-old deadlock in Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu reportedly rejected outright key American proposal for withdrawal from 13 percent of West Bank--part of package said to also include specific actions by Palestinians to fight terrorism as well as timetable for future steps; Ross's failure appears to confront US with options of either exerting greater pressure on Netanyahu by making proposals public, or of abandoning role of mediator (M)

headline: Spare Look, Thoughtful Style
abstract: Karen Wickre assesses on-line magazine Feed; photo (S)

headline: Hong Kong Rulings Stir Fears Over Law System
abstract: Series of rulings by Hong Kong Government in recent weeks have stirred fears that rule of law is being eroded as former British colony is absorbed into China; Government's refusal to prosecute politically well-connected newspaper publisher on fraud accusations, or to prosecute mainland's New China News Agency for violating Hong Kong's privacy statute discussed; legal experts worry rulings may indicate growing unwillingness to prosecute those with strong mainland ties; are worried that Hong Kong may hobble its legal system by exempting Chinese Government organizations from as many as 14 local laws (M)

headline: German Trade Surplus Was Lower in January
abstract: Germany's merchandise trade surplus almost halved in January, to a two-year low, as export growth slowed and booming production increased demand for imports; Germany exported goods worth 6.3 billion marks ($3.4 billion) more than its imports in January (S)

headline: Kidney-Drug Trials Halve Alteon Stock
abstract: Alteon Inc announces it might halt clinical trials of its drug for treating kidney disease in diabetics because of concern about side effects; shares of Alteon lose half their value after announcement (S)

headline: Japan Finance Minister Resigns, Opening Way to a Shift in Policy
abstract: Finance Min Hiroshi Mitsuzuka resigns to take responsibility for bribery scandal, raising possibility of shift in Japanese Government policy to spur economy and help ease rest of Asia out of financial crisis; press speculates Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto forced ouster, making issue out of entrenched business practice of entertaining government officials and expecting favors in return, as part of deal with opposition parties; Hashimoto will hold post until he names successor; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is at 123.19 Japanese yen, down from 124.04 yen on Feb 9 in late trading in New York; graph (S)

headline: Voice Technology Appears Ready to Recognize Bottom Line
abstract: Speech-recognition technology may finally be coming of age, moving beyond directory assistance and primitive dictation software after decades of unfulfilled promises; breakthroughs in programming and faster computers have persuaded some companies to begin using it, while others are investing significant amounts of time and money testing it in most grueling conditions, like on trading floors of brokerage firms and exchanges; analysts cite two catalysts to recent large-scale development of technology: introduction of Intel's Pentium chip in 1994, which gave computers enough processing power to run speech-recognition software quickly, and Dragon Systems' general-purpose dictation program that is better at deciphering conversational speech; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP., Orange, Calif., a drug distributor, received a five-year contract from United Drugs, an independent drug-buying group, that could produce new revenue of more than $600 million annually.    NOBEL EDUCATION DYNAMICS INC., Media, Pa., sold a 21.2 percent stake in the company to an investment group that includes Michael R. Milken and Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of Oracle Corp.

headline: Touchy Issue of Bigger NATO: Spy Agencies
abstract: NATO officials are scrambling to deal with one of most sensitive issues raised by impending membership of Poland, Czech Republic and Hungary: trustworthiness of intelligence agencies in former Soviet-bloc countries; some Western officials say Clinton Administration has bent over backward to treat newcomers as equal partners, planning to share sensitive information with them in same way it is shared with current NATO members (M)

headline: Bill Gates is Tiger Woods? Well, he's doing a commercial.
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates is doing television ad for Big Bertha line of oversized golf clubs sold by Callaway Golf Co; print ad is also scheduled, pending Gates's approval; photo (L)

headline: 3COM TO CUT 380 JOBS AND REPLACE A TOP EXECUTIVE
abstract: The 3Com Corp says it will lay off 380 workers at two Chicago-area plants and that John McCartney, president of 3Com's client access business unit, will leave company next week (S)

headline: Iraq Bars Arms Inspectors Again, Saying American in Charge Is Spy
abstract: Irag carries out its threat to block arms inspection by American-dominated team, provoking calls for action in Washington and foreign capitals, and forcing Security Council to look again for effective way to condemn Baghdad without threatening force; US officials reiterate earlier warnings but do not suggest what Council should do; Defense Sec William Cohen says Pres Saddam Hussein is not in position to dictate who can conduct inspections; photo of William Scott Ritter Jr, leader of barred inspectors (M)

headline: 2 European Publishing Giants Cancel Their Plans for Merger
abstract: Reed Elsevier PLC and Wolters Kluwer NV, European publishing giants, cancel plans to merge after encountering regulatory objections; European Commission and regulators in United States would have required companies to divest themselves of more assets than originally planned in their $9 billion deal, which would have formed world's largest publisher of professional and trade journals (M)

headline: Deep Thoughts: Digital Barbie and Ken
abstract: Intel Corp says it will work with Mattel Inc and other toy makers to develop standards for making personal computers and toys interactive; Intel, which has 85 percent of market for microprocessors, needs to broaden uses of PC's to increase its own profit (M)

headline: A Chance To Leap Into 2002
abstract: Utah Winter Sports Park, near Salt Lake City, houses combined luge and bobsled track and several ski jumps to be used when next Winter Olympic Games come to area, in 2002; park is open for business, available to athletes in training--as well as the general public; photo (L)

headline: Belle of the New-Issue Ball, But Will Its Charm Last?
abstract: Outlook for newly issued stock of Verisign Inc, which provides security for Internet commerce, discussed; company's revenues and losses have grown steadily; graph; photo (M)

headline: Mobil-Hoechst Venture
abstract: Mobil Corp and Hoechst AG agree to merge their polypropylene flexible films businesses; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Weaker demand for beef, bigger herds and slowdown in slaughter of animals causes steep selloff in cattle futures; chart (S)

headline: London Journal; Scare or No, the Britons Are Still Mad About Beef
abstract: Many Britons have flouted law banning sale of beef on the bone because of outbreak of mad cow disease; while many butchers have stopped selling it for fear of arrest and prosecution, others pretend to have stopped, but are willing to slip contraband beef to special customers; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Legoland California, Carlsbad, Calif., to Asher & Partners, Los Angeles, as the first agency to handle advertising for the theme park, scheduled to open in spring 1999. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

headline: Pitfalls Loom in Possible Merger of Two Exchanges
abstract: American Stock Exchange and Nasdaq stock market, which are planning to merge, are so different, and so entrenched in their ways, that many benefits of merger will be very difficult to achieve without substantial risk to both of their existing markets; moving operations of Amex to Nasdaq's computers would involve complex negotiations with New York Stock Exchange, cost lot of money, and force brokerage firms to reprogram computers to change way Amex orders are handled; even more difficult problem is potential that trading approaches of two exchanges would be merged; Amex uses auction system while Nasdaq is collections of dealers; photo (M)

headline: A $12 Billion Carrot for Prudential Policyholders
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, nation's largest life insurer, dangles prospect of windfall to its policyholders under plan announced to set up new corporate structure; company says as much as $12 billion is at stake, or about $1,100 on average per policyholder; pie, which reflects years of accumulated profit, may not be distributed entirely in cash, and critics worry that change company is contemplating may also end up costing policyholders more in premiums; company, which is still suffering after effects of series of scandals, stands to benefit; it proposes to shift from mutual ownership, in which policyholders nominally own company, to regular publicly traded company; policyholders would become shareholders and company would gain access to bounty of stock market, while enabling top managers to eventually collect potentially lucrative stock options in addition to their salaries; charts show Prudential's business; table of biggest life insurers (L)

headline: Times Company Profit Rose For Year and 4th Quarter
abstract: The New York Times Co says operating earnings rose 18 percent in fourth quarter; operating earnings were $82.7 million, up from $70.1 million a year earlier; revenues rose 6.8 percent, to $768.4 million; over all, net income rose to $79.3 million from $52.7 million; earnings for 1997 rose to $262.3 million from $84.5 million in 1996, but that figure is depressed by accounting charge; annual profits were $249 million, up from $185.9 million; revenue rose 9.1 percent, to $2.9 billion; chart (L)

headline: Aetna Returns to Profitability in Quarter and Its Shares Rise
abstract: Aetna Inc says earnings in fourth quarter rose 5 percent; earnings before gains from investment sales rose to $142.6 million from $136.2 million a year ago; revenue climbed almost 7 percent, to $4.8 billion from $4.5 billion; Aetna shares rise $2.75, to $79.1875 (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, GERALD (JERRY)
abstract: FORREST-Gerald (Jerry). Best husband of Loretta. Best father to Salli, Pamela and Mitch. Best friend, best dressed, best dancer, ...the best of everything. For shiva information call Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600.

headline: Volvo in Deal to Buy Korean Equipment Unit
abstract: Volvo AB says its construction division has agreed to buy Samsung Heavy Industries Co's construction equipment business for undisclosed sum; Volvo also reports its fourth-quarter profit fell 39 percent; net income fell to 1.106 billion kronor ($136 million) compared with 1.809 billion kronor a year earlier (S)

headline: A New Era Of Wheeling And Dealing; Rising Competition Squeezes Car Sellers
abstract: Sales of cars and trucks are booming, but car dealerships are closing, squeezed by competition from Internet car buying services; about 20 percent of auto purchases are made by buyers who consult Internet or traditional car buying services that for a fee help buyers locate car and price they want; dealers are also being squeezed by big players, publicly traded companies that buy dozens of dealerships at a time, hoping to operate chains with money-saving efficiencies; likewise, used car lots and service departments face fresh competition from superstore used-car chains and specialized repair stores; strong auto sales for last four years have helped even weakest dealers, but next sales slump could drive far more dealers out of business; 850 dealerships have closed since 1992; photos; graphs (L)

headline: The Issues Are Political More Than Legal at U.N.
abstract: Existing United Nations Security Council resolutions appear to offer ample legal basis for renewed American and British military action against Iraq, but politically the two countries are on shakier ground; there is no agreement with France, Russia, China and other countries over what the Iraqis have to do to comply with Council's inspection requirement and avoid military attack; scale of contemplated bombing is far more ambitious than previous strikes; goal and outcome are uncertain (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POMEROY COMPUTER RESOURCES INC., Erlanger, Ky., a network integration company, agreed to acquire Global Combined Technologies Inc., Oklahoma City, a closely held computer reseller and network integrator. Terms were not disclosed.    FRENCH FRAGRANCES INC., Miami Lakes, Fla., a maker and distributor of fragrances and cosmetics, agreed to acquire the privately held J. P. Fragrances Inc., of Port Chester, N.Y., another fragrances distributor, for an undisclosed amount of cash and a note.

headline: American Bidding War for a British Utility
abstract: Pacificorp raises its offer for Energy Group PLC beyond new bid made by Texas Utilities; Pacificorp's latest bid is $7.2 billion, against Texas Utilities' offer of $7.1 billion; fierce bidding war between American companies underlines how desirable British utilities have become as United States follows Britain's move toward deregulation; analysts say battle could intensify further, with other bidders entering race (M)

headline: Fraying Alliance: Iraq Sees Sanction Backers Divided
abstract: Barbara Crossette analysis contends that Pres Saddam Hussein, in orchestrated series of steps, has sent world unmistakable message: seven years after Persian Gulf war, Iraq is going to extricate itself from economic sanctions, with or without permission from United Nations; maintains that next two or three months will be most critical tests of US, British and United Nations resolve that Iraq has posed since it was put under international supervision in Aug 1990 after it invaded Kuwait (M)

headline: Arafat Departs, Calling Israeli Offer 'Peanuts'
abstract: Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, leaves Washington considering new American compromises but rejecting Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's offer of a limited Israel redeployment from less than 10 percent of the West Bank; officials of all sides say gaps between Israelis and Palestinians are narrowing (M)

headline: Operating Income Rises by 14%, But American Express Net Falls
abstract: American Express Co says its operating income in fourth quarter rose 14 percent from year-earlier quarter, to $493 million before one-time items; including special gains and charges year earlier, net income in latest quarter fell 17 percent; income at company's travel-related services unit, including its credit and charge cards, rose 9.7 percent, to $328 million; over all, revenue was $4.67 billion, up 8.7 percemt from year earlier (M)

headline: Wild Selling Sends Stocks Tumbling on Asia Markets
abstract: Southeast Asian markets tumble further after panicky selloff, frightened by worsening crisis in Indonesia, relentless currency turmoil and Standard & Poor's downgrading of some Thai debt to nearly junk status; in midafternoon trading, Hong Kong stocks fall 3.3 percent; stocks in Singapore fall a further 6.1 percent and Philippine market falls 8.3 percent in early afternoon trading; shares in South Korea are off 2.4 percent in afternoon of Jan 9; Tokyo stocks close tenth of 1 percent lower; Malaysia's main stock index drops 2.5 percent; shares in Thailand are down 1.8 percent (M)

headline: Taking In the Sites; The Easy Way to Discover the Titanic
abstract: World Wide Web offers rich resource of Titanic lore and facts (M)

headline: SAFETY-KLEEN SPURNS LATEST BID FROM LAIDLAW AS RISKY
abstract: Safety-Kleen Corp rejects revised $30-a-share stock-and-cash bid by Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc because an all-cash offer of $27 a share from Philip Services Corp is less risky; Safety-Kleen, which has agreed to $1.9 billion acquisition by Philip Sevices and American partners Apollo Advisors and Blackstone Group, delays Feb 11 shareholder vote on that proposal to Feb 25 (S)

headline: Lerik Journal; Yogurt? Caucasus Centenarians 'Never Eat It'
abstract: Lerik, Azerbaijan, produces astonishing number of centenarians despite poverty, poor medical care and ignorance; residents work very hard and eat little, mostly vegetables, fruit and sour cheeses, not yogurt; most researchers credit clean, stress-free living and genetics; photos; map (m)

headline: WESTMIN RESOURCES FAILS TO GET BIGGER TAKEOVER BIDS
abstract: Westmin Resources Ltd., a Canadian mining company, said yesterday that it had not been able to attract takeover offers topping Boliden Ltd.'s hostile bid of $809 million (Canadian), or $562 million (United States), in stock and debt, and its financial adviser warned that its shares would probably fall if it was not bought. Westmin has searched for a rival bidder since last year when Boliden, based in Toronto, offered to pay $5.40 (Canadian) a share and assume $228 million in debt. Yesterday, Westmin said its board would not make a recommendation on the offer, which expires Wednesday. Its shares closed at $5.30. Westmin, a target because of its low-cost Lomas Bayas copper deposit, said Boliden's bid did not fairly value the company.

headline: YELTSIN DISMISSES HIS ENTIRE CABINET IN SHOW OF POWER
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin dismisses his entire Cabinet, including his loyal and dedicated aide, Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin; says dismissals are effort to make economic reforms more energetic and effective; although much is made of Yeltsin's move, there are only three major victims so far: Chernomyrdin, First Deputy Prime Min Anatoly B Chubais, controversial economic reform leader, and Interior Min Anatoly S Kulikov; most of other Cabinet members will almost certainly keep their jobs; Yeltsin names Energy Min Sergei Kiriyenko as First Deputy Prime Minister until he names permanent Prime Minister (M)

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; 26 Journalists Were Killed Last Year
abstract: Number of journalists killed worldwide in 1997 because of their work was 26, same as previous year despite reduced hostilities in Balkins and in former Soviet republics; but number in prison declined to 129 from 189 in 1996, principally due to sharp decline in imprisonments in Turkey; figures were compiled by Committee to Protect Journalists (M)

headline: French Official Under a Cloud in Sale of Warships to Taiwan
abstract: Constitutional Council Pres Roland Dumas, one of France's highest officials, has come under scrutiny in connection with payments of $10 million made to Christine Deviers-Joncour, friend who was trying to arrange contested sale of six French-built warships to Taiwan in 1991 (M)

headline: Decidedly Un-Communist Goals For the Young of Central Europe
abstract: Young men and women of Central Europe are driven and ambitious, having escaped dictatorship and deprivation that were formative themes for their parents; they consider themselves lucky to have been born as Communism was losing its grip; they are more interested in money than politics; they are socially conservative; they are staunch patriots who want to help mold their nations' futures;it appears that generation that came of age since collapse of Communism is incomparably happier than its predecessors, far more competitive, and more materialistic than idealistic; photos (M)

headline: Treasuries Rise After Greenspan's Testimony Is Shrugged Off
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities gain for first time in six days; price of 30-year bond rises 18/32, to price of 102 29/32; yield drops to 5.92 percent; charts (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENSCO INTERNATIONAL INC., Dallas, a provider of offshore drilling and marine transportation services, ordered a jack-up drilling rig valued at $130 million from Keppel Fels Ltd., a rig builder based in Singapore.    KROLL-O'GARA CO., Fairfield, Ohio, said it was negotiating to buy Lindquist Avey Macdonald Baskerville Inc., Canada's largest independent forensic accounting firm.

headline: Netanyahu Tells Edgy Nation Chance of Iraqi Attack Is 'Very Low'
abstract: Prim Min Benjamin Netanyahu tells Israeli people that possibility of an Iraqi attack on Israel is 'very low,' but insists that Israel has right to self-defense should it be attacked; reports of his recent meeting with Sec of State Madeline K Albright suggest that she did not question Israel's right to defend itself (M)

headline: Huge Drug Merger Proposal Sends Industry Into Shock
abstract: Proposed merger of SmithKline PLC and Glaxo Wellcome PLC is beginning to send a shock through pharmaceutical industry; combined company, which would be formed in largest corporate merger ever, would have stock market capitalization of $166 billion and $19 billion in worldwide pharmaceutical sales, dwarfing its competitors; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: OIL PRICE LOWER AGAIN. Crude oil futures continued to fall, to the lowest price in more than three years, amid an increase in United States inventories and declining consumption in Asia. Oil for March delivery fell 32 cents, or 2 percent, to $16.04 a barrel. Heating oil and gasoline prices also fell.

headline: Nigerian Troops Near Sierra Leone's Capital
abstract: Nigerian troops, in day of heavy shelling, seize control of suburbs of Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital, from troops loyal to military junta that overthrew Pres Ahmed Tejan Kabbah; thousands of people reportedly seek to flee area by small boats, one of last escape routes, while some 10,000 others reportedly are huddled in city center; soldiers loyal to coup leaders reportedly arrest people caught trying to flee city and members of Kabbah's Mende ethnic group; Kabbah, in exile in Guinea, hails Nigeria's role (M)

headline: Roth I.R.A.'s Giving 401(k)'s a Run for the (Retirement) Money
abstract: New Roth IRA is attracting so much interest, with its promise of tax-free retirement distributions, that some company administrators of 401(k) tax-deferred plans are growing worried about maintaining required minimum employee participation; administrators weigh steps to make plans more attractive, including expanding number of offerings and increasing company match; graph; table (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of raw sugar falls; worry about canceled orders from Asia has undermined prices since late December; graph (S)

headline: Samsung Motors Seeks Alliance to Raise Capital
abstract: Samsung Motors Inc is negotiating to raise new capital from foreign auto manufacturers as part of strategic alliance; Samsung will proceed with second phase of automotive investment, which totals 1.6 trillion won ($1 billion), starting in 1999, as scheduled (S)

headline: Korea and I.M.F. Lower Targets for Growth
abstract: South Korean Government and International Monetary Fund agree at fund's board meeting to lower earlier growth targets to reflect more dismal outlook for country's economic performance this year; growth is forecast to rise 1 percent to 2 percent in 1998, down from targets set in early December of 2.5 percent; consumer prices are expected to rise 9 percent in 1998, up from earlier targets of 5 percent (S)

headline: Lawmakers Demand Prompt Test of Hussein's Promise to U.N.
abstract: Republican and Democratic lawmakers make demands for quick test of Pres Saddam Hussein's promise to allow United Nations weapons inspectors unfettered and unconditional access throughout Iraq; some senators remain deeply skeptical of accord reached by United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Hussein; growing number of legislators express guarded optimism as they are briefed by senior officials of Clinton Administration; House Speaker Newt Gingrich says he 'strongly supports' initiative Clinton has taken (M)

headline: COPPER PRICES SLIDE.
abstract: Copper prices fall on concerns about Asian economic crisis; Mar copper falls 0.55 cents, to $75.30 cents a pound; graphs; table (S)9

headline: TV Images Give Exiles In U.S. Some Hope
abstract: While visit of Pope John Paul II to Cuba prompted many Cuban-Americans to return to island for first time since fleeing to US, majority of those in Miami looked on with mixed emotions; some expressed religious solidarity, while others, fearing that visit would be public-relations bonanza for Fidel Castro, issued manifestoes, planned acts of civil disobedience and staged hunger strikes (M)

headline: American Weaver Revives Old Laotian Art
abstract: American entrepreneur Carol Cassidy is trying to revive Laotian art of silk weaving; she started her company, Lao Textiles, in 1990; it was first American company licensed in Vientiane after end of Indochina war in 1975, and is still one of few Western businesses in country; her business is thriving at time when Laotian textile industry has been badly wounded by recently imposed foreign tariffs; Cassidy pays her weavers professional wages, which can reach to nearly three times average national income of $350 a year; map; photo (M)

headline: It May Be Time to Go for Gold
abstract: Improved outlook for investing in gold discussed; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Bankers Trust Profit Up 12.5% in Quarter
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp says its fourth-quarter profit rose 12.5 percent from year-earlier quarter, to $207 million; revenue was $1.52 billion, compared with $1.36 billion; for all of 1997, Bankers Trust earned $866 million on revenue of $6.22 billion, compared with $766 million on revenue of $5.17 billion in all of 1996; Bankers Trust's charge-offs in latest quarter were $41 million, $21 million of which were Asian-related (M)

headline: TEXAS UTILITIES SEEKING ALLGAS ENERGY OF AUSTRALIA
abstract: Texas Utilities Co says its Australian unit will offer $135 million to purchase Allgas Energy Ltd, an Australian natural gas utility (S)

headline: Asia Crisis Hurting A Builder of Factories
abstract: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japanese builder of factories, cuts its full-year profit forecast by 25 percent because of up to 400 billion yen ($3.18 billion) in delayed payments from Southeast Asia; lowers forecast for year ending March 31, to 120 billion yen ($954 million) (S)

headline: Rapid-Fire Inspections Planned for Iraq Sites
abstract: Richard Butler, who heads United Nations commission disarming Iraq, plans rapid-fire inspections of previously off-limits Presidential properties to determine which will get spot inspections later--with much less notice; insists that this is only beginning of this phase of inspection process; there is speculation among diplomats that once the UN team has visited the eight Presidential sites, Iraq will argue that this phase of arms investigation is over and that country can move closer to a lifting of sanctions (M)

headline: Taxing Sales on the Internet: Many Governors vs. Congressional Legislation
abstract: Analysis on bill moving through Congress that would effectively bar sales taxes on Internet transactions until 2004; bill responds to fears that thicket of conflicting taxes will choke off growth of Internet commerce; some analysts worry that Federal moratorium would set precedent that would permanently deprive state and local governments of huge potential revenue source; National Governors' Assn is willing to accept permanent prohibition on taxing access to Internet, but it wants states to create single consolidated tax on out-of-state purchases; governors' approach faces strong opposition, because it would open Internet commerce to taxation (M)

headline: A Father of Low-Tech Invention
abstract: Charles Foley, 67-year-old inventor of un-du, which removes stickers, created game Twister and holds more than 130 patents; photo (S)

headline: WPP Group Acquires Consulting Company
abstract: WPP Group acquires Management Ventures Inc; president Dan O'Connor will continue to head company (S)

headline: Strong Retail Sales Report Pushes Share Prices Higher
abstract: Most major stock indexes reversed early losses yesterday and ended higher, helped by more good news on the economy and further indications that the robust demand for shares is showing few signs of slowing down.

headline: Hollywood Pros Put Music Hits, Movies and More on PC
abstract: Three Hollywood veterans, Jonathan Taplin, Richard Baskin and Jeremiah Chechik, form Intertainer Inc, one of early group of companies aiming to provide entertainment through 'broadband' circuits, so called because of their large carrying capacity; Intertainer plans to provide movies on demand, music, electronic shopping and other services delivered to personal computers over high-speed telephone lines or cable television systems; it is not yet clear that consumers really want such wide range of programming on demand; Time Warner Inc's 500-channel cable service has floundered, as have several other such ventures (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  None reported.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Scope of Columbia Inquiry Disclosed in an Affidavit  Extensive Federal investigations of Columbia/HCA focus on whether the nation's largest health care company cheated Federal programs, lied to hospital accrediting regulators and offered illegal compensation for doctor referrals, newly unsealed information in a Government affidavit shows.    Although most of the allegations had been previously disclosed in news accounts, the information released yesterday showed the full range of the Government's investigation for the first time, including detailed evidence of inflated costs aimed at obtaining bigger Medicare reimbursements. [Page D2.]

headline: Thompson Detroit To Stay Downtown
abstract: J Walter Thompson Co has decided to keep its Detroit-area office in downtown Detroit rather than move to suburban site (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Reports Flat Earnings for Quarter
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports earnings of $929 million for fiscal first quarter, up 1.9 percent from $912 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 14.8 percent, to $11.82 billion, from $10.3 billion in quarter a year earlier; chart (M)`

headline: Korean Air Says Losses Nearly Doubled in 1997
abstract: Korean Airlines says losses almost doubled last year; airline lost 397.4 billion won ($252 million) compared with loss of 210.5 billion won in 1996; revenue rose to 4.29 trillion won, from 3.67 trillion won a year earlier (S)

headline: Economic Scene; It's not easy to know when and how to act to protect the planet.
abstract: Peter Passell (Economic Scene) column recalls 1972 report entitled The Limits to Growth, prepared by mostly European group of business leaders who called themselves Club of Rome; says report warned that world was about to run out of essential commodities; also says report became holy writ of environmental movement; notes that since that time, global economic output has tripled without any indication that end is in sight; also notes world markets are currently glutted with commodities and that prices of most natural resources have fallen in real terms; says 1972 report looks foolish largely because computer experts who simulated resource use failed to incorporate market forces in their model; says technology, guided by market forces, has made it possible for huge population to live better than would ever have been guessed in 1972 (M)

headline: A 'Road Map' for the Future of Ulster Wins Agreement
abstract: Irish and British Governments agree on proposals they hope will result in lasting settlement of sectarian strife for first time since start of formal peace talks 19 months ago; proposals, offered as subject for discussion between Protestant and Roman Catholic negotiators in Belfast, address highly volatile issues, such as relationship between Northern Ireland and Irish Republic and conflicting claims on sovereignty in North by Dublin and London; also include creation of new elected Ulster Legislature; new body, Council of Isles, with members from Wales, Scotland, England and two Irelands, would meet twice each year to consult on Irish questions (M)

headline: Ulster Police Link 2 Deaths to I.R.A., Casting Pall Over Talks
abstract: Police in Northern Ireland say Irish Republican Army was involved in two recent killings of civilians in Belfast; British and Irish Governments say they will now have to decide whether this is grounds for expelling IRA's political wing, Sinn Fein, from peace negotiations (M)

headline: CORPORATE EXPRESS SETS BUYBACK OF ITS STOCK
abstract: Corporate Express Inc will pay up to $150 million to buy back as much as 25 percent of its stock for a premium (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Anand Wins to Tie Match And Force a Blitz Playoff
abstract: Viswanathan Anand defeats Anatoly Karpov and ties their International Chess Federation match at three games apiece; diagram (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wall St. Appeals For Millennium Break  Wall Street has been planning for at least the last two years how to update its vast networks of computers to insure that they are not thrown off kilter by dates in the year 2000 and beyond. Now, with less than two years to go, the securities industry is appealing for extra time.

headline: A Skillful Sprinkling Of Video and Sound
abstract: Brief assessment of Microsoft Encarta 98, encyclopedia on CD-ROM; photo (S)

headline: How Accord Will Work: Special Group Is Set Up
abstract: Text of agreement signed by United Nations and Iraq guaranteeing UN weapons inspectors unfettered access to sites across Iraq (M)

headline: Buoyant Investors Push Dow Above 8,700 for First Time
abstract: Major stock market indexes soar to records as investors rush to buy stocks, encouraged by rosy economic outlook of declining interest rates and strong corporate profits, as well as assuring remarks by Warren Buffett, famed value investor; Dow Jones industrial average surges 116.33 points to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for first time; Standard & Poor's 500 index gains 1 percent, or 10.66 points, to close at 1,079.27, another record; graphs (M)

headline: ASTEC REBUFFS EMERSON'S OFFER FOR REMAINING SHARES
abstract: An attempt by the Emerson Electric Company to acquire the shares of Astec (BSR) P.L.C. that it does not already own for $:170 million ($278 million) was dismissed yesterday by Astec as ''wholly inadequate.'' Emerson said it would continue its bid. The company, the St. Louis-based maker of electronic and electrical products, had offered 111 pence a share for the remaining 48.9 percent of Astec, which makes power supply and power conversion products. Emerson said that it had approached Astec on Friday with its offer and that Astec faced ''a number of significant commercial challenges'' because of changes in its markets and financial chaos in Asia.

headline: Euro Transformation Will Touch Every Ledger and Purse
abstract: Magnitude of transformation to European single currency is only beginning to sink in; once euro becomes fully established, it will wipe out large component of financial activity--the exchange trading between European currencies (M)

headline: Low Ceiling On U.S. Aims
abstract: Pres Clinton seen having outlined modest military goal in dealing with Iraq that can be achieved with few days of intensive air strikes, even if attacks fail to end larger threat posed by Pres Saddam Hussein; some in Congress and Administration critics are demanding harder goal: Hussein's ouster and destruction of chemical and biological arms factories and stockpiles (M)

headline: Manuel Pineiro, Spymaster For Castro, Is Dead at 63
abstract: Manuel Pineiro, ruthless but urbane spymaster who for more than 30 years led Cuba's intelligence apparatus and directed its efforts to export revolution to third world, dies in car crash in Havana; photo (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; A Little Caution in the Wind
abstract: Article on performance of hypothetical retirement savings portfolios created and managed for The New York Times by five investment advisers: Sheldon Jacobs, Eric M Kobren, Susan Dziubinski, Jack A Brill and Harold R Evensky; notes each began with $50,000 on July 7, 1993; charts (L)

headline: $3 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK FOR MORGAN STANLEY
abstract: Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co will buy back up to $3 billion of stock in company's first share repurchase since announcing merger plans a year ago (S)

headline: Now, Liquid Gold Comes in Bottles; Marketers Find a No-Frills Rival to Soda
abstract: A bottle of water instead of a Coke? It sounds downright un-American.    But that's what Bonnie Netjes chooses all the time. ''I am not a pop drinker,'' declared Ms. Netjes, a clothing-store owner from Rock Rapids, Iowa, who has also pretty much given up coffee. ''I just decided to drink more water a few years ago. I go for the cheapest kind because I can't tell there's a difference in taste.''

headline: Southeast Asians Like Idea of Using Local Currencies for Trade
abstract: Southeast Asian leaders are rallying behind proposal to trade goods in local currencies instead of dollars in move to reduce reliance on American dollar and shore up troubled economies; proposal by Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohammad, has been dismissed as quixotic by some currency experts (M)

headline: Fruit to Walls to Floor, Ads Are on the March
abstract: Some consumers say they are annoyed that advertisements are everywhere they look; tiny ads on apples and bananas are part of latest wave in onslaught of ads that accost Americans at every turn; commercials come at them from grocery store floors, airport baggage carousels and even from walls above urinals; Scenic America vice pres Frank Vespe says there are fewer and fewer places where you can look without seeing ad; adults often find it annoying to see ads everywhere, but younger people, nurtured on commercials, often find them entertaining; photos (M)

headline: French Insurer to Sell Its Unit in Britain
abstract: Groupe des Assurances Nationales SA, France's fifth-largest insurer, will sell its British unit, GAN Life Holdings PLC, to Life Assurance Holdings Corp (S)

headline: POPE CHALLENGES CUBA ON ABORTION AND ON EDUCATION
abstract: Pope John Paul II meets with Pres Fidel Castro hours after he opened his evangelical mission to Cuba with Mass attended by 60,000 to 80,000 people, largest crowd of Catholics to gather in Communist country in four decades; Angelo Cardinal Sodano, top Vatican official, submits to Government list of prisoners in Cuban jails for whom Pope is seeking clemency; Pope, in his homily at Mass, attacks acceptance of abortion and sexual promiscuity and stresses importance of parents' reasserting their influence over their children; says state has responsibility to educate its future citizens, but it does not have 'right to take the place of parents'; says parents should be allowed to take part in their children's education, one of demands of newly assertive Cuban Catholic Church; graph compares number of abortions in Cuba and other countries; photo of Pope at Mass in Santa Clara (M)

headline: Foreign Team in Mexico Warns of Growing Danger in Chiapas
abstract: Nearly 200 human rights observers from Europe and Canada leave Mexico after two-week mission in Chiapas state; call Government's campaign against foreigners 'way of distracting from the conflict' and warn that polarization between pro- and anti-Government factions in state is deepening dangerously; observers' findings are expected to have broad impact on how Mexico's human rights record is viewed in European Union, which is involved in major trade negotiations with country (M)

headline: Grumblings Over the Rise of Dividend Fees
abstract: Number of corporations with dividend reinvestment plans are levying charges for various services (S)

headline: 'Iron Ring' Around Russia? Comment Provokes Outburst
abstract: Debate in United States Senate over NATO expansion provokes Sen Joseph Biden to erupt in protest when Sens John Warner and Daniel Patrick Moynihan object to redrawing NATO's boundaries to admit Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic, and others in later rounds, including Baltic states, that would form 'iron ring' around Russia; Biden's protesting remarks about 'iron ring' noted (S)

headline: Gregoris Staktopoulos, 88; Imprisoned in Death of George Polk, a Reporter in Greece
abstract: Gregoris Staktopoulos, Greek journalist who spent decade in prison in connection with murder of George Polk, distinguished CBS news correspondent, in northern Greece in 1948, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: What's in a name? Della Femina, who could write a book on nomenclature, is adding a Jeary.
abstract: Michael J Jeary is joining Jerry & Ketchum, the New York agency that has been joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and Omnicom Group; Jerry & Ketchum is becoming Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, effective with arrival of Jeary as president and chief operating officer (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Procter & Gamble to Raise Its Paper Prices
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co will raise prices of its Charmin, Bounty and Puffs paper products 4 percent to 7 percent, in part to offset increase in manufacturing costs (S)

headline: SAGE GROUP TO BUY STATE OF THE ART
abstract: Sage Group PLC acquires State of the Art Inc for $22 a share, or about $263 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar reaches two-month high against yen, which weakened after senior policy maker in Japan ruled out tax cuts to stimulate economy; graphs (S)

headline: Under Close Scrutiny, Turkey's Pro-Islam Party Has a Makeover
abstract: Leaders of Turkey's banned pro-Islamic party are trying to reorganize themselves in another party, but federal prosecutors and their own former leader, Necmettin Erbakan, are watching them suspiciously (M)

headline: Echlin, the Target of a Takeover, Is Said to Receive Other Offers
abstract: Echlin Inc, target of $3 billion hostile takeover bid by SPX Corp, reportedly has been contacted by others interested in buying company; says company is not for sale (M)

headline: Russia Reported to Agree to Sell Heavy Weapons to Yugoslavia
abstract: US officials say that Russia has agreed to sell Yugoslavia tanks, attack helicopters and other weapons in move that could threaten delicate peace in Balkans; deal, which was arranged in Moscow in Dec, has not been made public, and US officials say they are in dark about details (M)

headline: French Police Evict Jobless Protesters From Government Offices
abstract: French Prime Min Lionel Jospin orders police across country to eject jobless protesters from public offices they have occupied since Dec to press demands for higher benefits (M)

headline: Business Travel: Who Needs Sidewalks?; Many 'Road Warriors' Prefer Airport Hotels to Downtown.
abstract: Growing number of travelers are making airport hotels their first choice; as record nationwide hotel occupancies and record airline traffic have created huge demand for hotel rooms, airport hotel rooms suddenly do not look so bad; to keep guests coming back at steadily rising rates, hotel companies have been pouring millions into renovations and amenities; through first 10 months of 1997, 72.4 percent occupancy rate at airport hotels outperformed every other part of hotel industry; and their $77.89 average room rate, up 8.2 percent over corresponding 10 months in 1996, is higher than industrywide average of $75.22; scene at some major airport hotels across country discussed; map; photos (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: Boeing Posts $498 Million Quarter Loss
abstract: Boeing Co reports fourth-quarter 1997 loss of $498 million, leading to its first annual loss in half a century; much of loss is related to merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp; company says it earned $290 million in quarter, compared with $528 million in 1996; revenues grew to $11.7 bllion, from $10 billion a year earlier; for the year, Boeing lost $178 million on $45.8 billion in revenues; table (L)

headline: Shaken Indian City Votes as Election Ends
abstract: India's general election comes to tense end with third round of voting on Feb 28; election violence killed at least 150 people, 62 in Coimbatore; when results begin flowing in on March 3, India will know whether seven-week election campaign produced return to government by Congress Party, whose frayed banner Sonia Gandhi carried, or historic turn to Hindu nationalists of Bharatiya Janata Party; map; photo (M)

headline: Look Who's Leaping From That Hollow Tree
abstract: Profile of Keebler Foods Co, cookie and cracker manufacturer, which is about to make initial public offering worth up to $275 million; says offering, which consists of about 11.5 million shares at $21 to $24 each, may be smart as well as fortunately timed; graph; chart; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Prudential Conversion Raises Questions
abstract: prudential conversion raises questions**Eleven million policy holders of Prudential Life Insurance Co of America stand to share windfall of as much as $12 billion as the nation's largest insurance company sets up new corporate structure, remaking itself from a mutual company, nominally owned by its policyholders, into a publicly traded company; customers express concern that value of their policies will be diminished and question how the money will be distributed (M)

headline: Oil Price Rises 13% on Pledges Of Supply Cuts
abstract: Price of crude oil rises 13 percent in world petroleum markets, biggest one-day surge since Persian Gulf war more than seven years ago, in reaction to weekend promises by producing nations to reduce their exports; it remains unclear just how much prices will continue to strengthen; crude for May delivery closes at $16.51 a barrel, up $1.90, or 13 percent on New York Mercantile Exchange; graph (L)

headline: U.N. Surveys Paid Leave For Mothers
abstract: United Nations survey of 152 nations finds United States is one of only six that does not have national policy requiring paid maternity leave; says majority of nations surveyed provide benefits through social welfare systems, some require employer to pay and others combine both financing sources; finds women contribute half or more of family income in some 30 percent of households in nations studied, compared with 55 percent in United States and 59 percent in Europe (M)

headline: Top U.N. Arms Monitor Is Said to Call Iraqi Plans to End Crisis Inadequate
abstract: United Nations chief weapons investigator Richard Butler tells Security Council that recent proposals floated by Iraq to defuse crisis over weapons inspections are not good enough (M)

headline: GOODRICH AND FREEDOM CHEMICAL IN $375 MILLION DEAL
abstract: B F Goodrich Co agrees to acquire Freedom Chemical Co for $375 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Silver for March delivery falls 32.8 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $6.007 an ounce; graphs (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: IMAGYN MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIES INC., Newport Beach, Calif., said it would close its plant in Laguna Niguel, Calif., and cut about 120 jobs, as part of a plan to consolidate facilities and save $18 million a year.

headline: Accra Journal; African Hospitality No Match for Clinton's Hordes
abstract: Accra, Ghana, first stop on Pres Clinton's six-nation African tour, is frantically preparing for his March 23 arrival; Clinton will not spend the night because capital does not have the facilities to put up the huge number of visiting officials and media; photo (M)

headline: Cary Reich, 48, Writer, Dies; A Biographer of Rockefeller
abstract: Cary Reich, financial journalist and author of widely praised biography of Nelson A Rockefeller, dies at age 48; photo (M)

headline: In the 90's, Trying to Keep Prudent With the Joneses
abstract: Consumer confidence in December hit its highest point since 1965, and debt levels continue to soar, but people are spending money differently than they did in 1980's; consumers are making 'sensible' purchases--buying homes instead of renting, trading in flashy sports car for more practical but equally expensive sport utility vehicle; consumers are uncertain about future, having lived through stock market crash of 1987, downsizing of companies and dismissal of many executives; nineties are time of careers, 401(k) contributions, promotions and stock options that come with them (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    800 Travel Systems Inc., Tampa, Fla., an initial public offering of 1.4 million shares and 2.7 million warrants. 1st London.    Diversified Senior Services Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C., an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares. Strasbourger Pearson.    Dynamicweb Enterprises Inc., Fairfield, N.J., an initial public offering of 1.2 million shares. H.J. Meyers & Co.    Heftel Broadcasting Corp., Las Vegas, N.V., 4.7 million class A shares. BT Alex. Brown.    Huaneng Power International Inc., Beijing, China, 6.3 million of American depository shares, each representing 40 class H shares, 5.6 million in the United States and Canada. J.P. Morgan.    Tag-It Pacific Inc., Los Angeles, Calif., an initial public offering of 1.6 million shares. Cruttenden Roth Inc.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Top-Level Lazard Executive Will Join Goldman, Sachs
abstract: Kendrick R Wilson, one of Wall Street's best-regarded investment bankers, will leave Lazard Freres & Co on Mar 30 to join financial institutions group at Goldman, Sachs & Co as a managing director (S)

headline: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO GET COMMERCIAL NATIONAL BANK
abstract: Colonial Bancgroup to acquire Commercial National Bank for $28.5 million in stock (S)

headline: The Other Side Of Parsonage Allowances
abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''From Holy Men to Houses, a World of Tax Breaks'' (March 1), which looked at the parsonage allowance in the Federal tax code:

headline: JAN BELL IS IN $92.8 MILLION DEAL FOR MAYOR'S JEWELERS
abstract: Jan Bell Marketing Inc plans to buy Mayor's Jewelers Inc for as much as $92.8 million in cash, stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: Why Not Look in the Gift Horse's Mouth?
abstract: Kurt Eichenwald column suggests that the sharp rise in price of SLH Corp shares in based on hyped-up expectations arising from its 32 percent stake in Syntroleum, which has developed technology to convert natural gas into liquid products like diesel fuel; notes that despite the great potential of this technology, Syntroleum is a private company and does not have to disclose the kinds of information that any smart investor needs to figure out a value of SLH's stake; graph of stock prices (S)

headline: Volkswagen in Spain Names Bates to Account
abstract: SEAT, Spanish operation of Volkswagen AG, names Bates Worldwide to handle European advertising, with billings at $150 million (S)

headline: Building Confidence In On-Line Shopping
abstract: Elliot Schwartz letter reports that American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and Canadian counterpart are developing new program to increase consumer confidence in on-line buying; vendors who meet standards will receive seal to display on Web (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar's volatility against German mark continues; dollar jumps .0212 percent, to finish at 1.8188; graph; chart (S)

headline: Some Lush Vineyards, but No Yield
