abstract: US investors in private winery venture in Tbilisi, Georgia, have learned hard way about difficulties of transforming former Communist hinterland into American-style business opportunity; string of American managers have quit or been dismissed from investment group; group invested about $1.5 million in winery; American investors do not expect to see any return on their money; group of investors included Eric Wente, top executive of Wente Brothers winery in Livermore, Calif, and George P Schultz, former Secretary of State (L)

headline: Words of Kim Dae Jung: Call for Reconciliation
abstract: Excerpts from South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung's inaugural address (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.69   5.49   5.20        3-month T-bills   5.15   5.17   5.03        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.10   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.67   3.68   3.32        10-yr. T-note   5.61   5.66   6.52        30-yr. T-bond   5.92   5.96   6.77        Telephone bd.   7.11   7.17   7.83        Municipal bds.   5.23   5.24   5.76          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Accord on Conversion May Elude Netanyahu
abstract: Israeli committee set up in June 1997 to resolve dispute over conversion to Judaism fails to come up with compromise that Orthodox Chief Rabbinate Council will agree to sign; Reform and Conservative will not sign accord if Orthodox rabbis refuse to sign; issue poses serious threat to Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's Government, which has razor-thin majority in Parliament (M)

headline: In Fighting Land Mines, Friendship Is Casualty
abstract: Jody Williams and Bobby Muller, who were friends and allies in leading campaign to ban deadly land mines, find that their friendship has become a casualty of grueling campaign; Muller, paraplegic and president of Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation, which had been paying Williams' salary, quietly dropped his support for his old friend last Dec 31, seven weeks after Nobel Peace Prize Committee honored Williams and her International Campaign to Ban Landmines with joint shares in $1 million prize; Muller observes 'She had outgrown our organization,' citing what he says were differences of policy, not personality; photos (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall on Concern in Advance of Fed Meeting
abstract: US Treasury securities prices are lower; 30-year bond slips only 14/32, to price of 102 6/32, while yield rises to 5.97 percent from 5.94 percent on March 25; graphs (L)

headline: One Pilot Is Killed as 2 U.S. Marine Jets Collide Over the Gulf
abstract: Two Marine Corps F-18 fighters on training mission collide over Persian Gulf, killing one of pilots; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Bates USA West, Irvine, Calif., part of Cordiant Communications Group, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $9 million to $11 million: Wham-O Inc., Torrance, Calif., to handle advertising for the toy company under its new ownership, and Outback Mountainboards, Seattle, to handle advertising for the maker of skateboards, snowboards and surfboards, which had been handled in-house.

headline: Scudder's European Emissary
abstract: Interview with Carol L Franklin, who manages two highly successful European funds for Scudder; she discusses her reasons for being bullish on European stocks; chart profiles one of funds she manages; her photo (M)

headline: Korea Electric to Offer Corporate Bonds
abstract: State-owned Korea Electric Power Corp to sell 100 billion won ($57 million) of three-year corporate bonds, paying annual interest rate of 19 percent (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WESTERN WATER CO., San Diego, said it had terminated talks to buy Vidler Water Co. from Global Equity Corp.

headline: Brokers Fined $305,000 in Warrant Case
abstract: Securities regulators order A S Goldmen & Co, brokerage firm in Iselin, NJ, and three employees to pay total of $305,000 in fines and to reimburse investors more than $1 million for manipulating price of stock warrants; National Association of Securities Dealers charges A S Goldmen with manipulating price of warrants of Innovative Tech Systems Inc; Goldmen's president Anthony J Marchiano disputes charges; Marchiano and vice president Stuart E Winkler are fined $50,000 each, while trader Stacy Myers is fined $5,000 (S)

headline: Productivity Jumps In 4th Quarter
abstract: Labor Department reports rapid economic growth at end of 1997 was accompanied by sharp gains in worker productivity; index of nonfarm productivity rose at 2 percent annual rate in quarter, faster than analysts had expected; graph (S)

headline: RUTHERFORD-MORAN IS CONSIDERING MERGER OR SALE
abstract: Rutherford-Moran Oil Corp says it might seek merger or sale to help pay for oil exploration in Gulf of Thailand (S)

headline: AT&T Deal Provides Path to Local Service
abstract: AT&T has agreed to acquire Teleport Communications for $11.3 billion in stock.

headline: A Korean Giant Spins Out of Control
abstract: Article on collapse of South Korea's Halla Group in December under $5.3 billion of debt after huge borrowing to fulfill Chung In Yung's dream of building a shipyard--at a time of overcapacity in shipbuilding business; says Chung's empire has been toppled by his overarching ambition and South Korea's changing economics; holds Chung Mong Won, Chung In Yang's son, must pick up the pieces of one of largest family-controlled conglomerates that dominate South Korea's economy; drawing; photos (L)

headline: Deal Expected For Cellular Phone Carrier
abstract: Alltel Corp reportedly is close to accord on acquiring 360 Communications Co for over $4 billion in stock; deal would greatly expand Alltel's presence in cellular phone industry (M)

headline: Chrysler Sales Increased 3.1% in February
abstract: Chrysler Corp reports domestic car and truck sales rose 3.1 percent in February, with surge in truck sales offsetting sharp drop in car sales; over all, sales rose 200,068 from 193,983 a year earlier; car sales fell 9.1 percent, to 64,506, while truck sales increased 10 percent, to 135,563; sales for Honda Motor Co, Toyota Motor Corp, Mitsubishi Motors Corp and Volkswagen of America Inc noted (M)

headline: Updates: Media and Technology; Critiques of Microsoft (With a Wink to Pogo)
abstract: New study of competition and innovation in computer software industry raises questions about truism linking two together; study found that crucial variable in determining software innovation is not competition but health of company: the more sucessful the company, the less incentive it has to innovate; research provides ammunition for both Microsoft Corp's defenders and its detractors (S)

headline: Peugeot to Build Plant in Brazil
abstract: PSA Peugeot Citroen says it will build $600 million car factory in Brazil as linchpin of plan to more than double Latin American sales; Peugeot will invest $300 million in plant, and Brazil's national development bank will finance remaining $300 million of investment; Peugeot hopes to sell 200,000 cars a year in Latin America from its new plant (S)

headline: Holocaust Museum Rejects Visit by Arafat
abstract: Holocaust Memorial Museum bars visit by Yasir Arafat, leader of Palestinian Liberation Organization, during his coming visit to Washington (S)

headline: Behind a Huge S.& L. Empire, a Low-Key Superstar
abstract: Profile of Kerry K Killinger, chief executive of Washington Mutual Inc, whose $9.9 billion acquisition of H F Ahmanson & Co will create second-largest consumer bank on West Coast; Killinger, in his eight years at helm of Washington Mutual, negotiated 22 deals that turned what had been small Seattle-based savings and loan with $7.6 billion in assets in 1990 into nation's largest savings and loan; analysts expect Killinger to continue his acquisitions (M)

headline: LIBRARY; Web Zines: An Immediacy Beyond Paper
abstract: Zines, magazines published on World Wide Web, enable readers to react quickly and publicly by posting comments; publish irregularly, when mood strikes or news unfolds (S)

headline: BAGHDAD ARRESTS A GERM SPECIALIST
abstract: Iraqi and Western officials say Iraq has arrested Nassir al-Hindawi, scientist regarded as father of Baghdad's germ weapons program, as he was preparing to flee country; Western officials have hoped they could freely interview him in absence of Iraqi secret police officers, who sit in on all interviews conducted by United Nations weapons inspectors; Hindawi's arrest deals significant blow to UN inspectors, who have spent much of last seven years trying to determine scale and killing power of Iraq's germ arsenal; former UN inspector Jonathan B Tucker and Iraqi Rep at UN Nizar Hamdoon comment (M)

headline: Aetna's Life Insurance Unit Is Reported to Be Up for Sale
abstract: Aetna Inc begins trying to sell its life insurance business in US to further concentrate on its main line, health care; CNBC reports Aetna might buy Oxford Health Plans Inc (M)

headline: XLCONNECT SOARS ON REPORT OF TAKEOVER BY XEROX
abstract: Stock of Xlconnect Solutions Inc surges 26 percent in wake of report that Xerox Corp may acquire company for as much as $25 a share, or $420 million (S)

headline: Global Surge Helps U.S. Shares Re-Enter High Altitudes
abstract: Resurgent stock markets in Asia and merger news in Europe give American stocks powerful lift; Dow Jones industrial average rises more than 200 points to close above 8,000 for first time since early December, and Standard & Poor's 500 index reaches record 1,000 for first time ever; graph (M)

headline: Net at Astra Rose 13% in 4th Quarter
abstract: Astra AB says fourth-quarter net rose 13 percent; profit rose to 2.740 billion kronor ($338 million) from 2.423 billion; graph (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUHAUS, ELLEN
abstract: NEUHAUS-Ellen. On March 21, 1998, the 71st anniversary of her marriage to her beloved late husband, Dr. Fritz Neuhaus. Born in Berlin, Germany, July 25, 1905, she was a refugee from Nazi Germany and a longtime resident of NYC and Miami Beach, FL. She is survived by her devoted children Dr. Robert P. Newhouse and his wife Mary of NYC, and Block Island, RI, and Marian Nachman of Greenwich, CT. Loving grandmother of Alisa Newhouse Smith of Los Angeles, Sarah Newhouse of Watertown, MA., Andrea Newhouse of NYC, Alex Nachman of Boston, MA, and Juliet Nachman of Oregon, and great-grandmother of Olivia Taylor Smith and Jules Haskell Smith of Los Angeles. Funeral services will be private.

headline: Mexican Officer, Critic of Army, Is Sentenced to 14 Years in Theft
abstract: Military tribunal in Mexico convicts dissident Gen Jose Francisco Gallardo Rodriguez of criminal corruption and sentences him to 14 years and 8 months in jail; verdict draws outrage from human rights groups (M)

headline: New Positions For 2 Executives
abstract: Top media executive at Procter & Gamble Co, Daryl Simm, is leaving to join Omnicom Group Inc as president and chief executive of its worldwide media operation; Bates Worldwide promotes Ian Smith to new position of president for international (S)

headline: How Do You Do When It Comes to Choosing a Course in English?
abstract: MANCHESTER, England—  This summer thousands of language students will travel to Britain and the United States to learn English to prepare for university or to further their careers. But, according to educationalists, a significant proportion will waste their time and money on an unsuitable or second-rate language program.

headline: Johannesburg Journal; For Rising Crime Rate, High-Rise Jail to Match
abstract: 54-story Ponte Building in Johannesburg, once-fashionable address that is now dilapidated, may become world's tallest prison, as South Africa copes with exploding crime rates and inmate population that has reached 140,000; escapes are major problem, dramatized last year when one escapee scaled zoo wall and shot gorilla; tower that dominates skyline would be converted into 11 mini-jails; New York architect Paul Silver says Ponte would be escape-proof and would help revive area; security chief says there are not more than '10 white people left' in giant building, with tales told of refrigerators tossed on police cars and corpses dropped down shafts (Johannesburg Journal) (S)

headline: Rungs Missing In Big Stores' Ladder to Top
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue's naming of Jeanne B Daniel, Tiffany & Co exec with no backgrond in clothing, as exec vice pres of merchandising is seen indicative of current state of executive succession in highest ranks of American retail; consolidation of department store business in 1980's severely limited number of top executives left to run national department stores, and few stores remained strong at training their young for eventual succession; Daniel was recruited by Saks with understanding that she will likely be groomed to one day become president; Philip B Miller, chmn and chief exec of Saks, says his most important criteria was someone with extensive experience in high end and someone who understands brand positioning; Saks appointment also points to undeniable influence that specialty stores have gained in the industry, a segment that department stores would not have stooped to for talent a decade ago; graphs show how Saks Holding performed in 1997 compared with other retailers (News Analysis) (L)

headline: HINDU BLOC GAINS WEAK GRIP ON HELM
abstract: Atal Bihari Vajpayee, parliamentary leader of India's main Hindu nationalist party, is asked to become new Prime Minister and to form new Government; invitation ends party's wait for power, but inconclusive results of national election apparently leaves party little room to carry out Hindu supremacist policies detested by country's 120 million Muslims; Vajpayee, who heads Bharatiya Janata Party in Parliament, hints at moderation that may be forced on nationalists by coalition partners--most longstanding opponents of policies that isolate or punish Muslims, lower-caste Hindus or other groups among country's 980 million people that have traditionally been suspicious of nationalists' brand of Hindu supremacy; photos (M)

headline: A Family's Survival In a Toyland Jungle
abstract: Profile of Colorforms Inc, small business struggling to survive in industry dominated by few large players; company, now owned by University Games, was innovator in marketing and advertising, seeing profit potential in licensing cartoon characters; photo (M)3

headline: Dejected Belgrade Embraces Hedonism, but Still, Life Is No Cabaret
abstract: Mood of hedonism, bred by hopelessness and apathy, sweeps over Serbian capital of Belgrade; social collapse comes as inflation eats away at local currency, as infighting destroys political opposition and as criminal underclass continues its steady growth; effects of social collapse has devastating effect on children, who have been exposed to scenes of graphic sadomasochism on television; domestic violence, often by men who are out of work or have not received small salaries for months, appears widespread, and crime is endemic; photo (M)

headline: Colombian Peasants Seek Way Out of Drug Trade
abstract: Some Colombian peasants, unhappy with social ills brought by drug money, other problems, seek to resume traditional way of life by planting food crops instead of coca and opium poppies; Pres Ernesto Samper's Government seeks to promote crop substitution with aid from European Union and United Nations; dearth of help from United States, which stresses massive aerial eradication in Colombia, stirs bitterness; map; photo (M)

headline: Camry and Accord Race for Sales Title
abstract: Comment on race for best-selling car of 1997; with last sales figures about to trickle in, Toyota Camry and Honda Accord are neck and neck, with Ford Taurus, five-time champion, demoted to third place; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Securities markets reach a preliminary agreement on making circuit breakers less restrictive.
abstract: Market Place column discusses preliminary agreement reached by nation's securities markets on loosening limits that can halt stock trading when prices plunge; under revisions, markets would remain open until Dow Jones industrial average falls 10 percent, or about 800 points at present level; current limits require halt in trading when Dow falls 350 points; under proposed trading halt changes, markets could reopen later in day unless drop in Dow is 20 percent, in which case markets must close for day (M)

headline: Argentines Press Ex-Soldiers on Swiss Cash
abstract: Recent discovery in Switzerland of at least four bank accounts registered to former members of Argentine military provides prosecutors, human rights advocates and politicians with new ammunition in battle to punish those responsible for crimes during country's last dictatorship; human rights groups say accounts contain millions of dollars pillaged from political prisoners during junta's campaign against leftists from 1976 to 1983; although amnesty laws protect military from prosecution, prosecutors are trying to determine whether those who hold Swiss accounts can be charged with tax evasion, illicit enrichment or other financial misconduct (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices drop 5 percent on commodities exchanges; analysts say Latin American growers will meet American demand; graphs (S)

headline: Study Faults U.S. Military Aid Sent to Mexico's Anti-Drug Effort
abstract: General Accounting Office concludes that planes, helicopters and ships sent to Mexico by US have largely been inoperable, inadequate or ineffective in battle against drug trafficking; suggests that poor planning and coordination, particularly by Pentagon, is source of problem (M)

headline: Stock Mutual Funds Attracted Yet More Money in February
abstract: Investment Company Institute says estimated net $19.5 billion was invested in stock funds in February, exceeding net $14.6 billion that went into funds in January; bond funds pulled estimated net $8.5 billion in February, down from $11.3 billion in January (M)

headline: Bellville Journal; University Insists That Tuition Be Paid . . . or Else
abstract: University of the Western Cape in Bellville, South Africa, refuses to allow students behind on tuition payments to register for classes and locks them out of dormitories; breaks with past tradition, in which it caved in to cash-strapped students, who staged demonstrations and resorted to violence; map (M)

headline: Code-Sharing Deal Reached By All Nippon
abstract: All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest carrier, says it reached separate alliances with United Airlines and Lufthansa of Germany that will give All Nippon greater access to North America and Europe by allowing it to sell seats on United and Lufthansa flights as if they were its own, practice known as code sharing; in return, Lufthansa and United will sell seats on All Nippon flights within Japan and to other parts of Asia; airlines will also coordinate schedules and allow passengers to earn credits in each other's frequent-flier programs; move is blow to Delta Air Lines in its effort to expand its presence in Asia (M)

headline: Mexican Indian Women Protest Army's Search for Weapons
abstract: Hundreds of Indian women from Mexico's Chiapas state gather in Altamirano to protest army searches for weapons in their villages; Pres Ernesto Zedillo ordered search for combat rifles after killing of 45 Indians in Chenalho on Dec 22 and said searches would be carried out even-handedly, in pro-Government communities as well as those that support rebels of Zapatista National Liberation Army; in practice, army has concentrated its searches on villages sympathetic to rebels; photo; map (M)

headline: Hospital Giant Expects to Post A Huge Loss
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, citing costs of reorganization and continuing Federal probe, says it expects fourth-quarter loss of up to $1.35 billion; expects losses from continuing operations of $375 million to $425 million and one-time charges totaling $870 million; stock drops 6.5 percent; graph (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL PLANS TO ADD FIRST COLORADO
abstract: Commercial Federal Corp agrees to buy First Colorado Bancorp for $525 million (S)

headline: Seagram's Net Takes a Tumble
abstract: Seagram Co's earnings before $50 million a charge dropped 52 percent in second quarter ended Dec 31; profit before charge fell to $78 million from net income of $161 million a year earlier; charge resulted in net income of $28 milion in latest quarter; revenue fell to $3.54 billion from $3.75 billion (S)

headline: Sears Agrees to Purchase Spray-Tech
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co agrees to buy Spray-Tech Inc (S)

headline: FINE HOST SHARES PLUNGE 64% ON ACCOUNTING PROBLEMS
abstract: *Shares of Fine Host Corp plunge 64 percent in their first day of trading in two and a half months, after company disclosed it would restate results because of accounting problems; shares plunge $6.50, to $3.625 (S)

headline: How to Build a Game's Rooms
abstract: Developers of computer games have had to choose between detail and speed, beauty and fun; new computer game, Journeyman Project 3: Legacy of Time, has found way to make game both beautiful and fast; detailed description; photo; drawings (M)

headline: 'Got Milk?' Gets Hot Wheels Truck
abstract: Hot Wheels line of miniature vehicles, best known for souped-up sports cars, is adding something different to its lineup: dairy delivery truck named for popular 'Got milk?' campaign by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners unit of Omnicom Group (S)

headline: Spanish Publishers Look to Latin America
abstract: Spanish publishers continue to believe that Latin America is Spain's natural growth market for books; export sales for all Spanish publishers rose by 33 percent in 1997, to $480 million, mainly to Latin America, but profits remain small; efforts to sell works in original Spanish in United States have generally not done well; photos (M)

headline: Where to Check That Plato Quotation
abstract: Prof Anthony Beavers has created World Wide Web sites on Plato and three other subjects designed to filter vast amount of information available on Web; search engines peruse sites of prescreened academics, then visit hyperlinks on those scholars' Web pages in effort to achieve de facto peer review (M)0

headline: ADAPTEC SAYS IT WILL BUY A HYUNDAI SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Adaptec Inc agrees to buy Symbios Inc, subsidiary of Hyundai Electronics America, for $775 million in cash (S)

headline: Two Units of Newell Change Agencies
abstract: Two units of Newell Co have changed agencies; Mirro Co names Milwaukee office of Cramer-Krasselt to handle advertising for Mirro and Wearever brands of cookware and bakeware products, which had been handled by Liggett-Stashower; billings estimated at $3 million; Sanford Corp names agencies Unger Group and Louis London to handle advertising of its Sharpie and Uni Ball brands of writing instruments, with combined billings at more than $2 million (S)

headline: Ameritech Sees Big Return in New Products
abstract: Ameritech Corp says it plans to triple revenue growth to about $300 million for new products and services in its phone operations in 1998 (S)

headline: Jakarta's Plan To Peg Rupiah Powers a Rally Across Region
abstract: BANGKOK—  Despite the opposition of the World Bank and the doubts of many economists, Indonesia confirmed Wednesday that it intended to stabilize its battered currency by pegging it at a fixed rate.

headline: India Begins Its Voting; More Political Instability Is Feared
abstract: India begins voting in general election amid widespread doubt that it will end instability that has dogged nation for nearly two years; voting will take place in four stages, and is expected to conclude with result as early as March 3; initial reports suggest low voter turnout, attributed by political commentators to feeling among many Indians that election will produce another shaky coalition that may be forced to struggle to last full five-year term; photo (M)

headline: 30-Year Yield Falls Below 6% as Low Oil Prices Spur Rally
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rise amid lower oil prices and expectations that concerns about Indonesia's economy will drive foreign investors to seek relative safety of American bond market; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 27/32, to 102 9/32, while yield drops to 5.96 percent from 6.02 percent; graph (M)

headline: British Music Company Hurt by Asian Turmoil
abstract: EMI Group PLC, citing Asian turmoil, says annual operating profit will be 25 million pounds ($41 million) lower than expected; plans to consolidate record labels and cut staff in Asia-Pacific region; report spurs sharp drop in stock price (S)

headline: Sticking to a Style That Children Know
abstract: Brief assessment of World Book 1998 Multimedia Encyclopedia, electronic version of 22-volume World Book; photo (S)

headline: Home Resales Soar by 8.7% As Slowdown Proves Elusive
abstract: National Association of Realtors say sales of existing single-family homes rose 8.7 percent in February, to record annual rate of 4.75 million units, up from January's 4.37 million units; Commerce Department says orders for durable goods fell 1.7 percent in February; graph (L)

headline: Jardine Fleming in Talks To Buy Peregrine Funds
abstract: Jardine Fleming Holdings Ltd says it may buy Asian bond fund and nine smaller funds from unit of failed Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd of Hong Kong (S)

headline: Japanese Bank Rally Is Just Beginning
abstract: Article on rally in Japanese bank stocks in wake of scandals and closures in the industry; says rally in stocks can be linked to promise by Japan's banks to come clean on bad loans by adopting international disclosure standards; holds since Jan 12, Topix index of 100 Japanese bank stocks is up 23 percent, much better than overall Japanese market; says if reform is coming, and power of Finance Ministry is really being broken, price of bank shares should continue to rise; graph (L)/

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of March cotton contract drops 1.26 cents, to 64.17 cents a pound on New York Cotton Exchange; cotton is off almost 13 percent in last six months; graph; chart (S)

headline: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL TO SELL INTOOL SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Global Industrial Technologies Inc agrees to sell its Intool subsidiary to Cooper Industries; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Correction: International Funds
abstract: Corrected version of table with Feb 1 article on Fidelity Investments international mutual funds.

headline: Welcome to Your Closet: Employers Cut Costs With Smaller Offices
abstract: Since 1960's, corporate America has cut real estate costs by putting support staff in cubicles, which are also becoming norm for senior managers; problem has progressed to point where requesting spacious private office as perk can be politically incorrect; drawings (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.44   5.44   5.15        3-month T-bills   5.05   5.04   4.93        6-month T-bills   5.08   5.07   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.66   3.27        10-yr. T-note   5.50   5.48   6.38        30-yr. T-bond   5.85   5.83   6.65        Telephone bd.   7.09   7.09   7.71        Municipal bds.   5.17   5.16   5.67          (Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones Markets; The Bond Buyer)

headline: They're Big. They're Expensive. They're the First High-Definition TV Sets.
abstract: Most of world's television makers demonstrate their first digital, high-definition sets at annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas; prices for introductory models range from $5,000 to $10,000 or more; manufacturers say prices will fall rapidly; nearly all prototype sets on display are large projection models, and most of them are size of refrigerator; little-discussed dimension of transition to digital television is that buying television will soon grow far more complicated because digital sets will come in many different styles; Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Assn has issued set of definitions detailing what kinds of televisions can accurately be described as high-definition (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: After Relentless Gains, Stock Market Turns Mixed  The stock market broke its streak of nearly uninterrupted advances since the beginning of last week, with blue-chip issues retreating as investors turned their attention to technology shares and those of companies reporting strong earnings results.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which had gained nearly 500 points over the prior seven trading sessions,fell 30.64 points, to 8,129.71. But broader indexes rose. The Nasdaq composite index increased for the third consecutive day, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eked out a small gain to close at its third straight record. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded 700 million shares for the fifth time in six days. [Page D10.]

headline: Churchs Chicken Names New Agency
abstract: Churchs Chicken, restaurant chain owned by AFC Enterprises, names Austin Kelley Advertising to handle its national advertising account, which has been handled by Levenson & Hill; billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million (S)

headline: Prices Fall, With Yield at 6%, as Economy Looks Strong
abstract: Bond prices plunge, pushing yield on 30-year bond over 6 percent for first time since mid-December; price of 30-year bond drops 1 6/32, to 101 21/32; graphs (M)

headline: Bates to Form Travel And Tourism Unit
abstract: Bates USA Midwest forms unit specializing in travel and tourism accounts after landing account of Resort Condominiums International LLC (S)

headline: Krupp Vote Is 11 to 9 For Thyssen Merger
abstract: Krupp says its supervisory board voted, 11 to 9, to approve proposal to merge with Thyssen AG; Krupp had withdrawn unsolicited takeover bid for Thyssen last March after protests by thousands of steelworkers; Krupp and Thyssen pledge that at least until 2001 they would not lay off any workers without compensation as result of merger (S)

headline: Gerald Pencer, 52, Chairman of Cott
abstract: Gerald Pencer, chairman and chief executive of Cott Corp, dies at age 52 (S)

headline: In New Balkan Tinderbox, Ethnic Albanians Rebel Against Serbs
abstract: Increasingly bold attacks against police stations in southern Serbia by Albanian guerrillas has alarmed Western diplomats, who fear prospect of another ethnic war in Balkans; guerrillas are members of Kosovo Liberation Army, which is fighting to create state for ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of population in southern Serbia; diplomats fear rising violence in Kosovo, until 1989 autonomous province of Yugoslavia, could set off kind of brutality carried out by Serbian military in conflicts in Croatia and Bosnia, and engulf restive ethnic Albanians in neighboring Macedonia; largely Muslim and Albanian-speaking region was absorbed by Serbia in 1989, which with Montenegro is all that remains of Yugoslavia after secessionist wars of 1991-95; photo; map (M)

headline: Talks Seen on Cowen Sale
abstract: Societe Generale, large French bank, is in discussions to acquire Cowen & Co, the New York investment bank (S)

headline: Joint-Venture Mexico Funds Halted by MCI
abstract: MCI Communications says it has halted plans to invest further $900 million in Avantel, its long-distance venture in Mexico, because current regulations make it hard to earn profit; MCI notes regulations require Avantel to pay 70 percent of its revenue to former state monopoly, Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) to use its network; AT&T Corp's Mexican unit, Alestra SA, is also fighting to get fees it pays to Telmex reduced (M)

headline: Nissan Motor Expands Agency Relationship
abstract: Nissan Motor Co expands its ties with TBWA Chiat/Day advertising agency, awarding firm Nissan Diesel America account; Temerlin McClain had handled account (S)

headline: I.M.F. May Be Closer To Lending-Curb Idea
abstract: International Monetary Fund may endorse rules that would prevent type of surge in foreign bank lending that played key role in current Asian crisis; Clinton Administration has distanced itself from such proposals, fearful of drawing criticism in Congess, which is considering Administration request to approve $18 billion in financing for IMF; any appearance of tampering with free markets would be potential obstacle in Congress; hundreds of government leaders, chief executives, financiers, investment bankers, artists, scientists and economists gathered in Davos, Switzerland, to discuss Asia crisis show widespread agreement on need for monitoring system, run by IMF, to track finances of countries more closely; rating system might also be developed, that might prompt foreign lenders to raise interest rates for countries with poor credit ratings (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Museum of Science, Boston, to Gearon Hoffman, Boston, to handle its account, which had been handled by Houston Herstek Favat, Boston, now part of Arnold Communications. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

headline: Netanyahu, in Washington, Courts Conservatives
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrived in Washington for talks about Middle East peace and went directly to a Christian-Jewish rally of conservative supporters, who include some of President Clinton's harshest political opponents.

headline: Coming to Terms With a Possible Surplus
abstract: Eight leading business executives comment on whether they believe Federal budget surplus will materialize, and how it should be used; photos; several of them recommend addressing Social Security financing problems (S)

headline: REGIONS FINANCIAL PLANS TO ACQUIRE VILLAGE BANKSHARES
abstract: Regions Financial Corp signs agreement to acquire Village Bankshares Inc of Tampa, Fla, for $55 million in stock (S)

headline: Backing IMF, Suharto Sends Signal That He'll Stay Put
abstract: SINGAPORE—  By taking charge of the key panel to carry out painful economic reforms and austerity measures in Indonesia, President Suharto has made it clear that he intends to continue his three-decade rule despite increasing calls for his resignation, analysts said Friday.

headline: BRITAIN TO REOPEN ITS INQUIRY OF '72 IN ULSTER KILLINGS
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair announces that he is opening new judicial inquiry into killings of 14 unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on Jan 30, 1972: Blair's action amounts to reopening of widely disparaged investigation in 1972 that exonerated heavily armed paratroopers and faulted civilian protesters; Blair says he is setting up three-judge panel led by Lord Saville; killings, in Londonderry, fueled hatred of British Government and its Protestant supporters and provoked thousands of young men to join Irish Republican Army; all victims were Catholics; photo (M)

headline: In Africa, Reality of Technology Falls Short
abstract: Vaunted new technologies lag far behind their promise for most of Africa, hobbled by fact that have-nots outnumber haves so greatly that many modernizing innovations simply pass millions by; continent's difficult economic straits present cruel barrier to very technologies that many expected would help create economic takeoff; few can afford $3,000 or $4,000 modest computer setup in countries where annual per-capita income is $650; and cellular telephone companies in Ivory Coast have signed up only 30,000 customers out of population of nearly 15 million, despite fierce advertising and promotion; photo (M)

headline: Late-Day Rally Sends Dow to Fifth Consecutive Record
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is up 34.38 points, to 8,584.83, its fifth consecutive reccord; Nasdaq composite index ends with 1.40-point loss, at 1,757.14; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 4.32 points, to record 1,052.02; chart; graph (L)

headline: Taxpayers, Defeated by Schedule D, Surrender to the Experts
abstract: Individual taxpayers who have prepared their own income tax returns in past are turning to tax professionals this year, defeated by complex Schedule D forms for reporting capital gains and losses under new law; photo; graph showing increasing number of hours needed to fill out typical tax returns; public confusion over dubiously named Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 described; political horse-trading in Congress has brought about five different capital gains tax rates (M)

headline: A Big Western Bell Rides East to Buy Connecticut Phone Company
abstract: SBC Communications Inc, parent of Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell, to acquire Southern New England Telecommunications Corp (SNET), local telephone company serving 2.2 million customers in Connecticut, for $4.4 billion in stock; deal would create one of largest local non-Bell phone companies and will relocate headquarters of Connecticut carrier from New Haven to San Antonio; SNET agreement seen recognition by that carrier of breakneck consolidation in industry and realization that it was too small to be financially viable; after the merger, most Connecticut residents will see little change in their day-to-day workings of telephone system; SBC will continue to operate under SNET name in Connecticut and companies say none of SNET's 9,700 employees will lose their jobs (M)

headline: Jailed Doctor's Wife Is Hoping the Pope's Words Sway Cuba
abstract: Caridad Pinon Rodriguez hopes that Cuban Pres Fidel Castro will respond to Pope John Paul II's request to free political prisoners; her husband, Dr Dessi Mendoza, is human rights advocate who is serving eight-year sentence on charges of 'disseminating enemy propaganda' (M)

headline: Markets Rally After Trading Lower for Most of the Day
abstract: Stock market stages comeback, with Dow Jones average closing at 8,413.94, up 33.36 points; graph (S)

headline: Russia's Stake In Iraq Bolsters Anti-War Cry
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin's opposition to American military action against Iraq is shared by Russia's political and business elite and the average Russian and reflects potent combination of foreign policy and commercial interests; economic ties include $3.8 billion agreement signed by Lukoil, Russia's premier oil company, to develop Iraq's Qurna oilfield once economic sanctions are removed; many Russians still find it hard to accept that US has the power, will and resources to launch a military campaign in the face of determined Russian opposition; however, there is no serious talk of providing military assistance to Baghdad or desire for renewing cold war hostilities with US; Russia also has a generally satisfactory record of observing economic sanctions against Iraq; graph of Russian opinion poll on conflict (M)

headline: $175 MILLION DEAL FOR 3D-LARGEST DENTAL CARE COMPANY
abstract: Protective Life Corp acquires United Dental Care Inc for about $175 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: ABC Stations Asked to Help Pay for N.F.L.
abstract: ABC-TV has asked its affiliated stations to contribute cash or return some commercials to the network to help pay $550 million a year to retain Monday Night Football; CBS and Fox Broadcasting have made or are expected top seek similiar arrangements with their affiliates; deal, would represent first time that networks have sought this kind of sizable contribution from their affiliates to help pay for program costs; ABC affiliates are expected to resist the request, while those of CBS and Fox are more likely to agree; ABC is seeking as much as $50 million a year from its affiliates (L)

headline: Investment Banking Visions Are Fading for German Giant
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG's aggressive expansion on Wall Street bogs down as costs rise and bank focuses more of its efforts in Europe; Carter McClelland, who joined Deutsche Bank to help lead its investment banking push, is expected soon to leave; Deutsche Bank's major reorganization is expected to cut 9,000 jobs; its investment banking arm, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, will be absorbed into main bank (M)

headline: Indonesian Currency Declines On Uncertainty Over Future
abstract: Indonesian rupiah declines in value, by as much as 15 percent in early trading on January 26, as no solution emerges to country's deepening debt crisis and as international banks continue to freeze lending (S)

headline: Do Grannies Know Best, Despite a Fiscal Slip-Up?
abstract: Despite acknowledgment by Betty Sinnock, who brought together 16 women and founded Beardstown Business and Professional Women's Investment Club, that accounting error meant club earned only 9.1 percent from its stock investments, not 23.4 percent as originally claimed, Beardstown Ladies are looked on by many investors as having done well for themselves as have those who followed their example on common sense investing; photo of Sinnock and another club member (M)

headline: The new 'I [Love] NY' commercials do without the Governor.
abstract: Gov George E Pataki, whose prominence in last year's 'I Love New York' tourism advertising generated complaints from critics, is notably absent from initial batch of commercials for 1998;, a year in which Pataki is up for re-election; commercials were developed by agency Toolbox; photo (L)

headline: Farewell to Arms, Hello to Doubts
abstract: Profiles of some of thousands of US military personnel who have left service because of downsizing and taken up new civilian lives; strains of adjustment to new jobs and different family circumstances are discussed by Mark Hoye, Navy aviator-turned-loan officer, Sam Martin, 55-year-old civics teacher who left Air Force after many years, and others; photos; graph showing declining number of personnel on active duty (M)

headline: Forget Big Brother
abstract: Peter H Lewis article on loss of privacy in information age; holds key issue is whether monitoring by surveillance cameras and computers that track movements and purchases influences behavior; cites ways in which his trip from Austin to New York was monitored; table of steps to cover ones data tracks; photos (L)

headline: China Keeps Murdoch And His TV On Hiatus
abstract: China continues to keep its media market closed to Rupert Murdoch even though he has curried favor when Chinese leadership for 10 years; Murdoch has invested over $1 billion in Star TV, Asian satellite television network that is intended to be New Corp's route to China, but winning approval to broadcast, collecting subscriptions fees and selling advertising are proving difficult; New Corp points to Star TV's partial ownership of Phoenix Satellite Television Co of Hong Kong as an important is modest sign of progress (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHTER, HELEN C. (NEE CYMROT)
abstract: SCHLACHTER-Helen C. (nee Cymrot). Of Royal Palm Beach, formerly of Bethpage, NY. Passed away on March 19th. Beloved wife of the late Fenimore (Monte), loving mother of David and Barbara Schlachter, of Merrick, NY, and Moshe and Marilyn Berger, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Devoted grandmother of Aliza, Natan, Oren, Yaakov, Jason, and Rebecca. Survived by cherished sisters, Dorothy Cymroth and Sadye Silver and brother Ben Cymroth. The warm and beautiful memories she created will always be with her loving family and very special friends.

headline: Justice Department Names 'Point Man' on Microsoft Case
abstract: Justice Department has hired Jeffrey Blattner, former chief counsel of Senate Judiciary Committee, as special counsel for information technology, a sign that department's confrontation with Microsoft Corp may be escalating; Justice Department official says Blattner will serve as 'point man inside Justice on the Microsoft case' (M)

headline: Investors See Their Own Kodak Moment
abstract: Shares of Eastman Kodak Co rise more than 5 percent in what analysts describe as combination of start-of-year buying and investor reaction to stepped-up cost cutting (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.69   5.41   5.61        3-month T-bills   5.02   5.00   5.18        6-month T-bills   4.95   4.98   5.32        10-yr. T-infl.   3.73   3.71   3.53        10-yr. T-note   5.64   5.56   6.77        30-yr. T-bond   5.94   5.88   6.98        Telephone bd.   7.05   6.99   7.99        Municipal bds.   5.25   5.22   5.89          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Coffee Prices Decline Slightly; Silver Hits a Five-Month Low
abstract: Coffee prices decline on NY Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, with March contract down 2.35 cents, to $1.6245 a pound; decline is result of signs that roasters have ample supplies; silver futures decline 3.2 percent, or 19.7 cents, to $5.998 an ounce, biggest daily drop since July 7 (M)

headline: From Swagger to Statecraft: Hussein's Newfound Elan
abstract: News analysis of outcome of latest gulf crisis finds that Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein appears to have achieved some of his goals; Hussein is seen satisfied that approach taken by UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan showed respect for Iraq's 'dignity'; Hussein has received considerable sympathy from most of Iraq's neighbors (M)

headline: Protestant Threat Imperils Peace Talks in Ulster
abstract: Ulster Democratic Party and Progressive Unionist Party threaten to withdraw from Northern Ireland peace talks that are scheduled to resume in Belfast on Jan 12; two Protestant groups say British Government is favoring Roman Catholic side in series of gestures; groups draw major part of their membership from prisoners and former prisoners, and their support is seen as essential if talks are to make any headway; Protestant leaders hold emergency meetings with inmates inside Maze Prison (M)

headline: The Global Ambitions That Drive A Merger
abstract: Proposed merger of Nasdaq stock market and American Stock Exchange is motivated in large part by quest for listings, especially listings of foreign companies, but these stocks can present some troubling risks for American investors, who may not understanding exactly how exotic such familiar-looking investments can be; graph of non-US listed on New York Stock Exchange (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Scuttling of Drug Merger Contributes to Stock Drop  Stocks fell, dragged lower by the collapse of what was expected to be the largest corporate merger ever, between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, and by rising bond yields.    The Dow industrials fell 40.10 points, to 8,370.10, while the Nasdaq composite index slumped 13.05 points, to 1,738.71, one day after reaching a new high. [Page D8.]

headline: AMERICAN ARCHITECTURAL PLANS TO BUY WEATHER-SEAL
abstract: Louisiana-Pacific Corp agrees to sell its Weather-Seal window and door unit to American Architectural Products Corp (S)

headline: United News Sells Northern England Papers
abstract: United News and Media PLC sells its United Provincial Newspapers, based in northern England, for 360 million pounds ($592.4 million) to group led by venture capital firm Candover Investments; also agrees to sell its Spanish advertising periodicals business, UPN Espana, for 42.75 million pounds ($70.3 million) to Cedant Corp; sales complete United's disposal of regional newspapers (S)

headline: Microsoft Rebuffed in Bid to Exclude Expert in Antitrust Case
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issues strongly worded rebuke, denying Microsoft Corp's request to remove Internet law expert appointed to investigate and recommend resolution in Microsoft's antitrust battle with Justice Department; says Microsoft's accusations that Prof Lawrence Lessig is biased against company are 'trivial' and 'defamatory'; Lessig, in sworn declaration, says he does not recall asking lawyer for Netscape Communications what kind of solution he would like to see embodied in decree against Microsoft, as Microsoft has contended (M)

headline: Threat to Corporate Computers Is Often the Enemy Within
abstract: Computer attacks by insiders are considered greatest threat to corporate data security; computer security official notes that 70 percent to 80 percent of security breaches are internal, although most companies are reluctant to publicize breaches by disgrunted employees; they range from sabotage, fraud and theft of proprietary information to unauthorized snooping in colleague's E-mail or storing of digital pornography on company computers; security officials say risk of insider fraud or sabotage has been increased as companies increasingly rely on outside contractors for technical work; another factor is often underpaid and under appreciated system administrator, who has access to sensitive company files and security systems that guard them; security analysts say worst mistake organization can make is to give one person control over critical 'choke points,' like computer networks (M)

headline: 'Black' Colleges Are Luring Back Their Own From the Ivy Leagues
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Ivy League and other prestigious universities in the United States compete vigorously to recruit the best and the brightest of each year's crop of African-American high school graduates. Last June Malaika Jones was one of them.

headline: The Newest Phone War
abstract: Internet has become latest arena for intense competition in telephone rates; AT&T will offer its Internet customers long-distance calls of must nine cents a minute, matching MCI; Tel-Save Holdings, small long-distance provider serving mostly smaller businesses, has contracted with America Online to offer nine-cent rate; chart (M)

headline: Laid Off? Dismissed? To Sue or Not to Sue
abstract: Dilemma of workers who are laid off and then asked to sign waiver releasing company from legal claims discussed; photo of Paul C Bevan, former Honeywell marketing director who refused to sign and later won age-discrimination lawsuit, and $900,000 (S)

headline: COMFORT SYSTEMS SAYS IT ACQUIRED 16 MORE BUSINESSES
abstract: Comfort Systems USA Inc has acquired 16 businesses for $125 million in cash, stock and debt to expand its heating, ventilation and air-conditioning installation and maintenance business (S)

headline: Ulster Is Downcast as New Violence Clouds Talks
abstract: People of Northern Ireland say they fear that sectarian killing is on verge of erupting again after four months of relative calm; recent surge of violence and Protestant threat to undermine peace talks, which are to resume in Belfast on Jan 12, has put British Army back on street; photo (M)

headline: Africa Enduring Rebirth Awaits Clinton's Arrival
abstract: Pres Clinton's 12-day trip to Africa will emphasize positive changes that have taken place in recent years; military rule is giving way to democracy, South African apartheid is gone and reforms have bolstered a continent-wide economic expansion; Clinton will seek to persuade American audience that Africa not only exists but matters and to impress on Africa that it and US must pursue a relationship marked by mutual respect, shared economic interests and deep veins of common history; map (M)

headline: Saudi Bases Not Essential
abstract: Even without using Saudi territory, the United States has more than enough firepower in the region to attack Iraq, officials say. Page A8.

headline: Holocaust Museum Rebuffs Arafat's Plan for a State Visit
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat cancels his plans to visit US Holocaust Memorial Museum when museum officials refuse to treat it as state visit; experts on Middle East disagree that incident has added awkward element to separate meetings Pres Clinton has scheduled with Arafat and Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu (M)

headline: Leap Day 2000 Might Pose Big Problems for Some Computers' Software
abstract: Computer experts concerned with so-called year 2000 problem say Feb 29, 2000, Leap Day, will offer new opportunites for computers to fail; that is because 2000 is a leap year and 1900 was not; any computer that believes it is 1900 will not allow Feb 29 to exist; this has made experts even more determined to correct all year 2000 bugs; drawing (M)

headline: Many Serbs Would Just Rather Not Fight to Keep Kosovo
abstract: Serbian nationalists and political analysts say Pres Slobodan Milosevic will be unable to rally Serbs to fight against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians; many Serbs, struggling to stay afloat in economy crippled by war, sanctions and government corruption, say they feel betrayed by Milosevic's failed promise of greater Serbia (M)

headline: UNION PLANTERS TO BUY SOME CALIFORNIA FEDERAL ASSETS
abstract: Union Planters Corp agrees to buy California Federal Bank's Florida branches from First Nationwide Holdings Inc for $110 million (S)

headline: Home Theater: Rival Sound Formats Mean Consumer Static
abstract: Advice on choosing home theater in light of failure of consumer electronics industry to agree on digital audio format; competing technologies discussed; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall Again Despite Weak Economic Reports
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities are down for sixth time in seven days; 30-year bond drops 11/32, to price of 102 18/32, pushing yield to 5.94 percent, from 5.92 percent on Feb 25; graph; chart (L)

headline: Algeria Killings: Brutal Ritual Defies Logic
abstract: Roger Cohen analysis contends that well-planned attacks against journalists, diplomats and other representatives of Western culture that marked first five years of Algeria's Islamic insurgency have given way to seemingly arbitrary butchery of ordinary people; notes that as many as 1,000 people have been killed in recent attacks in Relizane region, compared with estimated 400 people who were slain during Ramadan last year; photo (M)

headline: Report Says VW Profit Doubled Last Year
abstract: Der Spiegel, German weekly, reports profit of Volkswagen AG more than doubled in 1997 as new and updated vehicle models resulted in higher sales across company's product line; VW officials decline to comment on report (S)

headline: Chief Executive Named at Chiron
abstract: Chiron Corp names Sean Lance, former top executive of Glaxo Wellcome PLC, to be president and chief executive; Lance will succeed Edward E Penhoet, who cofounded company with William J Rutter and Pablo D T Valenzuela; Rutter will continue as chairman while Penhoet will become vice chairman; Valenzuela directs research (S)

headline: Falwell to Mobilize Support for Israel
abstract: Rev Jerry Falwell says he and Southern Baptist Convention leaders told Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu they would mobilize evangelical churches to oppose ceding of any more territory to Palestinians; Netanyahu's courting of conservative Christians has apparently angered Pres Clinton and dismayed American Jewish leaders; photo (M)

headline: Paribas Posts Gain Despite Asian Losses
abstract: Profit of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas rose almost sevenfold in second half of 1997 even after charges for bad loans and trading losses in Asia wiped out 3 billion francs ($500 million); Paribas earned 2.4 billion francs, up from 350 million francs a year earlier; for the full year, company posted 51 percent rise in earnings to 6.6 billion francs, from 4.35 billion francs (S)

headline: Auto Sales Fell In February, Hurt by G.M.
abstract: Auto sales declined slightly in the United States last month, as very weak car sales at General Motors offset flat or rising sales at other companies, particularly Chrysler Corp and Korean auto makers, which offered big rebates and other deals on small cars; GM reports 7 percent decline in sales in February from year earlier; because GM still holds nearly third of American auto market, more than every foreign auto maker combined, weak sales at GM were enough to drag overall auto sales down by seven-tenths of 1 percent; sales figures for Ford, Chrysler and some foreign auto makers noted; graphs on US vehicle sales in February (M)

headline: Biggest S.& L.'s In Merger Deal Of $9.9 Billion
abstract: Washington Mutual Inc and H F Ahmanson & Co, nation's two largest savings and loan companies, agree to merge in $9.9 billion stock swap that will create West Coast behemoth capable of competing with new giants of consumer banking; Washington Mutual, largest savings and loan association in US, says it will buy H F Ahmanson & Co to create new company with $149.2 billion in assets; that will make it seventh-largest company in entire banking industry; Ahmanson chmn Charles R Rinehart says he will leave company when merger is completed in third quarter; Washington Mutual chmn Kerry Killinger comments (M)

headline: AFTERMARKET TECHNOLOGIES BUYING AUTO PARTS UNIT
abstract: Aftermarket Technology Corp agrees to acquire auto parts manufacturing unit of Fred Jones Industries for $125 million (S)

headline: 2 Yeltsin Advisers Pushed More Deeply Into Shadows
abstract: Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister, Anatoly Chubais, is removed as overseer of Government policy on news media, and its other First Deputy Prime Minister, Boris Nemtsov, loses responsibility for fuel and energy sectors; their free-market policies have made them both unpopular with some business tycoons (M)

headline: How Drug Baron Set Up Shop Under a Mexican Governor's Not-So-Watchful Eye
abstract: Scandal surrounds Jorge Carrillo Olea, Governor of Morelos, state south of Mexico City, as revelations unfold showing that a major narcotics trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, established a major base of operations in Morelos; Carrillo Oleo, a retired general who is prominent member of party headed by Pres Ernesto Zedillo, insists he knew nothing of Carrillo Fuentes's high-profile presence in Morelos, but unfolding revelations about his activities in Morelos prompt increasing questions about his credibility; Carrillo Fuentes died last year; photo of Carrillo Olea (M)

headline: LAFARGE IN $690 MILLION DEAL WITH SHAREHOLDER
abstract: Lafarge Corp agrees to buy three construction-materials businesses in North America from its major shareholder Lafarge SA of France for $690 million; operations being acquired are Western-Mobile Inc, Redland Genstar Inc and Redland Quarries Inc (S)

headline: Britain to Urge U.N. to Find Iraq in Violation of Arms Terms
abstract: British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, meets Sec of State Madeleine K Albright in London and later says that Britain and US are united in commitment to prevent Iraq from acquiring weapons of mass destruction; says Britain will seek Security Council resolution condemning Pres Saddam Hussein for breaching arms agreement; suggests resolution could be coupled with expansion of oil-for-food program, under which Iraqi oil is sold to buy food, medicine and other relief items needed by ordinary Iraqis; he and Albright say they would prefer diplomatic solution that would allow UN arms inspectors to continue their work; photo (M)

headline: George S. Leonard, 86, Lawyer
abstract: George S Leonard, former Washington trial lawyer and Justice Department official during Eisenhower Administration, dies at age 86 (S)

headline: Mexican Governor Resigns in Aftermath of Indians' Massacre
abstract: Julio Cesar Ruiz Ferro resigns as Governor of Chiapas, Mexico, in aftermath of killings of 45 Indian villagers by pro-Government paramilitary gang in Decembery; Pres Ernesto Zedillo names Rosario Green Macias to be Foreign Minister; she is believed to be highest-ranking woman ever in Mexican Cabinet (M)

headline: Donald S. Russell Dies at 92; Politician and Federal Judge
abstract: Donald Stuart Russell, former Governor of South Carolina, former United States Senator and Federal judge for more than 30 years, dies at age 92; photo (M)

headline: Many at the Saturn Auto Factory Are Finding Less to Smile About
abstract: Saturn's 7,200 unionized workers will vote on whether to ask parent General Motors to jettison innovative labor contract forged by Saturn and United Automobile Workers union in favor of traditional contract that governs Big Three's 400,000 other unionized workers; negative vote would be staggering blow to corporate America's most ambitious continuing experiment in labor-management relations; Saturn workers are concerned that their contract does not protect them against layoffs, a growing possibility as market for small cars collapses and Saturn sales plunge; workers are bitter that GM ignored their suggestions to help Saturn grow into company selling cars and trucks of all sizes, including small sport utility vehicle, to accommodate loyal Saturn buyers who needed larger vehicles; photos; chart (L)

headline: No Injuries As Car Bomb Damages Ulster Town
abstract: Car bomb, believed planted by Irish Republican Army splinter group, explodes in Portadown, Northern Ireland; is second explosion in a Protestant stronghold in three days; they follow expulsion of Sinn Fein, political wing of IRA, from peace talks until March 9; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Jewish Group Sets Up Office In Berlin as Sentinel Against Bias
abstract: American Jewish Committee, in move reflecting resurgence of Jewish life in Germany, opens permanent office in Berlin at site once owned by Jewish family that fled Nazis; ceremonies attended by high-level German, US and Israeli officials (M)

headline: New Killing in Belfast Adds to Doubts on Ulster Peace Talks
abstract: Roman Catholic man is shot and killed in Belfast, ninth victim of sectarian attacks by Protestant and Catholic paramilitaries in Northern Ireland in the last four weeks; Ulster Freedom Fighters, a Protestant group, earlier claims responsibility for killing three Catholics since New Year's Day (M)

headline: Insurance Deal in Houston
abstract: HCC Insurance Holdings to buy Kachler Corp, privately-held agency, for $32.5 million in stock (S)

headline: McRooms No More; Holiday Inn Finds Predictability Isn't Enough Today
abstract: Thomas R Oliver, chief executive of Holiday Hospitality Corp, says Holiday Inn is trying to spiff up its image, which has not changed since first one opened in 1952; says new hotels will get lobby fireplaces and convenience stores; other changes noted; charts; photos (L)

headline: Auto-Lease Disclosure: Simplicity, Please
abstract: Letter by S Abraham Ravid on Jan 25 article on new financial disclosure form mandated by Federal Government that is benefiting consumers who lease cars and trucks (S)

headline: CFM TECHNOLOGIES DISCLOSES MERGER TALKS WITH RIVALS
abstract: CFM Technologies Inc holds informal talks with Applied Materials and Lam research Corp about possiblesale (S)

headline: Treasury's Schedule of Auctions Offers Only Bills for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.17 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent.     The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: RALLY'S AND CHECKERS DRIVE-IN COMPLETE STOCK SWAP
abstract: Rally's Hamburgers Inc completes stock swap with largest investors of Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc, giving company a 27 percent stake in Checkers and investors about 44 percent of Rally's stock (S)

headline: Colombia's Chief Sees Victory in U.S. Backing for Anti-Drug Effort
abstract: Colombian officials greet Washington's conditional certification of their efforts to combat flow of drugs into United States as victory for beleaguered Pres Ernesto Samper; Samper, blamed by many Colombians who saw decertification over last two years as personal rebuke to their Pres, uses waiver of drug sanctions on national security grounds to vindicate his long-standing criticism of United States ratings, which are highly unpopular throughout Latin America (S)

headline: Once Widowed in India, Twice Scorned
abstract: Years of social activism and legislation have only partly eased plight of 33 million Hindu widows in India; problem arises because brides traditionally largely sever ties with own families; custom leaves woman dependent on in-laws, whose main interest after husband's death is to rid family of burden of supporting her; many widows flock to Vrindavan, devoting lives to prayer, to escape lives as outcasts in native villages; others are abandoned there by families; map; photo (L)

headline: Samsung Will Sell Property And End a Skyscraper Plan
abstract: Samsung Group will sell $300 million portfolio of global properties, get $80 million cash infusion from its chairman and scrap plans for Seoul skyscraper under restructuring that Samsung says is aimed at improving competitiveness; Samsung is third big South Korean corporation to announce overhaul in response to Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung's plea for meaningful changes in business practices that are widely blamed for country's economic crisis (M)

headline: ENRON GETS $130 MILLION FOR RETAIL ENERGY STAKES
abstract: Enron Corp sells 7 percent of its retail energy business to Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board and California Public Employees' Retirement System for $130 million to offset cost of expanding retail energy sales (S)

headline: Craze for Beanie Babies Helped Surge in '97 Toy Sales
abstract: Craze for Beanie Babies helped push toy sales up nearly 8 percent, double what industry an analysts were expecting; retail sales increased 7.8 percent, to $22.5 billion, while manufacturers' unit sales rose 5.6 percent; Gary Baughman, chairman of Toy Manufacturers of America, gives address to open 95th annual American International Toy Fair in New York; graph (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Job Creation Surges, Confounding Expectations  Employers added more than 300,000 jobs to the economy in February for the fourth consecutive month and the unemployment rate edged down to 4.6 percent, matching the 24-year low reached last November, the Labor Department reported.

headline: OCCIDENTAL TO SELL VENEZUELA UNIT TO UNION TEXAS
abstract: Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc agrees to purchase Occidental de Hidrocarburos Inc for $204.5 million (S)

headline: New South Korea Leader Grants Sweeping Amnesty to 5.5 Million
abstract: South Korea Pres Kim Dae Jung approves most sweeping amnesty in history of his country, clearing the police and personnel records of 5.5 million people and freeing scores of political prisoners; announcement is unexpected and daring move by Kim, himself a former political prisoner; his Govt says it will help foster new period of unity in South Korea as country braces for severe financial downturn (M)

headline: The Awkward Growth Stage At J. P. Morgan
abstract: Market Place column on future direction of J P Morgan; says although Morgan has made strides, shifting from stodgy commercial bank to investment bank competing with Wall Street's titans, that transformation has yet to pay off; Morgan's stock price has sorely underperformed those of its peers in commercial and investment banking; Morgan's chief executive Douglas A Warner is unavailable for comment; photo (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Asking F.C.C. To Allow Big Data Network
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp asks Federal Communications Commission to allow company to build wide-ranging high-speed data network; petition is latest sortie by Bell company against regulations that prohibit the Bells from selling communications over long distances (M)

headline: Newsweek Getting A New Publisher
abstract: Carolyn Wall, longtime media executive, is joining Newsweek magazine in New York as publisher as part of top management restructuring; other changes include Richard Smith, who is named chairman, vacant post, and chief executive, new position, and Harold Shain, who relinquishes his title as publisher to Wall and succeeds Smith in post of president; Shain is also named to new post of chief operating officer (Advertising columnn) (S)

headline: Schweppes Is Said to Agree to a Bottling Deal
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes PLC reportedly plans to acquire and merge two Midwestern bottling companies, Beverage America and Select Beverages, in $730 million deal that would be first step in creating its own national distribution system; has long relied on bottlers controlled by its chief rivals, Coca-Cola Co and Pepsi-Cola, to distribute more than half of its products; Carlyle Group would be joint-venture partner in deal, with 60 percent equity stake in merged bottler (M)

headline: Suharto Faults I.M.F. on Family Principles
abstract: Pres Suharto of Indonesia says open economic system being promoted by International Monetary Fund may not be right for country, where economy is based on family principles; remarks come two days after IMF threatened to delay release of $3 billion, partly because Indonesia has not met basic requirements, including removal of price supports from basic commodities, reorganizing banking system and ending monopolies and cartels in economy dominated by private deals involving Suharto's family and friends (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Suharto Defies I.M.F., Removing Central Banker  President Suharto of Indonesia dismissed the head of his central bank, an act of defiance toward President Clinton and the I.M.F. that moved the country closer to possibly losing its economic rescue package.    The central bank chief had opposed a risky plan by Mr. Suharto to strengthen the Indonesian currency, saying it would subvert the I.M.F.-backed recovery plan. [Page A1.]

headline: EUROPEANS CLEAR REMAINING HURDLE TO CURRENCY UNITY
abstract: Countries across Europe clear crucial hurdle for introducing single currency, bringing their inflation rates and deficits down low enough to all but assure that 11 nations will meet strict economic requirements for adopting single currency known as euro; group includes three countries long viewed as reckless and profligate: Italy, Spain and Portugal; new reports testify to broad shift in European economic priorities, in which fighting inflation now takes clear priority over job creation and more expansive social programs; economists say both pain and gain are real; several European countries would qualify, but have chosen to stick with their own currencies: Britain, Sweden and Denmark; Greece is only member of European Union that wants to join but cannot meet qualifications; chart; graph (L)

headline: Merged Indonesian Banks To Be Opened to Investors
abstract: Government press agency reports six Indonesian banks will be combined into two in 1998; says Bank Bumi Daya, Bank Exim, Bank Dagang Negara, Bank Pembangunan Indonesia will merge into one; also says Bank Tabungan Negara will become subsidiary of Bank Negara Indonesia without merging their operations; says status of Bank Rakyat Indonesia will not be changed; press agency also says banking will be opened to foreign investors (S)

headline: Diageo May Sell Dewar's To Bacardi for $1.9 Billion
abstract: Bacardi Corp is expected to announce acquisition of Dewar's Scotch from Diageo PLC; Bacardi will also acquire Bombay gin in deal worth $1.94 billion; Federal Trade Commission had ordered sale of Dewar's as condition of approving merger of Guinness PLC and Grand Metropolitan PLC to form Diageo; as expected, that merger prompted consolidation efforts by other liquor companies who now find themselves dwarfed by Diageo in industry where demand has declined (M)

headline: BELL SPORTS AGREES TO BE BOUGHT BY HB ACQUISITION
abstract: Bell Sports Corp agrees to be acquired for $10.50 a share, or about $171.12 million in cash, by HB Acquisition Corp, company formed by investment funds Harvard Private Capital Holdings Inc and Brentwood Associates Buyout Fund II LP (S)

headline: 10,000 Jobs Must Be Cut, Seagate Says
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc, world's largest maker of disk drives for personal computers, says it will dismiss 10 percent of its employees, or about 10,000 workers, as it struggles to cope with pressure from its competitors and cooling market for its products; says 1,350 of layoffs will occur in United States, 1,120 in Europe and 7,530 in Asia; disk drive industry in general has been battered since middle of 1997 because of severe overcapacity; analysts cite aggressive expansion earlier this decade, when it appeared that market for personal computers, and hence for disk drives, would continue to blossom (M)

headline: Rallying the Troops
abstract: Comment on corporate presentations, which represent showtime for some people and is bane of many others; drawing (S)

headline: Another Jolt For Investors In Technology
abstract: Motorola Inc warns that earnings during current quarter will fall well below Wall Street's expectations, another jolt for investors in technology stocks who are already alarmed by Intel's similar announcement; Motorola attributes expected shortfall to weak semiconductor sales in Asia, while analysts say Intel's expected weakness hints at more fundamental shifts in market for chips that drive personal computers, of which Intel is biggest supplier; graph (L)

headline: 'Flawed' Armenian Election Forces Runoff
abstract: Sam Brown, senior foreign monitor of presidential elections in Armenia, says that vote has been 'deeply flawed'; Acting Pres Robert Kocharian faces runoff on March 30 with former Communist Party boss, Karen Demirchian (S)

headline: New N.A.S.D. President to Lead Expansion
abstract: Richard G Ketchum, chief operating officer of National Association of Securities Dealers, is promoted to president and will assume more responsibility for overseas expansion of Nasdaq stock market; Ketchum will replace Frank G Zarb, who will continue as chairman and chief executive; Ketchum will remain as chief operating officer, but will cede some of these duties to Salvatore F Sodano, chief financial officer (S)

headline: HOMEUSA SHARES SOAR ON $162 MILLION FLEETWOOD DEAL
abstract: Stock of HomeUSA Inc jumps 18 percent after agrees to be purchased by Fleetwood Enterprises Inc for $162 million (S)

headline: MONTGOMERY WARD HIRES HELP TO EXPLORE UNIT'S OPTIONS
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp says it hired investment bankers Lazard, Freres & Co and Furman Selz Inc to explore options in connection with its Signature Group direct-marketing unit, which was not part of Montgomery Ward's bankruptcy filing (S)

headline: THOMSON TO SPIN OFF ITS BRITISH TRAVEL BUSINESS
abstract: Thomson Corp will sell its British travel business in initial public offering to focus on providing business and legal information; analysts say transaction could raise as much as $1.5 billion pounds ($2.5 billion) for company (S)

headline: Git Along, Li'l Fashion Plates; A Rocky Mountain Upstart Wages Jeans Shootout in Wrangler Corral
abstract: Rocky Mountain Clothing Co hopes to win over cowboy market from Wrangler; Rocky Mountain is urging rodeo performers to take on trappings of urban styles and attitudes pioneered by designers like Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger; its jeans, under brand name Cinch, and bright-colored Hilfiger-inspired shirts, are marketed in ads that seem more like those in Vogue than in rodeo trade magazines; reason for raised fashion consciousness of cowboys include greater national exposure of rodeo through television, interloping of West Coast and East Coast fashion iconoclasts such as Ralph Lauren, as well as increasingly small cultural world that has evolved through music, marketing, movies and Internet; Wrangler has responded to challenge by introducing its own new fashions, adding looser fits, different colors of denim and softer fabrics; photos (M)

headline: The G.O.P. Is Urging Hussein's Ouster
abstract: Republican-dominated chorus in Congress and in foreign-policy circles is demanding long-term strategy to oust Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein; options include enlarging existing no-fly and no-drive zones, in Iraq, tightening economic embargo, disbursing billions in frozen Iraqi assets to provisional Government and setting up 'Radio Free Iraq' to stir public opposition and arming; photo (M)

headline: Powerful New Encryption Standard Delayed by a Weakness
abstract: Government standards group delays adoption of new data scrambling standard for protecting world's most sensitive financial transactions, including most banks' electronic funds transfers, after discovery by two computer scientists of weakness that could allow code to be cracked; computer security experts are eager to replace current code because it has become vulnerable to new code-cracking techniques; designers of code had predicted that it would take hundreds of years, if ever, to break it (M)

headline: Thyssen Krupp Talks Of Selling Some Units
abstract: Thyssen Krupp AG, which is being formed from merger of Thyssen AG and Fried Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp, expects to sell units or seek partners for units with sales of up to five billion marks ($2.8 billion) (S)

headline: Retail Sales Increased 0.7% in December
abstract: Commerce Department reports that retailers rang up biggest sales gain in half a year during December, total of seven-tenths of 1 percent, helped by last-minute holiday shoppers and strong demand for cars; analysts and retailers say consumers are likely to continue fueling economic growth early this year; retail sales in all of 1997 rose 4.2 percent, worst showing since 1991; analysts note Government report measures amount spent, not volume; say slowdown reflected fact that inflation was at its lowest rate in decade, which kept cost of goods low as volume of sales rose; graph (M)

headline: CIENA IN $52.4 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR ATI TELECOM
abstract: Ciena Corp says it will acquire ATI Telecom International Ltd for $52.4 million in stock (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  AAR

headline: Shandwick Chief Resigns Amid Takeover Talks
abstract: Shandwick International PLC says chief executive Dermot McNulty will resign as company continues talks with number of companies that might result in it being taken over; chairman Lord Chadlington will become full-time executive and assume day-to-day management responsibilities until third-party talks are resolved (S)

headline: Extortion and Protection Rackets Grow Into a Threat to Business : Organized Crime Strangles Slovakia
abstract: BANSKA BYSTRICA, Slovakia—  When the mob came calling in August at his office in this provincial capital, Frantisek Mojzis had a good idea what it was after: his business.

headline: Correction
abstract: Largest Stock Funds table that has appeared monthly in Money & Business section since 1995 has consistently misstated percentage returns of the average stock mutual fund because of a computer programming error; Vanguard has brought error to attention of Morningstar Inc, table's compiler (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 'A big event' for the Big Board, posing legal and competitive risks and even harm to its reputation.
abstract: Market Place column on Federal charges against eight members of New York Stock Exchange, including one of exchange's floor officials whose duties include making sure that rules are followed (L)

headline: Koong-Kai Tse, 91, Insurance Executive
abstract: Koong-Kai Tse, former senior executive of American International Group, one of nation's largest insurers, died March 9 at age 91 (S)

headline: Who Cares What Owners Think?
