abstract: Market Watch column on tight control of management at most American corporations; economic historian Peter L Bernstein notes that American corporate managers, who 'today stride the earth as global folk heroes,' are reinvesting most of company earnings, leaving only about one-third for investors; policy raises stock prices, which helps executives with their stock options (S)

headline: ASEAN Seeks Funds to Avert Another Costly Season of Haze
abstract: SINGAPORE—  With forest fires in Indonesia threatening to cast another pall of smoke-borne pollution over Southeast Asia, officials in the region appealed Wednesday for international aid to help prevent a recurrence of the 1997 crisis that is estimated to have cost more than $1.3 billion in damage to health, disrupted industry and transport and lost tourism.

headline: Sybase Loss to Grow as Sales Are Disputed
abstract: Sybase Inc says it discovered inappropriate accounting for sales by its Japanese subsidiary, forcing company to postpone release of its fourth-quarter financial results for one week and to revise results for quarter and year; says people responsible have either resigned or been dismissed; company estimates that amount of disputed sales was $60 million to $65 million; company had earlier said it expected fourth-quarter revenues of $245 million to $250 million (M)

headline: An Empire With Modest Beginnings
abstract: Article on modest beginnings of Random House, which is being acquired by Bertelsmann AG; book publisher was founded in 1923 by Bennett Cerf and Donald Klopfer; photos (L)

headline: ANNUAL U.N. RITUAL CONDEMNING CHINA LOSES U.S. SUPPORT
abstract: Clinton Administration drops American sponsorship of annual United Nations Human Rights Commission resolution condemning China's human rights record, effectively killing measure; cites China's recent efforts to improve record, including its decision to sign international human rights treaty; plans continued pressure on China; Administration aide hints China agreed to release prominent political prisoners if United States dropped sponsorship; human rights groups score decision (M)

headline: Asia's Interest In U.S. Market Suddenly Cools
abstract: Asian financial crisis has dealt serious blow to operations by American multinational companies in South Korea and other countries in region; subsidiaries and real estate are being sold, branch offices closed, people laid off or brought home, or once-ambitious investment plans scaled back or put on hold; impact has been felt most in New York and Los Angeles, where Asian investments and businesses are concentrated; photo (M)

headline: Cendant to Start Tender Offer For American Bankers Group
abstract: Cendant Corp will begin $2.7 billion tender offer for American Bankers Insurance Group Inc, topping $2.2 billion that American International Group Inc had agreed to pay for the company (S)

headline: Dollar's Gains Expected to Continue
abstract: Collapse of Asian currencies against dollar grabbed headlines in 1997, but dollar made remarkably powerful gains against other currencies, too; many analysts think rise will continue (M)

headline: The Man Likely to Be Mexico's No. 1 Trafficker (the Job's Open)
abstract: United States and Mexican authorities monitor drug trafficking scene in Mexico for signs of successor to Amado Carrillo Fuentes, who was Mexico's most influential drug trafficker, and who died during surgery last year; US official says that Rafael Munoz Talavera, long-time smuggler with links to same cartel, had emerged as likely heir (M)

headline: Who Said London Is Backward? The French. Now They Flock There.
abstract: French, who have long felt superior to British, are suddenly feeling inferior as economic opportunities in London lure tens of thousands of young French people; some French entrepreneurs and pro-business political leaders are concerned that Socialist-ruled nation is missing boom; photos (M)

headline: Catholic-Jewish Panel Meets on Holocaust Document and Agrees to Dig Deeper
abstract: Jewish and Catholic leaders meet in Rome in wake of Vatican's much-criticized statement on Holocaust; sessions are described as intense, frank and at times profoundly religious; participants agree to dig deeper into historical record of period; this is seen as very significant since debate had been fueled by Vatican's refusal to open its wartime archives to independent scholars (M)

headline: Monsanto Says Herbicide Sales Lifted Fourth-Quarter Earnings
abstract: Monsanto Co says fourth-quarter profit before charges rose to $55 million from $25 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 26 percent, to $1.82 billion from $1.45 billion (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Strong Performers Look at '98
abstract: Stock fund managers Bill Nygren, Samuel Harvey, Irving Levine and Christine Felipe, whose fund's had stellar performances for most of 1997, look at the past year and try to predict what might happen in 1998; photos (L)

headline: United Asset Hopes Its First-Aid Plan Will Stop the Bleeding
abstract: Norton H Reamer, chief executive of United Asset Managment Corp, is confident the plan he has devised will stanch the loss of assets under management; company recorded negative net cash flow from clients of $16 billion in 1997, almost all of it from institutional side of the business; root of UAM's problems is its failure to insure that managers of the asset management companies it has acquired maintain strong commitment to long-term asset growth; graph; photo (M)

headline: How Cartel Tried to Buy Bank Group In Mexico
abstract: Scandal surrounding efforts of late drug baron Amado Carrillo Fuentes to take over Grupo Financiero Anahuac reveals how far drug money-laundering has reached into upper echelons of Mexico's financial system; Carrillo, beginning in Mar 1995, sunk about $12.6 million into ownership position in bank, which he was already using to launder money; his drive to control bank was thwarted when regulators seized bank in Nov 1996 because big shareholder was implicated in fraud unrelated to drugs; money-laundering probe began in Apr 1997, when police found Anahuac company car at safe house used by drug cartel (M)

headline: The CD format is losing its cachet as everyone with a computer starts recording.
abstract: Proliferation of compact disk home-recording technology, and of cheap software packages that enable users to make CD recordings from cassette decks, turntables and Internet, has given rise to growing custom-CD market on World Wide Web; three rival Internet retailers are offering custom CD compilations; they are latest wave of entrepreneurs trying to cash in on Internet music retail business (M)

headline: Insurer Takeover Approved in France
abstract: French Government approves $10.3 billion takeover of French insurer Assurances Generales de France by Allianz AG of Germany, union that will make Allianz Europe's largest insurance company (S)

headline: TRACE INTERNATIONAL OFFERS TO BUY ALL FOAMEX SHARES
abstract: Trace International Holdings Inc, which owns 46 percent of Foamex International Inc's common shares outstanding, offers to buy all outstanding Foamex shares it does not already own, for $17 a share; Foamex board names special committee to study proposal (S)

headline: Pioneer to Sell 400 Oil and Gas Fields
abstract: Pioneer Natural Resources Co is planning to sell most of its US oil and natural gas fields, valued at $350 million to $550 million, as part of plan to cut costs and focus on more profitable acreage (S)

headline: Lott Abruptly Postpones Senate Action on NATO Expansion
abstract: Hour after Pres Clinton urges Senate to agree to expansion of NATO, majority leader, Trent Lott, abruptly postpones action on measure, partly in frustration over Democratic filibuster on other legislation: Republican-backed bill to establish education savings accounts; photo of Clinton with some Senators (M)

headline: Washington Listened, But Moscow Didn't Call
abstract: US officials express some surprise but not shock at Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin's sudden dismissal of his Cabinet; say that relations with Moscow remain unchanged by upheaval (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FIRST DYNASTY MINES LTD., Calgary, Alberta, agreed to sell its Energy Process Services unit to Equatorial Energy Inc. for about $40 million.    MAAX INC., Sainte-Marie-de-Beauce, Quebec, a maker of bathroom fixtures, agreed to acquire the closely held KSD Industries, Southampton, Pa., a maker of shower and medicine cabinets, for undisclosed terms.

headline: INTERNATIONAL GAME BUYS SLOT UNIT FOR $70 MILLION
abstract: International Game Technology buys slot machine business of Bass PLC for about $70 million (S)

headline: GROUP 1 AUTOMOTIVE SAYS IT WILL BUY FIVE DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Group 1 Automotive Inc agrees to buy five automobile dealerships in four states for about $37 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: What Now? Piercing The Credit Union Haze
abstract: Questions answered about effect on credit union members and other consumers of US Supreme Court ruling invalidating regulation that allowed credit unions to absorb unrelated employee groups; credit unions and bankers hotly debate implications, and Congress is expected to revisit 1934 Federal Credit Union Act (S)

headline: Times Appoints Head of Circulation Dept.
abstract: Richard H Gilman, senior vice pres for operations of New York Times, is appointed head of paper's circulation dept; he succeeds William L Pollak, exec vice pres who left Times last month to become chief exec of American Lawyer Media Inc; John R O'Reilly, pres of City and Suburban Delivery Systems Inc, a Times subsidiary, is promoted to vice pres for circulation; pors (S)

headline: AT&T Maps Its Battle Plan For Escalating Phone Wars
abstract: AT&T's new chairman, C Michael Armstrong, publicly explains his strategy for revitalizing company; says he will reduce work force by up to 14 percent and offer panoply of new services, including cheap phone calls over Internet and wireless phones that will receive calls free; says company will spend billions to upgrade its national communications network and to introduce new wireless phone made by Nokia with battery that lasts for eight days; says AT&T thrived in regulatory environment and must now prove itself in competitive environment; company says it will focus cuts in ranks of management rather than among union employees; says it expects 10,000 to 11,000 of its 55,000 management employees to accept new buyout offer, with additional 5,000 to 7,000 jobs cut through layoffs and attrition; Armstrong says company will take charge against earnings for second quarter of $800 million to $1.2 billion to help cover cost of cuts; company reports net income of $1.3 billion in last quarter, down from profit of $1.6 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenues dipped slightly to $12.83 billion from $12.87 billion; photo (M)

headline: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE PAID CHAIRMAN $3.85 MILLION IN 1997
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive Co paid its chairman and chief executive, Reuben Mark, $3.85 million in 1997, up 44 percent from 1996, and awarded him 2.6 million stock options after directors' compensation committee study found his pay ranked below that of comparable executives (S)

headline: Chief Chosen for French Military Supplier
abstract: Denis Ranque is named chief executive of Thomson-CSF, Europe's largest military electronics company; Ranque succeeds Marcel Roulet, who retires at end of January (S)

headline: Russia Announces a Deal; Iraq Says 'No Such Thing'
abstract: Russia announces with great fanfare that is reached agreement with Iraq that would stave off US military attack, only for Baghdad to deny that any such agreement had been reached (M)

headline: Computing; Eye to Eye With a Wily Virus
abstract: Article on advantages and disadvantages of antivirus software programs (M)

headline: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES IN TALKS TO SELL A UNIT
abstract: Eastern Utilities Associates says it is in talks to sell its EUA Cogenex Corp contracting unit to undisclosed buyer by middle of year (S)

headline: Karen Avenoso, 31, Boston Globe Reporter
abstract: Karen Avenoso, education reporter for The Boston Globe who also wrote about her yearlong battle with Ewing's sarcoma, a rare form of cancer, dies at age 31 (S)

headline: Pope's Call for Clemency Lifts Dissidents' Hopes
abstract: Dissident movement in Cuba is cheered by Pope John Paul II's appeal for clemency for imprisoned members of human rights and political groups; case that has drawn most attention in recent months is that of Internal Dissidence Working Group, whose four principal leaders--Vladimiro Roca, Marta Beatriz Roque, Felix Bonne and Rene Gomez Manzano--were arrested in July; another important case is that of Hector Palacios Ruiz, leader of Democatic Solidarity; many of those arrested in last two years belong to Concilio Cubano, umbrella organization seeking to bring greater unity and coherence to dissident movement (M)

headline: Marketers view the Winter Olympics as a commercial bonanza.
abstract: Advertising column on marketers' view of Winter Olympics as commercial bonanza; they are encouraged by latest survey, in which 83 percent of respondents with household income of $50,000 or more say they intend to watch Olympics; photo (M)

headline: U.N. REBUFFS U.S. ON THREAT TO IRAQ IF IT BREAKS PACT
abstract: UN Security Council unanimously endorses Sec Gen Kofi Annan's agreement with Iraq on weapons inspections, but without authorizing automatic military response of Baghdad fails to comply; majority of members--led by China, France and Russia--rebuff US and Britain by holding out against any explicit threat, particularly wording that would appear to give green light to American attack in event Iraq violates agreement; Pres Clinton reiterates threat of American military action, warning Iraq against blocking inspectors from carrying out their work; says unanimous vote sends clearest possible signal that Iraq must make good on commitment to give unfettered access to weapons inspectors; US Amb Bill Richardson says resolution reinforces US policy, and does not bar military strikes, which US believes it already has power to carry out (M)

headline: As Thousands Protest, Pinochet Assumes Chilean Senate Seat
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet, Chile's former dictator, assumes much-disputed Senate seat that protects him from prosecution for crimes committed during his 17 years in power; thousands of people demonstrate against him (M)

headline: C.I.A.'s Self-Critique In Bay of Pigs Fiasco
abstract: One of the most secret documents of the cold war is out, 36 years after it was written. It is the Central Intelligence Agency's own inquiry into the Bay of Pigs fiasco, the invasion to overthrow Fidel Castro that caused the deaths of nearly 1,500 raiders. With brutal honesty, the report put the blame squarely on what it described as arrogance, ignorance and incompetence within the C.I.A. itself.    The report painted a picture of an agency shot through with deadly self-deception, and concluded that its secret operations were ''ludicrous or tragic, or both.'' The document also warned those who would use the C.I.A. to overthrow enemies that such efforts belong to the Pentagon.

headline: GREAT UNIVERSAL WINS BID TO ACQUIRE METROMAIL
abstract: Great Universal Stores PLC wins battle to acquire Metromail Corp, for $905 million, after rival bidder, American Business Information Inc, fails to provide proof that it has necessary financing; American Business had bid $980 million (S)

headline: NU SKIN ASIA TO ACQUIRE ALL OF AFFILIATE
abstract: Nu Skin Asia Pacific will acquire core assets of its privately held affiliate, Nu Skin International Inc, for $70 million in preferred stock and assume debt of $180 million; combined company will be renamed Nu Skin Enterprises Inc (S)

headline: FSI WORKERS ASKED TO TAKE OFF 10 DAYS TO CUT COSTS
abstract: FSI International Inc asks all employees to take 10 furlough days sometime during fiscal year ending in August to cut costs; FSI also says it has cut its capital spending plans for 1998 to less than $10 million from as much as $15 million (S)

headline: With Malaysia Bleeding, Bill Collector Finds Work
abstract: Debt collection business is thriving in Malaysia, with economy in slump and bad debts piling up (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Sees First Loss Since 1974-75
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp says it expects sharply lower sales and projects its first annual loss in 24 years; Mitsubishi also announces that it will close plant in Thailand and plant in New Zealand, reduce work force by 12 percent, cut executive pay, halve capital investment and suspend shareholder dividend payable at end of fiscal year March 31 (M)

headline: Ex-MTV Executive Loses Contract Case
abstract: MTV Networks, unit of Viacom Inc, wins its court bid to keep Richard Cronin, former MTV executive, from joining rival Fox Kids network until July; MTV sued Fox Kids, its parent, the News Corp, and Cronin last year; Cronin, who developed TV Land classics network for MTV's Nickelodeon, broke his contract to stay at MTV until June 30 when he agreed to become chief executive of Fox Kids and Family Channel in October; Justice Herman Cahn sides with MTV and orders Cronin to stay away from Fox until June 30 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's Stumbling Bull Is Relying Heavily on 2 Legs
abstract: Market Place: American stock market has come under severe pressure early in 1998 and has slumped, but things could be much worse were it not for two groups of buyers: foreigners and individual Americans; foreign buying may have been more important factor in recent months, helping to explain why big stocks have been the strongest; it appears that domestic orders, many from individual investors but some from institutions, turned around latest world flight from equities (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Peter McHugh was named to the new position of managing director and executive creative director at Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland, Chicago. He had been group creative director at Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.

headline: Defiant on Apartheid, Botha Gets His Day in Court
abstract: P W Botha, South Africa's president from 1978 to 1989, appears in court but enters no plea to charges of contempt of court for refusing to testify before country's Truth Commission about atrocities committed under his rule; his lawyers are granted a postponement until Feb 23; South Africans have been debating for weeks about whether Botha, 82, is being prosecuted out of revenge or whether he must be held to account, like anyone else; Botha's appearance in court before before a black magistrate attests to how far South Africa has come since first all-race elections in 1994; photo (M)

headline: Since 70's, the World Has Become Safer for Consumerism
abstract: Consumer product safety has increased greatly since 1970's; consumer advocates and Government demanded better standards, and American industries were forced to comply to compete with products made abroad (M)

headline: Where's the Joy of Life? The Dirt Poor in Cuba Wonder
abstract: Article on Rancho Veloz focuses on plight of town's peasants in view of Pope John Paul II's visit to Cuba; map; photo (M)

headline: Speculation About Pol Pot Stirs Cambodia's Uncertainty
abstract: Unconfirmed reports are circulating in Thailand and Cambodia that Khmer Rouge founder, Pol Pot, may have fled his jungle stronghold in that country and taken refuge in China (M)

headline: China 'Somewhat More Tolerant' of Dissent, U.S. Says
abstract: US State Department's annual report on human rights worldwide says China was somewhat more tolerant toward disssidents in 1997 than before and that authorities took other positive steps on human rights even though serious problems remain; draws expressions of concern from human rights activists, who question whether Clinton Administration is overreacting to minor improvements in rights situation in hope of removing issue as obstacle to improved diplomatic and trade relations (M)

headline: Eastern Europeans Keep Ex-U.S. Spies in the Cold
abstract: Hungarians and Poles who spied for United States and NATO when nations were under Communist rule remain under cloud, even as nations seek to join NATO; anti-Communist governments that came to powerin 1990 saw selves as patriots first, and refused to pardon spies; photo (M)

headline: Good News for Columbia/HCA Investors
abstract: Shares of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp climb almost 9 percent in value after company announces that it expects its first-quarter earnings to exceed Wall Street expectations (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; U.S. v. Microsoft: The Bigger Question
abstract: Comment by James F Moore, chairman and chief excutive of Geopartners Research, says resolution of immediate crisis between Microsoft Corp and Justice Department opens way for considering potential damage that Government action can have on growth and vitality of information industry (M)

headline: Hunger Strikers Back an Albanian Who Defrauded Thousands
abstract: Twenty people are holding hunger strike at Vehbi Alimucaj's request in support of his claim that he will pay back creditors if Albania lets him continue bankrupt business; his investment scheme allegedly defrauded at least 92,000 Albanians, leading to nationwide violence that brought down Government; Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe aide Daan Everts seeks to negotiate end to 3-week old strike (M)

headline: PATTERSON ENERGY TO BUY ROBERTSON ONSHORE DRILLING
abstract: Patterson Energy will buy Robertson Onshore Drilling Co for $40 million (S)

headline: Credit Unions Lose to Banks In High Court
abstract: US Supreme Court gives banking industry important if perhaps temporary victory in intensifying battle to stop expansion of credit unions; it invalidates Federal regulation that had allowed millions of people to join the alternatives to banks; Court's ruling throws into question status of as many as 20 million customers of credit unions; Credit Union National Association president Dan A Mica scores decision; credit union leaders, expecting the ruling, have been gathering support in Congress for bill that would permit them to expand their membership, effectively overturning Court's decision; banks have vowed to fight the bill; chart (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Mariano Favetto, creative director at Lautrec Nazca Saatchi & Saatchi, Buenos Aires, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., was named chief creative officer of a sibling agency, Conill Advertising, New York, succeeding Luz de Armas, who left.

headline: Last week's deals proved that the networks can't live without high-rated programs.
abstract: Each of four broadcast networks spent more money last week on programming than they had ever spent before; commitments added up to more than $8 billion for ABC, more than $4 billion for Fox, $4 billion for CBS and just under $900 million for NBC; such binge spending proves that networks can not live without high-rated programming; Don Ohlmeyer, NBC official, says companies will have to reinvent themselves to make money in future; drawing (M)

headline: Palestinians Protest to CBS News Over a Report on the West Bank
abstract: Palestinian Authority bars CBS News from access to officials or territories under its control to protest report on 60 Minutes news program on December 7 which allegedly failed to follow up on information provided by Authority about supposed complicity of Israeli officials in monopolies controlling sale of certain goods in parts of West Bank under Palestinian control (S)

headline: When Life After Death Is the Company's Lot
abstract: THERE'S no good time to get bad news, but some times are worse than others. Nicole Maxwell was the humand resources director for Barrington International Hospitality Inc., an upstart hotel-management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight months pregnant - and had moved the previous day to a new house in a new neighborhood - when the word came: The plane carrying her boss and father, Barry L. Conrad, on a United States trade mission to the former Yugoslavia was missing.

headline: Trust to Buy Hotel Chain For $2 Billion
abstract: Meditrust Companies, real estate investment trust, will buy La Quinta Inns Inc for $2.1 billion in cash and stock in move to expand its real-estate holdings with its first hotel purchase (M)

headline: Labor Group's Talk of Strike Threatens Korean Layoff Deal
abstract: Agreement to legalize layoffs--negotiated last week by business, Government and labor leaders in South Korea, and regarded as big victory for Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung--is in danger of foundering over threat by Korean Confederation of Trade Unions to strike unless accord is renegotiated; widespread layoffs, previously unheard-of in South Korea, are viewed as necessary to help restore efficiency to its debt-laden economy and satisfy International Monetary Fund's requirements for $57 billion loan package signed in December (M)

headline: F.T.C. Votes to Halt Two Big Drug Mergers
abstract: Federal Trade Commission votes, 3-1, to block proposed mergers among nation's four largest drug wholesalers that would have created two of most dominant players in any industry; commission accepts recommendations of its lawyers to oppose McKesson Corp's $1.72 billion acquisition of Amerisource Health Corp and Cardinal Health Inc's $2.41 billion takeover of Bergen Brunswig Corp on ground that deals violate antitrust laws; graph (L)

headline: Morrison Knudsen Ends Mine Stake Talks
abstract: Morrison Knudsen Corp ends talks with its chmn, Dennis Washington, about acquiring his majority stake in copper mine after decline in copper prices; company also says its board approved repurchase of as many as two million common shares on open market or through block trades (S)

headline: Capel Name Dropped From HSBC Unit
abstract: HSBC Holdings PLC says it will change name of its institutional equity broking and research unit from HSBC James Capel to HSBC Securities (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NIKE INC., Beaverton, Ore., the athletic shoes and sports apparel company, will cut 300 temporary workers this week in the first step in a larger round of layoffs.    METALS USA INC., Houston, a metals processor, agreed to acquire the closely held building-products maker Levinson Steel Co. and completed the purchase of four other metals companies.

headline: People
abstract: * Bob Sarlin was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at Charron, Schwartz & Partners, New York. He had been president at Sarlin & Sarlin Ink, New York.    * Nina Lawrence was named publisher of Mademoiselle magazine, New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications, succeeding Victoria Lasdon Rose, who left. Ms. Lawrence had been publisher of Modern Bride magazine, New York, which is owned by Primedia Inc.

headline: Prices Decline as Auction of 30-Year Treasuries Disappoints
abstract: Early rally in Treasury securities fade and prices end lower for first time in three days, hurt by disappointing auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds; benchmark 30-year issue falls 8/32, to price of 103 23/32; yield rises to 5.86 percent from 5.84 percent on Feb 11; graphs (L)

headline: Earnings Up at Philip Morris Before Extraordinary Items
abstract: Philip Morris Companies reports earnings before extraordinary items rose more than 10 percent in fourth quarter; net income fell 12 percent, hurt by big charges to settle tobacco litigation in Texas and to cover cost of revamping company's international food operations; net income fell to $1.3 billion from $1.47 billion a year earlier; revenue increased 3.2 percent, to $17.3 billion from $16.8 billion; net income for 1997 was $6.3 billion, virtually unchanged from $6.303 billion in 1996; for the year, revenue rose by more than 4 percent, to $72 billion; chart (L)

headline: A Nearby Nation Glad To Be Above the Fray
abstract: Iran is watching confrontation between its two worst enemies, United States and Iraq, from sidelines; officially opposes any US military action; Pres Mohammad Khatami tries to use crisis to bolster standing with Arab neighbors and portray self as regional statesman calling for peace; photo (M)

headline: Two 'Bloody Sundays': Catalysts for Change
abstract: Jan 30, 1972 is not first day in 20th-century history of Irish conflict to have gained name Bloody Sunday and become rallying cry for political change; first occurred on Nov 21, 1920 at height of Ireland's struggle for independence from Britain, and led to over two dozen casualties, half of them British intelligence officers killed by Irish Republican Army gunmen; Prime Min Tony Blair's decision to reopen investigation of events of 26 years ago in Londonderry reflects importance that Catholics in Northern Ireland have attached to second Bloody Sunday (M)

headline: GULF CANADA RESOURCES PLANS ASSET SALES TO CUT DEBT
abstract: Gulf Canada Resources will sell oilfields in North Sea and other assets and spin off part of natural-gas pipelines in western Canada to raise money to lower debt (S)

headline: Earnings at Big Banks Meet Expectations
abstract: First Chicago NBD Corp says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent, to $382 million, from year-earlier period; Fleet Financial Group Inc says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, BankBoston Corp says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, Norwest Corp says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, PNC Bank Corp says its fourth-quarter earnings fell 2 percent, and Keycorp says its fourth-quarter earnings rose 14 percent (M)

headline: Greenspan Injects a Note of Caution on the Good Times
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, in an otherwise upbeat assessment of economy before House panel, warns that stock investors and lenders may be underestimating threats to continued economic growth; says economy remains balanced between potential inflationary pressures and forces that could lead to recession; remarks dampen financial markets, partly countering effects of Labor Department report that Consumer Price Index was unchanged in January, failing to rise on seasonally adjusted basis for first time in four years; Jan figures are first Bureau of Labor Statistics calculated using revised market basket of consumer goods that takes into account changing consumer behavior and technological changes; economists say changes will shave small amounts off index over year, but had no effect in January; graph; table; photo (M)

headline: ULTRA PAC SOARS ON NEWS OF COMPANY'S IMPENDING SALE
abstract: Ivex Packaging Corp will buy Ultra Pac Inc for about $63.6 million (S)

headline: In Giving, a Way to Avoid Capital Gains Tax
abstract: Advice on avoiding capital gains tax by giving appreciated assets to charity; drawing (S)

headline: Daihatsu to End Thai Operations
abstract: Daihatsu Motor Co has stopped production in Thailand and will close its sales outlets there at end of month, becoming firstJapanese auto maker to pull out of an economically troubled Southeast Asian country; auto sales in Thailand fell 38 percent last year from record 570,000 vehicles in 1996; in last four months, sales are down two-thirds from year earlier (S)

headline: Bailout Rules For Japan Banks
abstract: Japanese authorities announce conditions under which public money is to be distributed to nation's banks, which will begin applying for funds next week; eighteen of Japan's biggest banks will apply for total of 2 trillion yen ($15.6 billion) in Government money to replenish their capital (S)

headline: 2 Executives Dismissed by Salomon Over Pornography
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney dismisses two executives after concluding that they used company's electronic equipment to transmit pornography; company's employee handbook explicitly forbids such activity; dismissed employees said to be Dean Eberling and Anthony N Maltese, managing directors in firm's equity research department (M)

headline: A Rising Hindu Tide Frightens India's Muslims
abstract: India's muslims feel anxious about rising tide of Hinduism in their country; since 1947, when partioning of British-ruled Inida set off vast migration of Muslims and Hindus across frontiers of newly independent nations of India and Pakistan, there have been few moments when India's 120 million Muslims have felt so vulnerable; Muslims' current anxiety is that when election results are known, about two weeks hence, a new govt will be formed by Hindu nationalist group, Bharatiya Janata Party, which has maintained wide lead over other parties; for India's Muslims, a Hindu nationalist govt would come to power with legacy many find frightening; there is no escaping what Hindu hard-liners intend--that India should abandon sense of itself as mosaic of different faiths, and establish primacy of Hindu majority, now 700 million in population of 980 million; photo (L)

headline: Istanbul Journal; A Woman, Her Scarf and a Storm Over Secularism
abstract: Conflict between secularism and conservative Islam erupts anew in Turkey, where devout Muslim women are defying Government ban against wearing of head scarf as Islamic symbol; battleground in latest confrontation is campus of Istanbul University, where medical student Tuloy Erdogan and scores of classmates were turned away for wearing traditional head scarf after Government decree ordered school administrators strictly enforce secular dress code; conflict poses threat to current Government of Prime Min Mesut Yilmaz, which faces no-confidence vote on issue in Parliament on March 17, and has resulted in sharp warnings from top military commanders; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Arabs March Home, To a Place They Can't Live In
abstract: Thousands of Israeli Arabs march, Sheik Dannun, Israel, protesting Israeli expropriation of their villages; mark anniversary of similar 1976 protest during which Israeli forces killed six Israeli Arabs; map; photo (M)

headline: Annan Tries to Untangle U.N. Dues From Abortion
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan asks United States House Republican leaders to justify their decision to hold up payment of back dues to United Nations until Administration agrees to provision cutting off aid to groups that support abortion (M)

headline: Computers in U.S. Do Far More and Are Cheaper : Why Europeans Lag in Using PCs
abstract: PARIS—  In the computer industry, where there are buzzwords for everything, the catch phrase is "the technology gap."

headline: Netscape Reports Losses, and Its Shares Tumble
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp says it will report losses for both fourth quarter and year; links its disappointing results to drop in sales of its Navigator browser as result of aggressive competition from Microsoft, which makes its browser available free on Internet; Netscape says it expects to report net loss for fourth quarter in range of $85 million to $89 million, including $52 million in merger-related charges and $35 million in restructuring costs; also says it will reduce it work force, close some offices and refocus on corporate sales (M)

headline: Argentines Fight Razing Of a Place Of Horrors
abstract: Argentine Pres Calos Saul Menem has announced plans to demolish Navy Mechanics School in Buenos Aires where estimated 4,000 political prisoners were killed as part of military's 'dirty war' of repression against leftist guerrillas that ended 15 years ago; human rights groups, opposition political leaders, survivors of detention center and relatives of people who perished there oppose razing school and are calling for buildings to be preserved as museum (M)

headline: C.I.A. Tutors Palestinians in Tricks of Trade
abstract: With Israel's knowledge, the Central Intelligence Agency has been training the security forces of the Palestinian Authority in the arts of espionage, information-gathering, interrogation and other techniques of the trade, American officials say.    The program has two aims. The first is to increase the professionalism of the Palestinian security forces and to improve their ability to identify and arrest suspected terrorists, a task in which the officials say the C.I.A. has partially succeeded. The second is to increase the Israeli Government's confidence in the Palestinians, a political goal that has proved more elusive.

headline: DIARY
abstract: TRADE DEFICIT  Give Us Your Tired,  Your Poor, Your Exports  The nation's 1997 trade deficit reached its highest level in nine years, and a jump in December suggested that the deficit would surge again in 1998 because Asia's financial crisis makes Asian products cheaper in the United States. Imports of goods and services exceeded exports by $10.8 billion in December, a deficit increase of $2.1 billion from November. Economists had expected the December deficit to be about $9 billion. The monthly figures showed the first tentative signs of Asia's effect on trade patterns. The trade deficit with economically ravaged South Korea, for example, expanded by $300 million in December, to $343 million.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currency trading table; Canadian dollar rallies (S)

headline: To an Ovation in Congress, Clinton Warns Saddam on Weapons : 'You Can't Defy the Will of the World'
abstract: PARIS—  The State of the Union Message provided President Bill Clinton with a solemn occasion to deliver a warning about U.S. determination to destroy Iraq's missiles and biological and chemical arms and to root out the country's capability to rebuild them.

headline: Gunung Kaler Journal; The Empty Bowls That Fill Indonesia With Fear
abstract: Ethnic Chinese businessmen donate 20 tons of rice to poor people of Gunung Kaler, Indonesia, as part of public relations effort to defuse anger that has caused mobs in dozens of towns to loot and burn Chinese-owned shops; map; photo (M)

headline: Dr. Thomas Frist Sr., HCA Founder, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr Thomas F Frist Sr, widely regarded as father of modern for-profit hospital system, dies at age 87; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   6.00   5.45   5.55        3-month T-bills   5.07   5.06   4.98        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.01   5.03        10-yr. headline: Seeking Turnaround, Polaroid Introduces Many New Products
abstract: Polaroid Corp, whose growth and profits have been flagging, introduces more than two dozen new products, including disposable instant camera, fiber laser for printers, and anti-glare screens for automatic teller machines; company announces joint venture with Intel Corp to create digital cameras (M)

headline: Wells BDDP, roiled by management changes, loses its third big client in two months.
abstract: Wells BDDP advertising agency, formerly Wells Rich Greene BDDP, loses another large longtime client as agency continues to grapple with turmoil in executive ranks; Liberty Mutual Insurance Co dismisses agency after about dozen years and places account in review; billings are estimated at $27 million to $28 million; Wells BBDP has lost three big clients in two months (L)

headline: Hostage Incident Ends in Tokyo
abstract: Tetsuo Itagaki, former leader of ultranationalist group in Japan who took Masahiro Abe, staff member of Finance Ministry's oversight office, hostage at Tokyo Stock Exchange, is arrested; Itagaki had demanded a trading halt and meeting with Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka (S)

headline: Cuba and the Church Continue To Maneuver Over Pope's Visit
abstract: Cuban Government and Roman Catholic Church are maneuvering over visit by Pope John Paul II that could determine whether political impact of trip is muted or enhanced; Pres Fidel Castro is seeking to use state-run media to portray Pope as ally in struggle against American imperialism, but his Government has erected obstacles making it difficult for church authorities to take their case to Cuban people; Castro reportedly believe he can direct packaging and presentation of Pope's visit in direction that suits his political goals (M)

headline: BBC and Discovery to Develop Programming Together
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp and Discovery Communications Inc sign deal under which they would form $565 million alliance to create new programs and new cable channels around world; joint-venture production agreement will be financed by Discovery and owned equally by the two; it gives Discovery right of first refusal on all new BBC documentary programming, as well as access to BBC's library; BBC can sign co-production agreements with other American partners, as it has traditionally done with PBS and several cable networks, for projects Discovery turns down; deal took 18 months to complete because of its complexity and BBC's exacting guidelines about commercial ventures; BBC, 90-percent funded from British public, is forbidden to invest public money in commercial ventures (M)

headline: Stocks Rally After Recovering From Overnight Selloff in Asia
abstract: Stocks stage muted rally, recovering from early losses that were set off by sharp overnight selloffs in Asia; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 66.76 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 7,647.18; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rises 11.52 points, to 939.21; Nasdaq composite index rises 4.36 points, to 1,507.58; graph; charts (L)

headline: Treasury Prices Drop as Traders Await 3 Days of Auctions
abstract: Bond prices end lower, weakened by selling ahead of Treasury's quarterly refunding auction of $35 billion in new debt this week; 30-year bond falls 12/32, to price of 102 18/32, while yield rises to 5.94 percent from 5.92 percent on Feb 6; graph; chart (L)

headline: LEGGETT & PLATT BUYS 7 PRIVATE FURNISHING COMPANIES
abstract: Leggett & Platt Inc says it acquired seven privately held home and office furnishing companies with combined sales of $175 million; selling prices not disclosed; companies are Syndicate Systems, Wilson Display, American Woodworks, Cumulus Fibres Inc, Falcon Industries, Phoenix Metal Technologies and Miller Manufacturing (S)

headline: Unilever Earnings Drop After Charges in Quarter
abstract: Unilever says fourth-quarter 1997 profit plunged worse-than-expected 95 percent after charge for selling some businesses and for raising its marketing budget; net income fell to 59 million guilders ($30 million) from 1.153 billion guilders in year-earlier period (S)

headline: EARNING IT; The Hunt for Bias in Hiring
abstract: Legal issues in hiring, firing or disciplining workers discussed as major concern for employers; training exercises for supervisors at Tower Records described; photo (S)

headline: Agency Ties Are Cut At Aamco and Cunard
abstract: Aamco Transmissions Inc searches for agency after parting ways with Publicis/Bloom; media spending is more than $20 million; Bates Worldwide says it resigned Cunard cruise line account owned by Kvaerner AS, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Treasuries Move Lower as Report Shows Strength in Economy
abstract: US Treasuries are lower; 30-year bond falls 9/16, to price of 104 1/8; yield rises to 5.83 percent, from 5.79 percent on Feb 17; charts (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Compromises, Avoiding Punishment  Microsoft agreed to separate its Web browser software from its Windows 95 computer operating system in a last-minute deal with the Justice Department that partly settles its antitrust battle and avoids a possible contempt-of-court citation.   With the compromise, Microsoft retreated from its insistence that the browser and Windows were inseparable.   [Page A1.]    Lincoln-Mercury Heads West  Ford said it would move the headquarters of its Lincoln-Mercury division to Southern California, to help it better understand that trend-setting market. The move is the first time that a division of one of the Big Three has left the Detroit area.   [D3.]

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Microsoft Will Soon Offer Peek at New-Media Strategy
abstract: Microsoft Corp is about to reveal its new-media strategy; new Microsoft Start Web site will feature Web-searching technology, E-mail and special software for personalized data collection (S)

headline: Technical Team Is Sent to Iraq To Try to Define Off-Limits Sites
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan sends technical team to Iraq to clear up confusion over so-called presidential sites that Saddam Hussein has declared off-limits to United Nations inspectors (M)

headline: Patents; Could a new chip in your electricity meter become the brains of a household computer?
abstract: Prof Charles Roos patents electric meter containing computer chip; invention would not only eliminate manual checking of meters, but could also serve as the operating brain of a household computer and Internet access system, enabling electric utilities to become major communications players (Patents column) (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Dec 28 article on Gabelli Growth fund manager Howard F Ward's investment strategy1

headline: Changing Fortunes: Hubris and Humility as U.S. Waxes and Asia Wanes
abstract: Nicholas D Kristof analysis on the confounding of the expectation that was widely held in Japan and elsewhere in Asia just a few years ago that their economies were ascendant while America was in decline; says the kind of hubris and triumphalism that blinded Asians to their problems may well do the same to US; says that when things are going well, one is always liable to credit the billiance of one's economic and social structure (M)

headline: The Final Word
abstract: Letter from Sabin Streeter says Mar 5 article on Web zines contained inaccuracies and misinterpreted tone and intentions of Word, for which he was senior editor until it ceased publication (S)

headline: Havana Journal; Divided Loyalties Tugging at Cuba's Children
abstract: Cuban schools continue to teach that United States is evil and threatening enemy even though most Cuban families have relatives in US and Government lets dollars sent by relatives or spent by American tourists circulate freely; hearing one message in school and often hearing radically different one at home confuses some children; photos (M)

headline: Imperial Bancorp To Spin Off Units
abstract: Imperial Bancorp says it received Internal Revenue Service approval to spin off part of its entertainment and specialty-lending busineses to shareholders in tax-free transaction; George L Graziadio Jr, chairman, president and chief executive of Imperial Bancorp, will be chairman of new company, called Imperial Financial Group Inc (S)

headline: Thomas F. O'Neil, 82, Ex-Chief of RKO, Dies
abstract: Thomas F O'Neil, former chairman of RKO General studios who brought movies to television and experimented--unsuccessfully--with early coin-operated pay-TV system, dies at age 82 (M)

headline: MONSANTO SAYS IT MAY SELL OR REVAMP 2 OPTICAL UNITS
abstract: Monsanto Co is considering sale, revamping or other alternatives for its Orcolite and Diamonex optical and ophthalmic lenses divisions, as it looks to focus on its life-sciences business (S)

headline: Responding to Rivals, Sun Plans to Revamp Work Station Business
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc to announce overhaul of its work station business, including machines priced below $3,000, in response to competition from increasingly powerful personal computers (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Profit Warnings Shrugged Off as Dow Climbs Over 8,600
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 75.98 points, to close at record 8.643.12; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 1.13 percent, or 11.94, to close at record 1,064.25; Nasdaq rises 1.35 percent, adding 23.35 points, to 1,748.51; graph; chart (L)

headline: CHIEF OF U.N. SEES GLIMMER OF HOPE IN BAGHDAD TALKS
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Iraqi leaders hold their first round of talks on finding solution to standoff over United Nations weapons inspections; Annan says he hopes to have written agreement when he returns to New York City; meets with Iraqi team led by Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz, and is expected to see Pres Saddam Hussein on Feb 22; says Iraqis have been cooperative, especially in discussions on inspecting eight 'presidential sites' that have been banned to weapons inspectors; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil prices fall to their lowest level since 1995, dragged down by mild weather in Northeast, biggest market for the fuel, and by report that shows substantial rise in inventories last week; heating oil for February delivery falls 0.43 cent, to 47.33 cents a gallon; graph (S)

headline: Promotion Honors For Packard Bell
abstract: Promotion marketing campaign for Packard Bell NEC in Sacramento, Calif, takes top honors at 15th annual Reggie Awards competition sponsored by Promotion Marketing Assn (S)

headline: Daiwa Bank Doubles Bad Loan Write-Offs
abstract: Daiwa Bank Ltd says it is writing off twice as much in bad loans as it had forecast earlier, using money it set aside to cover stock losses; Daiwa also widens its current loss forecast (S)

headline: Guess Who Was There First
abstract: Internet's inventors and earliest users, scientists and researchers at universities around world, now in their middle and late years and still going strong on Net, have for most part greeted general influx onto Net with surprising magnanimity; many are amused by proprietary claims of young users; Internet pioneer Steve Crocker, 53, comments; photos (M)

headline: Most Asian Stocks Surge, Led by Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian stocks surge to their highest point in over three months on optimism that banking reforms announced by Government will put economy back on track (S)

headline: Inflation Whimpers. What's Next for Fed?; New Stresses at Home and Abroad
abstract: Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, no longer have to worry about bringing inflation down sharply, but they face formidable challenge in keeping it down and in keeping economy on track amid powerful crosscurrents; some of issues Federal Reserve and Greenspan are concerned about include change in gross domestic product, increased wages and strong housing market, which is pushing up home prices; graphs; photos (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: MARKETS  Exuberance Dashed, Exuberance Regained  Intel sneezed and the stock market caught a cold, or was it pneumonia? Neither, it seems. Just a one-day panic attack. The Dow industrials, which had been rising at a torrid rate lately, skidded 1.11 percent on Thursday, reacting to Intel's announcement late Wednesday that its earnings would not meet analysts' expectations. Intel's shares tumbled 12.5 percent, but they gained more than 3 percent on Friday to end the week at $78.125. The selling pressure moved first through the technology sector and then to the broader market. But on Friday, traders were more optimistic, with the Dow industrials ending the week at 8,569.39, up 23.67. The Nasdaq composite, however, slipped 17.02 for the week, closing at 1,753.49.

headline: America Online's Triumvirate in Cyberspace; The Service Provider Everybody Loves to Hate Changes by the Nanosecond
abstract: Article profiles America Online, where chief executive Stephen M Case has attracted a group of eccentric, flamboyant executives, most notably Theodore J Leonsis and Robert W Pittman; company earned $20.8 million on sales of $592 million in last quarter of 1997; the value of its stock has tripled in past year, and its advertising revenue has nearly doubled; charts; photo (M)

headline: Turkish Inquiry Links Government Agents to Assassinations
abstract: Official investigating Turkey's bgiiest modern political scandal implicates previous Governmentts in clandestine murders and other illegal activities; 120-page report says Government spent millions of dollars on efforts to assassinate Kurdish rebels and overthrow Government of Azerbaijan (M)

headline: The Shopping Mall And the Community
abstract: Mark Hinshaw letter points out that first shopping center designed to cater to auto-borne customer was Country Club Plaza in Kansas City, built by J C Nichols in 1927, and still thriving with its tree-lined streets and rear parking (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn futures prices fall 2.5 percent on forecast of big planting; May contract drops 7 cents a bushel, to $2.7474; graphs; table (S)

headline: Russia's Tax Police Press Media Message: Pay Up
abstract: Russia's tax service to begin media blitz to prod tax-shirking Russians to file their tax returns before April 1 deadline; low level of compliance in Russia noted; last year, Russian Govt collected only about 52 percent of taxes due; last year in Moscow, city of 10 million, only 120,000 people filed their income taxes on time; photos (M)

headline: STATE AUTO FINANCIAL PLANS 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
abstract: State Auto Financial Corp plans to splits its shares 2 for 1 and purchase Milbank Insurance Co, mutual, or policyholder-owned, parent company, State Automobile Mutual (S)

headline: MCI and Worldcom Set For Telefonica Alliance
abstract: Telefonica de Espana SA, Spain's dominant telephone company and largest communications provider in Latin America, will announce alliance with MCI Communications Corp and Worldcom Inc, less than year after Telefonica jilted its original American partner, AT&T Corp, in favor of deal with Concert group led by British Telecommunications PLC; MCI was once part of Concert, but Telefonica's latest plan makes plain that company is mainly interested in dealing with MCI all along; details of Telefonica's alliance with Worldcom and MCI remain unclear, but some analysts feel Telefonica might have been in stronger position had it stuck with AT&T all along (M)

headline: The Hollywood Stock Market: You Can't Lose
abstract: HSX Holdings runs Hollywood Stock Exchange, World Wide Web site where film fanatics use play money to trade shares in new films and actors; site, supported by advertising, was created by former stockbrokers Michael Burns and Max Keiser; they hope film industry will eventually use exchange for market research and for financing films; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Patents; So much for those inert computer mice. A new version lets users get downright touchy-feely.
abstract: Louis Rosenberg, founder of Immersion Corp, receives patent for new computer mouse, called Feelit, that allows users to feel physical shapes, textures and other qualities of anything that appears on computer screen (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER UNIT IN DEAL FOR IP TIMBERLANDS
abstract: IP Forest Resources Co buys all publicly traded depository units of IP Timberlands Ltd for about $99.5 million; IP Forest, subsidiary of International Paper Co, is managing partner for IP Timberlands (S)

headline: GTE Profits Down 10% in 4th Quarter
abstract: GTE Corp says profits fell 10 percent in fourth quarter; net income declined to $702 million from $784 milion a year earlier; revenue rose 10 percent, to record $6.35 billion from $5.75 billion (S)

headline: Rio Journal; The Beauty of It! Face Lifts Pay for Poor's Surgery
abstract: Brazil's obsession with beauty has made plastic surgery popular in Rio de Janeiro, where many plastic surgeons perform expensive cosmetic surgery on wealthy patients and orthopedic surgery on poor free of charge; photo (M)

headline: Another Record for Dow as Investors Dismiss the Negatives
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at record 8,398.50, up 28.40 points; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.67 points, to 1,022.76; Nasdaq composite index falls 6.99 points, to 1,703.43; graph; chart (L)

headline: A Year Before the Millennium Bug, There's the Euro Problem
abstract: European Monetary Union's new currency, the euro, could have more serious consequences for world's computer systems, and pose more technological problems, than year 2000 problem; on Jan 1, 1999, when euro is introduced, exchange-rate and tax software will need to be upgraded, financial statements redesigned, automated teller machines revamped and historical data converted; Gartner Group Inc, research company, estimates it will cost European corporations and their worldwide operations $150 billion to $400 billion to upgrade their systems for euro, in addition to expense of fixing millennium bug; Gartner Group finds many companies do not yet grasp reality of situation; problem is compounded by shortage of available programmers; another problem is transition period from 1999 to 2003, when companies will have to deal with two sets of currencies: euro and local money, even though most software packages can handle only one currency at a time (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS INC., Parsippany, N.J., a packaged foods company whose best-known brands are Chef Boyardee, Bumble Bee Tuna and Gulden's Mustard, will buy Unilever Canada's Puritan line of canned stews and meats for an undisclosed price.    SABA PETROLEUM CO., Santa Maria, Calif., an oil and natural gas exploration and production company, hired CIBC Oppenheimer to explore selling all or part of the company.

headline: Schick unveils its biggest ad campaign ever this weekend.
abstract: Schick, division of Warner-Lambert Co, will formally begin its largest advertising program ever--a campaign for its newest razor the Protector--during National Basketball Association's All-Star Weekend; Tim Duncan of San Antonio Spurs will be standard-bearer for new razor; ads were created by Market Growth Resources; photo (L)

headline: SmithKline Beecham's Net Increases 8.9% in Quarter
abstract: Smithkline Beecham PLC reports 8.9 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings; company earned 315 million pounds, or $525 million, for quarter, up from 299 million pounds a year earlier; Smithkline's chief executive Jan Leschly says announcement about Glaxo Wellcome PLC's merger will come in early March; chart (M)

headline: Stock Offerings Planned During the Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MICROAGE INC., Tempe, Ariz., a computer reseller and technology services company, laid off 300 employees, or 6 percent of its work force, and is considering splitting into two independent companies to cope with slow sales and lower profits.    REPTRON ELECTRONICS INC., Tampa, Fla., an integrated electronics company, agreed to acquire Hibbing Electronics Corp., a contract manufacturer, from Oeco Corp., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: Istanbul Journal; Armenians Among the Turks: A Happier Chapter
abstract: Recent funeral for Karekin II, Armenian Patriarch of Istanbul, produced scene that some foreigners found surprising; over 1,000 Turkish citizens of Armenian background, together with senior diplomats and Government officials, attended funeral; occasion served as reminder that while in some parts of world Turks and Armenians are viewed as natural enemies, in Istanbul they live peacefully together; photos (M)

headline: Oxford Investors Build In Some Insurance, in Case Things Don't Work Out
abstract: Analysis of rescue plan for Oxford Health Plans; investors led by Texas Pacific Group will invest $350 million in preferred stock convertible to common stock; will end up owning 22.1 percent of Oxford; conversion price will drop if Oxford's share price slumps over next year (M)

headline: Baghdad May Ask Court in Hague to Intervene in Inspection Crisis
abstract: Iraqi Foreign Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf blames US and United Nations disarmament chief Richard Butler for creating 'fabricated crisis' over arms inspections; says Iraq may ask International Court of Justice to intervene in confrontation (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hilton Hotels Ends Bid To Acquire Circus Circus  Hilton Hotels and Circus Circus Enterprises have called off merger talks that would have created the world's largest casino company, industry officials said. The companies agreed Friday to call off the talks after they found themselves unable to resolve some issues and other concerns arose that would have made the proposed deal less attractive.

headline: Oracle Reports Sharp Rebound That Beats Analysts' Estimates
abstract: Oracle Corp reports sharp rebound in its third fiscal quarter ended Feb 28 with record results; company earned $215.1 million, up from $169.3 million in year-earlier period; revenues rose 27 percent, to $1.75 bilion from $1.37 billion (M)

headline: Israel Seeks Deal to Quit Buffer Zone In Lebanon
abstract: Israeli Government sends out diplomatic feelers to end increasingly costly military involvement in southern Lebanon; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says Government is ready to comply with UN resolution calling on it to withdraw, if Lebanon cooperates in insuring security along border (M)

headline: Cuban Catholics Feverishly Prepare for Pope
abstract: For two straight hours, Maria de los Angeles Romero has been gluing paper Cuban flags to rough wooden sticks. The glue, a homemade lumpy mixture of water and flour, sticks to Ms. Romero's bony fingers, and from there to her limp hair.    But Ms. Romero, an intense and wiry woman of 53, does not seem to mind. When Pope John Paul II arrives in this city on Wednesday afternoon, thousands of people waving Cuban and Vatican flags will be waiting for him. Ms. Romero knows that at least 1,200 of those flags will have gone through her hands. And that makes her very happy.

headline: Delaying the Pay
abstract: Joan Mary Macey letter points out that teachers in some school districts inadvertently provide districts with interest-free loans by taking their paychecks every two weeks (S)

headline: COINMACH ACQUIRING MACKE LAUNDRY FOR $214 MILLION
abstract: Coinmach Laundry Corp agrees to acquire Macke Laundry Service LP for about $214 million (S)

headline: TV's Olympic Ads: Straight From Dullsville
abstract: Article on dull television commercials during Olympic Games; examples of how major advertisers and their agencies fared described (L)

headline: California Merger to Form No. 3 S.& L.
abstract: Golden State Bancorp Inc, parent of Glendale Federal Bank, to acquire First Nationwide Holdings Inc, parent of California Federal Bank, to form nation's third-largest savings and loan; Ronald O Perelman, who controls First Nationwide Holdings, agreed to selling price that values California Federal at $2 billion to $2.5 billion, well below what he wanted, after several other potential buyers walked away because of California Federal's heavy dependence on mortgage lending; combination of Glendale and California Federal will create huge institution with assets of $51 billion; Glendale has made important gains diversifying into new businesses; new institution will be called California Federal Bank; Gerald J Ford, Perelman's partner, will be chairman and chief executive of new institution, but Golden State's shareholders will control 55 percent to 58 percent of new institution; chart (M)

headline: Tricon Chairman Got $3.1 Million in '97
abstract: Tricon Global Restaurants Inc reports paying chairman and chief executive Andrall Pearson total of $3.1 million in 1997 and stock options valued at $13.1 million (S)

headline: Peter Kiewit Sons to Build National Fiber Optic Network
abstract: Peter Kiewit Sons Inc intends to spend up to $3 billion over next three years to build 20,000-mile web of fiber optic cable; system, which company wants to complete by 2001, would be first national fiber optic network based on Internet technology rather than on standard telephone technology; if Internet technology works, it could allow Kiewit to charge prices for voice and data communications much lower than those of its competitors while maintaining health profit margins (L)

headline: Maintaining Local Flavor; Will Too Much Success Spoil Blue Bell Ice Cream?
abstract: Blue Bell Creameries Inc seeks to expand market for its ice cream beyond its regional base in Texas and neighboring states; hopes to retain quality and homespun image while gradually expanding into national brand; expansion efforts of other regional brands recalled; photos (M)

headline: Relocations for China Dam Are Found to Lag
abstract: Relocation of at least 1.2 million people to make way for Three Gorges Dam in central China is off to poor start, calling into question official timetable for filling dam's reservoir five years from now; China diverted Yangtze River around construction site and began building dam in Nov 1997; map (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Soar Like a Falcon . . .; . . . Sink Like an Overextended Investment Bank
abstract: Article on factors that led to collapse of Peregrine Investments Holdings in Hong Kong, Asia's biggest underwriter of stocks; says 10-year-old investment firm rose to prominence by taking greater risks than anybody else on Asian enterprises; holds its brashness proved its undoing when region's currency collapse brought Asia's high-flyers down to earth; chronology of events that led to company's demise; graphs; photos (L)

headline: With Revenue From Oil Reduced, Mexico Again Cuts Its Budget
abstract: Mexico cuts $1.05 billion from the budget for second time in 1998 because of weak oil prices; Government also revises downward by $1 a barrel, to $12.50, its provisional calculation for average price of Mexican petroleum exports will bring over course of the year; new cutbacks represent 1.4 percent of the budget (M)

headline: FIRSTPLUS FINANCIAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE LIFE FINANCIAL
abstract: Firstplus Financial Group Inc acquires Life Financial Corp for $138 million in stock (S)

headline: Accounting Change Urged to Help Japan's Banks
abstract: Japan's governing party wants to change an accounting rule so that banks can increase their dwindling capital by trillions of yen; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto and other leaders of Liberal Democratic Party endorse plan under which banks and other companies could, for bookkeeping practices, put values on their land holdings that are based on current market prices; currently, property assets are kept on books at prices at which they were acquired (M)

headline: Optimum Takes On Media Planning
abstract: Optimum Media, media buying and research division of DDB Needham Worldwide, is assuming media planning functions of sibling, Griffin Bacal, making Optimum a full-service media services agency; Steven Naftelberg, media director at Griffin Bacal, takes that position at Optimum Media Planning (S)

headline: Building Girls Cyber Rooms Of Their Own
abstract: Interview with Brenda Laurel, who helped found Purple Moon, Interval Research spin-off company that creates adventure software for girls 8 to 12 years old; photos (M)

headline: Germans Protest as Unemployment Reaches a Postwar Record
abstract: Unemployed Germans, inspired by French demonstrators but lacking their passion or numbers, stage protests across country as federal Labor Office announces postwar record of 4.8 million people on jobless lines (M)

headline: New Panel Is Planned to Press Insurance Firms on Holocaust
abstract: Sen Alfonse D'Amato and other leaders of effort to press European insurance companies to pay claims of Holocaust victims and their heirs say they will propose creation of independent panel to supervise searching of company files and creation of fund to help aging Holocaust survivors; plan follows months of talks with insurers by New York Insurance Supt Neil Levin and World Jewish Congress aide Elan Steinberg; Assicurazioni Generali, dominant underwriter of policies sold to Eastern European Jews before World War II, indicates it may not cooperate and wants focuse of debate shifted (M)

headline: Why Do People Quit Their Jobs? Because They Can
abstract: James G Cobb article on Honda Accord and Pontiac Grand Prix midsize coupes; photos (M)

headline: In Mixed Day, Dow and S.& P. 500 Dip as Nasdaq Rises
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 25.91 points, to 8,846.89; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 1.13 points, to 1,100.80; Nasdaq index gains 4.03 points, to record 1,828.54; Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks rises 0.67 point, to record 477.81; graph; chart (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A new trading system may bring a shift in the balance of power on the Nasdaq exchange.
abstract: Market Place column on announcement that Nasdaq Stock Market intends to offer high-technology trading system backed by mutual funds and other professional investors; says many Wall Street dealers are lukewarm about system, in part because it has potential to eat into their profits (L)

headline: Energy for a Power Source; The Keys to Electricity: Cost and Cleanliness
abstract: Emission of greenhouse gases from power plants is likely to be cut at least in part by retiring inefficient coal plants, because coal burned in those plants emits most carbon dioxide; question then becomes what most cost-effective approach is; nuclear reactors produce no carbon dioxide, but they are expenisve and pose environmental risks; experts say it might be preferable to build much larger number of plants running on natural gas, which produce little carbon dioxide; coal remains most widely used fuel for producing electricity, despite some limited inroads by nuclear power; use of oil and gas has declined; chart (L)

headline: S.E.C. pressure on 3Com signals that it might be time to tighten the accounting rules in mergers.
abstract: Market Place: 3Com Corp, under pressure from Securities and Exchange Commission, has revised accounting after books of combined 3Com and US Robotics vanished; reversal is interesting because it may signal tightening of the way SEC is interpreting merger rules when two companies with different fiscal years are merged and their books are combined using pooling of interests accounting method; it appears to have been first time SEC has stepped in to correct what it saw as abuse of that accounting rule (L)

headline: Ex-Perot Executive To Lead Cybersafe
abstract: James Cannavino, former IBM executive and former chief executive of Perot Systems, will become chairman and chief executive of Cybersafe (S)

headline: Microsoft Adding to Java and to Sun Rift
abstract: Microsoft Corp plans to announce new capabilities for its version of Java programming language that are certain to deepen bitter rift with Sun Microsystems Inc, Java's inventor; Microsoft says it is departing further from Sun's standard in effort to give software programmers better performance and increase compatibility with Microsoft's Windows operating systems features (M)

headline: Prices Rally After Friday's Sharp Selloff as Dollar Gains
abstract: Bond prices rally and dollar rebounds as investors shift their attention to positive economic fundamentals supporting both markets; price of 30-year bond jumps 1 1/4 to 103 1/4 as yield drops to 5.89 percent from 5.96 percent; graph (M)

headline: Fila and Arnell Are Parting Ways
abstract: Fila USA and its agency, Arnell Group Brand Consulting in New York, say they will part ways; account has billings of $15 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Market Timing
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department releases its weekly planting report on seven crops.

headline: PLAINS IN $420 MILLION DEAL FOR 3 GOODYEAR BUSINESSES
abstract: Plains Resources Inc agrees to buy All American Pipeline System, Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co's oil pipeline unit, and Goodyear's Celeron Gathering Corp and Celeron Trading and Transportation Co units, for $420 million in cash (S)

headline: Yeltsin Sends Envoy to Iraq to Try to Finesse Crisis With the U.S.
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin, angered by what he considers needless intensification of tensions between Iraq and US, sends special envoy to Baghdad with orders to end mounting crisis over weapons inspections (M)

headline: Wunderman, at 77, Is Calling It a Day
abstract: Lester Wunderman, pioneer of direct marketing, is retiring as chairman of Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKES, BETTE S. (NEE KAPLAN)
abstract: MENKES-Bette S. (nee Kaplan). Of Fort Lee, N.J. Formerly of Teaneck, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Sherwood Bradford. Devoted mother of Holly and Alan Freedman, Laurie and Jeffrey Hollman, Jill and Robb Kushner and the late Peter K. Menkes. Loving grandmother of John and Michael Freedman, David and Richard Hollman, Matthew and Liz Kushner. Services were held at Gutterman - Musicant, Hacken sack, N.J., Sunday. Contributions to Peter K. Menkes Memorial Fund, C/O Teaneck Public Library, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666. The family will sit shiva at their respective homes on Tuesday.

headline: Professor Named to Lead St. Louis Fed
abstract: Brown University Prof William Poole is named president of St Louis Federal Reserve Bank; Thomas Melzer, previous president, resigned at end of January (S)

headline: The Original Mr. Fix-It Gives Way to a Super-Salesman
abstract: Dennie M Welsh, passionate, workaholic IBM executive who founded services unit and engineered its fast growth, is forced to take time off for treatment of immune disorder; photo; Samuel J Palmisano, super-salesman who 'does not suffer bureaucracy well,' takes over post (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, FRANKLIN H., JR.
abstract: NICHOLS-Franklin H., Jr. Of Guilford, CT, formerly of Greenwich, CT. Husband of Joy (Hallock) Nichols and the late Louise (Newell) Nichols. Services Thurs., March 26, 11 AM, Trinity Episcopal Church, 1109 Main Street, Branford, CT.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMARKIN, CAROLYN
abstract: TUMARKIN - Carolyn. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum note with sorrow the death of Carolyn Tumarkin, mother of Curator Susan Goodman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Joan Rosenbaum, Director Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President

headline: Coca-Cola Flexes Muscle for a Blitz
abstract: Coca-Cola Co is beginning monthlong marketing blitz that includes advertising during high-profile events like Super Bowl XXXII and Winter Olympics; new commercials will include first work for Diet Coke from Wieden & Kennedy advertising agency (S)

headline: AMPAL-AMERICAN ENTERING MOTOROLA ISRAEL VENTURE
abstract: Ampal-American Israel Corporation to buy a one-third interest in Motorola Israel, Motorola's wireless-communications business in Israel, for $110 million; acquisition is springboard for other telecommunications and high-technology investments (S)

headline: Will a Child's Troubles Erase a Parent's Smile?
abstract: CSY Liquidating Corp, formerly known as Caruthersville Shipyard Inc, contends in lawsuit that Harris Bankcorp took bribe from competitor Trinity Industries in deal that put Carutherville out of business; Harris is subsidiary of Bank of Montreal; diagram (L)

headline: . . . With Liberty and Laptops for All?
abstract: More than 50 public and private schools nationwide take part in Learning With Laptops, Microsoft-Toshiba venture started three years ago, which arranges computer service and lease agreements for schools; most Learning With Laptops schools market program to parents, who receive slightly discounted three-year lease at roughly $58 a month for basic laptop package; some schools split lease payments evenly with students' families; chairman of Texas Board of Education received favorable reviews from some state legislators on his proposal to divert textbook funds toward purchase of laptops (M)

headline: After Land-Mine Triumph, a Crusade Against Small Arms
abstract: Nongovernmental groups from academic institutes to human rights and aid agencies, encouraged by their surprising success in achieving treaty to ban land mines, are girding for campaign against assault rifles and other light weapons that inflame ethnic and nationalist wars around world; groups seek to curb brisk trade in light weapons that end up in hands of terrorist groups and organized crime syndicates as well as warring factions (M)

headline: Proposal to Revamp South Korean Debt
abstract: South Korean Government and international banks are considering repackaging slightly less than $30 billion in short-term loans due the end of the year as new, longer-term debt; Government is unwilling to guarantee all the debt that may be exchanged, which may mean that banks will be forced to take losses on Korean loans (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of December 28 article on ways for individuals to invest in institutional mutual funds

headline: New Chicago Office For Ammirati Puris
abstract: Ammirati Puris Lintas, unit of Interpublic Group of Companies, names creative leadership for office in Chicago that the agency is opening to service its new Ameritech Corp account; Jonathan Moore and Tim Kane are named executive vice presidents and co-creative directors (S)

headline: Merger by 2 Russian Tycoons Creates an Oil Colossus
abstract: Two of Russia's most powerful tycoons merged their oil companies today, creating a politically potent enterprise with control over one of the world's largest oil reserves.    The move, the largest merger in the brief history of Russian capitalism, was immediately blessed by Russia's Prime Minister, who spent much of his own career in the country's state-owned energy industry.

headline: Saddam Hussein Sees Himself as the No. 1 Target, and Lives His Life Accordingly: In Secret
abstract: Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein reportedly has adopted pattern of surreptious moves to evade attempts to make him target of expected American air attack; some Arab officials say Hussein will almost certainly survive attack, unless United States lands troops to find and kill him; photo (M)

headline: Gateway 2000 Hires Partners for TV Ads
abstract: Gateway 2000 Inc expands its roster by naming partnership of Corra Films and agency DiMassimo Inc to create series of television commercials (S)

headline: Heirs Try to Keep A Black Press Heritage Alive
abstract: Heirs of John Sengstacke hope to keep his chain of black-owned newspapers in family despite financial problems that include $4 million estate tax bill; newspapers include Michigan Chronicle and Chicago Defender; Myiti Sengstacke, granddaughter, has decided to replace Northern Trust as trustee, fearing its dedication to its fiduciary duties would result in sale of newspapers; advisers say she could pay off tax debt and then reorganize company under either merger or issuance of additional stock; another possibility would be to find investor to pay off debt in exchange for nonvoting preferred stock; Myiti Sengstacke says her family could put together management team to entice advertisers and try to lure back many of black readers, now middle class, who have abandoned black newspapers across country for more upscale newspapers and magazines; photo (L)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Emerging Markets: Nice Concept, Bad Outcome
abstract: Poor performance of emerging market mutual funds discussed; such funds, which mostly produced respectable, not extraordinary, five-year returns before Asia crisis, have been badly hurt by crisis; graph (M)

headline: BASF Plans to Buy Korean Lysine Business
abstract: BASF AG says it will pay $600 million for lysine unit of Daesang Group of South Korea to make it world's third-largest producer of lysine; graph (S)

headline: J.G. Williams, 84, a Legend As Naturalist And Guide
abstract: John George Williams, self-taught naturalist who gained international renown as safari guide to bird life and other fauna of eastern and central Africa, dies at 84 (M)

headline: Panic in Indonesia Replaced by Political Anxiety
