abstract: Public pressure for Pres Suharto to resign mounts in response to Indonesia's economic crisis; Jakarta, buoyed by prospect of closer United States role in solving crisis, reportedly is calmer in wake of panic that led hoarders to strip supermarket shelves of food; shoppers continue to crowd markets, but are more orderly; photo (M)

headline: Jaded See South Africa As 'Flavor of the Month'
abstract: South African reaction to Pres Clinton's visit has been subdued; variety of reasons have been offered, with some analysts saying Clnton himself may be partly to blame for tepid reception; note how disappointed Parliament was that Clinton failed to acknowledge America's relationship with white-supremacist Government in 1980's; nor did Clinton come offering much in way of aid (M)

headline: SARA LEE SELLING 9 PLANTS TO NATIONAL TEXTILES
abstract: Sara Lee Corporation to sell nine United States yarn and textile plants to National Textiles LLC, Winston-Salem, NC, as part of a plan to focus on selling brands like Hanes underwear instead of making them; analysts say sale price is $450 million; Sara Lee's 3,865 plant workers will be hired by National Textiles, which is expected to be key Sara Lee supplier (S)

headline: Keeping Bookmarks In a Place That's Safe
abstract: Q. How can I permanently save the bookmarks that I use with my Netscape browser? I want to back them up so the site-address part (and not just the title of the site) is retained if they get corrupted. I have been a victim of corrupted bookmarks too often.

headline: U.S. Is Pressing Moscow on Iran And Missile Aid
abstract: US reportedly offers Russia opportunity to expand lucrative business launching foreign satellites if it clamps down on sale of missile technology to Iran; offer has been conveyed confidentially to Russians and is part of broad effort to discourage Russian companies and institutes from helping Iran develop new surface-to-surface missile; is worth potentially hundreds of millions of dollars to Russian companies and Western companies that have formed partnerships with them; Iran has been developing Shahab 3 missile, which has range of approximately 800 miles--long enough to reach Israel and Saudi Arabia with more than twice range of Scud missile (M)

headline: Japanese Auto Exports Increased in January
abstract: Japanese car makers increased exports in January as strong sales in Europe and US offset declines in Asia (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Prices of gold and other precious metals surge in tandem with rebound in oil prices; in New York, gold for April delivery rises $7.30 an ounce, to $299.50; graphs; chart (S)

headline: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO PURCHASE LOGIC WORKS
abstract: Platinum Technology Inc says it agreed to acquire Logic Works Inc for $174.8 million in stock (S)

headline: Several More Recipes For Consulting Success
abstract: Letter by Catharine M Napolitano on Thomas J Waite's Jan 4 article on criticisms of consulting industry (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Optimistic Signs in Japan  Global stock markets rallied yesterday after the Japanese Government backed a plan that many investors believed would stimulate its economy and help ease concerns about the Asia crisis.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Public Television Needs More Than Virtue
abstract: Newton N Minow and Craig L LaMay article urges renewed research and discussion on letting public television sell advertising; drawing (M)`

headline: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, BETTY (NEE MAYER)
abstract: JORDAN-Betty (nee Mayer). Passed away March 23, 1998. Survived by William Murrell, mother of Barbara Noriega and Shoshana (Susan) Benmosche, grandmother of Cristina Noriega, Diana Targia, and Antony Graf, great-grandmother of Andrew, sister of Marjorie Mayer Curnan, and Benjamin H. Mayer.

headline: U.N. Delegate Sees Support Worldwide For the U.S.
abstract: Bill Richardson, chief United States repr to United Nations, after shuttling 18,000 miles among far-flung countries that have seldom hit radar screen of American foreign policy, comes home to report that a 'silent majority' of nations supports Washington's policy on Iraq (M)

headline: Hitler's Genocide Order: 5 Days After Pearl Harbor?
abstract: German scholar Christian Gerlach has set off debate among historians with theory that Hitler personally decided to order annihilation of Europe's Jews and announced it to his most senior Nazi followers Dec 12, 1941; bases theory on notation by SS chief Heinrich Himmler, found in previously secret Soviet archives, and on other documents; holds decision was spurred in part by America's entry into World War II after Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor (M)

headline: Now, Big Blue Is at Your Service
abstract: Article on IBM's emergence in last few years as world's largest provider of technology services, including support systems, technology-strategy advice, employee training and disaster-prevention; service business was started in 1990, three years before Louis Gerstner became chairman, but has played into his strategic gamble that way to revive tottering giant was to capitalize on its sheer size; unit now called IBM Global Services, under Samuel J Palmisano, had revenue of $19 billion last year, with annual increases exceeding 25 percent; photos of Palmisano and of command center in Boulder, Colo, one of nine worldwide where technicians control computer operations of clients; graphs profiling service unit (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JDN REALTY CORP., Atlanta, a real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire a portfolio of five shopping centers in Milwaukee for $58.4 million.    AMB PROPERTY CORP., San Francisco, an industrial and commercial property management concern, said that it had acquired two industrial real estate portfolios in Portland, Ore., for $30 million.

headline: Hilton Casinos' Head Was Paid $1 Million
abstract: Arthur Goldberg, who heads gambling operations at Hilton Hotels Corp, received salary almost twice as large as that of company's chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach, last year, according to proxy statement filed with Government (S)

headline: A Quebecer Trumpets The Case For Canada
abstract: Interview with Min Stephane Dion, bilingual professor who is Canada's official crusader for national unity, chosen in 1996 by Prime Min Jean Chretien to stand up to Quebec separatists; he notes how his views differ from those of late father, Leon, considered intellectual leader of Quebec's search for identity (M)

headline: From a Friend Indeed, Clinton Awaits a Visit
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, who arrives in Washington on Feb 4, says he considers Pres Clinton a friend and criticizes 'arrogant' politicians and media who he says 'try to reverse the outcome of elections'; praises Clinton's backing for British and Irish efforts to achieve settlement in Northern Ireland; photo (M)

headline: Interpublic Opens A Sports Unit
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies in New York says it has opened sports marketing unit named Octagon (S)

headline: Currency Hits Record Low Vs. Dollar In Canada
abstract: Canadian dollar drops to its lowest value ever against American dollar, falling to 68.85 United States cents, or $1.4523 (Canadian) to dollar; graph (M)

headline: The bottom-line publisher of The Los Angeles Times faces the hard-line skeptics.
abstract: Mark H Willes, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and chairman of Times Mirror Co, defends his bottom-line-oriented newsroom policies before skeptical crowd of journalism students and former Times Mirror employees at Columbia Graduate School of Journalism; Michael Parks, Willes's point man, faced similar audience at journalism school of University of California at Berkeley; sessions sum up debate in American journalism: how big newspaper profits have to be and at what price to journalism and to journalism jobs; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Considers a Radical Shift For Currency, Hitching It to Dollar
abstract: Indonesia, scrambling to contain inflation and control social unrest, is actively considering radical change in its monetary system that would fix Indonesian currency's value to the dollar and essentially eliminate central bank; system, known as currency board, could help end uncertainty surrounding rupiah's value by making it worth same amount in dollars all the time; photo (L)

headline: Nexstar Makes Deal On DNA Technology
abstract: Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc. has agreed to buy DNA synthesis patent rights from Perseptive Biosystems Inc., a move that will allow Perseptive's $360 million merger with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation to take place.    In August, Perkin-Elmer, based in Norwalk, Conn., agreed to acquire Perseptive, based in Framingham, Mass. Perkin-Elmer and Perseptive were the only companies that held the patents necessary for production of certain DNA molecules, used in certain types of medical research.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil surges 3.5 percent on OPEC's call for emergency meeting on March 30, suggesting it will seek deeper production cuts than those already pledged; crude for May delivery costs $16.48 a barrel, up 56 cents; graphs; chart (S)

headline: India, Eager for Stability, Frets at Another Indecisive Vote
abstract: There is widespread apprehension in India, as election results flow in, that huge, impoverished nation may be headed for another period of revolving-door governments that lack political clout to tackle country's problems; there will be at least 38 parties in new Parliament, none with anything close to a majority; largest, Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, will have 177 seats, 95 short of a majority of 272 seats in Parliament with 543 elected members (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Mexican peso slips against dollar as it continues to struggle to regain ground lost after financial turmoil in Asia sent world stock markets lower in October; graph (S)

headline: New Top Executive For Mesa Air Group
abstract: Mesa Air Group Inc names Jonathan Ornstein to succeed its founder Larry Risley as chief executive on May 1 (S)

headline: MAKER OF POLYESTER FIBERS TO SELL ITS PACKAGING UNIT
abstract: Wellman Inc, maker of polyester fibers, agrees to sell its Creative Forming Inc unit to group of managers and M&I Capital Markets Group Inc (S)

headline: 4.3% Growth In 4th Quarter While Inflation Stayed Tame
abstract: Commerce Department says nation's gross domestic product expanded at 4.3 percent annual rate in fourth quarter of 1997, up from 3.1 percent rate recorded in third quarter; for the year, economy grew by 3.8 percent, fastest pace since 1988; price measure linked to gross domestic product rose by 1.5 percent, only marginally higher than 1.4 percent rate in third quarter; for all of 1997, inflation rose by 2 percent, smallest increase in more than 30 years; chart (L)

headline: LIFE RE TO BUY LINCOLN LIBERTY AND FIRST DELAWARE
abstract: Life Re Corp agrees to acquire Lincoln Liberty Life Insurance Co and First Delaware Life Insurance Co for $50 million (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Easy Credit: A Wall Around The Poor
abstract: Comment by Fred Waddell on how consumer problems of the poor have been aggravated by misunderstanding and misuse of consumer credit; says what is needed is more education in money management and use of credit--beginning with training for organizations and individuals who work with the poor; drawing (L)/

headline: MACK-CALI REALTY ADDS SEVERAL NEW PROPERTIES
abstract: Mack-Cali Realty Corp has spent $147 million in six transactions to buy or develop properties in Northeast and Southwest; transactions total 1.6 million square feet of office space (S)

headline: NBC to Seek Affiliates' Aid To Help Pay Costs of 'E.R.'
abstract: NBC will seek contributions from its affiliates to help pay soaring costs of ER, television's most-watched program; Neal Braun, president of NBC Television Network, says he already approached several NBC affiliates, suggesting new kind of 'joint venture' agreement that would change way networks and affiliates do business; all major networks are re-examining their economic relationships with stations that broadcast their programs; ABC has asked its affiliates to pay up to $50 million toward network's recent purchase of NFL Monday Night Football, and CBS and Fox have similar plans in place to seek financial help from stations that broadcast their hugely expensive new football deals; one way local network stations could pay would be to give up some commercial time to networks (M)

headline: SHARES OF LONG-DISTANCE PHONE CONCERNS FALL
abstract: Shares of AT&T Corp and other long-distance companies fall during first market session after Federal court strikes down portions of Telecommunications Act of 1996 that prevent companies spun off from AT&T in 1980's from offering long-distance services (S)

headline: CAMPBELL SETS $253 MILLION CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
abstract: Campbell Soup Co will take third-quarter charge of $253 million, resulting in loss, as company sheds businesses and cuts costs (S)

headline: Chase Will Lay Off 2,250 in Latest Cuts
abstract: Chase Manhattan, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to lay off 2,250 employees, or about 3 percent of the work force.    About half the layoffs will be in the New York metropolitan region and New York State. The cuts are part of a plan to eliminate about 4,500 of the bank's 69,033 positions over the next 18 months by laying off workers and by not replacing others who depart.

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions and appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Norway Pledges to Take Part In Worldwide Oil Supply Cuts
abstract: Norway, major oil exporter, says it will cut its output as much as 100,000 barrels a day, strengthening emerging coalition of oil-exporting countries seeking to reduce production and raise prices; members of Orgn of Petroleum Exporting Countries approve cuts totaling 1.25 million barrels a day, or 4.3 percent of group's output; despite this, crude oil prices fall on New York Mercantile Exchange because most people do not think reductions are enough (M)

headline: Correction: Averages for All Stock Funds
abstract: Table of Largest Stock Funds (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Classic Sports Network by ESPN, New York, owned by the ESPN unit of the Walt Disney Co., to Wieden & Kennedy, New York, to develop the first national branding campaign for the cable channel. Billings were not disclosed. The agency creates campaigns for the ESPN network and the ESPN program ''Sports Center.''

headline: New York's Specialty Shops Bounce Back With Trendy Lines
abstract: NEW YORK—  If you find yourself in New York in need of an Armani suit, chances are you'll hit one of the many department stores uptown.

headline: Hearings Focus on Union Pacific Rail Safety
abstract: National Transportation Safety Board will open hearings on what went wrong at Union Pacific Corp after it bought Southern Pacific in 1996; following the merger, snarled rail traffic cost shippers billions of dollars and a series of crashes last year left 11 people dead; Union Pacific denies merger compromised safety; Jolene M Molitoris, chief of Federal Railroad Administration, says she plans to tell safety board that to avoid further carnage, Government should have authority to revise or block major mergers that increase risks of harm (L)

headline: FIFTH THIRD BANK OF OHIO AGREES TO BUY W. LYMAN CASE
abstract: Fifth Third Bank agrees to buy privately held W Lyman Case & Co for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: U.S. Will Proceed With Buildup In Mideast, Clinton Officials Say
abstract: Clinton Administration warns deeds not words are required to resolve crisis with Iraq over arms inspections and will withhold judgment on agreement reached between UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Pres Saddam Hussein pending detailed briefing; say extra time will be needed for experts to study details to insure that UN inspectors have unfettered access to suspected biological and chemical weapons sites; US military buildup in Gulf continues; Defense Department officials are studying how Pentagon will deal with prolonged American military deployment in Persian Gulf to monitor Iraq's compliance with UN-brokered settlement; photo (M)

headline: After 32 years and some of the most successful campaigns ever, Wells BDDP will close its doors.
abstract: GGT Group PLC will close down Wells BDDP, onetime advertising powerhouse that has recently stumbled into a stunning free fall as large clients left amid executive turmoil and ownership changes; shutdown will affect 133 employees in New York (M)

headline: Ta-Ta, Los Angeles, And Hello, London
abstract: Steve Blamer, executive vice president and managing director of Grey Advertising in Los Angeles, will become managing director and chief executive in agency's London office; Blamer will succeed Nigel Sharrocks, who left Grey in September; Jeff Alperin, president of Los Angeles office, will assume Balmer's responsibilities (S)

headline: Kenichi Fukui, 79, Nobel Winner in Chemistry
abstract: Dr Kenichi Fukui, Japanese theoretical and physical chemist who was one of two winners of the 1981 Nobel Prize for chemistry, dies at age 79; photo (S)

headline: Will the Armed Forces Abandon Suharto After So Many Years?: In Indonesia, All Eyes on the Military
abstract: SINGAPORE—  As Indonesia's economy stalls, social unrest and ethnic tension rise and the long rule of President Suharto draws to an end, the role of the armed forces in maintaining stability in the world's fourth-most-populous nation is becoming increasingly critical, analysts say.

headline: Economists Ask Loan Curbs in Crises
abstract: American, South Korean and Japanese economists, citing rapid buildup in short-term foreign loans as major cause of Asian crisis, call for new ways to curb such lending and borrowing, interviews at conference of American Economic Association, Chicago; economists say that rules should be developed to discourage sort of short-term borrowing that can suddenly leave country like South Korea overindebted to industrial nations; Japanese, European and American banks are faulted for eagerly making loans despite growing evidence of possible defaults (L)

headline: QWEST TO CARRY APEX INTERNET DATA FOR $260 MILLION
abstract: Qwest Communications International says it will transmit Internet data for Apex Global Internet Services on its fiber optic network; deal is valued at $260 million, but Qwest would get as much as $575 million over life of 20-year contract (S)

headline: AMERICAN RESOURCES TO ADD TECO GULF OF MEXICO ASSETS
abstract: American Resources Offshore Inc agrees to acquire offshore Gulf of Mexico assets of Teco Oil and Gas unit of Teco Energy Inc for $57.5 million (S)

headline: Bob Wilvers, 65, Ad Executive; Put 'Plop, Plop' With 'Fizz, Fizz'
abstract: Bob Wilvers, former advertising executive, dies on Dec 10 at age 65 (S)

headline: Imperial Chemical to Buy Acheson Industries
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries PLC says it agreed to acquire Acheson Industries for $560 million (S)

headline: Brazil Pays to Shield Currency, And the Poor See the True Cost
abstract: First of two articles in series A Region at Risk focuses on economic problems in Brazil and whether global economic pressures exact too high a cost in stability in highly unequal societies; steps Brazil has taken to save its currency, which have so far satisfied fast-moving global markets, are hurting poor and middle class and undermining popularity of Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso; graphs; photos (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A 2-Way Contest to Pick Up Philadelphia's Options
abstract: American Stock Exchange and Chicago Board Options Exchange want to combine their options businesses with Philadelphia Stock Exchange; Philadelphia exchange, plagued by regulatory problems, confirms it is considering two unsolicited proposals; exchange also announces resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Leopold Korins, after just seven months; management continues to be sore spot for Philadelphia, which had trouble regrouping after series of embarrassing incidents, including criticism from SEC that exchange favored its own interests over those of investors; Amex suffers from identity problem despite making great strides to increase its equity offerings and retain growing companies; Chicago Board has 53 percent of total trading volume in options market, Amex accounts for 25 percent and Philadelphia has 9 percent; Pacific Stock Exchange has 13 percent; chart (M)

headline: The Scoop? Gossip Maven Starts Saving
abstract: Interview with 75-year-old gossip columnist Liz Smith about her personal finances; confesses she has never been a saver, and that says she first gave thought to saving six years ago, prompted by increasingly large salary--estimated at $1 million annually--and by nagging of financial advisers, Peter G Peterson, chairman of hugely successful Blackstone Group, and wife Joan Ganz Cooney; photos (M)

headline: In Paraguay Border Town, Almost Anything Goes
abstract: Ciudad del Este, Paraguay, could be called monument to free enterprise and absence of government regulation; it is city where 90 percent of what is sold is counterfeit, where 3,000 pounds of cocaine a month leaves for other countries, including US, and where arms trafficking and money laundering are rampant; city is latest battleground in fierce dispute between American companies that are trying to protect their patents, licenses and trademarks, and legions of third world entrepreneurs who make their livings from cheap imitations; chief of Paraguay national police's anti-counterfeiting squad says judges in city are bought and controlled by organized crime; recording industry estimates losses of $125 million a year from counterfeiting in Paraguay, and software makers say they lost up to $25 million; photo; map (M)

headline: Ford Is Considering A Stock Repurchase
abstract: Ford Motor Co board will consider stock buyback to buoy its shares after completing spinoff of its consumer finance unit this quarter (S)

headline: The Price of Privacy
abstract: Kenneth Share letter on Mar 19 article on consumers' data trail and its threat to privacy (S)

headline: Nice Videos Can't Hide Flaws
abstract: Robert Hercz assesses Wines of the World Gold Edition, on CD-ROM (S)

headline: COLONEL'S INTERNATIONAL SEEKS MERGER WITH DURAKON
abstract: Colonel's International Inc proposes merger with Durakon Industries; Colonel's will offer Durakon holders one share of its own stock for each share of Durakon (S)

headline: GE CAPITAL TO BUY BARCOM FOR $67 MILLION
abstract: GE Capital Corp buys Barcom PLC for $67 million (US) (S)0

headline: Treasury's Schedule Offers Bill Auction
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent and a six-month bill was 4.98 percent.

headline: William Lambert, 78, Writer Who Exposed Justice Fortas
abstract: William G Lambert, investigative reporter, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: Clinton May Veto Funds Bill on Abortion Issue
abstract: Pres Clinton scores Republican efforts to slip unrelated controversial provisions into emergency spending bills, radio speech; hints he may veto bill if Congress attaches ban on financial aid to groups that offer abortion services abroad; scores Republican efforts to bar Federal Communications Commission from ordering free broadcast time for political candidates (M)/

headline: January Car Sales Slowed By Incentives at End of '97
abstract: Sales results released by auto makers show January got off to slow start, partly because of year-end incentives that led many customers to buy in December; Chrysler Corp and three of largest Japanese auto makers--Toyota, Nissan and Mitsubishi--report double-digit declines in car sales in January; while Chrysler's car sales plunged 14.7 percent, sales of light trucks rose 10.8 percent; overall, Chrysler's sales rose 2 percent last month compared with year earlier (M)

headline: For Britain and Ireland, One Goal: Peace in Ulster Now, Imposed if Necessary
abstract: British and Irish Government are united on strategy to drive lagging peace talks on Northern Ireland to an early conclusion, even implying that they may impose a solution if talks fail; hope threat will prod talks toward a settlement, but there is a risk that if settlement that emerges appears imposed, and not the product of eight local parties in the talks, it will fail to get necessary support of the parties themselves or attract critical backing of voters; level of violence from fringe groups opposed to settlement rises as talks near a resolution; photos (M)

headline: Several Agencies Get New Names
abstract: Capener, Matthews & Walcher changes its name to Matthews/Mack to reflect arrival of Michael Mark in new position of president and chief executive officer of agency; James S Matthews continues as chairman and chief executive; Stricevic, O'Connell & Norton is renamed O'Connell, Norton & Partners; change comes after departure of Dan Stricevic, senior vice president and creative director; Dan O'Connell will head division as senior vice president and general manager; McCann Direct unit of McCann-Erickson World Group is being renamed McCann Relationship Marketing to reflect broadening services beyond traditional direct marketing; In-Sync Communications changes its name to Heitner Weiss, reflecting its principals, Michael Heitner and John Weiss; Interbrand Schechter has become Interbrand; Alvin Schechter remains chairman; Bennett Keeble Martyn, direct marketing agency in Sydney, Australia, is being renamed BKM Ogilvy One Worldwide, direct marketing division of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide; Ogilvy One office in Sydney is being merged with Bennett Keeble Martyn to form BKM Ogilvy One; Ogilvy Adams & Rinehart has been renamed Ogilvy Public Relations (M)

headline: PHONE COMPANIES CANCEL $63 MILLION MERGER PLANS
abstract: ACC Corp scraps its proposed $63 million acquisition of US Wats Inc becuase of delays; ACC decides not to extend merger agreement because it would delay its $1 billion acquisition of Teleport Communications Group; Teleport agreed in November to acquire ACC; in turn, Teleport agreed in January to be acquired by AT&T Corp for $11.3 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. and Japan in Deal To Increase Air Traffic  The United States and Japan agreed to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries, ending a longstanding dispute.

headline: This Deficit Is Soaring Again
abstract: Market Watch column on growing trade deficit, which is expected to reach record $195 billion for 1997; says Asian exports are expected to flood US market, which will hold down inflation in US; holds net effect will be to cause trade deficit to zoom, slowing American economy as well; graph (L)

headline: Argentine Economy Reborn but Still Ailing
abstract: Roger Cohen, in second of two articles, A Region At Risk, notes that Argentina during 1990's adopted International Monetary Fund program that Brazil had shunned and transformation was stunning; Argentina became model of newly globalized economy; Pres Carlos Saul Menem privatized or sold major enterprizes to international investors as country embraced free-market capitalism with vengeance it had once shown in nationalizing everything; shock has been that much greater as globalization has shown its other face; since Asian crisis, Argentine plants have idled, growth forecasts have been slashed and Argentine stock market has plunged over 25 percent; graph; photos (M)

headline: FUND WATCH
abstract: T Rowe Price has introduced two new funds in its quest for indexed assets: Total Equity Market Index fund, tracking Wilshire 5000 equity index, and Extended Equity Market Index fund, which follows Wilshire 4500 equity index of small and midsize stocks (S)

headline: Jefferson-Pilot Splits Stock
abstract: Jefferson-Pilot Corp will split its stock 3 for 2 and raise its dividend on post-split shares by 10 percent (S)

headline: Japan's Cabinet Clears Huge Bank Bailout
abstract: Japan's Cabinet gave its approval yesterday to one of the largest bank bailouts in history -- a 30 trillion yen ($232 billion) package to protect depositors and increase banks' capital -- and sent the measures to Parliament. The Cabinet also approved a 77.7 trillion yen budget for the year starting April 1. In contrast with the bank bailout, the budget calls for spending cuts across the board.

headline: Milken's Probation Extended to March 2
abstract: Michael R Milken's probation has been extended for eighth time as Government keeps talking with lawyers for Milken; latest extension means Milken's probation runs until March 2 (S)

headline: Angotti, Thomas Wins Hardee's Account
abstract: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. in Rocky Mount, N.C., said yesterday that it had named Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York to handle the creative portion of its account. Billings, estimated at $80 million, are expected to rise to $100 million.    Jerry Lacy, advertising director for Hardee's, part of CKE Restaurants, said that Angotti, Thomas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was awarded the account after a five-month review that began with about 50 agencies and was eventually narrowed to that agency and two other finalists: the Leap Partnership in Chicago, part of Leap Group, and Publicis/Bloom in New York, a unit of Publicis S.A.    Angotti, Thomas had been considered a dark horse in the review, but Mr. Lacy said the agency ''best understood the Hardee's brand.'' A campaign is expected to begin in two months, he added.

headline: Students and Laptops
abstract: Letter from Ray Brown, commenting on use of computers in schools, says E-mail and World Wide Web access are critical components of technology use in schools (S)

headline: FORTRESS GROUP IN $61.75 MILLION DEAL FOR HOME BUILDER
abstract: Fortress Group Inc agrees to acquire Whittaker Homes for $61.75 million in cash and assumed debt; Fortress reports income of $4.8 million on revenue of $293.4 million for nine months ended Sept 30 (S)

headline: Doctors Press Oxford Health On Payments
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc is being pressed by doctors and regulators to pay tens of millions of dollars in medical claims it owes; New York County Medical Society, representing 5,000 Manhattan doctors, will file two arbitration proceedings against Oxford; group seeks arbitrator to review doctors' claims and order Oxford to pay money they say they are owned, and second arbitrator to require Oxford to establish clearer payment guidelines; separately, New York State Atty Gen Dennis C Vacco issues subpoena to Oxford requesting information related to settlement agreement he negotiated with company last July, in which Oxford agreed to pay 9 percent annual interest on undisputed claims more than 30 days old; at heart of matter is question of how much Oxford actually owes and when it might pay it (M)

headline: Treasuries Fall as Demand Decreases and Stock Prices Rise
abstract: US Treasury securities fall in choppy trading; 30-year bond drops 29/32, to price of 105 23/32; yield rises to 5.73 percent, from 5.69 percent on Jan 12; graph (L)

headline: ARCO Says It Plans to Sell Its Coal Business in the U.S.
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co (ARCO) reaches premiminary agreement to sell its large coal business in the US to Alliance Coal Corp, unit of Beacon Group, NY investment firm that would become second-biggest coal operator in the country with the purchase; ARCO does not disclose terms but source close to the bidding says ARCO seeks about $1.6 billion; Alliance Coal already owns mines in Midwest and East and deal represents bet that coal will remain critical source of fuel depite emission of carbon dioxide from burining coal (M)

headline: U.S. Insists It Retains Right to Punish Iraq
abstract: Pres Clinton and his aides say United Nations Security Council resolution threatening Iraq with 'severest consequences' authorizes military action if Pres Saddam Hussein defies accord on arms inspections; stand puts United States at odds with other Council members, who said they backed measure only because it did not call for automatic military strike; Office of Management and Budget seeks added $1.36 billion to pay for buildup of forces in Persian Gulf; Defense Department orders vaccination for anthrax of all troops now in region (M)

headline: A European Inquiry on Accounting Mergers
abstract: Giant mergers proposed by four of Big Six accounting firms encounter potentially serious roadblock, when European Commission's top antitrust official Karel van Miert says that he will conduct investigations of both deals; announcement signals growing concern among European officials that two proposed mergers could damage competition and perhaps undermine integrity of independent auditors; first deal would combine Price Waterhouse with Coopers & Lybrand; second deal would merge KPMG Peat Marwick with Ernst & Young (L)

headline: Trump Hires Firms to Aid Casinos Sale
abstract: Donald J Trump hires Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Bear, Stearns & Co to help him sell all or part of his Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts; move spurs further skepticism on Wall Street that any deal will happen soon (M)

headline: Indonesia Currency Falls Hard, Clouding Recovery
abstract: Indonesian currency plummets to new lows week after country agrees to stringent new austerity measures; fall of Indonesian rupiah, to 20 percent of its value six months ago, raises fears that $40 billion rescue package organized by International Monetary Fund would be inadequate; plunge in rupiah means Indonesia's $65 billion in private, dollar-denominated debt has swelled to exchange levels that borrowers cannot afford to repay; this raises possibility of mass bankruptcies; political uncertainty is another major problem in restoring confidence in country's economy; fall of rupiah was spurred by hints from Pres Suharto that he would name as his Vice President B J Habibie, man widely distrusted by investors because of his unorthodox economic views and record of fostering expensive and unrealistic projects; photo; graph (M)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Says Earnings Will Fall Short of Estimates
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc warns that it expects to fall significantly short of earnings estimates for the year; company says Robert C Nakasone, its president and chief operating officer, will be promoted to chief executive, replacing Michael Goldstein, who will become chairman of the board; Charles Lazarus, company's founder and chairman, will become chairman emeritus and remain on the board (M)

headline: Rao Gazprom and ENI Reach $3 Billion Deal
abstract: Russian and Italian companies sign six accords during visit to Rome by Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin, with biggest deal worth more than $3 billion and involving Rao Gazprom of Russia and Entre Nazionale Idrocarburi, or ENI SpA, of Italy; Yeltsin and Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi preside over signing ceremonies at conference of Russian and Italian businessmen; ENI will invest billions of dollars in cooperation with Gazprom, including joint venture to explore and develop promising reserves in Russia's Astrakhan region in Caspian Sea; ENI is already involved in oil and gas projects in Azerbaijana nd Kazakhstan on Caspian (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: South Korea Over a Hurdle To Stabilize Weak Economy   South Korea has cleared a crucial hurdle in its effort to stabilize its battered economy, paying off or extending a large portion of debt it owes foreign banks.

headline: Castro's Spin: Pope Is on Our Side
abstract: Analysis of Pres Fidel Castro's effort to convince Cubans that he and revolution he leads will benefit from Pope John Paul II's visit, which looks to rest of world like challenge to Castro; Castro has been so adept at co-opting visit that most Cubans think he sponsors it; photo (M)

headline: Aetna Is Said To Seek Deal In Health Care
abstract: Aetna Inc, one of nation's largest insurers, is in talks to buy NYLCare Health Plans, health care unit of New York Life Insurance, in deal that would be valued at about $1 billion; Aetna is seeking to sell its life insurance and focus increasing on health care operations; NYLCare provides coverage to about 2.5 million people, about 1.5 million of them in managed care networks; it provides coverage in every state but is strongest in metropolitan New York, Washington-Baltimore region and in Texas; company lost $30 million last year (M)

headline: Market Place; SmithKline-Glaxo Failure Dampens Merger Talk and Drug Stocks
abstract: Outlook for drug stocks discussed in light of collapse of merger talks between SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome; collapse ends merger pressure on American pharmaceutical companies; stocks of two companies and most American drug makers fall (M)

headline: Time Warner Exercises Canal Plus Option
abstract: Time Warner Inc says its Warner Brothers Television International unit exercised option to buy 10 percent of Canal Plus SA's satellite pay-television company, giving it foothold in Europe's emerging digital television market; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: April contract for platinum jumps $15.80, to $388 an ounce; palladium also rises; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Judge Stays His Ruling On Long-Distance Service
abstract: Federal Judge Joe Kendall temporarily stays his year-end decision that invalidated major portions of Telecommunication Act of 1996; action keeps telecommunications industry in regulatory status it had before Dec 31, when Kendall ruled that local Bell telephone companies should be allowed to sell long-distance service without passing rigorous review by Federal Communications Commission; that process was cornerstone of act, and in ruling that portions forcing review unconstitutional, Kendall throws into question entire structure of telecommunicationss regulation in US (L)

headline: Six Leaders In East Africa Agree to Build Democracies
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with six East African leaders in Entebbe, Uganda, and secures commitment from them to work toward building more democratic governments in their countries and to prevent genocide in strife-torn region; leaders are Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda, Laurent Kabila of Congo, Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia, Yoweri K Museveni of Uganda, Daniel arap Moi of Kenya and Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Faces Hard Choice as Suharto Balks at Economic Reform
abstract: Clinton Adm concludes that Pres Suharto of Indonesia has once again put effort to rescue his country wildly off track, ignoring most of commitments he signed six weeks ago with IMF; Suharto's continued refusal to enact economic and political reforms he committed to in return for $43 billion bailout presents Clinton Adm with tough choice; they must either threaten to suspend huge rescue program and risk further collapse of Indonesian economy--and further outbreaks of violence--or let Suharto undermine fund's credibility by taking its money and ignoring its dictates; former Vice Pres Walter Mondale to visit with Suharto next week (M)

headline: EDITORS' NOTE
abstract: Editors' Note regarding Investing It article Jan 18 about child-care industry; analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities recommended Corporate Family Solutions, but article should have noted that Nationsbanc took company public and has a stake in it; name of another company mentioned is Bright Horizons, not Bright Horizons Children's Centers

headline: Influential Sudan Official Is Killed in Plane Crash
abstract: Lieut Gen al-Zubeir Mohammed Saley, Sudan's influential and populist Vice President, is killed when plane carrying several military officers and politicians crashes as it tries to land in southern town of Nasir; it is major blow to Islamic party that controls country; at least seven other people, including provincial governor and former rebel leader who had switched sides, are killed when plane crashes in bad weather; map (M)

headline: Market Place; It was a quartarius horribilis for Asian stocks but a wash in America and Europe.
abstract: Market Place column on how stock markets fared in fourth quarter of 1997; focuses on huge declines in Asian markets; says American stocks posted modest gain on the quarter, as did stocks in several major European markets measured in local currency; graphs (L)

headline: NOMURA PULLS OUT OF BRITISH UTILITY TALKS
abstract: Nomura International PLC withdraws from takeover talks with Energy Group PLC, balking at cost of topping offer from Pacificorp of 6.43 billion pounds ($10.68 billion) in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: A consortium of independent grocers is stepping up efforts to compete with supermarket chains.
abstract: Advertising column describes stepped-up marketing and advertising effort by consortium of 2,200 independent grocers under IGA Inc to compete for shoppers with large supermarket chains (M)

headline: Putting Steel In Diplomacy
abstract: Analysis of Clinton Administration's slow-paced move toward military strike on Iraq; cites time needed to put military force in place and hope that credible threat of force will produce diplomatic progress; notes continual and unconditional inspections demanded by United States would do better job of ending threat that Iraq will use weapons of mass destruction than riskier military action; photo (L)

headline: Economic Scene; The I.M.F. must go, critics say, but who will cope with crises?
abstract: Economic Scene column on growing sentiment in world economic community that International Monetary Fund must go; says in wake of IMF's failure to predict crisis in Asia or resolve it promptly, movers and shakers of international finance have distanced themselves from the fund; holds first among demands of IMF's newly empowered critics is end to secrecy that shrouds the fund; says there is push to streamline fund's decision-making, allowing managers to short-circuit elaborate consultative procedures now in place so they can react to financial panic in days rather than weeks; holds everybody wants IMF to exact money from private bank lenders, who have generally gotten most of their money back after IMF intervenes; says US Congress is unlikely to approve $18 billion in financial commitments to embattled lender unless internal reform is put at top of IMF's agenda; drawing (L)

headline: South Korean Unions to Accept Some Layoffs
abstract: Labor leaders agree for first time that some layoffs will be needed to rescue South Korea's economy and satisfy International Monetary Fund's stringent conditions for $57 billion bailout, meeting with industry and Government leaders; do not agree to widespread job cuts required by IMF deal, holding labor will accept adjustments in work hours and salaries to minimize layoffs; Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung scores reorganization plans set by two of largest conglomerates as insufficient (M)

headline: After a Battle, Israel President Is Re-elected
abstract: Israeli Parliament re-elects Ezer Weizman to second five-year term as President after unexpectedly charged campaign for largely ceremonial office; Weizman beats back challenge by Likud party candidate Shaul Amor; photo (M)

headline: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL TO ACQUIRE A. P. GREEN INDUSTRIES
abstract: Global Industrial Technologies Inc to acquire A P Green Industries, Mexico, Mo, in deal valued at $195 million (S)

headline: Theodore Schultz, 95, Winner Of a Key Prize in Economics
abstract: Theodore W Schultz, economist at University of Chicago who won Nobel Memorial Prize in 1979, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Introduces Key Banking Changes
abstract: Indonesia's Finance Ministry announces package of measures intended to restart flow of money into economy, as banking system slows almost to a halt; package includes guarantees on bank deposits, end to all curbs on foreign ownership of banks, and creation of special agency that would rehabilitate ailing banks; banking changes are not considered cure-all for deep economic damage that has also become political crisis in Indonesia, causing widespread loss of confidence; uncertainty about political future of Pres Suharto has made investors unwilling to do business with Indonesia (M)

headline: 3 Top Cabinet Members Lobby Congress for I.M.F. and U.N.
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen, Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin warn that US economic and security interests would suffer badly if Congress fails to approve new financing for International Monetary Fund and pay its back dues to United Nations; they go to Capitol Hill to plead for $18 billion for monetary fund, nearly $1 billion for UN and $2.5 billion for military costs in Bosnia and Persian Gulf and for disaster relief (M)

headline: Jakarta Journal; Weighty Past Pins the Wings of a Social Butterfly
abstract: Interview with former Indonesian First Lady, Dewi Sukarno, who has been widowed since 1970 and says she is still struggling for new identity after marriage to Indonesia's founder and late strongman; photo (M)

headline: No Need to Humiliate Iraq, The Secretary General Says
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, urging flexibility in finding peaceful solution to Iraqi crisis, holds UN should not insist on humiliating Pres Saddam Hussein; sounds his strongest reservations yet about military option; Britain circulates document about Iraqi chemical weapon not previously mentioned publicly by UN inspectors (M)

headline: Robust Sales News Snaps 4-Day Bond Rally
abstract: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds snap four-day rally; 30-year bond falls 29/32, to price of 104 23/32; yield rises to 5.78 percent from 5.72 percent on Jan 6; graph (M)

headline: Firstplus Buys Texas Unit
abstract: Firstplus Financial Group Inc says it bought Regional Management Corp's Texas consumer finance business; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: New Tinderbox, Same Fuse: A Serb Comes Full Circle
abstract: Analysis of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic's drive to crush budding uprising by ethnic Albanian majority in Serbia's Kosovo province; discusses threat that violence could knindle wider Balkan war; Milosevic has used Kosovo issue before, beginning with his 1987 transformation into Serbian nationalist leader (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar falls against German mark and Japanese yen; graphs; table (S)ú

headline: Settlement By Exchange Is Questioned
abstract: Bruce C Levine, administrative law judge, says agreement arranged between officials of New York Mercantile Exchange and Manhattan lawyer Scott M Brenner, who sued exchange in 1995, is 'certainly unethical' and violates Federal regulations; exchange officials and Brenner agreed they would settle case that was brought on behalf of trader if Brenner agreed to never again sue the exchange; Levine refers case to New York State Bar Association and Federal regulators for further review; exchange officials and lawyers named by judge for ethical violations are Daniel Rappaport, chairman, R Patrick Thompson, president, Ronald Oppenheimer, former general counsel of exchange and now general counsel at Merrill Lynch and Martin I Kaminsky, outside lawyer for exchange, and Brenner (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * DKB & Partners, Morristown, N.J., was awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at $16 million: Public Service Electric and Gas Co., Newark, to handle product and service advertising and promotion; MD Foods, Union, N.J., to handle advertising for the dairy company, which had been handled by FDN&P Advertising, Whitehouse Station, N.J., and NYU Downtown Hospital, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising to promote a recent name change and affiliation with NYU Medical Center.

headline: Disappointing Raises Set for Japan's Workers
abstract: Annual ritual of wage negotiations taking place this week in Japan is seen one more sign of depths of Japan's economic distress; raises will be coming, but labor officials are all but certain that average rate of increase in wages will fall below 2.9 percent increase that workers received last year; this year's rate of increase will be about 2.7 percent, giving rise to fears that workers are losing ground; graph (M)

headline: Amoco to Split Stock 2 for 1
abstract: Amoco Corp says it will split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend by 7 percent (S)

headline: Allen B. Morgan, 89, Banker in Tennessee
abstract: Allen B Morgan, former chairman and chief executive of First Tennessee Bank, dies at age of 89 (S)

headline: PHARMACOPEIA IN STOCK DEAL FOR MOLECULAR SIMULATIONS
abstract: Pharmacopeia Inc agrees to buy Molecular Simulations Inc for about $140 million (S)

headline: Trade Group Is Opposing Bank Measure
abstract: American Bankers Association, Washington trade group that represents nation's largest banks, says it opposes bill intended to break down barriers that separate banking, insurance and securities businesses; association says bill is problematic because it would weaken regulatory authority of Comptroller of the Currency, whose office charters national banks and who has historically been advocate of allowing banks to pursue new lines of business; group also cites concerns that bill would allow state insurance regulators to limit banks' ability to sell insurance in favor of local insurance agents and that it would give Securities and Exchange Commission unwanted authority to define banking products (L)

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 3 Arabs at Checkpoint, Setting Off New Clashes
abstract: Israeli soldiers kill three Palestinians at checkpoint between West Bank and Israel, setting off street clashes in Hebron and raising fears of new round of violence that could further set back peace efforts; two Israeli soldiers are arrested in shooting, and Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu telephones Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to express his condolences and to promise investigation (M)

headline: Militant Jews Start Melee By Marching In Hebron
abstract: Jewish militants march into Palestinian-controlled area of Hebron, touching off melee in which 12 Palestinians, including several journalists, are hurt; bomb explodes in largely Arab section of Jerusalem's Old City, lightly wounding four people; police quickly converge on area to preclude rioting; report of blast touches off stone-throwing by Palestinians in Hebron, Dura and Nablus; Palestinian police try to turn back rioters (M)

headline: MATRIX CAPITAL TO BUY LEADER MORTGAGE FOR $32 MILLION
abstract: Matrix Capital Corp acquires Leader Mortgage Co for $32 million (S)

headline: When Rage Is All the Rage
abstract: Employers begin addressing the problem of anger in the workplace, giving rise to cottage industry of therapists, speakers and so-called rage gurus; photo (M)

headline: Exel to Buy Rest of Mid Ocean In a Deal by Bermuda Insurers
abstract: Exel Ltd says it will pay $2.1 billion in stock for 75 percent of Mid Ocean Ltd it does not own to increase its size and help attract larger clients (M)

headline: Crisis in Asia and Rail Delays Hurt Manufacturing in December
abstract: National Assn of Purchasing Management reports that manufacturing activity slowed in December as economic crisis in Asia and rail traffic delays in United States hurt orders and production; industry group's main index declined to 52.5 in December, its lowest rading since January 1997, from 54.5 in November (S)

headline: Cathay Pacific May Cut More Jobs, Officials Say
abstract: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd plans to dismiss employees in second wave of job cuts this year; airline may eliminate as many as 1,000 employees, or 7 percent of its workers (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AETNA INC., Hartford, purchased 49 percent of Seguros Mercantil, a Venezuela-based insurance company, for about $30 million in order to enter the country's recently formed pension fund industry.    RECYCLING INDUSTRIES, Englewood, Colo., a supplier of raw materials, agreed to buy the remaining 50 percent of United Metal-D. H. Griffin Recyclers L.L.C. it does not already own for an undisclosed price.

headline: DIARY
abstract: MARKETS  Higher Still and Higher  Ignoring earnings warnings from several companies -- most recently, Sunbeam and Rockwell International -- investors kept bidding up stock prices, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to five consecutive records. The Dow ended the week at 8,906.43, up 303.91. Behind the market's gains are low interest rates, low inflation and bullish analysts. Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised her 1998 Dow target to 9,300. . . . The boards of the National Association of Securities Dealers, and the American Stock Exchange backed merger plans. Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the N.A.S.D., said a market of markets would result. The N.A.S.D. promised to invest at least $110 million in technology and other improvements if it takes control of the Amex.

headline: Gene-Engineered Anthrax: Is It a Weapon?
abstract: American scientists will seek to determine whether new form of anthrax created by Russians through genetic engineering is merely theoretical or a practical weapon and whether it is able to defeat the vaccine American troops will soon get to protect them from anthrax (M)

headline: WPP Group Buys 2 Specialist Agencies
abstract: WPP Group acquires two agencies specializing in consulting on high-technology marketing--MSI Channel Research and Consulting and Charles River Strategies Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: On Line and Personal: Wanna Make a Baby?
abstract: New Life, new Web site, is database created to let its members search one another's personality profiles for like-minded individuals looking for mate to help raise child, for sperm or egg donor, or for surrogate mother; photo (M)

headline: $1.4 Billion Boeing Charge to Force First Yearly Loss Since '47
abstract: Boeing Co says it will take $1.4 billion pretax charge against earnings for fourth quarter of 1997 related to merger with Mcdonnell Douglas Corp; charge compounds one of Boeing's worst annual financial performances in 50 years; combined with $2.6 billion in charges announced in October, Boeing has effectively written off about half of its shareholder equity in last three months as it struggles with production problems in manufacture of its flagship commercial jets (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AGCO CORP., a farm-machinery maker in Atlanta, named John Shumejda president and chief operating officer.     AVON PRODUCTS INC., New York, named Robert Corti chief financial officer, succeeding Edwina Woodbury, who will now concentrate on redesigning the company's computer systems.

headline: Felcor Suite Agrees to Purchase Bristol's Hotels
abstract: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc agrees to buy Bristol Hotel Co's hotel properties for almost $1.2 billion in stock and assumption of $700 million of debt, making it largest owner of Holiday Inns and expanding it beyond all-suite hotels (M)

headline: Nigerians Take Capital of Sierra Leone as Junta Flees
abstract: Nigerian forces take Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, forcing country's military junta to fly and clearing way for return of its elected President, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah; junta members are forced to land near Monrovia, Liberia, and are taken into custody at a Nigerian-run base; photo of refugees arriving in Conakry, Guinea; map (M)

headline: Income Up 11% At Abbott Labs
abstract: Abbott Laboratories says that net income, lifted by increased sale of drugs and hospital products, rose 11 percent in fourth quarter, matching expectations; posts net income of $567 million, or 74 cents a basic share; Abbott reports only basic earnings per share; spokesman says that figure for diluted earnings per share will be disclosed only in company's annual report (S)

headline: Serbs Force a Crude Burial For 51 Left Dead in Kosovo
abstract: Witnesses say Serbian police dumped bodies of 51 ethnic Albanians killed in Kosovo province into graves and bulldozed earth; forced burials deny families chance to have autopsies performed and to hold funerals; map; photo (M)

headline: FIRST DATA BUYS A UNIT FROM, AND SELLS ONE TO, CERIDIAN
abstract: The First Data Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the gambling division of the Ceridian Corporation and that Ceridian had bought First Data's NTS transportation-services unit. Terms were not disclosed. Ceridian's gambling services unit provides credit card, debit card and money transfer help for 800 casinos and their customers. It will be integrated with Telecheck Services Inc., a check-acceptance company owned by First Data, which is based in Hackensack, N.J. Ceridian, of Minneapolis, will combine First Data's NTS transportation services business with its Comdata unit. NTS provides transaction services related to fund transfers, fuel purchases and permits to the trucking industry.

headline: Hopping On the Dow Bus
abstract: Waterhouse Securities will begin selling mutual fund in March that mimics Dow Jones industrial average; new fund, Strong Dow 30 Value, which started on Jan 5, mimics average with half its assets and invests rest using Dow-linked strategies; Diamonds Trust, which began trading on Jan 20, mimics average; chart (L)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., named Mark Begor chief financial officer of its NBC television network unit effective immediately, succeeding Warren Jenson, who is leaving to become chief financial officer of Delta Air Lines Inc.

headline: 2 Charged With Insider Trading Of Lotus Stock In '95 Scheme
abstract: Federal prosecutors bring first insider trading charges after probe into possible illegal trading that occurred in shares of Lotus Development Corp before it was bought by IBM in 1995; Robert M Cassano and Gerad P Mazzone are accused of participating in schemes that generated $200,000 in illegal profits for total of six people; schemes allegedly stemmed from leak from IBM employee, a relative of Cassano's, concerning IBM's confidential plans to buy Lotus; relative has not been identified; Cassano is accused of passing merger information on to Mazzone, and suggesting that he buy shares of Lotus and secretly share any profits with him; Mazzone is said to have told three other people about pending Lotus offer; Mazzone is also charged with witness tampering and perjury in connection with his attempts to dissuade witness from testifying truthfully to Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: Gustavo Lobo, 92, Commodities Executive
abstract: Gustavo F Lobo Jr, leading commodities executive for 57 years, dies at age of 92 (S)

headline: Microsoft Profit Gained Sharply During Quarter
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports strong growth in earnings in its fiscal second quarter, a 53 percent increase in profits from year earlier, to $1.13 billion, on revenues of $3.59 billion, up 34 percent; Microsoft warns that weakness in Asian economies might reduce its revenues by $300 million in first half of 1998 from its own internal targets, trimming earnings by up to 15 cents a share over two quarters; Asia represents 13 percent of Microsoft's sales; company's comments about impact of Asian crisis echo pessimistic tone of other high-technology companies; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- A Stock Crusader In a Short-Seller Suit; He Says Blunt Talk Fights Fraud, But Critics Say He Talks Too Much
abstract: Market Place column on Manuel P Asensio, who makes a living betting that certain stocks will fall; says Asensio has drawn attention to himself by publicly challenging some companies' claims; notes Asensio dismisses criticism of his practices, maintaining that his blunt talk fights fraud; also notes that in 1996 Asensio attacked claims by Diana Corp, now called Coyote Network Systems, that it had innovative Internet technology; says eventually Diana collapsed and stock was kicked off New York Stock Exchange; notes fiercest battle Asensio has undertaken thus far is against Avant, software company; photo (L)

headline: I.M.F. Opposing Indonesia's Plan For Currency
abstract: International Monetary Fund managing director Michel Camdessus seeks to veto Indonesia's risky plan to lock value of its beleaguered currency to that of dollar under currency board mechanism; stand sets up showdown with Pres Suharto, whose family would benefit if strategy worked; Suharto meets with economist Steven Hanke, leading advocate of currency board; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Will Revise European Contracts Amid an Investigation
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it will revise contracts with two dozen European Internet service providers to drop requirement that they offer their customers Microsoft's World Wide Web browser in return for being listed in Windows 95 operating system; move is likely to persuade European Commission to drop its antitrust inquiry; new contracts will allow consumers to choose different Web browser, including Microsoft's biggest competitor, Netscape Communication Corp's Navigator; new accord should be boon to Netscape (M)

headline: ITT and Cuban Investors
abstract: letter from ITT Corp vice president, secretary and general counsel Richard S Ward disputes December 7 article on company's receipt of millions of dollars in reparations from Telecom Italia, company active in Cuba (S)

headline: The Risks and Rituals of Doing Lunch
abstract: Readers offer anecdotes about business lunches; drawing (M)

headline: S.E.C. Charges A Former Broker
abstract: Kerrigan Sean Weber, 51, former broker at Smith Barney Inc, is charged by SEC with failing to invest customers' checks worth $245,459 and falsely telling clients he planned to buy stocks with their money (S)

headline: Kodak Cuts Chairman's Pay to $2 Million
abstract: Pay of chairman and chief executive of Eastman Kodak Co, George M C Fisher, was cut in half last year to $2 million, as company withheld his bonus after disappointing 1997 performance; Fisher did receive options and shares worth estimated $64 million, as well as $1.82 million in interest forgiven on loans and $27,180 for life insurance premiums; Kodak stock fell 25 percent last year and net income plunged to just $5 million after $1.5 billion charge related to plan to eliminate 19,900 jobs, or 20 percent of work force (S)

headline: KODAK TO INVEST $1 BILLION IN CHINA FOR MANUFACTURING
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co will invest more than $1 billion in China in next several years to make film and paper (S)

headline: Strong Home Sales Report Pushes Price of 30-Year Issue Down
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities fall after stronger-than-expected home sales report for February raises investors' concerns about how long Federal Reserve can refrain from raising interest rates; price of 30-year bond drops 27/32, to 102 5/8; yield rises to 5.94 percent, from 5,88 percent on March 24; graphs (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Fall Sharply Following Intel Warning  Stock investors rushed to sell yesterday in the aftermath of a late Wednesday warning from the technology leader Intel that its first-quarter results would fail to meet expectations.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: In the Data Storage Race, Disks Are Outpacing Chips
abstract: Disk storage, one of computer industry's oldest technologies, is in midst of remarkable renaissance; disk drive engineers, making gains in storage density that outpace semiconductor density gains, are now suggesting replacing computer memory chips in many devices with tiny disk drives; graphs; photos (M)

headline: 2 Agencies to Focus On Direct Marketing
abstract: Major changes are made in direct marketing operations at Lowe & Partners/SMS and at JWT Direct New York (S)

headline: Charges of Incompetence and Laxity Are Leveled at Fragmented Forces : Belgian Police Face Growing Distrust
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Passengers leaving the Anderlecht Metro station in Brussels on a recent evening were subjected to an unusually stringent ticket control.

headline: Cathay Pacific Shares Plunge on Forecasts
abstract: Stock of Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd declines as analysts slash their 1998 profit forecasts because last year's earnings fell 55.5 percent (S)

headline: When Management Goes in Circles, or in Metaphors
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews new books on business management; photo (M)s

headline: Israel's 50th Anniversary Preparations Are Mired in Squabbling
abstract: Israel's planning for its 50th anniversary celebration is in disarray, as Tourism Min Moshe Katsav resigns role in effort, citing negative stories leaked to press by Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's office; agrees not to quit Government after Netanyahu condemns press attacks; resignation follows successive resignations of three directors of planning committee, which is mired in political, budgetary and personal squabbles; date of formal start of celebration has been changed several times and many events canceled or changed (M)

headline: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE DECLINES TO BACK OFFERS
abstract: American Bankers Insurance Group Inc board declines to back rival bids from either American International Group Inc or Cendant Corp; sues Cendant, charging it bolsters offer with 'campaign of misinformation' (S)

headline: Hopes for Peace Talks Dim As Israel Extends Settlement
abstract: Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel attends cornerstone-laying ceremony for new extension of Jewish settlement at Beit El on West Bank; United States has repeatedly called for 'timeout' on settlement building to smooth path for upcoming talks between Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat when they travel to Washington to meet with Pres Clinton in late January; Mordechai claims new construction is to accommodate natural growth of Beit El, and not meant as political signal to US or Palestinians; Hanan Ashrawi, minister in Palestinian cabinet, calls Israeli settlement expansion a deathknell for peace efforts; map (M)

headline: VW Shares Surge As Stock Plan Is Cut
abstract: Shares of Volkswagen AG surge after company says it has canceled half of planned $3.3 billion share sale and indicates fourth-quarter profit more than doubled; graph (S)

headline: The Reformers Did It. No, Blame the Bankers.
abstract: Alessandra Stanley analysis contends that when Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin dismissed his entire Cabinet, question was not just why, but who was really behind decision; maintains that bombshell mostly appears to be messy blend of Yeltsin's will and wishes of some of his closest advisers; says that while some observers paint decision as backstage maneuver by powerful bankers seeking to consolidate their influence, economic reformers chose to view shake-up as small victory for their team; photo (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 2.8% on Nasdaq for Month
abstract: Open positions on short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose 2.8 percent, to 1.820 million, as of mid-February; in January, uncovered short sales declined slightly, to 1.77 million; charts (S)

headline: BOEING WILL BE 5 PLANES SHORT OF FIRST-QUARTER GOAL
abstract: Boeing Co says it will miss its delivery goals for first quarter by five planes, as production bottlenecks on its 737 assembly line persist; total of 110 aircraft will be delivered in first quarter (S)

headline: Memos Said to Detail Reuters Effort to Obtain Bloomberg Data
abstract: Federal prosecutors obtain more than 100 written communications between American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings PLC and consulting company suspected of being hired to steal information from computers of competitor, Bloomberg LP; they have memos from subsidiary, Reuters Analytics Inc, requesting detailed information about technical programs for analyzing investments; consultant allegedly broke into Bloomberg's corporate computers electronically and obtained information, then passed it to Reuters, sometimes directly to parent company's London headquarters; computer consulting company, whose name is not yet determined, was said to be founded by former Bloomberg employee; Reuters has already placed three executives in subsidiary on paid leave in wake of scandal; from its earliest days, Reuters Analytics has faced accusations that it used unsavory business practices to obtain other companies' technologies (M)

headline: Ruling by Federal Judge on Leasing Planes Worries Airline Industry
abstract: Unexpected ruling by Federal Judge John L Kane Jr in Colorado severely weakens provision in bankruptcy code that gives special protection to companies that finance airplane purchases and lease airplanes; ruling increases risks associated with financing and leasing airplanes, threatening to depress value of billions of dollars worth of deals and to make it harder for new and financially troubled airlines to get airplanes; decision stems from appeal of bankruptcy court ruling by Western Pacific Airlines and Smith Management Inc, investment firm that invested more than $24 million in carrier after it filed for Chapter 11 (M)

headline: Quebec Liberal Quits, Unsettling Canadian Politics
abstract: Surprise resignation of Daniel Johnson, leader of anti-separatist Liberal Party in Quebec, unleashes political turmoil across Canada; Johnson acknowledges he is not the man to stand up to Quebec's popular Premier, Lucien Bouchard; strong victory by separatists would allow Bouchard to call third referendum on Quebec's bid to separate from rest of Canada; speculation on who would replace Johnson turns to Jean Charest, solid anti-separatist who believes way to keep Quebec in Canada is to convince Quebeckers they are better off remaining (M)

headline: Delta Woodside To Shed Units
abstract: Delta Woodside Industries says it will sell or close its three Stevecoknit fabric plants and sell its Nautilus International fitness unit to focus on textiles and apparel; says it will not be able to place all 1,000 former Stevecoknit employees elswhere within Delta Woodside (M)

headline: Indian Congress Party Picks Sonia Gandhi
abstract: India's Congress Party elects Sonia Gandhi president, re-affirming family dynasty that has long governed party; she scores Hindu nationalists as 'threat' to secular ideals of independence leaders, speech; Hindu nationalists, after days of uncertainty, win support of Jayalalitha Jayaram, whose control of 27 parliamentary seats makes her key to their efforts to win parliamentary majority; she accompanies letter of support with fierce denunciation of nationalist leaders (M)

headline: On Taxes, Count on Congress for More Discussion but No Big Changes
abstract: Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 has been described by many experts as badly drafted mess that actually adds complexity and creates burdens for many people, especialy those with modest incomes; one fact remains unchanged: share of national economic pie going to taxes continues to enlarge, despite half century of talk by politicians of both parties who portray themselves as tax cutters; graph (M)

headline: But Middle-Level Retailers Hard Hit by Crisis : Luxury Goods Still Strong in Asia
abstract: HONG KONG—  A year and half ago it seemed that Asia's retail boom would never stop. Each new designer entry into the market was greeted by enthusiastic consumers eager to sport the latest international labels. Few anticipated that the party would come to such an abrupt halt.

headline: For Ohioans, Hussein Must Go, But Bombs May Not Be the Way
abstract: Most residents of Columbus, Ohio, where US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and Defense Sec William S Cohen will hold town meeting on possible military strikes against Iraq, say US should take action, but express doubt and almost universal exasperation that American forces might once again be placed in harm's way; there is sense off weariness and outrage over image of dangerous despot like Saddam Husein tweaking US, but also anguish over best course to follow; photos (M)

headline: Baghdad's Ability to Sell Oil Is Hurt by Poor Maintenance
abstract: Iraqi officials say that nation's oil production system has deteriorated so badly during years of economic sanctions that it cannot take full advantage of recent Security Council resolution allowing Baghdad to more than double its oil sales; Oil Min Amir Mohammed Rasheed says Iraq could export no more than $4 billion worth of oil over six months, unless sanctions are eased allowing it to buy new equipment (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TODAY'S MAN INC., Moorestown, N.J., the men's apparel retailer, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after obtaining financing to pay off its creditors.

headline: Sybase Eliminates 600 Jobs In a Move to Restore Profits
abstract: Sybase Inc, struggling to regain profitability, has dismissed nearly 600 employees, or about 10 percent of its worldwide work force; cutbacks are expected to save company $100 million annually; Sybase reports loss of $25.5 million for quarter ended Dec 31, compared with earnings of $5.1 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue fell 17 percent, to $223.2 million, from $267.8 million in fourth quarter of 1996 (M)

headline: PROFILE; Aiming Camera at Web, and Himself
abstract: Profile of documentary filmmaker Doug Block, whose film Home Page is evolving from study of self-revelation on Web to account of how Web has inspired him to re-examine important connections in his life; his own home page is playing crucial role in evolution; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Austere Japan Budget Stirs Recession Fear  Japan's lower house of Parliament approved a budget that could squeeze money out of the economy just as the nation is careening toward a recession. Despite pleas from the United States and other trading partners of Japan, the budget provides no additional spending or tax cuts.

headline: HASBRO TO CLOSE PLANT THAT MAKES SCRABBLE LETTERS
abstract: Hasbro Inc plans to close Fairfax, Vt, plant that makes letter tiles for Scrabble board game and dismiss 87 workers (S)7

headline: Ju Tang Chu, 97, Chinese Banks' Ex-Head
abstract: Ju Tang Chu, retired chairman of Shanghai Commercial Bank, now based in Hong Kong, and Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank, now based in Taipei, Taiwan, dies at age 97 (S)

headline: Economic Scene; In the economy's success, don't forget somy lucky breaks.
abstract: Economic Scene column on success of US economy focuses on some lucky breaks that have helped economic expansion; says first was Soviet Union's disintegration and end of cold war, which unleashed a much greater worldwide output of goods and services; then came Asian crisis, which suppressed demand in Asia without suppressing supply; and finally, there is year-long decline in oil prices, also a case of more supply than demand; drawing (L)

headline: OSHKOSH TRUCK ADDS MCNEILUS FOR $250 MILLION
abstract: Oshkosh Truck Corp buys McNeilus Companies, Dodge Center, Minn, for $250 million as it expands into garbage- and construction-truck business (S)

headline: A Wink and a Prayer: Netanyahu's Hope
abstract: Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel fails to attend scheduled meeting with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, prompting speculation they he might defect from Government; defection by Mordechai could topple Netanyahu's coalition, since resignation of Foreign Min David Levy and his five-man faction has left it with one-vote majority in Parliament (M)

headline: UNIVERSAL FOREST TO BUY STRUCTURAL SUPPORTS MAKER
abstract: Universal Forest Products Inc says it will buy Shoffner Industries for $90.7 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: TEL-SAVE SEES A STRONG CHANCE IT WILL STAY INDEPENDENT
abstract: Tel-Save Holdings Inc, long-distance telephone service provider that last month hired Salomon Smith Barney for advice on possible sale, says that there is 'strong possibility' it will remain independent (S)

headline: In the Race for the Fastest Chip, Just Don't Blink
abstract: Digital news roundup; Apple Computer and Intel demonstrate high-speed prototype computer chips; high-resolution digital cameras, which formerly cost over $10,000, are now being offered at under $1,000; Circuit City electronics retail chain ends policy of offering 30 days of free technical support for personal computer buyers; France, which earlier denounced Internet because not enough of content is in French, declares two-day festival to show off its World Wide Web pages (M)2

headline: 1997 Sets the Bar High
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 20 percent in 1997, for the third consecutive year, something that had never happened. Can the financial markets ring up another stellar year? Part Two.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: March silver contract drops 16.3 cents, to $5.475 an ounce; in last three sessions, price has fallen 9 percent amid rumors of price manipulation over last six months; from July 16 to Dec 24, 1997, price of silver jumped almost 52 percent; graph (S)

headline: Internet Group Challenges U.S. Over Web Addresses
abstract: Internet Society, nonprofit organization whose members are drawn largely from technical community, objects to Federal Government having sole voice on crucial issue of naming addresses on Internet; at stake is who can assign Internet domain names--addresses ending in '.com' and other suffixes that define identity in cyberspace; Council of Registrars argues that seven new domains are necessary so organizations not quick enough or rich enough to register domain identity of their choice could have more options; Ira Magaziner, Clinton Administration's chief Internet adviser, is likely to endorse only one new domain name, while moving to establish nonprofit organization to oversee new competitive system for domain registrars (M)

headline: Seoul Journal; Korea Deflated, but a Diplomat's Hopes Are High
abstract: Interview with Stephen W Bosworth, new US Ambassador to South Korea; photo (M)

headline: World News Briefs; Solo American Balloonist Races Across Atlantic
abstract: Steve Fossett's Solo Spirit balloon, racing along at up to 161 miles per hour, reaches Europe barely two days after ascending from St Louis (S)

headline: Turkish Premier Confronts Military Over Islam
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Mesut Yilmaz, after surviving attempt by religious conservatives to bring down his Govt this week, is confronting an even more powerful group: the military commanders who effectively put him into office last year, and military is pushing back; Islamic-oriented members of Parliament try to topple Yilmaz after his Education Minister ordered ban on wearing of head scarves by female university students; motion fails; Yilmaz has expressed ambivalence about ban on head scarves, which military commanders view as symbols of religious fundamentalism; in recent days, military commanders have complained that Yilmaz is not fighting hard enouh against fundamentalism (M)

headline: Glaxo and SmithKline Talks Send Share Prices Soaring
