abstract: Expectation of possible merger of Glaxo Wellcome with SmithKline Beecham lofts American depository receipts of both companies and helps lift share prices of other major drug companies; it also puts abrupt end to merger talks that had been taking place between SmithKline and American Home Products; American Home expected to look for another deal (M)

headline: U.S. Says Force Will Be Set To Launch Strike in a Week
abstract: Gen Anthony C Zinni, commander of American forces in Persian Gulf, says United States will be ready within about week to launch attack that would seek to weaken Saddam Hussein's hold on power in Iraq, interview; completes trip to region with Defense Sec William S Cohen; he and Cohen stress US prefers diplomatic solution to crisis over United Nations arms inspections; Cohen aide says he won private authorization for variety of specific military activities in region (M)

headline: S.E.C. Studies Whether Mutual Funds Pass Along Merger Benefits
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission's director Barry Barbash has begun study of whether mutual funds are passing along to investors the benefits of recent wave of fund company mergers, particularly in form of lower fees, address to conference of mutual fund executives, Orlando, Fla (M)

headline: Blue-Chip Issues in Retreat; Dow Off 30.64, to 8,129.71
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 30.64 points, to 8,129.71; Standard & Poor's 500 index gains 0.90 point, to record 1,006.90; Nasdaq composite index rises 14.10 points, to 1,680.44; graph; chart (L)

headline: Peregrine Considers Deal With Chinese
abstract: Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd says it might sell parts of its profitable equity business to a Chinese company; declines to name which companies might be involved (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Bonds May Win the Catbird Seat
abstract: Tumble in long-term bond rates in early days of 1998 could be beginning of good news for investors who have been moving holdings into bond funds, seeking haven from world's tumultuous equity markets; graph (L)

headline: Seeking to Open a Door to U.S., Iranian Proposes Cultural Ties
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami proposes cultural exchanges as way to end years of mistrust between Iran and US, but rules out Government-to-Government dialogue, saying there is no need for political ties with Washington; Khatami, in interview with Cable News Network, praises America's civilization, but he also attacks American policy towards Iran over last half century; he also repeats Iran's long-held opposition to Arab-Israeli peace talks, branding Israel 'racist terrorist regime'; photo (M)

headline: CENTOCOR TO ACQUIRE RIGHTS TO MAKE HEART DRUG
abstract: Centocor Inc to pay $335 million to acquire rights to make cardiovascular drug Retavase in United States and Canada from Roche Holdings AG for $335 million, resulting in pretax charge of up to $145 million (S)

headline: Israel Tries to Hush Clinton on Peace Proposal
abstract: Israeli Cabinet defiantly steps up Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's already furious drive to head off new public peace initiative by Pres Clinton; rejects reported American demand for withdrawal from 13 percent of West Bank; Israel says US envoy Dennis Ross is set to visit; new poll shows majority of Israelis apparently favor increased American involvement in peace process (M)

headline: Island Life Not Idyllic For Youths From U.S.
abstract: Some Dominican Republic parents living in New York area, concerned about drugs and crime, are sending their children back to Dominican Republic to live, where they are cared for by grandparents or other relatives; they hope their children will get better education, and have better opportunities; many of teen-agers describe return to their parents' homeland as wrenching experience (M)

headline: Milk Promoters Agree to Cooperate
abstract: Two national organizations that promote sale of milk agree to create single marketing plan, with combined budget next year of $190 million, to increase total fluid milk sales by 4 percent by 2000 (S)

headline: Acquirer Found for Part Of Failed Japanese Bank
abstract: Chuo Trust and Banking Co of Japan will acquire over 63 branches of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd and hire 1,100 employees of lender, whose collapse in November shook Japan's financial industry (S)

headline: Elf Aquitaine Buys Stake in AO Yuksi Oil
abstract: French energy company Elf Aquitaine acquires 5 percent stake in AO Yuksi Oil Co, Russia's largest oil producer, for $528 million (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE  Don't Be Happy, Worry  Though no one would guess it from listening to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, consumer confidence surged to a 30-year high in February as Americans' satisfaction with low unemployment and strong economic growth overshadowed economic turmoil in Asia and political problems at home. The Conference Board reported that its index of consumer confidence rose to 138.3 in February, from a revised 128.3 in January. The February figure was the highest since October 1968, when it reached 142.3. Consumer sentiment is viewed as important because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's overall economic activity. In testimony before Congress on Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan said, ''Events in the months ahead are not likely to unfold smoothly.'' On Friday, the Commerce Department gave Mr. Greenspan a bit of support, reporting that the American economy ended 1997 by growing at a 3.9 percent annual rate, a downward revision from January's 4.3 percent estimate.

headline: Japanese House Votes to Bail Out Banks
abstract: Lower house of Japanese Parliament approves bills to spend $240 billion to bail out banks; many analysts doubt plan is adequate to resolve nation's financial crisis (M)

headline: Barry Diller, Media Titan, Wants a Shot at the Small Time
abstract: Barry Diller, chairman of newly minted USA Networks Inc wants to return to world of local television; since 1995, Diller has spent $325 million to acquire 18 stations across country, and has used them to broadcast his Home Shopping Network 24 hours a day; he plans to shift Home Shopping Network from those stations to cable and free up broadcast stations to make more money by running high-quality local news and entertainment programs; charts; photos (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Outrigger Hotels, Honolulu, to Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown, Orlando, Fla., to handle its account, which had been handled by Peck Sims, Honolulu. Billings were estimated at more than $4 million.    * Interpublic Group of Cos., New York, to Compelling Content, New York, as the first agency to create and introduce a World Wide Web site (www.interpublic.com) for the agency company. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: HANDY & HARMAN STUDIES SALE OF COMPANY
abstract: Handy & Harman weighs strategies to increase shareholder value, including possible sale of all or parts of company; reports getting several takeover inquiries since WHX Corp made bid in Dec (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold rises above $300 an ounce for first time in two months as dollar weakens; gold for Feb delivery rises $9, to $300.30 an ounce; graphs; table (S)

headline: Bond Prices in Spurt, but Stock Rally Later Trims Gains
abstract: US Treasury prices rise sharply in early trading, stock market rally trims gains; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 20/32, to 106 9/32; yield finishes at 5.69 percent, its lowest level since bond was first regularly issued in 1977; chart; graph (L)

headline: A Turn Away From Eastern Europe?
abstract: Eastern Europe has become world's most expensive emerging market, less attractive to investors than other regions (S)

headline: Is There Life After Wall Street?; Tales of the Players Who Quit the Game
abstract: Profiles of three Wall Street executives who amassed a fortune and retired early so they could get into other careers and pursue their dreams; focuses on Jeff Stambovsky, former managing director at Schroder & Co who is now jazz musician and children's record producer, Christophe J Richter, former bond saleswoman at Nomura Securities who now teaches yoga and runs Body Wisdom, a message therapy studio, and Miles Slater, former president of Salomon Brothers International in London who has become a sculptor; photos (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.38   5.52   5.21        3-month T-bills   4.99   4.98   5.01        6-month T-bills   4.99   4.99   5.11        10-yr. T-infl.   3.65   3.66   N.A.        10-yr. T-note   5.53   5.57   6.58        30-yr. T-bond   5.81   5.84   6.86        Telephone bd.   7.16   7.18   7.87        Municipal bds.   5.13   5.12   5.84          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Disney Policy on Directors Is Criticized
abstract: College Retirement Equities Fund, part of world's largest pension fund, has asked Walt Disney Co to place majority of outsiders on its board; CREF, stock-owning part of TIAA-CREF, says it has filed its resolution on board independence, its first of that type, because it found Disney's definition of independence too lax; Disney says that former employees who have been gone from company for more than three years and directors with personal ties to Disney's chief executive, Michael D Eisner, can be considered outsiders (S)

headline: Nagging Worries on Asia Deflate a Rally on Wall St.
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 13.95, to 7.978.99; economic situation in Far East is factor among investors; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 2.03, to 977.07; Nasdaq composite index gains 12.59, to 1,594.12 (M)

headline: Crisis Grows in Asia As Major Bank Falls
abstract: The largest investment bank in Asia outside Japan was forced to shut down today, the first major casualty of the economic and currency crisis that has swept through the region since the summer. It is the first major bankruptcy in Hong Kong since the territory reverted to Chinese rule in July.

headline: U.S. Treasury Plans to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: Schedule of US Treasury auctions and listing of taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues scheduled for pricing this week (S)

headline: Browser War: A Concession And a Push
abstract: Analysis of Microsoft's concession in high-stakes antitrust battle with Government; settlement will have little effect on competitive landscape in computer industry, because Microsoft has not given an inch on any of larger issues in case; analysts say more significant announcment for software business came from Netscape Communications Corp, Microsoft's main rival in browser market; Netscape says it will distribute its browser products free, and will freely license basic computer code for its browser products to outsiders and let them tailor Netscape technology for their own use; this free licensing, far more than Microsoft settlement, could open door for Netscape's technology being preferred browser used by personal computer makers; Netscape is taking large gamble to try to stop erosion of its share of browser market in face of Microsoft's vast wealth, market power and armies of skilled programmers (M)

headline: PURCHASE OF BORDEN DAIRY UNITS ANNOUNCED
abstract: Nestle SA says that it bought some dairy products units in Latin America and elsewhere from Borden Inc to increase its sales in emerging markets (S)

headline: Financial Chief Is Leaving New York Times Co.
abstract: New York Times Co says Diane P Baker, senior vice president and chief financial officer since September 1995, has resigned, effective March 31; John M O'Brien, senior vice president for operations, is appointed acting chief financial officer while company searches for permanent replacement; Baker says she resigned to spend more time with her family (M)

headline: TREX MEDICAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE FRENCH DENTAL IMAGER
abstract: Trex Medical Corp agrees to acquire Trophy Radiologie, French maker of dental X-ray systems; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Sanwa Bank Investing In Yamaichi Trust Unit
abstract: Sanwa Bank says it will acquire 18.6 percent of shares outstanding in Yamaichi Investment Trust Management Co, bringing its total stake to 20.7 percent (S)

headline: S.E.C. Initially Backs Fidelity Plan to Insure Money Funds
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission gives preliminary approval to plan allowing Fidelity Investments, giant mutual fund company, to establish mutual insurance company to guarantee its money market funds against some losses; Fidelity's proposal calls for its money funds to share cost of insuring against annual losses up to $100 million that are caused by default by issuer of security that some or all of funds own; SEC ruling places limits on how mutual fund can publicize its insured status, partly because insurance is unlikely to cover all of fund's assets; other fund companies and insurers have until Feb 16 to comment on insurance plan, after which SEC will render final decision (M)

headline: Prudential Profit Falls 43% On Life Insurance Problems
abstract: The Prudential Insurance Company of America reported a 43.4 percent drop in profits for 1997 yesterday, as sales of its main product, life insurance, remained depressed and the company set aside more than $1.6 billion to pay policyholders who contend they were deceptively sold insurance they did not need.    Prudential reported net profits for 1997 of $610 million, down from $1.078 billion for 1996.    The company set aside $410 million last year for payments to policyholders, and the money this year brings to $2.05 billion the total that the company says it expects to have to pay to settle a class-action lawsuit involving 8.7 million people who bought policies over more than a decade ended in 1995.

headline: HARNISCHFEGER TO IMPOSE CUTBACKS AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: Harnischfeger Industries will cut jobs and investment and take charge of as much as $150 million to improve its pulp and paper machinery business, which has been weakened by Asia's economic crisis; reports its quarterly net income fell to $21.7 million from $30.9 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Brokerage Firm Settles Price-Rigging Suit
abstract: BancAmerica Robertson Stephens & Co agrees to pay $17 million to settle class-action lawsuit that accused it of colluding with 36 other brokerage firms to rig securities prices on Nasdaq stock market; firm was lone holdout from landmark settlement last year between the other brokerage firms and investors who filed 1994 antitrust suit (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall Slightly in Light Trading
abstract: US Treasury prices decline modestly; price of 30-year bond slips 8/32, to 103 28/32; yield edges up to 5.85 percent, from 5.83 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: Threatening Parliament, Yeltsin Names Neophyte Premier
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin names Sergei Kiriyenko, little-known 35-year-old technocrat, as Russia's new Prime Minister and warns that he would disband Parliament if it rejects nomination; Yeltsin stunned nation by dismissing several Cabinet members, including his longtime Prime Minister, Viktor S Chernomyrdin; Kiriyenko was plucked from obscurity to fill Chernomyrdin's post after aides told Yeltsin that he could not himself take on role of Acting Prime Minister, as he planned, because it would be unconstitutional; Yeltsin appears to be keeping field open by selecting Kiriyenko, but there is streak of recklessness to strategy; Yeltsin is not well and if he should die or become incapacitated, Kiriyenko would take over as President for three months until new elections are called (M)

headline: Pope Names 22 Cardinals
abstract: Pope John Paul II yesterday named 22 new cardinals, including 2 Americans and 2 whose names were kept secret for now. Page A8.

headline: Official's Prison Visit Defuses Threat to Ulster Talks
abstract: Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, Mo Mowlam, visits Maze prison and persuades Protestant paramilitary prisoners not to try to disrupt formal peace talks; Ulster Freedom Fighters says it no longer opposes participation in the talks; photo (M)

headline: Ogilvy One Takes Marketing Honors
abstract: Ogilvy One Worldwide takes top honors at 20th annual presentation of John Caples International Awards for direct marketing (S)

headline: John Fisher, 68, Retired Insurance Executive
abstract: John E Fisher, who served as chief executive of Nationwide group of insurance companies in 1980's and directed its national expansion, dies at age 68; photo (M)

headline: NISSAN SUES TO BLOCK REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES' ACQUISITIONS
abstract: Nissan Motor Co sues Republic Industries in attempt to stop Republic's acquisition of two Florida Nissan dealerships (S)

headline: A company is counting on a market for old television and film clips.
abstract: Worldwide Broadcasting Network, privately held company based in Cambridge, Mass, is using technology that it developed to test an on-line service that will allow users to search for old television broadcasts and play them back on their World Wide Web browsers; company's nascent efforts are object lesson in difficulties involved in building a video search engine; photos (Media column) (M)

headline: TEXAS UTILITIES SEEKS LARGEST BRITISH UTILITY
abstract: Texas Utilities Co says it is in talks to acquire interest in Energy Group PLC, rasiing possibility of takeover battle for Britain's largest utility (S)

headline: Ex-Denver Archbishop Was Host To 'Catholic Woodstock' in 1993
abstract: Profile of James Francis Stafford, head of Pontifical Council for the Laity in Rome, who has been named a cardinal by Pope John Paul II; he is a conservative who will defend Vatican's stands against those who would question them; hosted so-called Catholic Woodstock in 1993, when floods of young Catholics from around world descended on Denver for four-day meeting; photo (S)

headline: An Opulent Estate, Quietly Bought in England's Countryside
abstract: Asif Ali Zardari bought sprawling Rockwood estate in Brook, England, for $4 million in Oct 1995; Pakistani investigators say that in Rockwood deal, as in case of at least dozen other overseas properties they have linked to Bhutto family, elaborate steps were taken to disguise identity of estate's owners; photo (M)

headline: Four Are Finalists In Nordstrom Effort
abstract: Nordstrom Inc names four finalists to compete in review for its first major national branding effort (S)

headline: CLINTON HESITATES TO PUNISH NATIONS FOR IRAN OIL DEALS
abstract: Clinton Administration is backing away from imposing sanctions on foreign energy companies that are investing in Iran, despite law signed with great fanfare by Pres Clinton in 1996; Administration hopes that Asian financial crisis and recent drop in oil prices will cause two major deals at issue to collapse, and that sensitive foreign policy problems will simply go away; even if that does not happen, Administration is negotiating with European Union to find enough cause under law to waive sanctions if they are imposed (M)

headline: Ziff-Davis Expects to Raise $460 Million
abstract: Softbank Corp, Japanese parent of Ziff-Davis Inc, says Ziff-Davis expects to raise $460 million through initial public offering of stock in US (S)

headline: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL TRUST ADDS TO PROPERTIES
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust says it bought 15 apartment properties containing 4,645 apartments in 10 states for about $294.4 million in separate transactions; sells six properties for $28.5 million (S)

headline: MARCUS CABLE WEIGHS BUYOUT BIDS OR STOCK OFFERING
abstract: Marcus Cable Co receives unsolicited bids from two unidentified companies interested in buying cable-television company; chief executive Jeff Marcus says company is considering several options, including sale of entire company or public stock offering (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.56   5.52   5.05        3-month T-bills   5.07   5.10   5.03        6-month T-bills   5.06   5.06   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.65   3.66   3.44        10-yr. T-note   5.68   5.68   6.61        30-yr. T-bond   5.94   5.93   6.90        Telephone bd.   7.29   7.29   7.93        Municipal bds.   5.23   5.23   5.87          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Ham Radio, Version 2.0, for the Silicon Era
abstract: Ham radio continues to thrive and evolve as hobby; new, digitally hip generation is virtually reinventing it; much of innovation involves much shorter, higher-frequency radio waves that can carry more data, are less subject to interference and make possible greatly miniaturized equipment; photos (M)

headline: A Market That Quivers as Refinancings Rise
abstract: Recent surge in mortgage refinancings and prepayments upsets investors in mortgage-backed securities; wealth of choices in specialized funds noted; list (M)

headline: Hindu Party Asked to Form A Government For India
abstract: Pres K R Narayanan asks Hindu nationalist party to form coalition Government in India, stirring fears among many Indians, particularly Muslim minority, that party will dismantle country's historic commitment to equality for people of all faiths (M)

headline: Break on Gains, but Not on Frustration
abstract: Advice on calculating tax on capital gains, made far more complicated by law that also cut capital gains tax rate; table (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RICHFOOD HOLDINGS INC., Richmond, will close its frozen foods distribution plant in West Point, Pa., resulting in a fourth-quarter charge, as it reorganizes its frozen foods operations in Pennsylvania.

headline: Nissan Says Profits Will Be Disappointing
abstract: Nissan Motor Co says it probably will not reach its profit target of 100 billion yen ($775 million) for year ending March 31 (S)

headline: Q&A / Juwono Sudarsono, Defense Official : Racism in Indonesia Undercuts Unity
abstract: The 7 million ethnic Chinese in Indonesia make up just 3 percent of the population, but they control a large share of economic wealth. On a visit to Singapore, Juwono Sudarsono, deputy governor of the National Resilience Institute, an arm of the Indonesian Defense Ministry that trains senior civilian and military officials, discussed the situation of the Chinese minority with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: British Aerospace Sells Its Orion Stake
abstract: British Aerospace PLC sells its 26 percent stake in Orion Network Systems Inc, international satellite communications company, for $143 million cash, to Loral Space and Communications Ltd (S)

headline: MacManus and Ayer Appoint Executives
abstract: MacManus Group names Michael D Moore director of media development; N W Ayer hires Stuart Hazelwood for new position of executive vice president and executive planning director in charge of strategic research operations (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Did Sunbeam go too far to keep Dunlap in its corner office?
abstract: Market Place column on compensation package of Sunbeam Corp chairman-chief executive Albert J Dunlap; questions whether package should be designed to give Dunlap more incentive to raise Sunbeam's stock price (L)

headline: Asian Blues: A New Salve
abstract: Warburg Pincus Asset Management has started Warburg Pincus Managed EAFE Countries fund, overseas stock fund that steers clear of Asia's volatile emerging markets; fund aims for long-term capital growth by investing in companies in countries in Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Australasia and Far East Index (M)

headline: Yeltsin Says Clinton Could Blunder Into a World War; Press Imagines Nuclear Attack
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin of Russia stuns world by warning that US activities in Iraq could lead to world war; world financial markets plunge briefly; State Department disavows any plans to use nuclear arms in Iraq, which were rumored in Russian press; acts after Min Yevgeny Primakov lectures Amb James Collins about horrors of nuclear arms; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia's Crisis Deepens Over Reform Rift
abstract: Indonesian crisis deepens as rupiah plummets 10 percent on concern that International Monetary Fund would suspend $3 billion loan due on Mar 15 unless Pres Suharto stops backtracking on promised economic reforms (S)

headline: Fiber Optics Venture
abstract: Williams Companies, natural gas pipeline concern, is expected to once again offer fiber optic network to telephone companies that are seeking added capacity because of strong demand (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHARMACEUTICAL RESOURCES INC., Spring Valley, N.Y., said Lipha Americas, a unit of the German pharmaceutical company Merck K.G.a.A., would buy 10.4 million newly issued Pharmaceutical Resources shares for $2 a share in cash.    PAN-AMERICAN LIFE INSURANCE CO., New Orleans, will quit the United States health insurance market to concentrate on its life insurance and retirement planning businesses. As a result, 300 employees, or 20 percent of the company's 1,500-member work force, will be dismissed.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At Occidental, So-So Results But Big Pay For the Boss
abstract: Market Place column examines employment contract of Occidental Petroleum Corp's chairman and chief executive, Ray R Irani, after Occidental directors paid him $95 million to 'extinguish' his existing contract for new one they said would tie his pay more to performance and would be more 'progressive'; although some aspects of Irani's pay did decline last year, declines were more than offset by his bonus, which rose to $1.4 million; portion of his pay that was tied to company performance rose by $279,000; Occidental's performance, meanwhile, has been lackluster at best; company reported net loss of $390 million in 1997 (M)

headline: U.N. Chief to Name Special Envoy to Improve Links to Baghdad
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan has decided to assign special political representative to Iraq to improve lines of communication between Baghdad and United Nations; leading candidate appears to be Prakash Shah, India's representative at UN from 1995 to 1997 (M)

headline: GEORGIA-PACIFIC WILL BUY CECORR FOR $190 MILLION
abstract: Georgia-Pacific Corp agrees to acquire Cecorr Inc for $190 million in cash and stock plus assumption of $86 million of Cecorr's debt (S)

headline: Nike's Problems Don't Seem To Be Short Term to Investors
abstract: Nike Inc's warning that earnings will be disappointing for current quarter and announcement that corporate restructuring is coming leaves investors unfazed as price of stock rises; analysts say while investors looking for beaten down stocks in this pricy market may be forgiven for latching onto Nike, they had better brace for turnaround that could take at least a couple of years; graph (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL MOTORS CORP.,  Detroit, said its Delphi Automotive Systems unit had agreed to sell two spring factories in Michigan to the Walton Johnson Group Inc., a minority-owned Texas company, for undisclosed terms.    KENAN TRANSPORT CO.,  Chapel Hill, N.C., a tank-truck carrier for the petroleum, propane gas and chemical industries, agreed to buy Petro-Chemical Transport Inc., a trucking company owned by Petroleos de Venezuela's Citgo Petroleum Corp. unit, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: BALLARD MEDICAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE TRI-MED SPECIALTIES
abstract: Ballard Medical Products agrees to acquire Tri-Med Specialties Inc for $26 million in stock (S)

headline: Mandela Eases His Criticism of White Privilege
abstract: Pres Nelson Mandela addresses South Africa's Parliament on state of the nation, calling on whites who gained from apartheid to repay society by performing voluntary public service; remarks represent a retreat from the bitter attack he delivered six weeks ago on whites who had failed to help in country's transformation (M)

headline: Soft-Dollar Case Filed by S.E.C.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files civil fraud charges against California investment advisory firm Sweeney Capital Management, now defunct, its owner Timothy Charles Sweeney and portfolio manager Susan Mary Gorski, saying they misappropriated commission income through use of so-called soft-dollar commissions; charges say that clients of firm were defrauded of more than $109,000 in 1994 and 1995 (S)

headline: A Suitor for the Illinois Central Railroad
abstract: Canada's largest railroad, Canadian National Railway Co, is negotiating to acquire Illinois Central Railroad; deal being negotiated, including assumption of Illinios Central's outstanding debt, is estimated to be worth $2.7 billion to $3.1 billion; some analysts say terms being discussed might attract other bidders; map; graphs (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.50   5.42   5.22        3-month T-bills   5.01   5.05   4.99        6-month T-bills   4.95   4.95   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.70   3.70   N.A.        10-yr. T-note   5.45   5.43   6.51        30-yr. T-bond   5.73   5.73   6.79        Telephone bd.   7.07   7.04   7.82        Municipal bds.   5.10   5.10   5.82          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Bigger Amounts May Bring Bigger Risks
abstract: Perhaps most aggressively promoted and risky deal in home financing is '125 percent loan'--financial product in which mortgage and home equity add up to as much as 125 percent of home's market value, compared with normal ceiling of approximately 90 percent; majority are made by lenders other than banks, and $10 billion worth were made in 1997 (S)

headline: In Asia, Stocks Melt Faster Than in '29
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on plunge in Asian stock prices as investors flee; sees alarm starting to spread to United States markets; graph (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Doubts About Slowdown Push Yields to 1998 High  Investor skepticism about a widely expected weakening in the economy rattled the bond market, depressing prices and elevating the 30-year Treasury yield to 6 percent for the first time since mid-December.    Analysts attributed the change to new evidence that the economy was not slowing, as well as fear of inflation expressed last week by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The reversal suggested many investors fear Asia's economic crisis will not repress inflation as much as hoped. [Page D9.]

headline: Merger Negotiations End For Telenor and Telia
abstract: Norway and Sweden end talks on merging state-owned communications companies, Telenor ASA and Telia AB; Norway feared Sweden would become dominant partner (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Europe's Ire at Hollywood Is Taken Out on Distributor  Europe's love-hate relationship with Hollywood veered back toward hostility last week, when a European Commission antitrust official moved to break up a joint distribution company owned by Paramount, MCA and United Artists.

headline: Sinclair to Sell Two TV Stations
abstract: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc will sell two television stations in Burlington, Vt, area--WPTZ-TV and WNNE-TV--and a contract to manage WFFF-TV to closely held STC Broadcasting Inc for $72 million; stations are part of package of TV and radio stations that Sinclair agreed to buy from Heritage Media Corp for $630 million; Sinclair says it has completed its acquisition of WEAR-TV and local management contract for WFGX-TV, which serves Mobile, Ala-Pensacola, Fla, market and acquisition of WCHS-TV in Charleston-Huntington, W Va market; Sinclair has purchased option from Sullivan Broadcasting Group Co to buy KOKH-TV in Oklahoma City for $60 million (S)

headline: For Lockheed, A Showdown Over Merger
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp and Government head toward showdown over company's $8.3 billion acquisition of Northrop Grumman Corp; Justice Dept and Defense Dept threaten antitrust court action unless Lockheed agrees to sell $4 billion in military electronics operations, precisely what makes Northrop attractive to Lockheed in first place; Lockheed calls Government demand unprecedented and says it is prepared to fight in court, but that could cost Lockheed millions of dollars in legal fees and put company into conflict with Defense Dept, its biggest customer; if Lockheed walks away from deal, it would lose competitive advantage it seeks against other military contractors; Government's fear is that merger, as proposed by Lockheed, would wipe out any chance for other electronics subcontractors to get into Lockheed's aircraft (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  A young couple with strong earnings potential are struggling to pay $462,000 in personal and business debt. Fresh Start, by Paul Sweeney.

headline: Patents; The process of filing an application is slowly catching up with the technology available.
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office is sorting through options for electronic filing of patent applications, which is expected to streamline procedures, decrease time it takes to process applications and reduce costs; Patent Office has experimental software designed to insure that only authorized individuals can gain acccess to patent application; agency still does not have technology to include 'key recovery' system in software in case encryption has to be broken; Patent and Trademark Office issues guidelines for seeking trademark application for domain name (M)

headline: CABLETRON TO BUY REMAINING SHARES OF YAGO SYSTEMS
abstract: Cabletron Systems Inc agrees to buy 76 percent of Yago Systems Inc it does not own for about $87.8 million in stock (S)

headline: Ethnic Violence Flares Anew After Election in Kenya
abstract: Less than month after Pres Daniel arap Moi won re-election in contest that divided Kenyans along tribal lines, new round of tribal clashes has broken out in Rift Valley region near town of Sipili, claiming at least 80 lives in last two weeks; police assert killings are work of cattle rustlers, who have long operated in region, but opposition leaders and clerics say attacks appear to be well-orchestrated campaign to drive members of Kikuyu tribe from area, which is political stronghold of President; Kikuyu voted against Moi in election, overwhelmingly backing kinsman, Mwai Kibaki, economist and former Vice President; map; photo (M)

headline: Gary Nardino, 62, TV Executive And Situation Comedy Producer
abstract: Gary Nardino, television executive, dies at age 62 (S)

headline: U.N. Council Asked to Raise Limit on Sale Of Iraqi Oil
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan, acknowledging widespread deprivation that international sanctions have inflicted on people of Iraq, asks Security Council to more than double amount of oil Baghdad is permitted to sell to meet basic needs and to repair deteriorating infrastructure (M)

headline: Paris Journal; Did VW Mock the Gospel? French Bishops Sue
abstract: France's Roman Catholic bishops sue Volkswagen and its ad agency, DDB-Needham, charging that series of car ads mock religious images, including the Last Supper; seeks $400,000 in damages from the company, which would be paid to an aid organization in Sudan; hope suit will stimulate public discussion on limiting use of religious images to sell products; believe advertisers would not treat Islamic or Jewish images as lightly as they do Christian ones; photo (M)

headline: FIFTH THIRD IN $904 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR STATE SAVINGS
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp to acquire State Savings, privately held savings and loan holding company, Columbus, Ohio, for $904 million in stock (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Cleveland, to BBDO Chicago, part of Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been at Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, Cleveland, a unit of Wolf Group. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: OBERLIN FARMS DAIRY TO BE SOLD TO SUIZA FOODS
abstract: Suiza Foods Corp will acquire Oberlin Farms Dairy Inc (S)

headline: Bonds Fail to Hold Gains on More Signs of Asian Stability
abstract: US Treasury bonds fail to hold gains and finish lower; price of 30-year bond drops about 15/16, to 104 2/32; yield rises to 5.84 percent from 5.80 percent on Jan 16; graph; chart (L)

headline: Gates, on Capitol Hill, Presents Case for an Unfettered Microsoft
abstract: Chairman William H Gates defends Microsoft Corp's business practices, portraying company as standard bearer of nation's high technology economy, Senate committee; warns against government curbs on industry; Sen Orrin G Hatch says hearing weighs how market power works in software industry and whether Microsoft abuses its market power; says Congress has no present plans for new antitrust law tailored to high-technology industries; Scott McNealy of Sun Microsystems Inc and James L Barksdale of Netscape Communications Corp call for moves to keep Microsoft from using monopoly power to stifle competition and innovation; Michael S Dell of Dell Computer Corp and Douglas Burgum of Great Plains Software Inc, Gates's allies, and venture capitalist Stewart Alsop also speak; photos (M)

headline: Despite controversy, most agencies don't shy away from using the President as a pitchman.
abstract: Most advertising agencies are not shying away from using Pres Clinton as a pitchman despite sex scandal; ads are beginning to appear that allude to his difficulties involving Monica S Lewinsky; some examples cited; photo (L)

headline: BOOK DEAL: THE BUYER -- Hansel & Gretel Inc.; Bertelsmann's Journey From Fairy Tales to Multimedia
abstract: Article on growth of Bertelsmann AG as multimedia company in light of its plan to acquire Random House; says Bertelsmann will be biggest commercial book publisher in US and in the world if it carries out acquisition; merger deal was negotiated by Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann chief executive-elect, and Peter Olson, who would head unit if sale is completed; charts; photo (L)

headline: Looking to Israel for High-Technology Buys
abstract: Outlook for investing in high-tech Israeli companies traded in United States discussed; Israel has produced at least 2,000 established high-tech companies, over 100 of which are traded in US; graphs (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When a 'socially responsible' fund has a problem of its own.
abstract: Market Place column on Parnassus fund, one of best known of 'socially responsible' mutual funds, which last year was accused by Securities and Exchange Commission of violating Federal securities laws, including mispricing a security; says Jerome Dodson, fund manager, one of those charged, says his solution is to raise fee that investors pay him to manage fund, insuring that he has more money to support 'administrative and compliance services' (M)

headline: Shareholders Vote to Approve Merger of MCI and Worldcom
abstract: Shareholders of MCI Communications Corp and of Worldcom Inc overwhelmingly approve their companies' pending $37 billion merger (M)

headline: John L. Bissell, 66, Entrepreneur In Handloomed Textiles in India
abstract: John L Bissell, American businessman who ran a handloomed-textile export business in India for more than 30 years, dies at age of 66; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ralston Purina shuns news, even when it's good.
abstract: Market Plyce column on Ralston Purina Co; focuses on lack of investor confidence in company because company shuns news on the company, even when it is good; says revenues for most recent quarter rose 4.5 percent, to $1.32 billion; net income rose to $857.8 million from $137.4 million in year-earlier period (L)

headline: I.R.S. Has Sent Out More in Tax Refunds
abstract: Treasury Department has sent out 11.3 percent more in tax refunds this year than in corresponding time last year, providing potential push for economy in first quarter; Internal Revenue Service reports that it sent taxpayers $45.02 billion in refunds through March 6, up from $40.46 billion in year-earlier period (S)

headline: CHESAPEAKE ENERGY TO ACQUIRE AN OCCIDENTAL UNIT
abstract: Chesapeake Energy Corp agrees to acquire Occidental Petroleum Corp's MC Panhandle Corp unit for $105 million (S)

headline: Daiwa Unit in U.S. Settles Stock Charges
abstract: Daiwa Securities' US unit to agrees to pay $100,000 fine and $300,000 in restitution to settle allegations it overcharged American customers trading Japanese securities on Tokyo and Osaka Stock Exchanges; National Association of Securities Dealers, which brought charges, contended Daiwa's Los Angeles office gave false information to two institutional customers about prices at which firm traded their Japanese stocks from 1987 to 1991 (S)

headline: Argentina to Hasten End of Phone Monopoly
abstract: Argentina's Pres Carlos Saul Menem announces that monopolies held by two Argentine telephone companies will end in 1999; move could significantly expand presence of US companies in Argentina's $10 billion telephone market; at present, Telefonica de Argentina SA and Telecom Argentina monopolize all long-distance and local telephone services (M)

headline: Pentagon Chief Gets Tour Of Key China Command Site
abstract: Inside a drab, innocuous cluster of buildings, the very existence of which the Communist Government here refused to acknowledge only a short time ago, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen on Monday took what American officials hope will be a significant step toward better relations with China.    In a gesture supposed to build confidence, China's military leaders allowed Mr. Cohen and his entourage to tour one of their more sensitive military sites, a command center that monitors air and missiles defenses for 200 miles around Beijing.

headline: Bombing Gas Sites May Pose Risk of Gulf War Syndrome
abstract: Some members of White House panel of experts on illnesses of Persian Gulf war veterans, noting United States preparations to bomb Iraqi poison gas sites, cite possible link between veterans' illnesses and exposure to Iraqi poison gas, letter to Pres Clinton; Prof Marguerite Knox, letter's main author, disputes recent news reports suggestings illnesses result soley from wartime stress; Prof Arthur L Caplan, letter signer, warns American troops are still not adequately defended against chemical or biological arms (M)

headline: Health Industry Seeks Congressional Relief
abstract: Hospital industry is waging battle on Capitol Hill to make it more difficult for prosecutors to use Federal fraud statute against health care providers; False Claims Act has been primary tool used to recoup Government losses from fraud, but Congress is considering legislation that would create exemptions and special considerations for providers; thinking is that changes are needed to insure that hospitals are not sanctioned for innocent mistakes that result from vague and poorly worded billing rules; law-enforcement officials say revisions would severely hamper their ability to combat fraud; say that because proposed legislation is retroactive, it could impede Government's efforts in sweeping investigation of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, including more than dozen civil actions filed against Columbia under act (M)

headline: Some stock analysts may end up working for the companies they cover. Does that color views?
abstract: Market Place column discusses possible ethical implications when Wall Street analysts go to work for industry they formerly tracked; such moves make some investors even more skeptical about objectivity of average Wall Street analyst (M)

headline: With the Way to Power Open, Hindu Nationalists Falter
abstract: India's quest for new government falters when main Hindu nationalist party falls into dispute with major ally, leaving door open for possible rival bid for power by Congress Party; in a sequence that exasperates many Indians, Jayalalitha Jayaram, former movie actress facing investigation in $1 billion fraud scandal, emerges as spoiler of what had seemed only 48 hours ago to be almost certain ascent to power by Hindu nationalists; her case reviewed; photo of Atal Bihari Vajpayee, man nominated by nationalists to be Prime Min (M)

headline: U.S. Spy Agencies Find Scant Peril on Horizon
abstract: Asst Sec of State Phyllis Oakley, Army Lieut Gen Patrick M Hughes and Central Intelligence Agency Dir George J Tenet tell Senate intelligence committee that while world still bristles with weapons, US is relatively secure from threat of war; say nation confronts dangers to world peace, personified by Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq, but danger of nuclear attack and other threats to our national existence is low (M)

headline: TRIZECHAHN TO OFFER STAKE IN BARRICK GOLD TO PUBLIC
abstract: TrizecHahn Corp will sell its interest in Barrick Gold Corp in public offering valued at $516.9 million (S)

headline: STOCK OF BINGO OPERATOR FALLS AFTER OFFICE IS SEARCHED
abstract: Shares of Multimedia Games Inc fall 24 percent after Federal agents search its offices for evidence that its electronic bingo game used on Indian reservations might violate gambling laws (S)

headline: With Pope Due, the Cubans Wrest Dollars From Heaven
abstract: Television army has invaded Havana on eve of Pope John Paul II's visit to Cuba, speeding up city's normally slow-paced routine and probing without interference into nearly every corner of normally restrictive society; influx yields financial windfall for Government, particularly ministries and state companies providing services at greatly inflated prices and imposing creative new charges on equipment and supplies; photo (M)

headline: Tobacco Industry, Conciliatory in U.S., Goes on the Attack in the Third World
abstract: Tobacco companies have agreed to sweeping restrictions in US on cigarette marketing and second-hand smoke and to bolder cancer-warning labels, but they are fighting as hard as ever in third world to convince media, public and policy makers that similar changes are not needed (M)

headline: Microchips Are Latest Addition To Gear for London's Marathon
abstract: Runners in London Marathon will attach microchip to shoe so their time can be tracked by computer; device was designed by Champions Worldwide, Dutch timing company; photos (M)

headline: Two Banks Agree to Merge in Berlin Deal
abstract: Bankgesellschaft Berlin AG agrees to buy Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale for $3.54 billion (US) in cash and stock, after breaking 10-month deadlock over sale by compensating its own majority shareholder, city-state of Berlin, for loss of control (S)

headline: Arabs Want Israel to Feel U.S. Pressure
abstract: Arab leaders make clear their hope that Pres Clinton will use upcoming meeting in Washington to take unparalled steps to persuade Israel to modify positions on next steps in Mideast peace efforts; Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad is increasingly blunt in urging US to turn up heat on Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; his unexpected talks with Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak are clear sign of Arab alarm (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Tuning Into the Music of Developing Nations
abstract: Quincy Jones, music impresario, will introduce Qradio, venture that marries Internet to his advocacy of rich, varied and largely unknown music of developing nations; site is not limited to sound, offering data base of South African musicians, including biographies, discographies and sample clips; he hopes to broaden site to embrace music from other parts of Africa and the world; photo (M)

headline: Another Lazard Executive Exits
abstract: Gerald Rosenfeld, head of investment banking at Lazard Freres & Co for last five months, will leave to head $600 million private equity fund at securities unit of Nationsbank Corp; Rosenfeld is third senior Lazard execurive to depart in last three months, after reorganization at investment banking partnership (S)

headline: Oil and Technology Are Off in Mixed Performance Over All
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 31.14 points at 8,749.99; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 1.18, to 1,080.45; Nasdaq composite index slips 8.88, to 1,779.30; graph; charts (L)

headline: Biggest British Bank Posts 10% Profit Gain
abstract: HSBC Holdings PLC says net income rose 10 percent in second half of 1997; net income was 1.76 billion pounds ($2.89 billion), up from 1.60 billion pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Ferdinand Porsche, Creator of the Sports Car That Bore His Name, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Ferdinand Porsche, creater of German sports car that bore his family name, dies at age 88; photos (L)

headline: Drug Abuse Problems Are on the Rise as the Labor Pool Shrinks
abstract: Human resources managers, faced with shrinking labor pool, say they are starting to see small but disturbing rise in number of job applicants who fail screening for drug abuse; apparent trend is not yet reflected in data; table (M)

headline: When Love Turns to Obsession, Games Are No Game
abstract: Compulsive computer-game playing is likened to drug or alcohol or gambling addiction by experts on obsessive behavior; say most people who consider themselves home computer game addicts are in their 40's, 50's or older, and almost all are men; players speak of need to play game over and over, not stopping for food or sleep, until they win; Dr William S Pollack, psychiatrist, says such addicts are often dodging job worries or marital disputes; list of psychological and physical symptoms that could suggest addiction to compiter games, photo (M)

headline: Partial Halt By Indonesia On Payments
abstract: Indonesia announces 'temporary pause' in payments on billions of dollars in private debt to overseas lenders, formalizing halt on repayment that had already taken effect quietly among most corporations; move is cautiously welcomed by US, International Monetary Fund and Asian financial analysts; they view it as sign that Indonesia is finally grappling with its financial problems (L)

headline: Lucent Is Planning a 2-for-1 Stock Split
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc schedules 2-for-1 stock split; forms $100 million venture-capital fund to invest in new wireless, semiconductor and software technologies (S)

headline: Vast India Seeks a Focus in Its Election Campaign
abstract: Sonia Gandi, campaigning for Congress Party, is only figure who has shown any signs of rousing Indian electorate from widespread apathy; noncandidate draws large crowds across nation reminiscent of enthusiasm stirred by her mother-in-law, late Indira Gandhi, and her slain husband, Rajiv Gandhi; few believe she alone can restore party to dominant position it long held; polls indicate swing toward Bharatiya Janata Party, Hindu nationalist group; photo (M)

headline: Russia Names Atomic Chief, And the U.S. Is a Little Wary
abstract: Yevgeny Adamov is named Russia's Minister for Atomic Energy; Adamov went to Teheran in Feb with Viktor N Mikhailov, minister who was ousted on March 2, to meet with Iranian officials; Adamov later assured US officials that he had no intention of helping Iran develop nuclear weapons, but trip still touched off concerns in Washington; Adamov photo (M)

headline: Record Momentum Wanes, With Dow Retreating 31.64
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is down 31.64 points, to close at 8,872.80; Nasdaq composite index is up 12.07 points, to close at record 1,824.51; graph; chart (L)

headline: MCI Is Ending Plans to Resell Local Service
abstract: MCI Communications Corp president, Timothy F Price, says MCI cannot make money reselling local residential phone service and will focus on providing businesses local service through its own networks (S)

headline: Japan Plans New Financial Terms for Old Privatization
abstract: Japanese Government discloses plans to change financial terms of decade-old privatization of Japan National Railways; revision likely to have chilling effect on future privatizations and on foreign investment; Cabinet is expected to approve bill that would shift more debt onto private companies that were formed when Government sold railway system in 1987; notion that terms of deal negotiated long ago could suddenly change at Govenrment's whim causes stir (M)

headline: U.S.A. FLORAL TO ACQUIRE 6 FLORAL PRODUCTS COMPANIES
abstract: USA Floral Products Inc, wholesale flower distributor, says it will acquire six floral products companies and two of their affiliates for $50.3 million in stock and $51.8 million in cash; companies to be acquired are H & H Flowers, Ultraflora Inc, Everflora Inc, Koehler & Dramm Inc, XL Group Inc and Contintental Farms Ltd (S)

headline: COLONY CAPITAL TO ACQUIRE HARVEYS CASINO RESORTS
abstract: Harveys Casino Resorts agrees to be acquired by investment firm Colony Capital Inc for $420 million, including assumed debt (S)

headline: Deutsch to Open Office in Chicago
abstract: Deutsch Inc says it will expand by opening full-service office next month in Chicago (S)

headline: Silicon Graphics Projects Loss and Big Revenue Drop
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc expects to report significant quarterly loss and 23 percent drop in revenue; cites declining demand for its work stations and supercomputers (S)

headline: Business Travel; With corporate hotel rates on the rise, the search is on for good rooms that don't break budgets.
abstract: Business travelers are looking for good budget hotel rooms and finding them aplenty; American Express estimates that corporate hotel rates will escalate around 15 percent this year; some first-rate restaurants to visit in San Diego, Calif, before and after Super Bowl noted; several thousand business fliers are testing new 'smart card' ticketing system, imbedded with personal preferences and other information, offered by American Express and Continental Airlines (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: U.S. Is Linking Aid to Jakarta To Its Reforms
abstract: Walter F Mondale, Pres Clinton's special envoy, fails to win commitment from Indonesian Pres Suharto that he will end resistance to economic reforms that are part of $43 billion International Monetary Fund bailout; Deputy Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers tells Senate subcommittee that Clinton will not support added IMF emergency aid unless Suharto makes 'adequate progress' toward reforms he agreed to in Jan; senior officials say Clinton signals Suharto will not be allowed to ignore accord, despite concerns about impact of aid cutoff (M)

headline: Net's a Natural for Fantasy Baseball
abstract: World Wide Web sites provided baseball statistics and offer simunlations that enable fans to play virtual ball games; photo (M)

headline: A Look at Trimming Aid to Israel by U.S.
abstract: The Israeli Finance Minister will meet with Congressional and Administrative officials this week to discuss phasing out America's $1.2 billion in economic aid to Israel starting in the year 2000, according to Congressional officials and Jewish organizations.

headline: Battle Is Seen After Bid for Parts Maker
abstract: SPX Corp, maker of automobile parts and tools, makes $3 billion hostile bid for Echlin Inc, setting off possible bidding war for one of biggest auto-parts companies; chart (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODBART, ESTELLE NELSON
abstract: RODBART-Estelle Nelson. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Louis S. Nelson, and Nathan Rodbart, cherished mother of Harriet (Robert) Levy, Dr. Irwin Nelson (Myrna), and the late Myra B. Ruskin, devoted sister of Miriam Levine, loving grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, March 25 at 1 P.M. at The Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

headline: Women See Key Gains Since Talks In Beijing
abstract: Representatives from women's organizations from around world are meeting at United Nations for two weeks to take stock of progress two and half years after United Nations international conference on women in Beijing put forward proposals for govt action on women's rights; even skeptics say they are impressed at extent to which many govts have followed through on their pledges; they attribute this largely to pressure from increasingly strong local and international women's orgns (M)

headline: SYKES AGREES TO PAY $50 MILLION FOR PRUDENTIAL UNIT
abstract: Sykes Healthplan Services Inc agrees to buy Prudential Insurance Co of America's Prudential Service Bureau unit for $50 million in cash (S)

headline: MOTOROLA MAKES A BID TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN NETSPEAK
abstract: Motorola Inc offers to pay $90 million to increase its stake in Netspeak Corp; it will take its $30-a-share cash offer directly to Netspeak shareholders in effort to acquire 3 million additional shares (S)

headline: Murdoch Halts a Book Critical of China
abstract: HarperCollins drops plans to publish book by Chris Patten, last British Governor of Hong Kong, because of complaints from company's owner, Rupert Murdoch, that book takes too negative a view of China, where Murdoch has extensive holdings; Daily Telegraph of London prints photograph of 'private and confidential' HarperCollins memo setting out strategy for disguising reason for abandoning publication; Patton is suing HarperCollins for damages and breach of contract; his editor at HarperCollins, Stuart Proffitt, who praised book, has been threatened with dismissal if he discusses matter with anyone; he also is suing HarperCollins for breach of contract; Patton says his book, East and West, will be published by Macmillan and in United States by Times Books, division of Random House (M)

headline: Castro and Cheering Crowds Greet Pope
abstract: Pope John Paul II begins 5-day visit to Cuba, greeted by respectful Pres Fidel Castro and cheering crowds lining roadway; Castro, wearing suit instead of usual military fatigues, likens hardships caused by United States embargo to persecution of Christian martyrs, speech; scores religious intolerance he says was preached in Catholic schools of his boyhood and defends nation's respect for both believers and nonbelievers; Pope stresses pastoral side of visit, but urges faithful to take control of own personal and national history, news conference; urges Cuba and world to end nation's isolation; told reporters on plane that he wants to discuss church-state relations with Castro; said he favors end to US embargo and hopes visit will change US policies; photos (M)

headline: Review Is Started By Chase Manhattan
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp begins agency review involving assignments with billings estimated at $40 million; agencies now handling those duties are McCann-Erickson New York and Wells BDDP (S)

headline: REIT to Buy 3 Hotels
abstract: Equity Inns Inc agrees to acquire three hotels in two separate transactions totaling $43.1 million; Equity will pay $30.5 million for Residence Inns in Portland, Ore, and hotel in Boise, Idaho; Equity will also buy Hampton Inn in San Antonio for $12.6 million (S)

headline: Banks in Accord to Extend $24 Billion in Korea Loans
abstract: South Korean banks and their international creditors reach agreement to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans, granting country important reprieve in financial crisis that has afflicted much of Asia since last summer; agreement marks first time in crisis that banks have given any of stricken Asian nations such a measure of relief; it also reflects pressure confronting banks and their creditors to find solution to avoid defaults on most pressing debts (M)

headline: U.S. and I.M.F. Delay Funds for Indonesia
abstract: US and International Monetary Fund agree to delay billions of dollars in aid to Indonesia until Pres Suharto begins to act on revised plan for economic reform being negotiated in Jakarta; US says it will send over $70 million in emergency food and medical aid to Indonesia in effort to alleviate food riots that some Indonesians blame on austerity measures required in plan; photo (M)

headline: Gray to Acquire Midwest Concern
abstract: Gray Communications Systems will buy Busse Broadcasting Corp for $47.6 million in cash and assumption of $64.4 million in debt; will gain entry into three midsize television markets serving Midwest; Busse filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1995 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Thailand's currency the baht, has strengthened in last three days, bolstered by rallies in Thai stock market and in other Asian markets; graphs (S)

headline: Advertisers Part With 2 Agencies
abstract: Porsche Cars North America parts ways with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco; billings on account estimated at $10 million to $15 million; review to begin in spring; Cliff Freeman & Partners says it has resigned creative portion of account of Pep Boys; billings estimated at $23 million to $30 million (S)

headline: ZURICH INSURANCE GROUP ADDS REST OF KEMPER
abstract: Zurich Insurance Group acquires remaining twenty percent of Kemper Corp from Insurance Partners, making Kemper full subsidiary (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Korea will suffer, but the banks that lent the money won't.
abstract: Economic Scene column on $57 billion bailout of South Korea by International Monetary Fund and Japanese, European and American banks; says South Koreans will pay long and dearly for their financial transgressions, but banks that provided much of capital seem destined to remain unscathed; drawing (L)

headline: Beijing Journal; Delectable Materialism Catching On in China
abstract: Popularity of newspapers like Shopping Guide and Fine Goods Shopping Guide attests to growth of consumer culture in China, at least among its younger generation; department stores and boutiques in Beijing carry brands like Benetton, Nautica and Sony, and ads on television and in magazines and some newspapers extol the world goods and gadgets; even People's Daily, Community Party mouthpiece, now reports on world of finance, shopping, society and culture; photo (M)

headline: Many Indonesians See Military as Rock of Stability
abstract: Indonesians, rocked by economic crisis, see military not as threat but as promise of stability; praise for its methods is far from unanimous and it is suspected of widespread corruption; experts say military is unlikely to stage coup against Pres Suharto unless Indonesia disintegrates into chaos; military is integral part of Suharto administration and powerful force at every level of government (M)

headline: Chip Plant Plans Job Cuts
abstract: Mitsubishi Semiconductor America Inc to close its wafer fabrication operations in Durham, NC, on March 16 and dismiss about 200 employees because of weak sales (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; A Virtual Trip to World Fairs Past
abstract: Several Internet sites are devoted to World's Fairs of past, particularly those held in New York in 1939-40 and 1964-65 (M)

headline: Japan's King of the Mountain; The Man Who Made Nagano Also Owns Part of It
abstract: Profile of Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, Japanese businessman who was instrumental in bringing Winter Olympics to Japan; Tsutsumi's vast holdings include Olympic ski slopes in Nagano, city where he once lived; fact that Nagano was chosen is testiment to Tsutsumi's skill as master manipulator who knows how to exercise influence behind scenes; Nagano is farther south than any other site chosen for Winter Games, and it has narrow roads and remote location; Tsutsumi ingratiated himself to Juan Antonio Samaranch, head of International Olympic Committee, by donating $1 million of his own money and helping raise $10 million more for new Olympic Museum that Samaranch is building in Switzerland; Tsutsumi is thought to be world's richest man, and his solitary life style has been likened to that of Howard Hughes; photos; chart (L)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:   Boston Properties Inc., Boston, 15 million shares, 12 million in the U.S. and Canada. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Prof. Richard Allen Lester, 89, Expert in Wage and Labor Issues
abstract: Richard Allen Lester, economist who specialized in wage and labor issues, and dean of faculty emeritus at Princeton University, dies at 89; photo (S)

headline: Washington And Moscow Show Split Over Iraq
abstract: US and Russia display sharpest disagreements over Iraq, with Sec of State Madeleine K Albright expressing deep skepticism in Madrid, Spain, that diplomatic solution to standoff is possible, and Russian Foreign Min Yevgeny Primakov stating that negotiating process has just begun; combined with call by China for peaceful resolution to problem, Russia's stand is setback for Albright, who has been touring Middle East to win support from Arab countries (M)

headline: G.M. Reports Strong 4th-Quarter Earnings
abstract: General Motors Corp reports earnings for fourth quarter more than doubled to $1.74 billion, from $786 million in year earlier quarter; profits in all of 1997 reached $6.7 billion, up from $5.0 billion in 1996; GM's revenue in 1997 was $177.7 billion, up from $164 billion in 1996; GM's fourth-quarter results include gain of $4.3 billion that is nearly offset by after-tax charges of $4 billion; without one-time charges and gain, GM's fourth-quarter earnings reached $1.5 billion, compared with $848 million in year earlier quarter (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merger of Weapons Giants Faces Unexpected Hurdle  Lockheed Martin's $8.3 billion acqusition of Northrop Grumman is running into unexpected resistance from the Government, suggesting that Washington may now believe that the consolidation among military suppliers, which it had been encouraging, has gone too far.     Lockheed and Northrop said in a joint statement that they had been told over the weekend that the Justice Department was ''fundamentally opposed'' to the proposed combination of the companies. [Page A1.]

headline: Homeowners' Assurance
abstract: Article on what real estate experts think buyers and sellers should do to protect themselves during a home sale; chart; drawing (L)

headline: Apple Computer Hiring Compaq Executive
abstract: Apple Computer names Timothy D Cook, executive at Compaq Computer Corp, as its senior vice president for worldwide manufacturing operations (S)

headline: Foreign Investors Start Return to Thailand
abstract: Fresh investment begins flowing into Thai companies and banks for first time since financial system started to crumble eight months ago, raising hope that foreign investors are starting to acquire assets made cheap by severe currency and market losses; Thai officials say country cannot recover on its own, and they urge foreign investors to bail out banks and finance companies; even largest Thai companies have suspended payments owed to banks, putting them in technical default and raising tricky legal questions for potential foreign suitors (M)

headline: Rally on Defused Iraqi Crisis Is Short-Lived as Dollar Falls
abstract: Early bond market rally on defused Iraqi crisis fades and leaves prices lower for fourth day; 30-year bond falls 14/32, to price of 103 5/32; yield rises to 5.90 percent, from 5.87 percent on Feb 20; charts (L)

headline: It Isn't Just Big Brother Who Is Watching
abstract: Workers in several states say they have been dismissed or disciplined for content of their Web pages, even though pages are maintained with their own computers, time and money; others say they have been ordered to modify their pages; both groups say common directive was to remove any reference to where they work, making it difficult to publish resume on line; experts in employment law say dismissals are legal; Web page cases reveal culture clash between long-standing, unwritten standards of corporate propriety and new perspective of Web-savvy employees--kind of workers companies are clamoring for; photo (M)

headline: Suharto Vows to Step Up Economic Reform, IMF Says
abstract: SINGAPORE—  President Suharto of Indonesia, under mounting international and domestic pressure to put into effect painful austerity measures or resign, agreed Monday to strengthen and accelerate the country's reform program, the International Monetary Fund said.

headline: U.S. Officers In Gulf Ready For Increase In Firepower
abstract: American military commanders in Persian Gulf prepare to receive possible reinforcements, including additional strike aircraft, to boost combat strength in standoff with Iraq; reinforcements would compliment force of 24,000 troops, more than 200 warplanes, plus aircraft carriers and Navy vessels equipped with cruise missiles (M)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : 'Caged Bird' Is Silenced In Maryland Classrooms
abstract: In Maryland, two public school superintendents have removed books by prominent black authors from high school English classes at the urging of some parents who called the works "anti-white."

headline: Get Inside Data On Any Broker
abstract: National Assn of Securities Dealers will put brokers' employment histories on line as first step in $50 million project to make it easier for investors to find out about backgrounds and disciplinary histories of United States brokers (S)

headline: Cuba's Protestant Churches: A Growing Flock
abstract: Visit of Pope John Paul II to Cuba focused world's spotlight on budding revival of Catholicism there; religious experts say that revival has been dwarfed by explosive enthusiasm for Protestant churches, particularly for evangelical churches, that has swept country in recent years; Cuban Council of Churches says Protestant congregations, small religious minority before Fidel Castro seized power in 1959, have nearly doubled in number over last six years from some 900 to about 1,700; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.50   6.00   5.19        3-month T-bills   5.04   5.07   4.95        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.07   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.65   3.25        10-yr. T-note   5.48   5.43   6.30        30-yr. T-bond   5.83   5.79   6.57        Telephone bd.   7.09   7.05   7.63        Municipal bds.   5.16   5.15   5.65          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBERG, MARY
abstract: ELLENBERG-Mary. We express our deepest sympathy to Maggie's family on her untimely passing. CAMP NYDA Junior Division

headline: Yeltsin Gives His Cabinet Public Rebuke On Economy
abstract: Russia Pres Boris N Yeltsin, in special Govt meeting that is half encounter group and half staged show trial, lashes out at his Govt for failing to correct country's ailing economy and threatens Cabinet shakeup (M)

headline: ALLIANZ A.G. UNIT TO OBTAIN 35% STAKE IN LIFE USA HOLDING
abstract: Allianz Life Insurance Co of North America, unit of Allianz AG, agrees to buy as much as 35 percent of Life USA Holding Inc for estimated $171 million (S)

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM TO SELL SOME PROPERTIES
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp to sell some natural gas properties in Oklahoma and Kansas to Oneok Inc for $135 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices jump as manufacturers step up purchases to take advantage of recent low prices; mine production is also being cut; copper for May delivery rises 1.70 cents, to 80.45 cents a pound; chart; graph (S)

headline: I.M.F. Relaxes Loan Terms For Russians
abstract: International Monetary Fund, against backdrop of economic crisis in Asia, says it will continue lending money to Russia and reduce tax collection targets that have been condition for further funds (M)

headline: As Iraqi Tension Eases, Arabs Criticize U.S. Role
abstract: Assessment of question of whether United States' standing in Middle East has suffered, with Iraq crisis now in remission; some diplomats and experts argue that crisis demonstrated that there is still no viable alternative to American power in region, or to American mediation between Israel and Palestinians; many Arabs and some Israeli commentators attribute outpouring of support for Iraq on Arab streets to popular perception that United States maintains double standard in Middle East (M)

headline: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?
abstract: Ira P Hasson letter on Fred Waddell's Dec 7 article on financial planning for retirement (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Construction Spending Nov.

headline: PALEX TO BUY FOUR CONTAINER-MANAGEMENT BUSINESSES
abstract: Palex Inc willl buy four container-management businesses, Acme Barrel Co, Container Services Co, Consolidated Container Corp and Drum Service Co, making it nation's largest provider of steel drum services (S)

headline: TITANIUM METALS BUYS PART OF PIPE AND FITTINGS MAKER
abstract: Titanium Metals Corp to buy titanium business of Loterios SpA, maker of titanium pipe and fittings for oil and gas drilling (S)

headline: Panasonic Names Warwick Baker
abstract: Panasonic, subsidiary of Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, names Warwick Baker O'Neill to handle advertising for its electric shavers; that advertising was handled by Poppe Tyson; billings estimated at $6 million to $8 million (S)

headline: Hong Kong Frees A Former Broker
abstract: Hong Kong unexpectedly drops all criminal money-laundering charges against former Merrill Lynch & Co private-client banker Kevin Wallace, leaving him free to leave (S)

headline: Market Place; Sometimes not even a nifty product can save an investment in a new and untried company.
abstract: Market Place column on Heartstream Inc, manufacturer of portable defibrillator; focuses on shareholder losses when Hewlett-Packard Co acquired Heartstream for $11 a share in December; holds Heartstream went public two years ago at $13 a share, and at one point got as high as $17.50 (L)

headline: Hostile Offer For Computer Services Unit
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc intensifies hostile pursuit of Computer Sciences Corp, filing formal tender offer to buy its stock for $108 a share in cash (M)

headline: When Going the Club Route Goes Awry
abstract: Membership in National Association of Investors Corp, umbrella group of about one-third of American investment clubs, has grown rapidly in recent years; one reason is that many investment clubs outperform Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; chart; photo (L)

headline: Oxford Health May Be Facing Deep Changes
abstract: Oxford Health Plans sets shake-up in face of financial losses that could radically change company's policy of offering affordable coverage with tremendous flexibility for consumers in picking doctor; names Dr Norman C Payson chief executive; Stephen F Wiggins will step down as chairman, but remain director; William Sullivan, who replaced Wiggins as chief executive, will remain with company; Oxford says Texas Pacific Group will provide $350 million in fresh capital; plans to seek added $350 million in debt financing; map; graphs; table; photo (M)

headline: St. Bruno Journal; The Babies of Quintland Now: Broke, and Bitter
abstract: Three surviving Dione quintuplets, Yvonne, Cecile and Annette, 63, once among most well-known and photographed children in world, have emerged from decades of seclusion to ask government of Ontario for full accounting of their early years; want to know what happened to some $1 million that disappeared from trust fund set up for them when they were taken from their parents, made wards of state and used as tourist attraction; reject Premier Mike Harris's offer of small pension, interview; map; photos (M)

headline: TMP Worldwide Makes Acquisitions
abstract: TMP Worldwide acquires yellow pages advertising unit of Earle Palmer Brown, as well as four agencies overseas that specialize in recruitment advertising; terms undisclosed; recruitment agencies are Media Partners in Christchurch, New Zealand, Lorraine Jones & Associates in London, Thirty Dogs SA in Paris and De Bussy BV in Baarn, the Netherlands (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ACQUIRE WESTON PAPER
abstract: International Paper Co says it will buy Weston Paper and Manufacturing Co for $232 million in stock (S)

headline: Patents; Giving away money, even quite a bit of money, to support inventors turns out to be not so easy.
abstract: Patents column on difficulty of tracking down inventors to apply for various awards offered to honor American invention; Christopher Columbus Fellowship Foundation, which offered $100,000 prize, found there is no easy way to reach nominees, and ended up with only six; inventors have no common characteristic other than inventiveness, there are no inventors' newsletter that everyone reads or trade group that represents them all; even when inventors can be found, it does not mean they will seek recognition; Christopher Columbus foundation has extended its deadline and is making further efforts to reach out to potential nominees (M)

headline: Reference Disks Speak Volumes
abstract: Multivolume encyclopedia has been rendered nearly extinct by microchip; CD-ROM has become dominant format and has made encyclopedias far more available; compared with book counterparts, CD-ROM encyclopedia is one-tenth the price, takes up one-hundredth the space, contains even more information and can remain up to date by being replaced every few years; photo (M)

headline: Jerome Murray, 85, a Many-Faceted Inventor
abstract: Jerome L Murray, inventor, died Jan 7 at age 85; photo (M)

headline: Raymond-Leopold Bruckberger, Priest and Author, Dies at 90
abstract: Rev Raymond-Leopold Bruckberger, member of the Roman Catholic Dominican Order who became chaplain general of the French Resistance in World War II and a best-selling author in the United States, dies at age 90; photo (M)

headline: Albright Tours Europe to Whip Up Resolve to Punish Serbia
abstract: Foreign ministers of US, France and Germany agree on need for firm and clear measures to stop violence in Serbian province of Kosovo before it spreads to other nations; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright wants mix of diplomacy and punitive sanctions in dealing with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic from six members of contact group that monitor former Yugoslavia, but Russia remains opposed and France noncommital; British and Germans are expected to support Americans, with Italians edging closer to French; Albright says Belgrade must understand seriousness of situation in Kosovo province, where Serbs have cracked down extremely harshly on independence movements by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of population; says regime in Belgrade should pay price for damage it has already done (M)

headline: Some Analysts Warn Investors March May Be Volatile Month
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average ends up 4.73 points, to 8,550.45, but Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 1.64 points, to 1,047.70, in gentle session; analysts warn investors to brace for volatility and to look for selloff when companies begin to warn about first-quarter earnings shortfalls in two weeks; graph (M)

headline: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.04 percent and a six-month bill was at 5.01 percent.
