The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:    TAXABLE

headline: Thousands March in France to Protest Far-Right Push for Power
abstract: Tens of thousands of people march in Paris and other cities to protest power-sharing deals by conservatives with far-right National Front to retain control of some regional parliaments; respond to calls for protests by religious leaders, left-wing parties, civic groups and labor unions (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Lyon's Restaurants, Foster City, Calif., to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young, San Francisco, as agency of record on the account of the chain of 79 casual dining restaurants, which had been handled by Evans, Hardy & Young, Santa Barbara, Calif. Billings were estimated at $5 million.  * Score Learning Centers, San Francisco, a unit of Kaplan Education Centers, a subsidiary of the Washington Post Co., to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners West, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle integrated communications, including advertising, direct mail and design. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: Iraqi Exiles Want Strike Aimed at Hussein
abstract: Iraqi National Congress leader Ahmed Chalabi and other exiled opposition leaders say any military operation that does not explicitly aim to remove Pres Saddam Hussein from power could be counterproductive; say kind of attack Clinton Administration is planning may leave Hussein stronger (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Devalue the yuan? China doesn't seem about to do that.
abstract: Economic Scene on unlikely prospect that Chinese Government will devalue the yuan despite slowing growth, increased pressure from Asian competitors for its export markets and desperate need to create real jobs for millions now ungainfully employed in bloated state enterprises; drawing (L)

headline: A New Kind of Leader for Korea, and Asia Too
abstract: Interview with Kim Dae Jung, who will be sworn in as South Korea's President on February 25; renowned dissident imprisoned in 1980's and later exiled for opposing country's military dictatorship, says he is willing to speak out against human rights abuses in Asia; says solution to region's economic crisis is more democracy, greater openness and freer markets; photos (L)

headline: Puzzle in Mexico Killings: What Did Officials Know?
abstract: Opposition leaders in Mexico, country's newspapers and its angry people demand to know whether anyone with authority in governing Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) knew about, or failed to prevent, massacre of 45 Toztzil Indians in the hamlet of Acteal on Dec 22; state police in Chiapas, which is controlled by PRI, allegedly knew about gunfire in village early on and failed to act; party appears to argue that its vast size, its many layers and deep divisions within it distance federal Government from massacre; photo; map (M)

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: London Journal; What, P.R. at the Palace? A Royal Bother, but . . . .
abstract: Britain's royal family is seen making some adjustments in its public image, following criticisms that royals are out of touch, aloof, arrogant and spoiled, criticisms that erupted with death of Princess Diana; some signs of royals' public-image makeover is that royal yacht is gone, Union Jack flew over Buckingham Palace for Diana's funeral, and Queen Elizabeth went on walkabout on her golden wedding anniversary; photos (L)

headline: Canada Concern In a Realty Deal
abstract: Dundee Realty Corp says it agreed to acquire two closely held real estate concerns, Camreal Corp and Lehndorff Tandem Group, for stock valued at $246 million (Canadian), or $173 million (US); Dundee, based in Toronto, would create one of largest public real estae concerns in Canada, with almost $3 billion (Canadian) in commercial real estate assets under management (S)

headline: Box Office: Top Gauge For Films
abstract: Movie industry is unanimous on one basic measure of success: ticket sales; but this method does not account for effect of inflation; chart listing films with largest domestic box-office grosses, adjusted for inflation (M)

headline: Indonesia Begins the Rescue and Consolidation of Banks
abstract: Moving quickly to fire up the country's stalled economic engine, Indonesia announced the first of an expected series of bank mergers today, aimed at making the financial system more efficient and accountable.    Five private banks will be combined, beginning a process of consolidation of some 240 banks that was called for in a new agreement signed last week with the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Texas Utilities Raises Bid for Energy Group
abstract: Bidding war for Energy Group PLC intensifies as Texas Utilities raises its bid to $7.34 billion, slightly more than Pacificorp's offer of $7.2 billion; Texas Utilities Co says it has spent little more than $1 billion to buy 72.6 million shares, or 13.9 percent stake, in Energy Group (M)

headline: China Will Allow 3 U.S. Clerics to Visit Tibet, Group Says
abstract: American religious leaders traveling to China to investigate religious persecution will be permitted to visit Tibet on their trip; remote region is usually off-limits to human-rights investigators; Clinton Administration officials say they will welcome visit to Tibet by such high-ranking delegation, given continuing reports of brutal human rights abuses against Buddhists; delegation selected by White House and State Dept consists of Rev Don Argue, Archbishop Theodore E McCarrick and Rabbi Arthur Schneier (M)

headline: GE Capital Acquires Factoring Business
abstract: GE Capital Services says it bought First Factors Corp; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: World Bank Vs. Reformers on How to Still Feed Russia When It's 64
abstract: World Bank forces Russia's most ardent reformers to scale back their plan to convert state-run pension system into a program of private individual retirement accounts; thought plan is too risky and pressed for an incremental approach that would leave state-financed pension system with a major role; critics say World Bank dogmatically imposed its vision of a paternalistic state role in social welfare; dispute illustrates enormous influence of World Bank and International Monetary Fund over Russia's social and economic policy and also shows that World Bank's role in encouraging social change is more complex--and more contentious--than generally realized; graph (M)

headline: COMMODITIES
abstract: Frozen concentrated orange juice falls more than 4 percent on signs that Florida will have bumper crop despite heavy rain in December; graph (S)

headline: UNICO AMERICAN SAYS IT IS IN TALKS ABOUT A MERGER
abstract: Unico American Corp says it is in preliminary talks to merge with another company (S)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; INVESTING WITH: Rimas M. Milaitis
abstract: Interview with Rimas M Milaitis, who manages Strong Growth and Income and Strong Equity Income funds; photo; graph (M)

headline: Union Planters To Buy Magna
abstract: Union Planters Corp, Tennessee's largest bank holding company, will acquire Magna Group for $2.3 billion in stock (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; The Internet Gears Up For Conflict With Iraq
abstract: Internet sites on Iraq discussed in light of possible United States attack on Iraq; attack would be first major American military action since emergence of World Wide Web; table; map (M)

headline: HOLLYWOOD PARK TO BUY CASINO MAGIC FOR $81 MILLION
abstract: Hollywood Park Inc agrees to buy Casino Magic Corp for $81 million in cash and assumption of $240 million in Casio Magic debt (S)

headline: G.O.P. Plan Would Cut Capital Gains Holding Time to Year
abstract: Rep Bill Archer, chairman of House Ways and Means Committee, says he will seek to reduce to a year, from 18 months, holding period necessary for investments to qualify for most favorable capital gains treatment; says he will propose that change be effective for sales on or after Jan 1, 1998; officials at Treasury Department give Archer's proposal cool response (M)

headline: GNI GROUP AGREES TO ITS PURCHASE FOR $50.7 MILLION
abstract: GNI Group to be bought by unidentified financial institution and some managers for $50.7 million and assumption of $30 million in debt; GNI shares rise 10 percent (S)

headline: Kenya's President Holds Lead in Tense Race
abstract: Ballot counting continues in Kenya's presidential race, with ex-Vice Pres Mwai Kibaki trailing Pres Daniel arap Moi by small margin; situation remains explosive, with violence possible by loser's supporters and both men accusing electoral commission of rigging race; Kibai urges supporters to remain calm; commits self to forming national unity government with Raila Odinga and other opposition leaders (M)

headline: Japan Shuffles Finance Ministry
abstract: Japan's Ministry of Finance announces new lineup of senior officials after Vice Finance Min Takeshi Komura resigns following bribery scandal; Koji Tanami will succeed him (S)

headline: Lucent Profits Top Estimates
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc announces quarterly financial results beat expectations of Wall Street analysts; during three months ended in December, first quarter of company's fiscal year, earnings excluding one-time charges rose by 30.8 percent, to $1.12 billion, from $859 million in year-earlier period; revenues increased 10 percent, to $8.72 billion, from $7.94 billion in period a year earlier; company announces that chief executive Richard A McGinn will assume chairman's post in February; he will succeed Henry B Schacht, who has left company; photo (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Chris Grindem, new business director at J. Walter Thompson Detroit, a unit of WPP Group, was also named to the position of director for the agency's new retail unit, J. Walter Thompson Retail Group.    * Tina Georgeou was named to the new position of executive vice president and client services director at DeWitt Media, New York. She had been executive vice president and managing director for business development at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

headline: SEAGATE EXPECTS TO POST A SUBSTANTIAL OPERATING LOSS
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc says it expects to post substantial operating loss in its second quarter as lower prices for its goods and slack demand hurt revenues much more than company had originally expected (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, HERBERT
abstract: MENDELSON-Herbert. Thanks for the integral part you played in our success. For 38 years you were always there to guide us. Without you, who knows where we would have been. Gould Investors LP    MENDELSON-Herbert L. On March 23, 1998 of streptococcus A infection. Treasured husband of Joan, cherished father of Susan and Barry Stein, Billy and Carole and Clifford and Tammy, proud grandfather of Benjamin and Noa, Sophie and Michael and Amanda and Annie, devoted son of Ralph (and Edna), adored brother of Myra Waldman and brother-inlaw of Arthur and Susan Resnick, caring uncle of Steven and Bobby (and Amy) Scher and Ben Resnick, and beloved cousin of Marilyn Marber. Herb was a senior partner of Herrick, Feinstein LLP where he practiced law for fortythree years. Herb assisted many organizations with his time, abilities and resources. He served as a member of the board of directors of ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children in Israel, as Chairman of the Greater New York Campaign Cabinet of UJA/Federation, as Chairman of the North Shore Long Island UJA/Federation Campaign Cabinet, and as Head of the UJA Long Island Country Club Mission Program. Herb was also a board member of The Daniel Heumann Fund for Spinal Cord Research, was Chairman of the Glen Oaks Country Club Charity Committee and a board member of the Sigma Alpha Mu Fraternity. At Syracuse University, Herb was selected as the MVP of its lacrosse team and as All American goalie in soccer. The funeral service will be on Wednesday, March 25, 1998, 10:00 AM at Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in Herb's memory may be made to ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children in Israel, 19 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036.    MENDELSON-Herbert L. The Herrick, Feinstein Family is suffering and grieving deeply over the most untimely loss of our ''golden boy,'' our ''go to guy,'' our senior partner. Herb's boyish good looks and athletic prowess, his brilliant and incisive intellect, his lifelong practice of menschlichkeit and devotion to charitable activities on behalf of so many worthy causes will be sorely missed by us, his law firm, by each of the members of the ''one for all, all for one'' Mendelson/Scher Family of which he was the kindly patriarch and by the hundreds of people who consider Herb and his love partner for life, darling Joan, as good friends. Herb taught others about living by the golden rule, about ethics and honesty, about the importance of family and friendship and other values all good people cherish, not by talking, but by his actions and the manner in which he conducted his personal and professional affairs day in and day out. The minions of lawyers and clients he worked with over the last 43 years, not only those in our law firm but also the men and women who sat on the other side of the table, could see in Herb a lawyer who immediately could digest and understand the highly complex issues and quickly devise creative and practical solutions. Herb's talents were prodigious-a resourceful and fertile brain, deep expertise in his specialty, a masterful negotiator, scrupulously honest and fair, all blended in with such a winning personality. After graduating as an All American goalie on the Syracuse University soccer team, Herb became an editor of the Syracuse Law Review. That dynamic combination of mind and body combined with his goodness, sweetness and great sense of humor explains Herb's star quality. We will adore and respect Herb's memory always. Herrick, Feinstein LLP    MENDELSON-Herbert. The Officers and Board of UJA-Federation of New York join members of the Long Island Cabinet in expressing their sorrow at the passing of a kind friend and major supporter. Mr. Mendelson was a chair of the Long Island North Shore Cabinet and was the founder and organizer of the Long Island Country Club Missions program. He was an honoree at the Long Island Inaugural Dinner, and was active for many years in our New York Lawyers Division. We extend our sincere sympathies to his father, Ralph; his wife, Joan; his children, William and Carole, Susan and Barry, and Clifford and Tammy; and to his grandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Martin Rosenman, Chair, L.I. Cabinet Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.    MENDELSON-Herbert. The National Board of the ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children mourns the passing of our devoted, faithful, and beloved member, Herbert Mendelson, husband of Joan, our esteemed Executive Director. The memory of Herbert's devotion to the children of ALYN will always live with us. Herbert was an inspiration to us all. We greatly appreciated his counsel and guidance. We shall miss him and never forget him. Our deepest condolences to his wife Joan, his parents Ralph and Edna, his beloved children Susan and Barry, Billy and Carole, Clifford and Tammy, and adored grandchildren; his sister Myra Waldman and entire family. Simone P. Blum, Chairman of the Board Minnette Halpern Brown Honorary President    MENDELSON-Herbert L. It is with the deepest sorrow that our family mourns the passing of our beloved father, father-in-law and Pop-Pop. He was a unique man. His devotion to us was unwavering as was his love. His good judgment and guidance helped us to make our major life decisions with confidence. He was a great champion throughout life, as an athlete, as a friend and as a total ''mensch.'' He fought the brave battle to the end. We love you Pop-Pop and we will always cherish the legacy of love you left us. Susan & Barry Stein, Ben & Noa Billy & Carole, Sophie & Michael Cliff & Tammy, Amanda & Annie    MENDELSON-Herbert L. It is with tears and profound sadness that we mark the passing of our esteemed friend. You touched our lives significantly and the emptiness that you left can not be filled. To Joan, his beloved wife and his children Susan (Barry), William (Carol) and Clifford (Tami). We extend deepest sympathy. We thank God that Herb lived to enjoy his grandchildren. Our hearts also go out to Myra, his dear sister and Ralph, Herbert's Dad. The world will be somewhat diminished without him. Rest in loving peace. Robert and Andrea Weiss    MENDELSON-Herbert. The entire Alyn Young Leadership Board deeply mourns the loss of Herb, beloved husband of our adored and fearless leader Joan. We, and all of the children of the Alyn Hospital in Jerusalem, benefitted from his kindness, generosity and wisdom. Our hearts go out to Joan, his loving sister, Myra, his parents, Ralph and Edna, and to all of his devoted children and cherished grandchildren. Marilyn Ostro, Hon. Chairman Laura Anreder, Chairman Scott Ostro, President    MENDELSON-Herbert. The Directors and Officers of the former Bank of Great Neck mourn the passing of our good friend and director. His wise counsel and support were always greatly valued. Our condolences to Joan and the entire family. Martin Lifton Robert Fromer Paul Settelmeyer    MENDELSON-Herbert L. My beloved husband, my love for you was and will always be the most profound truth in my life. Your confidence and love for me gives my courage. ''Did you ever know that you're my hero, everything I'd like to be. I can fly higher than an eagle, cause you are the wind beneath my wings.'' Joansie    MENDELSON-Herbert. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Sisterhood and Couples Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Susan Stein, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President    MENDELSON-Herbert L. The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Mr. Herbert L. Mendelson, beloved husband of Joan. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Norman Ricken, President    MENDELSON-Herbert L. Our friendship started with four years of living together in college and endured for over fifty years. A special relationship that cannot be replaced. Robert Fischer    MENDELSON-Herbert. We will miss our dear friend with whom we shared so much. You will always be in our hearts. Sincerest sympathy to Joan and family. Ruth and Nat    MENDELSON-Herbert.Good bye, Friend. Without you, there will always be an unfillable void in our lives. We will miss you so. Helaine and Fred    MENDELSON-Herbert. Goodbye old friend, you will be greatly missed. To the Mendelson family, our hearts are with you. The Maharam family    MENDELSON-Herbert. The best brother in the world. You were always there for me. I will never forget you. Love, Myra    MENDELSON-Herbert L. To a great philanthropist and a great lawyer and a great friend. From Bobbi and Mel Weiss

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Swedish Match North America, Richmond, to Buntin Group, Nashville, to handle its Red Man Brands, which had been handled by Keller Crescent, Evansville, Ind., which will continue to handle other Swedish Match brands. Though billings were not disclosed, total brand spending for Red Man is estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

headline: Now, Two $2.7 Billion Offers for Insurer
abstract: American International Group escalates takeover battle for American Bankers Insurance Group, raising its bid by 23 percent to match amount offered in hostile bid by Cendant Corp, $58 a share for total of about $2.7 billion; Henry R Silverman, chief executive of Cendant, says he is determined to buy American Bankers, and will make his next move in few days; R Kirk Landon, chairman of American Bankers, favors merger with American International (M)

headline: Stumble on the Road to Market; Haste Makes Problems for Creator of Alzheimer's Test
abstract: Nymox Pharmaceutical Corp, Rockville, Md, has run into problems in its efforts to market its test to help doctors rule out Alzheimer's disease in diagnosing their patients; like many other biotechnology companies that are overdependent on single product, Nymox tried to produce some quick sales through newspaper and magazine advertising, but encountered more trouble than it expected; advertising riled the Alzheimer's Association and several neurologists, who maintained test was being marketed directly to consumers without independent verification that it worked; neurologists also reported that some people who feared they had the diseased rushed to their doctors' offices expecting test to ease their fears; Nymox test, if reliable, could bring big advantages in early detection Nymox president, Dr Paul Averback, responds to criticism about advertising of test; photos; graph on number of people reported to have died each year from Alzheimer's; chart on some methods of detection and treatment of the disease (L)

headline: Sears's Net In 4th Quarter Down and It Warns on '98
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co says its earnings dropped in fourth quarter, and warns that first-quarter profit will decline substantially, as more customers fall behind on credit card payments; earnings in fourth quarter, before one-time gain of $24 million, fell 9.7 percent, to $512 million, from year earlier; revenues in quarter were $13.15 billion, up from $12.04 billion (M)

headline: Tanker Operator Stops Takeover Effort
abstract: Frontline Ltd abandons its bid of 3.22 billion kronor ($400 million) for rival tanker operator, ICB Shipping AB of Sweden; says crisis in Asia is clouding outlook for industry (S)

headline: DOVER DOWNS IS GETTING GRAND PRIX ASSOCIATION
abstract: Dover Downs Entertainment Inc to buy Grand Prix Association of Long Beach Inc for about $88 million in stock, cash and options (S)

headline: Bad News, Silver Lining For Indonesian Laborers
abstract: Indonesian security forces are preparing for social unrest as millions of people lose their jobs during nation's deepening recession; situation at steel plant in Surabaya noted; map (M)

headline: Anguish in Biggest Arab-American Community
abstract: Arab-Americans in Dearborn, Michigan, hub of nation's largest Arab-American community, overwhelmingly oppose prospect of American military action against Iraq; say they do not care about Saddam Hussein but about innocents who would be killed; photos (S)

headline: Amnesty Fray Is Heading To the Courts
abstract: Truth and Reconciliation Commission says it will let court decide whether it has exceeded its powers by granting blanket amnesty to top officials of South Africa's governing party (M)

headline: Where Every Worker Is Ruler of the Thermostat
abstract: Team of architects and engineers at Center for Building Performance and Design on campus of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pa, have created prototype for what they have called 'intelligent workplace'; center's director Volker Hartkopf says pleasant workplace may help productivity; he adds that number 1 complaint of office workers is that workplace is too cold and number 2 complaint is that office is too hot; photo (L)

headline: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARD COVER    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH

headline: Merrill Lynch Fails to Reach an Agreement in Women's Suit
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co unexpectedly fails to reach agreement with several female financial consultants on settlement of sexual discrimination case against the firm (M)

headline: Mexico Accuses Foreigners of Aiding Rebels
abstract: Mexico is clamping down on foreigners with tourists visas who sympathize with Zapatista rebel movement in Chiapas; has deported two Americans and probes dozens of other tourists for possible visa violations; is allowing over 200 foreign human rights activists to tour Chiapas on special visas; photo (M)

headline: Block Sells Worldcom Stock to Goldman
abstract: H & R Block Inc says it sold its 30.1 million shares of Worldcom Inc to Goldman, Sachs & Co for $1.03 billion (S)

headline: A Touchy South Africa Takes Pains Not to Kowtow
abstract: Pres Clinton is spending 11 days in Africa, but he is really making two different trips: one to Africa and one to South Africa; South Africa is of Africa, but different too; its economy dwarfs that of any other African countries; some 300 American companies do business there; in Nelson Mandela, South Africa has President whose international stature rivals Clinton's (M)

headline: Official Stamps of Approval for the Euro Plan
abstract: European Commission officially recommends that 11 countries, including Italy, be allowed to join Europe's new single currency plan next year; European Monetary Institute, precursor of new, single European central bank, emphasizes that several countries will still face arduous cost-cutting in years ahead; it also warns that double-digit unemployment in many European countries could create long-term strain on new currency unless countries change their labor policies (L)

headline: Jews Remember Forced Labor Camps in Wartime Swiss Refuge
abstract: Report prepared by Alan Morris Schom for Simon Wiesenthal Center holds Swiss forced thousands of Jews and others given refuge in World War II to work under prison-like conditions, sometimes making gear sold to German Army; several camp survivors attending center conference on restitution of Jewish assets seized by Nazis, Los Angeles, describe beatings and mistreatment in Swiss camps (M)

headline: Suharto Picks A Likely Heir As President Of Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto, 76, strongly hints he favors Min Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie as his next Vice President and potential successor; confirms he plans to seek another term; has been under pressure to name successor to spur investor confidence (M)

headline: EVI to Buy Weatherford in Oil-Gear Deal
abstract: EVI Inc, in latest move by oil-service companies to combine, cut costs and better meet strong demand for exploration equipment, to buy Weatherford Enterra Inc for $2.6 billion in stock; under deal, Weatherford stockholders will get 0.95 share of EVI stock for each share of Weatherford; Thomas R Bates Jr, president and chief executive of Weatherford, comments; chart profiles both companies, noting that acquisition will make EVI fourth-largest oilfield services company worldwide; graphs (M)

headline: Union Leaders Say Railroad Resists Change
abstract: Union leaders contend that Union Pacific's plans to avoid accidents like those that killed 11 people last year are foundering on resistance from railroad's middle managers and field supervisors; comments are made at hearing of National Transportation Safety Board panel that is considering need for tougher Federal rules and enforcement; union leaders cite continuing risks of excessive and unpredictable work hours and lack of training for engineers new to their routes; Union Pacific is in midst of intense hiring and training program to speed its trains and improve working conditions (M)

headline: Mitsubishi to Merge Petroleum Product Units
abstract: Mitsubishi Corp and Mitsubishi Oil Co will merge petroleum product sales units in July and cut staff to reduce operation costs; Mitsubishi Corp is Mitsubishi Oil's largest shareholder (S)

headline: Libya Partners Dismiss Talk of 'Military' Pipe
abstract: LONDON—  Libya and its British engineering partner dismissed as "fantasy" Wednesday the suggestions of some Western security experts that a huge water pipeline project had secret military uses.

headline: Tel Hashomer Journal; A Soldier Dies, and a Forlorn Family Shames Israel
abstract: Economic plight of family of Sgt Nikolai Rappaport, Russian immigrant killed while serving in Israeli army in southern Lebanon, shames Israel; death calls attention to difficulties that remain for many new immigrants from former Soviet Union; map; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Somali Army Officer Is Arrested in Virginia
abstract: Yusuf Abdi Ali, former Somali army officer suspected in deaths of thousands of his countrymen in early 1990's, is arrested by INS in suburban Virginia for lying about his past in order to remain in US (S)

headline: Risk-Reducing Strategy Has Its Own Risks
abstract: Mutual funds can take market-neutral approach because of changes in tax law; in market-neutral investing, managers invest money in stocks that they think are undervalued and then try to 'neutralize' risk by sellling short an equal amount of stocks that they believe are overvalued; if prices of shorted stocks fall, as expected, borrowed securities can be replaced with shares that cost less; first to use market-neutral approach is Barr Rosenberg Market Neutral fund (M)

headline: John Paul Creates 22 More Cardinals, Including 2 American Archbishops
abstract: Pope John Paul appoints 22 new cardinals, including Archbishop Francis Eugene George of Chicago and James Francis Stafford, Archbishop Emeritus of Denver and president of Pontifical Council for the Laity in Rome; of current 123 cardinals eligible to elect new pope, 106 have now been chosen by John Paul (M)

headline: THERMO ELECTRON TO PURCHASE 6 BRITISH BUSINESSES
abstract: Thermo Electron Corp agrees to buy six units from Smiths Industries PLC for $73 million in cash to expand its food-inspection and emissions-monitoring equipment businesses (S)

headline: PSINET REJECTS OFFER FROM USINTERNETWORKING
abstract: Psinet Inc says its board rejected offer from USinternetworking Inc to buy at least 51 percent stake in company for $10 a share in cash, price 19 percent higher than Psinet's closing price (S)

headline: Iraq Toxin Tests on Prisoners Are Not Proved, U.N. Says
abstract: UN officials say that reported photographic evidence supposedly showing Iraq tested chemical and biological toxins on prison inmates is inconclusive; considered more intriguing is Iraqi admission that American investigator, William Scott Ritter Jr, was looking for more solid evidence when he was blocked from visiting two sites as part of UN inspection team; farm where suspect photograph was found two years ago belonged to Hussein Kamel, son-in-law of Saddam Hussein who fled to Jordan in 1995 (S)

headline: SAMSONITE DISCUSSES SELLING 50% STAKE TO PAY DIVIDEND
abstract: Samonsonite Corp is in talks to sell 50 percent equity stake to unnamed investors and use proceeds to pay $30-a-share dividend to stockholders, including Apollo Advisors LP, which is headed by Leon Black, a Samsonite director (S)

headline: On the Record, Arab Leaders Oppose U.S. Attacks on Iraq
abstract: Arab leaders publicly oppose US threat to use military force against Iraq, but some reportedly are hinting in private that they will not be dismayed if US carried out threat (M)

headline: Machine Tool Orders Rose in December
abstract: Domestic orders for machine tools rise 15.1 percent in December to estimated $787.43 million, wrapping up 1997 with fifth straight year of positive annual growth; for all of 1997, estimated orders for tools total $8.6 billion, up 24 percent from 1996; figures are from Assn for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn (S)

headline: Handheld Computer Starts to Come of Age
abstract: PARIS—  This year should see the handheld computer graduating from a costly gadget to a relatively inexpensive and productive tool.

headline: Monsanto Paying Delta Farmers to Settle Genetic Seed Complaints
abstract: Monsanto Co begins paying settlements to Mississippi Delta farmers who contend that cotton strain genetically engineered to survive being sprayed with company weed killer failed to perform as promised; in addition, Monsanto and Delta Pine and Land Co have withdrawn from sale 100,000 50-pound bags of genetically altered seed, although not variety being challenged, for reasons that companies say are unrelated to Mississippi complaints (L)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Vernon Jordan's Resume: Is Too Much Too Much?
abstract: Dan R Dalton article defends Vernon E Jordan against complaints he sits on too many corporate boards and that there is undercurrent of impropriety surrounding his service; holds his long tenure on most boards attests to his positive contributions; holds there is nothing unsavory about expertise he brings as Washington insider; drawing (M)

headline: SYBRON TURNS DOWN CASH OFFER FROM GENCORP
abstract: Sybron Chemicals Inc rejects unsolicited cash offer of $38 a share, or about $215.5 million, from Gencorp Inc after group of shareholders that owns 45 percent of Sybron's stock says it will not sell its shares (S)

headline: Free Baby-Sitting? Just Sit for Others
abstract: Baby-sitting co-operatives, which let families swap sitting duties without exchanging money, are growing in popularity; how such cooperatives work discussed; photo (L)

headline: General Tells Rwanda Court Massacre Was Preventable
abstract: Maj Gen Romeo Dallaire of Canada, former commander of UN peacekeeping troops in Rwanda, tells UN tribunal that 1994 massacre of at least 500,000 people could have been halted if small, well-armed force had been sent in early with that objective; says his force was too small, ill-equipped and poorly trained, and lacked legal mandate to intervene; unanswered is why UN officials apparently ignored his warning that Rwandan Government was planning massacre and why he was not given new mandate to step in; questions are politically delicate for Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who in 1994 was head of UN peacekeeping operations; documents leaked to reporters last year suggested Dallaire had warned Annan; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Asian and Rail Problems Slow U.S. Industry's Pace  American manufacturing growth slowed in December, reflecting the impact of Asia's economic crisis and railroad bottlenecks in this country, the executives who do the buying for the nation's factories said yesterday in a widely followed monthly survey.

headline: People
abstract: * Tim Blett, executive vice president and automotive director at W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield, Mich., was promoted to the new position of president for Doner Automotive, overseeing the agency's new Mazda North American Operations account.    * Barbara A. Salerno was named to the new position of president at Impax Marketing Communications, Philadelphia. She had been vice president for national advertising and broadcast at the Estee Lauder Cos., New York.

headline: Internet Bureau Locates in New York
abstract: Internet Advertising Bureau, association for on-line advertising, establishes headquarters in New York and names Frank Dudley its first director; Rich LeFurgy is re-elected chairman; Richy Glassberg is re-elected vice chairman (S)

headline: LIBRARY/HOME DESIGN; Dreams on Screen, Including Kitchen Sink
abstract: Erika Belsey Worth reviews array of CD-ROM home-design programs; photos (M)

headline: America Online to Raise Fee For Unlimited Use to $21.95
abstract: America Online, whose 11 million members make up more than half home Internet market in US, announces it is increasing its charge for unlimited access to $21.95 from standard monthly price of $19.95; company says it is laying off 500 of 1,000 employees of Compuserve, onetime rival that it purchased last week; America Online's shares surge $11.9375 to all-time high of $110.4375 (L)

headline: New Markets Pages
abstract: Beginning today, Business Day is reorganizing its coverage of the markets for easier reading; new format will appear Tuesdays through Saturdays (S)

headline: NOBLE BUYING OIL PROPERTIES FROM NEW ENGLAND ELECTRIC
abstract: Noble Affiliates Inc says its Samedan Oil Corp unit will buy oil and gas properties from New England Energy Inc, subsidiary of New England Electric System, for $50 million, increasing its reserves in Gulf of Mexico (S)

headline: Feeling Abandoned By America Online
abstract: There is growing frustration among America Online's small content partners, who used to be guaranteed that their site would be featured on America Online's opening screen for at least 15 minutes daily; ever since AOL redesigned its service, users have more complicated steps to get to small partners; photos (M)

headline: Sony Will Buy 5% of Nextlevel
abstract: Sony Corporation to buy 5 percent of Nextlevel Systems Inc for about $188 million and will help Nextlevel develop and distribute set-top devices for digital cable television; set-top boxes increase quality of television pictures and allow users to connect their televisions to Internet over high-speed cable wires (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Intel Goes, So Goes the Rise in Stocks?
abstract: Market Place column discusses adverse impact on stock market following announcement by Intel Corp, dominant maker of computer chips, that its first-quarter sales will fall about 10 percent below modest predictions it made less than two months ago; notes at that time Intel said it expected to match $6.5 billion posted in fourth quarter of 1997; says company is now projecting first-quarter sales of about $5.85 billion; says Intel has become somewhat of bellwether for overall corporate earnings and that its performance this year has played influential role in broader stock market's recent advances to record levels; also notes that after Intel's announcement, stock-index futures contracts dropped sharply, an indication investors fear pullback in market today; says Nikkei index in Japan fell more than 1 percent in early trading (L)

headline: U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS TO SPIN OFF 4 OF ITS UNITS
abstract: US Office Products Co will spin off four units to shareholders, buy back up to $1 billion of its stock and sell $270 million stake in private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc (S)

headline: Buffett's Purchases Push Silver Past $7 an Ounce
abstract: Price of silver jumps to more than $7 an ounce--its highest since 1988--as market gets lift from news that Berkshire Hathaway Inc, controlled by Warren E Buffett, owns $910 million worth of silver; announcement by Berkshire helps explain recent rally in price of silver, which has jumped more than 60 percent since Buffett began buying on July 25; Berkshire owns 129.7 million ounces; graph (L)

headline: Young & Rubicam Hires Media Officer
abstract: Paul Woolmington, top media executive at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, joins Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York in the new post of president and chief media officer for international media operations (Advertising column) (S)

headline: South Africa Gesture Reopens Old Wound
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission said it would let a court decide whether it had exceeded its powers by granting a blanket amnesty last month to top officials of the governing party.     The amnesty, which grants immunity from civil and criminal liability, drew fire from a wide range of opposition parties. They said it was an example of favoritism that undermined the mandate of the commission, which was created as part of the political compromise that eased the way for a peaceful transition from apartheid to a multiracial democracy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: January Job Gains Reflect Economic Vibrancy  The economy created jobs at a surprisingly strong pace in January, evidence that America's economic stamina has withstood any disruptions caused so far by the financial crisis in Asia.

headline: Reporter Visits Pol Pot, Still Held by Khmer Rouge
abstract: Bangkok Post reports that Khmer Rouge guerrillas in Cambodia have allowed Thai reporter, Prasit Saengrungruang, to meet with their imprisoned former leader, Pol Pot, dispelling rumors that he had fled abroad from their jungle hideout; rumors have added to confusion in Cambodia as country begins political maneuvering before elections scheduled for July (M)

headline: Union Pacific Faulted in '97 Accidents
abstract: Federal Railroad Administration says Union Pacific Corp's faulty operating and safety practices contributed to series of rail accidents that killed 11 people in 1997 (S)

headline: Lagerfeld's 'Cosmovision' a Winner for Long-Line Chanel(folo)
abstract: PARIS—  The British designer Deborah Milner confirmed Friday that she had signed a contract to work with Versace.

headline: U.N. Expands Quota for Iraq's Oil Sales
abstract: UN Security Council more than doubles amount of oil that Iraq will be allowed to sell to buy food, medicine and other essential goods; approves Sec Gen Kofi Annan's proposal to allow $5.2 billion in sales every six months (S)

headline: SONOCO SELLING BUSINESS AND EXPECTING LOWER EARNINGS
abstract: Sonoco Products Co will sell its North American labels operations to CCL Industries for $100 million; says it fourth-quarter earnings will be reduced by about $175 million (S)

headline: False Starts Aside, Virtual Reality Finds New Roles
abstract: Languishing technology of virtual reality may reach spotlight now that Sun Microsystems Inc has acquired rights to many of its defining elements; Sun's acquisition of patent portfolio of VPL Research Inc, defunct company that pioneered virtual reality, releases some 35 patent applications, 12 of them already granted, along with other intellectual property from four years of limbo in bankruptcy court; despite patent uncertainty, some applications of virtual reality have emerged from labs into everyday use; photos (M)

headline: In Software Sleight of Hand, Video Ghosts Rise
abstract: Joys of playing vintage video arcade games on personal computer using Mame emulator software discussed; software mimics operating system of coin-operated machines; can play over 300 old games on all current platforms; photos (M)i

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Bayer Diagnostics, Tarrytown, N.Y., to Lehman Millet Inc., Boston, to handle advertising for the Diagnostics Laboratory and Point-of-Care testing units, which had been handled by CRE Communications, Indianapolis. Billings were estimated at more than $3 million.    * Mauna Lai Tropicals Ltd., Braintree, Mass., to Clarke Goward, Boston, to handle its account, which had been inactive when the beverage company was owned by Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

headline: Kenya's Leader Wins a 5th Term, But Opposition Candidates Gain
abstract: Pres Daniel arap Moi is officially declared winner of Kenya's presidential election, giving final term to 20-year-old administration widely criticized for corruption and mismanagement; international and domestic election observers say that Kenya's election, while flawed and chaotic, was not substantially rigged to favor Moi; photos (M)

headline: Dutch Grocery Chain Is Expanding in China
abstract: Royal Ahold NV, Dutch food retailer, says its 50-50 Chinese joint venture in Shanghai, Zhonghui Supermarkets Co, has acquired 22 supermarkets of the Yaohan Liancheng Supermarkets Company, making Ahold the No. 1 foreign operator of supermarkets in China (S)

headline: Hitachi Cuts Jobs in Texas
abstract: Hitachi Ltd of Japan will cut 200 manufacturing jobs as its semiconductor plant in Irving, Tex, in response to market volatility for memory chips (S)

headline: EXCEL TO ACQUIRE 70% STAKE IN GERMAN AUTO SUPPLIER
abstract: Excel Industries agrees to acquire 70 percent stake in Schade GmbH for undisclosed amount in cash; remaining 30 percent of Schade is owned by Hella KG Hueck & Co (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, RUTH S.
abstract: HERZOG-Ruth S. Age 94, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and great grandmother. Dearie to all. An elegant lady of a bygone era.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices fall 2.5 percent to lowest level since January 1997 after Brazilian exporters forecast their biggest crop in 11 years (M)

headline: At Work and at Play, Time's Editor Seeks to Keep Magazine Vigorous at 75
abstract: Walter Isaacson, managing editor of Time magazine, is credited with restoring magazine's authority, raising its profile and helping redefine role of newsweekly in era when people do not need it for news; he has hammered away at idea of telling stories through people, giving readers the news behind the headlines; he has expanded coverage of science and technology and cut back on coverage of foreign affairs; he has initiated special projects, including series of six special issues and television shows looking at influential people of century; Time's competitors, including Newsweek and US News & World Report, say Isaacson has made Time a formidable rival; photos (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: McDonald's Alters System For Kitchens
abstract: McDonald's Corp, in an attempt to freshen its business, says it is switching to high-tech kitchen system that will eliminate warmed-over burgers and fries; company also plans to streamline operations at its headquarters in Oakbrook, Ill, likely resulting in layoffs (M)

headline: 'Who's a Jew' Puzzle Gets More Tangled
abstract: Bitter dispute in Israel over who can perform conversionsto Judaism deepens with competing proposals before Chief Rabbis of Israel; during past seven months, committee headed by Finance Min Yaaakov Neeman has worked out compromse plan that would involve all three movements in preparing candidates for conversion, but actual conversions would still be done by Chief rabbinate, which is Orthodox; in Israel, only legal conversions are those performed by Orthodox rabbis; issue is important because with authority to decide who is Jew also comes power to decide who is eligible for automatic Israeli citizenship (M)

headline: An Extra Day to Fine-Tune 1,000 Years
abstract: Securities Industry Assn will recommend that markets be closed on Dec 31, 1999, to allow brokerage industry extra day to close out its books before millennium; securities industry is spending $6 billion to reprogram every computer to insure that it can handle dates in year 2000 and beyond; one of biggest fears is that different firms and exchanges will adjust their date processing in different ways; in that case, two computers that each have been fixed might nonetheless crash when they are connected to each other; Securities Industry Assn has planned elaborate fire drills during which all brokers, investment companies and exchanges in US will test how their systems work together (M)

headline: To: Readers
abstract: From: Circuits@nytimes.com  Subject: Anything with a chip in it    With this first issue of Circuits, the Times is expanding its coverage of the kind of technology that has already changed the lives of everyone who uses a computer or a cellular phone, everyone who uses a credit card or drives a car, everyone who has a Social Security number.

headline: Saatchi Appoints Top Creative Official
abstract: Stan Becker, who has served as the top creative executive at the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, will step down, the agency said yesterday, and will be replaced by Tod Seisser, a former top creative executive of J. Walter Thompson New York.    Mr. Becker, 63, has worked at Saatchi & Saatchi, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., for 27 years; for the last four years, he has been chief creative officer. Mr. Becker will remain at the agency as a consultant through December.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Says He'll Quit in Budget Dispute
abstract: Israeli Foreign Min David Levy says he will vote against Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's 1998 budget, resigning from Government, news conference; acts after right-wing and religious parties win budget concession at expense of Levy's priorities; Netanyahu delays vote to seek budget agreeable to Levy (M)

headline: Korea Reported To Seek Billions In Bond Offers
abstract: South Korean Government is attempting on its own to secure as much as $35 billion in new financing, according to American commercial and investment bankers; move comes as Bank for International Settlements releases report pointing out that global bankers stepped up lending to country in early 1997 despite indications of 'growing strains in Southeast Asia'; South Korea, by moving to sell bonds on its own, will sidestep American commercial banks' efforts to lead repackaging of country's mountain of troubled loans; almost $40 billion in short-term South Korean debt will have to be restructured by end of March to ease crisis (M)

headline: VENTURE PROMISES FAR FASTER SPEEDS FOR INTERNET DATA
abstract: Three titans of the personal computer industry have joined with most of the nation's largest local telephone companies to enable consumers to receive Internet data over regular telephone lines at speeds much higher than are currently possible, according to executives involved with the alliance.    The Compaq Computer Corporation, the Intel Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation intend to announce the venture next week at a communications conference in Washington, the executives said.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that magazine advertising pages in January increased 1 percent from January 1997, to 13,841.

headline: Algeria Rebuffs a Peace Delegation From the European Union
abstract: Algeria reverses itself and says it would reject European Union peace mission aimed at stopping killings of civilians; holds European Union is not ready to offer help in fighting terrorism and planned to send only mid-level delegation; Britain says higher-level delegation could be put together if other European nations agree (M)

headline: GGT Is in Talks To Be Acquired
abstract: GGT Group PLC acknowledges that it is in talks to be acquired after its Wells BDDP unit lost its Procter & Gamble Co account (S)

headline: Inflation Climbed Only 1.7% in 1997, Its Smallest Increase in 11 Years
abstract: US Bureau of Labor Statistics reports Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, matching analysts' expectations; index rose 1.7 percent in 1997, lowest rate since 1986; rate for 1996 was 3.3 percent; chart (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income Jan.  Construction Spending Jan.

headline: Prince Rupert Journal; On a Menu of Despair, Salmon Is Just the Starter
abstract: Fishermen in Prince Rupert, British Columbia, are locked in bitter dispute with competitors in Alaska over rights to dwindling salmon stocks; struggle came to peak last summer when two hundred Canadian fishing boats blockaded Alaskan ferry to protest lack of progress on fishing rights treaty; Alaskan officials sued Canadian fishermen; they have offered to drop suit if Canadians agree to drop their countersuit and never take out their frustrations on ferry again; map; photos (M)

headline: COLE NATIONAL TO CLOSE ALL 430 GIFT BOUTIQUES
abstract: Cole National Corp will close its 430 department-store gift boutiques, operated mainly in Sears, Roebuck & Co stores, and dismiss 2,000 people to concentrate on its eyewear centers and Things Remembered gift chain; company, which also sells eyeglasses and contact lenses under Sears Optical and Pearle Vision name, will take 1997 charge of $12 million to $14 million (S)

headline: Echlin Loses Effort to End Hostile SPX Bid
abstract: Legislators in Connecticut defeat bill that would have helped Echlin Inc, auto parts maker based in the state, repel hostile $3 billion bid from rival, SPX Corp; lawmakers kill measure that would have forced Echlin shareholders to wait nine months before they could hold special meeting on whether to oust company's board of directors and replace them with appointees of SPX (L)

headline: Prices of Treasuries Little Changed After Day of Fluctuation
abstract: US Treasury securities end slightly higher; 30-year Treasury bond rises 1/16, to price of 103 15/32; yield remains at 5.88 percent for third consecutive trading day; graph; chart (L)

headline: 'Titanic' is turning out to be a success on the scale of its doomed subject.
abstract: Titanic, three-hour and fourteen-minute film that was trashed before it even opened, has turned into movie that just may draw biggest box office in history; photo; graph (M)

headline: Iraqis Must End Defiance On Arms, Clinton Warns
abstract: Pres Clinton steps up pressure on Iraq, sending senior officials to consult with allies in Europe and Middle East and warning Pres Saddam Hussein, in State of Union address, that his defiance of United Nations arms inspections cannot continue; notes Hussein's past use of weapons of mass destruction and cites determination to deny him capacity to use them again; holds Congress is united on issue; weighs sending Defense Sec William S Cohen to Persian Gulf to seek backing for military strike; is sending State Sec Madeleine K Albright to Europe to confer with British, French and Russian counterparts on Iraq; Britian leads talks on new Security Council resolution to give Hussein another chance to back down; Russians seek way to avoid military strike (L)

headline: U.S. Officials Tackle Crisis In Indonesia
abstract: Team of Pres Clinton's top aides arrive in Singapore and immediately begins searching for ways to stop free fall of Asian currencies and stock markets; economic crisis in region is beginning to take a political and social toll, especially in Indonesia, where Pres Suharto is under pressure from three directions: the markets, International Monetary Fund and retired generals and academics calling for him to step aside or designate a successor whoc an soon take over; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MIRAMAR MINING CORP., Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would cut ore production at its Con gold mine in Canada's Northwest Territories by 50 percent and lay off 130 employees because of lower prices for gold and high operating costs.

headline: Bond Yields At the Lowest In Decades
abstract: Recent speech by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan in which he mentioned deflation (widespread price declines) results in yield on 30-year Treasury falling to 5.74 percent, lowest level since Government began issuing the bond regularly in 1977; yields on other long-term debt hover at about 6.6 percent; market analysts link decline in long-term rates to continuing good news on inflation--now below 2 percent--and hope that rapid pace of economic growth in 1997 will slow by right amount this year; despite decline in long-term rates, shorter-term rates have not fallen so far; Greenspan's remark on deflation came in speech to American Economic Association and American Finance Association, Chicago; chart; graph on 3-month Treasury bills (M)

headline: Boeing and Lockheed Have a Pact On Supplies
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp and Boeing Co, nation's two largest military contractors, agreed on principles to govern their relationship in order to eliminate antitrust concerns of Government; in particular, they agreed not to discriminate against each other in buying and selling components and electronic systems; two companies also agreed to protect each other's proprietary information; need for agreement reflects fact that with all acquisitions they have made, two competitors are also involved in dizzying array of cooperative activities, including supplier arrangements on three dozen major Pentagon programs (M)

headline: It's Brand Over Bargain In the World of Cigars
abstract: Outlook for investing in stock of American cigar makers discussed; stock prices have dropped sharply as shortage of premium cigars has eased; table; photos (M)1

headline: France Telecom Returns To Profitability
abstract: France Telecom SA says it returned to profitability in second half of 1997; company earned 6 billion francs ($980 million) in latest six-month period, compared with loss of 4.2 billion francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Hollywood Entertainment Corp., Wilsonville, Ore., to Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., to handle advertising for the Hollywood Video retail chain, which had been handled by Suissa Miller Advertising, Santa Monica, Calif. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them as $10 million to $20 million.

headline: U.S. to Auction Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the auction of two-year notes tomorrow and five-year notes on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.04 percent and a six-month bill was 5.05 percent. In when-issued trading ahead of the note auctions, the two-year was offered at a price to yield 5.48 percent, and the five-year at a price to yield 5.53 percent.

headline: On U.S. Carrier, Not Just a Routine Day
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen visits aircraft carrier USS George Washington, which polices 'no flight' zone over southern Iraq; says he hopes American military buildup in area will result in peaceful end to confrontation with Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Small Satellite Phones: An Expensive Gamble
abstract: Iridium LLC has developed first truly hand-size satellite phone, usable anywhere on globe on single number; Iridium and its rival, Globalstar LP, are expected to spend combined $7 billion on competing versions of phone; they are gambling on swiftly profiting from globe-trotting business people and local users in vast, underdeveloped regions of Russia, Latin America and China, which have recently opened to businesses such as but lack modern communications; industry critics and some regional wireless providers say companies have inflated demand for advanced phone costing up to $3,000, with per-minute charges of $4.50 and higher; Wall Street has endorsed idea, sending stocks of Iridium and Globalstar soaring; photo; chart (M)

headline: Texaco Stock Buyback
abstract: Texaco Inc says it will buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock, or 3.1 percent of its 522.2 million basic shares as of Dec 31 (S)

headline: RAYOVAC TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND EXPAND BATTERY OUTPUT
abstract: Rayovac Corp will close two plants, consolidate operations at three sites and expand output of alkaline batteries, which make up 90 percent of the market (S)

headline: Senate Fails to Reverse Ruling That Mexico Is Fighting Drugs
abstract: Senate upholds Clinton Administration's decision last month to certify that Mexican Government is 'fully cooperating' with US in fight against drug trafficking; bipartisan effort to reverse Administration's decision is rejected by Senators, by vote of 54 to 45; Senate takes action despite confidential Government assessments that anti-drug efforts by Mexico have not produced significant results, and that Mexican military's ties to drug cartels may be much broader than Mexican authorities have acknowledged (M)

headline: Campaigns are making mistakes on purpose in the quest to stand out from the crowd.
abstract: PRINT advertisements have become replete with inadvertent mistakes, from a reference to a student making the ''honor role'' by the Partnership for a Drug-Free America to a description of Pepperidge Farm garlic bread as ''the ultimate compliment to pasta'' to a sale on ''classic music'' at the Nobody Beats the Wiz retail chain. Now, though, some print ads feature mistakes that are anything but accidents.    The ploy, meant to help sales pitches stand out in a sea of look-alike advertising, appears in print ads that are presented in the form of hand-written letters or notes. There are words scratched out or crossed out or obscured by ink blots -- as if the creators were too harried or hurried to correct their missives or too hazy to write right the first time.

headline: Canadian Indians Win a Ruling Vindicating Their Oral History
abstract: Recent ruling by Canadian Supreme Court will allow Gitxsan Indians of Kispiox, British Columbia, to use folklore as legally binding evidence that can be used, along with other histories, to support their claim to as much as 22,000 square miles of area's remote interior; by essentially validating Indian claims to land even where no treaties or titles exist, ruling may redefine how Government deals with 1.3 million Indians across Canada; claims by other Indian groups cover all of province's nearly 600,000 square miles; map; photo (M)

headline: Federal Express to Raise Shipping Rates
abstract: Federal Express Corp will increase rates for shipments within US an average of 3 percent to 4 percent on Feb 15 and will expand its international service to include cheaper freight delivery; Federal Express says it will begin international economy shipping Feb 2 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A REIT with nursing homes adds a race track and so on. Growth is good, but is there a strategy?
abstract: Market Place column on strategy of Meditrust Companies, a real estate investment trust that started with nursing homes, then combined with Santa Anita Race Track and is now on full-fledged acquisition spree; graph (L)

headline: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL SAYS IT BOUGHT 12 PROPERTIES
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust, nation's largest apartment owner, buys 12 properties in six stats for $158.2 million (S)

headline: Suharto Is Still Weighing a Drastic Economic Move
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto, in major address, says austerity measures demanded by International Monetary Fund to overcome nation's economic crisis have not borne fruit and that country must find its own formula for recovery; thanks international community for assistance and says Indonesia will continue working with IMF, which he calls authoritative and highly effective international institution; says he is still considering pegging exchange rate of rupiah to dollar, drastic measure opposed by IMF and US; photo (M)

headline: Spreading the Medicare Umbrella Earlier
abstract: Implications for early retirees and others of Pres Clinton's proposal to let people as young as age 55 buy into Medicare, Federal health insurance program now limited to those 65 or older, discussed; plan is likely to attract those with pre-existing medical problems that led private insurers to reject them or charge them high premiums; would be too expensive for many middle-aged Americans; photos (M)

headline: Cambodia Coup Leader Battles Instability
abstract: Hun Sen, who six months ago led coup in Cambodia in which he ousted his coalition partner, Norodom Ranariddh, is still struggling to consolidate political and military control in country; he has failed to win international legitimacy as criticism continues from abroad about his Government's human rights abuses and repression; political, military and international pressures on Hun Sen have begun to intensify with election expected later this year; photo (M)

headline: Antitrust Concerns May Scuttle Merger Of 2 Arms Makers
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp says Government 'fundamentally' opposes its planned purchase of Northrop Grumman Corp, suggesting Federal regulators believe consolidation among military suppliers has gone too far to maintain competition; Defense and Justice Departments say they have serious concerns about merger; Pentagon has recently encouraged such mergers to help cut costs amid falling military spending; belated news of Government's concerns surprises industry and Wall Street; Northrop's shares plunge; many analysts think deal will still go through, but that Lockheed will have to sell some operations of combined companies and take other steps to enhance competition (M)

headline: From a Supplier of Gas Comes a Digital Pipeline
abstract: Williams Companies has announced its return to national communications business with 11,000-mile fiber optic network and $1 billion in contracts; Williams is bidding to become one of country's main providers of wholesale high-speed communications services, capitalizing on practically insatiable appetite for advanced networks that can carry voice, video and data traffic; real question facing Williams communications operation is whether nation needs another high-speed communications network (M)

headline: Keating Convictions in Collapse Of an S.& L. Thrown Out Again
abstract: Federal Judge John Davies throws out for second time the criminal convictions of Charles H Keating Jr for his part in collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan, debacle that cost taxpayers $3.4 billion; state prosecutors say they will appeal decision; Judge Davies rules that Judge Lance Ito, who originally heard state's case, gave jury improper instructions (M)

headline: An Interview With Kim Dae Jung
abstract: In his first interview since he was elected president of South Korea on Dec. 19, Kim Dae Jung said Sunday that he had warned the outgoing government to take some emergency steps on the economy but that "it disregarded every one of my proposals."

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil pirces are near four-year lows on futures markets due to mild winter, decline in demand in Asia and squabbling among OPEC members; graph (M)

headline: The Price of Privacy
abstract: Jonathan Coe letter on Mar 19 article on consumers' data trail and its threat to privacy (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  CERTNER, JOEL
abstract: CERTNER-Joel. In loving memory of our beloved Joel, who would have been 53 today. Mother, Naomi and Jerry

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Toys 'R' Us in Shake-Up As It Issues Profit Warning  Toys ''R'' Us warned that it expected to fall significantly short of earnings estimates for the year, catching Wall Street off guard. It also appointed a new president and chairman.    The earnings disappointment is especially troubling because it comes after one of the toy industry's most successful years recently, one in which shoppers could not get enough of a variety of hot sellers, from Sing & Snore Ernie to virtual pets. [Page D2.]

headline: New Air Chief In Russia Has No Regret On Korean Jet
abstract: Col Gen Anatoly Kornukov, new chief of Russian Air Force, acknowledges that he gave the order to shoot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 in 1983 and says he does not regret the decision, which resulted in death of all 269 people aboard (M)

headline: Ex-Moscow Atom Chief Still in the Fray
abstract: Interview with Russia's former atomic weapons chief Viktor Mikhailov, who has re-emerged with little loss of influence as First Deputy Minister and chairman of ministry's scientific council (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In Search of a More Democratic Grapevine
abstract: Market Place column on concern of Arthur Levitt Jr, chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, about misuse of telephone when corporations put out important news; at issue is common practice of companies holding telephone conference call with favorite Wall Street analysts and selected institutional investors to announce important developments prior to drafting news release on subject; Levitt notes that after analysts know news, but before public knows it, there is great deal of unusual trading; says such trading violates spirit, if not letter, of insider trading prohibitions; says SEC may take action to prevent such abuse; suggests that companies advise everyone on conference calls that they are privy to inside information and should not trade until news is disseminated; photo (M)

headline: Technology to Let Engineers Filter the Web and Judge Content
abstract: World Wide Web Consortium, group of 200 computer scientists and engineers, has endorsed technical standard for filtering electronic information on World Wide Web, called PICS; new standard is being cheered as tool for concerned parents, but civil libertarians argue that members of consortium are acting as unelected world government, wielding power that will shape social relations and political rights for years to come; critics contend that in cyberspace, computer code has force of law; Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of World Wide Web and director of consortium, defends it as force for social good; Microsoft Corp has already incorporated early version of content selection technology into its Internet Explorer Web browser; diagrams (M)

headline: 'Q' for Quebec Electric Loses Political Glow, Too
abstract: Week of heavy ice that wrecked electric pylons and left millions of people without power has cast shadow on image of Hydro-Quebec, government-owned company that is symbol of Quebec's self-sufficiency; number of households without power has been cut from peak of 1.4 million to 400,000; company's woes raise questions about policies that left Quebec one of most electricity-dependent places in world; photo (M)

headline: Pope Elevates 20 Cardinals, Who Include 2 Americans
abstract: Pope John Paul II elevates 20 prelates to rank of cardinal; Pope receives 19 of them during outdoor ceremony in Rome; one cardinal is hospitalized; Pope also names two other men cardinals 'in pectore,' procedure to keep their identities secret; Francis Cardinal George of Chicago and James Cardinal Stafford, former archbishop of Denver, are among new cardinals (M)

headline: Fund Concern Fined $125,000 Over Ads
abstract: Fundamental Service Corp and company's vice president, Vincent J Malanga, and marketing director, David P Wieder, agree to pay $125,000 to settle charges that they falsely advertised volatile, money-losing mutual fund as conservative investment; combined fine is one of largest ever imposed by National Association of Securities Dealers on a fund company for deceptive advertising; Fundamental neither admits nor denies any wrongdoing (S)

headline: Fiery Uprising Kills 8 Detainees in Camp And a Police Officer : Crackdown In Malaysia Sets Off Riot By Illegals
abstract: SEMENYIH, Malaysia—  Nine people were killed Thursday as hundreds of illegal Indonesian immigrants rebelled at a detention camp here hours before they were to be deported across the Strait of Malacca.

headline: British Giant Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: BAT Industries reports loss of 15 million pounds ($24.7 million) in three months ended Dec 31 after making 279 million pounds in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Ground Zero, Santa Monica, Calif., was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $10 million. One was Activision Inc., Santa Monica, the interactive entertainment software company, previously handled by Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica. The other was the Genesee Brewing Company, Rochester, previously handled by Pedone & Partners, New York.    * Share Wave Inc., El Dorado Hills, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to introduce a wireless home networking product. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cadbury Schweppes's stock has run up despite loose ends in its American soft-drink business.
abstract: Market Place column rise in stock of Cadbury Schweppes despite loose ends in its American soft-drink business; Cadbury Schweppes announced last month that it had extended bottling agreement for its Dr Pepper soft drink through 2005; distributor, Coca-Cola Enterprises, has operations only in certain areas of US and Britain and accounts for just under 19 percent of Dr Pepper's sales volume; pact also does not cover most of other Cadbury brands, including 7-Up; graph (L)

headline: Prices Rise Despite Strength In February's Report on Jobs
abstract: US Treasury prices rise; 30-year Treasury bond is up 22/32, to price of 101 16/32; yield falls to 6.02 percent from 6.06 percent on March 5; chart (M)

headline: California Federal Stock Offering Delayed
abstract: California Federal Bank's initial public offering of stock is delayed as savings regulators review plan (S)

headline: 3,000 G.I.'s To Be Added To U.S. Force In Kuwait
abstract: US will build up forces in Persian Gulf by sending 2,500 to 3,000 more soldiers to Kuwait; disclosure comes day after Pentagon said it would not use Saudi bases for attacks against Iraq; Defense Sec William S Cohen visits Kuwait and Oman on second day of whirlwind tour of region; photo; map (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of last week's events affecting financial markets and the economy; photos

headline: When Reservations Aren't
abstract: Letter by Mandy Katz on Jan 11 article on revamping of rental car industry (S)9

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Instability by the Barrelful?; Central Asia's Coming Oil Bonanza and Its Consequences
abstract: Vast tide of oil profit is about to hit Azerbaijan; by 2005, Azerbaijan will receive about $5 billion in annual state income from oil, five times its entire 1997 budget, with more money coming in later years; coming cash flood is provoking as much anxiety as excitement in Azerbaijan and overseas; worry is that wealth may foster instability in Caspian Basin--Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan--by fortifying short-sighted autocracies that are allowing privileged few to grab almost all the initial spoils; experts estimate that three Caspian republics possess more than 100 billion barrels of oil; map; chart; photo (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies column; dollar falls for first time this week against yen; graphs (S)

headline: Profits Fall 11% At Semiconductor Maker
abstract: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics NV says fourth-quarter profit fell 11 percent as semiconductor prices drop amid worldwide overcapacity (S)

headline: Business Travel: Open Skies, Closed Markets?; Growing Debate Over Keeping Airlines Competitive
abstract: Twenty years after Federal Government deregulated airline industry, there is growing debate over whether major carriers are unfairly reining in their smaller rivals, curbing their growth and even blocking their access to new markets; Justice Department has started antitrust investigation of biggest airlines and Transportation Department is on verge of issuing guidelines that would define for first time when Government might take action against carrier for competing unfairly; several bills have been introduced in Congress that aim to blunt dominance of big carriers and promote competition; charts; graphs; map; photo (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: VW Is Fined $111 Million in Antitrust Case
abstract: European Commission fines Volkswagen AG a record 102 million European Currency Units, or about $111 million, because its Italian dealers broke European Union antitrust law by refusing to sell cars to Germans and Austrians seeking lower prices (M)

headline: Asian Ripples Seen
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned that Asia's financial crisis would be felt in the United States, but said that the slowdown would reduce any risk of inflation and that the economy was sound.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Turnaround at Apple Surprisingly Strong  Apple Computer made good on a promise of quarterly profit, saying it earned $47 million in the three months ended Dec. 26, compared with a $120 million loss a year earlier.     The turnaround was stronger than expected, and company executives attributed it to cost reductions and vibrant sales of its G3 Power Macintoshes. But industry analysts cautioned that it remainedunclear whether the company could sustain profitability and reverse the long-term erosion in its market. [Page D2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Surges 116 Points, As Market Sets Records  Stock market indexes soared to records, as investors bought on expectations of strong corporate profits and declining interest rates -- the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.86 percent.    The Dow Jones industrial average surged 116.33 points, or 1.35 percent, to 8,718.85, closing above 8,700 for the first time. Since the beginning of the year, the Dow has risen 810.60 points, or 10.25 percent. [Page D10.]

headline: SUN COAST SHARES LEAP ON WORD IT WILL BE ACQUIRED
abstract: Stock of Sun Coast Industries rises by more than 51 percent after Kerr Group Inc says it has agreed to acquire Sun Coast for $44 million; Sun Coast shares close at $10.4375, up $3.5625 (S)

headline: State Crimes Shake Turkey As Politicians Face Charges
abstract: Turkish court rules that Sedat Bucak and Mehmet Agar, leading figures in major political scandal, may be tried for crimes they claim they committeed on behalf of the state; two were named in parliamentary report investigating charges that successive Turkish Governments have used death squads against Kurdish nationalists and other perceived enemies; defendants do not deny anti-terrorist work, but say it was authorized by high officials; scandal erupted after 1996 crash of car in which Bucak, who heads pro-Government Kurdish militia, was riding with senior police officer and convicted heroin smuggler wanted by police and Interpol (M)

headline: Cosy Paris Boutiques That Dare to Be Different : Off the Beaten Shopping Path
abstract: PARIS—  Mega boutiques for mega names have been monopolizing the main shopping axis of Paris, from the just opened Louis Vuitton on the Champs Elysees and the Emporio Armani on the Left Bank's Boulevard St. Germain to the madly multiplying Gap stores, but a handful of smaller boutiques are daring to be different.

headline: VIEWPOINT; Consulting: Don't Lose It, Improve It
abstract: Thomas J Waite article on current criticisms of consulting industry; offers companies advice on ways of finding consultants best suited to their needs (M)

headline: Accord Is Reported to Open Eight Iraqi Sites
abstract: Accord reached between UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan and Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein reportedly will allow inspections of eight presidential sites previously off limits, including variety of buildings and grounds enclosed in three compounds in Baghdad, as well as around Tikrit, Mosul and Basra; apparently does not address issue of other presidential properties, excluded from eight listed by Baghdad, identified by inspectors as suspect weapons areas or places where crucial documents may be hidden; Iraq has reportedly been persuaded to drop time limit of 60 days it wanted to impose on inspections of presidential sites (M)

headline: Continental Is Said to Reach Deal On Contract With Pilots' Union
abstract: Continental Airlines reportedly reaches tentative accord with Independent Association of Continental Pilots on new five-year contract; deal reportedly offers pilots chance to share in profits that may result from Continental's alliance with Northwest Airlines and protects pilots in event airlines merge (M)

headline: Bank of England Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: Bank of England leaves its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 7.25 percent, amid growing evidence that earlier rate increases were cutting into consumer demand; borrowing costs in Britain are already highest among Group of Seven industrializled countries (S)

headline: A Background Check Far From Ordinary
abstract: Pakistan investigators say Asif Ali Zardari, husband of then Prime Min Benazir Bhutto, opened Citbank account in Geneva in Feb 1995 through which they say he passed some $40 million of the $100 million he received from payoffs from foreign companies doing business in Pakistan; bank declines comment (M)

headline: In the Beginning, There Was Kaypro
abstract: Justin Kaplan and his wife Anne Bernays, both writers, buy their computers in pairs; some have died, some have become obsolete, some have been given away; most just sit somewhere or other in their home; photo (M)

headline: Machine Tool Orders Down In November
