abstract: Orders from American companies for domestic- and foreign-produced machine tools fell 12.7 percent in November, to estimated $637 million, from revised gain of 11.3 percent, to $730 million, in October; estimated machine tool orders for first 11 months of 1997 totaled $7.51 billion, 18.8 percent ahead of corresponding period year earlier; figures are from Assn for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn (S)

headline: Small Progress in U.N.'s Chasm With Iraq
abstract: Iraqis and chief United Nations weapons inspector Richard Butler make some progress in talks, Baghdad; Butler charges Iraq refuses to provide further documentation to back its claims that certain weapons have been eliminated; rejects demands that American U-2 surveillance planes flying over Iraq for UN be replaced by Russian or possibly French planes, but agrees to weigh using other aircraft to supplement U-2s; calls talks toughest yet, interview; photos (M)

headline: From Lake Wobegon and Beyond, A Round Table on Economics and Finance
abstract: Radio talk show host Garrison Keillor discusses stocks and matters financial, from perspective of Lake Wobegon, with additional observations from writings of Mark Twain and Will Rogers; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Inquiry Hears Audio Tapes Of Jet That Hit Ski Lift Cable
abstract: Italian authorities listen to tape recordings between crew of NATO-based American plane that clipped ski cables in northern Italy and air traffic controllers; hope tapes will help them answer fundamental questions about plane's altitude, speed and flight path; accident, in which all 20 people aboard ski lift car were killed, occurred during low-level flying exercise aimed at avoiding detection by radar (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; Ruble Is Streamlined, Trimmed Down by 3 Zeros
abstract: *Russia, in new bid to revise battered currency, lops three zeros off ruble; cosmetic change, announced last Aug, is essentially psychological; old rubles will be accepted with new ones for year; Russians, recalling history of painful ruble reform, rushed to change rubles into dollars in advance of change; photo (M)

headline: Silicon Graphics Selects McCann
abstract: Silicon Graphics, San Jose, Calif, names McCann-Erickson San Francisco as first agency to handle advertising for its new Visual PC Group; billings are estimated at $40 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: ALLEGHENY TELEDYNE EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW ESTIMATES
abstract: Allegheny Teledyne Inc predicts its first-quarter earnings before special items will fall below analysts' estimates (S)

headline: TCI Resolves Long Dispute With Estate of Company Founder
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc says it reached an arrangement that will give its chief executive, John C Malone, greater control of the company; says it reached complex resolution of its dispute with the estate of the founder of the company, Bob Magness, and that agreement could give Malone effective voting control over stock of Magness estate; dispute has been closely followed because of its potential effect on who controlled Tele-Communications; Magness heirs had sued TCI and some of their own advisers, contending earlier arrangement, which would have let TCI buy large amount of their holdings at market price, was unfair; new agreement detailed (M))

headline: Deutsche Telekom Posts A Drop in Profits
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG says in preliminary report that its profit fell 6 percent in second half of 1997 to 1.5 billion marks; graph (S)

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN EYE CARE CENTERS
abstract: Eye Care Centers of America Inc says Thomas H Lee Co, investment company, and its affiliates will acquire 90 percent of company for $300 million; current majority owner, Desai Capital Management Inc, will hold remaining 10 percent (S)

headline: U.S. Training of Indonesia Troops Goes On Despite Ban
abstract: US Defense Department still trains Indonesian military forces in specialized arts of warfare, despite 1992 Congressional ban intended to curb human rights abuses by Indonesian soldiers; Pentagon says training is entirely legal since it is taking place under auspices of program different from one curtailed by Congress, and enhances rather than diminishes US ability to positively influence Indonesia's human rights policies and behavior; some members of Congress criticize training as dramatic end run around rules that Congress has carefully prescribed for military training and education of Indonesian forces (M)

headline: Chrysler takes wing on effort to revive identity of its Chrysler division as the home of the upscale.
abstract: Chrysler Corp is trying to revive its Chrysler division with new campaign, three new cars and a new symbol; new advertising campaign was created by Bozell Worldwide (L)

headline: Strong Finish to Christmas Season Cheers Retailers
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co same-store sales index reports retail sales were up 4.4 percent in December, compared with 2.9 percent gain in December 1996 and well above 3 percent gains most retail experts were forecasting; strong sales showings were due almost entirely to 48 hours before Christmas and the week after Christmas; graph; chart (L)

headline: World Court Claims Jurisdiction In Pan Am Flight 103 Case
abstract: World Court in The Hague rules it has authority to decide whether Libya should surrender two suspects for trial on charges of blowing up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988; rejects US and British claims to jurisdiction (S)

headline: Aetna Deal for New York Life's Health Unit Is Expected Today
abstract: Aetna Inc is reportedly buying NYLCare Health Plans, health care business of New York Life Insurance Co, for $1.05 billion in cash; reportedly will pay as much as $300 million more if NYLCare meets certain growth targets in next two years; NYLCare provides health insurance for 2.2 million people, including 1.5 million under managed care; Aetna has 13.7 million health insurance customers; merger is not expected to have immediate effect on costs, benefits or physician relationships for customers of two companies; analysts say melding NYLCare with Aetna may prove challenging, in light of difficulties Aetna has had in absorbing US Healthcare, which it acquired in 1996 (M)

headline: Seed of Hope In Ulster Soil
abstract: James F Clarity analysis contends that while encouraged by new willingness of both sides finally to grapple with details after 19 months of peace talks in Northern Ireland, Catholic and Protestant leaders fear that effort remains vulnerable to fringe groups determined to wreck accord; says most officials agree that proposals put forward on Jan 12 by British and Irish Governments are important step toward ending sectarian warfare (M)

headline: In Six Markets, I-Link Offers 4.9-Cent Calls
abstract: Small company called I-Link Inc will offer long-distance callers in six markets opportunity to make calls for 4.9 cents a minute if they converse using Internet technology rather than traditional communications systems; catch is that calls using Internet systems rarely sound as good as those that travel over older sorts of networks (S)

headline: Hitting a Bump in the Medical Leave Law
abstract: Communications Workers of America files Federal class-action suit charging Bell Atlantic with not properly informing 35,000 Nynex workers about Federal family and medical leave act, and violating guidelines for approving leaves; employees Penny Wortz and Maureen Evans discuss their cases; photo; Donna Lenhoff of Family Leave Commission says overall assessment is that law is working well for most companies and employees; bipartisan commission was set up by Congress to evaluate law (M)

headline: Cohen Tries To Calm Italy Over Deaths At Ski Lift
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen seeks to contain political fallout in Italy over deaths caused when American jet clipped ski lift's cable, pledging full cooperation in joint investigation and review of all NATO training flights in Italy; despite his pledges and apologies, it is clear that divisions remain over investigation and its consequences (M)

headline: The Latest Wrinkles in the Battle to Look Young
abstract: PARIS—  An obsession with youth and a stigmatization of age dominate today's world. And it has become big business for those professionals who depend on making women feel good — plastic surgeons, skin specialists and cosmetic companies.

headline: Vanguard's Index Killer
abstract: John J Nagorniak discusses his successful management of Vanguard's Growth and Income (formerly Quantitative) Fund, which has bested stock-index rivals year after year; photo; fund had 19.1 percent annualized return over last ten years, and 46.4 percent return in last year (S)

headline: Tighten Belts, Suharto Tells His People, It's All Over
abstract: Pres Suharto calls on Indonesians to tighten their belts, saying rapid growth in prosperity they have enjoyed over last 25 years is gone for good; it is his strongest public statement about economic crisis that has made almost all of Indonesia's 200 million people suddenly poorer; Suharto begins his seventh five-year term as President; assembly endorse B J Habibie as new Vice President; photo (M)

headline: Power Deregulation: Shadow, Substance and Politics
abstract: Analysis of Clinton Administration's presentation of guidelines as to how it would like to see utility industry deregulated, including innovative way for consumers to easily compare deals offered by rival sellers of power; says it is unclear whether proposals will help expedite process of dismantling the industry; says under some of major guidelines, utilities would have to open themselves to competition by year 2003, a fund of $3 billion would be established to help low-income people with their electric bills, and old laws governing utility industry would be repealed (L)

headline: Selling Europe on the Stock Market
abstract: Europeans, who have long viewed stock investing as too risky, are learning to become shareholders; are shifting savings to common stocks and mutual funds, spurred by low yields on competing investments and by greater sense that they are responsible for their financial security; both European and American financial services companies prepare to serve expanding market; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Hively Agency Shuts Down
abstract: Hively Agency in Houston, Tex, has closed; it liquidated after 11-month effort to reorganize under Chapter 11 Federal bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: HINDU-FIRST PARTY EXPECTED TO GAIN IN INDIA'S ELECTION
abstract: India's Hindu nationalist party, led by Atal Bihari Vajpayee, is expected to make major gains in voting set to begin across India ; expectation that party may do well enough to form government, or at least head governing coalition, is disturbing to many Muslims and to other Indians who reject Hindu nationalism; anxieties have been growing, with troops moved into some areas and curfews set to bar election violence; Sonia Gandhi, Italian-born Roman Catholic who pits her soaring personal popularity against tarnished image of her Congress Party, poses strongest challenge to nationalists; map; photo (L)

headline: IRON MOUNTAIN IN $28 MILLION DEAL FOR INTERMATION
abstract: Iron Mountain Inc acquires Intermation Inc, closely held records-management business, for $28 million in stock, cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: The Little Project That Couldn't; Others Learn From a Failed Test in Worker Democracy
abstract: * Article reviews pioneering Bolivar Project that tranformed operations of Harman Automotive rear-view mirror factory in Tennessee in 1970's through worker empowerment and management innovations; audacious experiment fell victim to changes in mnanagement and human nature, as workers took advantage of disastrous 'earned idle time' benefit to leave early and cheat on time and production; former owner Sidney Harman says he did not realize how critical good management would be when he devised project with UAW official Irving Bluestone; Harman sold factory in 1976 and subsequent owners were happy to see experiment die; UAW also lost interest once Bolivar was used to get Big Three auto makers to look at power sharing; concepts developed by Bolivar are now widespread; photos; graph; missteps that led to shutdown recounted; current owner Harvard Industries is now in bankruptcy (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HONEYWELL INC., Minneapolis, the maker of automation and control systems, bought Hughey & Phillips Inc., Simi Valley, Calif., a closely held company that makes airfield lighting systems, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: NETWORK ASSOCIATES ACQUIRING TRUSTED INFORMATION
abstract: Network Associates Inc agrees to buy Trusted Information Systems Inc for $300 million in stock (S)

headline: 5 Companies Are Seeking Inter-Continental Hotels
abstract: At least five companies are bidding to buy Inter-Continental Hotels, Japanese-owned company whose portfolio includes some 175 hotels and resorts; winning bid is expected to top $2.5 billion; bidders in auction are Marriott International Inc, Patriot American Hospitality Inc, Meditrust Companies, Bass PLC and Ladbroke Group (L)

headline: MARCUS CABLE TO DIVEST ITSELF OF TV ASSETS IN 2 STATES
abstract: Marcus Cable Co to sell its cable television assets in Connecticut and Virginia to TMC Holdings Inc for $150 million; systems serve about 46,000 customers in Connecticut and about 17,000 customers in Virginia (S)

headline: Canada Railway Agrees to Buy Illinois Central
abstract: Canadian National Railway Co agrees to acquire Illinois Central Corp for cash and stock valued at $2.4 billion, creating railroad linking Canada to Gulf Coast; merger will make Canadian National fifth-largest railway in North America; combined, the two railways will cover 18,700 miles in Canada and US with 24,600 employees (M)

headline: Thyssen Workers Seek Influence Over Merger
abstract: Workers at Thyssen AG say they will try to block German company's merger with Fried Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp if they do not receive promises that jobs will not be cut and that they will get equal voice in management; worker protests helped scuttle attempted hostile takeover of Thyssen by Krupp last year (S)

headline: Nigerians Pin High Hopes on Pope's Visit
abstract: Pope John Paul II, mixing spiritual and political in nation bracing for critical elections, beatifies Nigeria's first candidate for sainthood, Rev Cyprien Michael Iwene Tansi, and presides over Mass for some million people, Onitsha, Nigeria; repeatedly alludes to human rights situation and need for greater democracy in Nigeria; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.25   5.35   5.32        3-month T-bills   5.02   5.00   5.18        6-month T-bills   5.05   5.04   5.30        10-yr. T-infl.   3.71   3.69   3.49        10-yr. T-note   5.56   5.57   6.72        30-yr. T-bond   5.89   5.90   6.95        Telephone bd.   6.99   6.99   7.98        Municipal bds.   5.25   5.25   5.86          (Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones; Markets; The Bond Buyer)

headline: From Highflier to Downer; Transformation Plans at Hoechst Are Losing Thrust
abstract: Profile of Hoechst AG under chief exec Jurgen Dormann; Dormann, since taking over Hoechst in 1994, has been trying to change company from chemicals giant to leader in pharmaceuticals and biotechnology; but transition has gone badly, failing to generate much growth and inspiring protests from employees; Dormann comments; photos (M)

headline: A Burst of Renewal Sweeps Old Beijing Into the Dumpsters
abstract: Much of Beijing is being cleared by real-estate developers to make way for high-rise apartments, office buildings and shopping centers; familiar syndrome of urban renewal, long delayed by China's isolation and poverty, is unfolding fast, changing face of ancient city; single-story compounds and narrow alleys that made up much of Beijing are nearly all scheduled for demolition--their condition deemed beyond repair and their use of space too extravagant for modernizing metropolis; photos of artist Deng Haifan's paintings of life in old Beijing (M)

headline: Ryanair to Buy 45 Boeing Jets
abstract: Ryanair Holdings PLC says it will buy as many as 45 single-aisle 737 jetliners worth $2 billion from Boeing Co; victory for Boeing reverses string of losses against Airbus for orders from European airlines (S)

headline: Great Universal Stores Sues Merger Rival
abstract: Great Universal Stores PLC, Britain's largest home shopping company, has filed countersuit against American Business Information Inc, contending US company interfered with its $831 million bid for Metromail Corp, a direct marketer (S)

headline: Defying Pressure, Tokyo Scrimps on Budget
abstract: Japan's lower house of Parliament passes nation's budget, approving $600 billion plan that could squeeze money out of economy just as it is careening toward recession; but approval also creates basis for politicians to discuss more openly thier long-awaited plans to spend more money to strengthen economy (M)

headline: UNION REJECTS NCO IN FAVOR OF OUTSOURCING SOLUTIONS
abstract: Union Corp says it rejected offer to be acquired by NCO Group Inc for $232 million in favor of $190 million bid from Outsourcing Solutions Inc (S)

headline: Bond Prices Climb in Australia
abstract: Australian bonds rise in first trading session of 1998, amid optimism that cooling Asian economies will take heat off domestic growth, and keep any risk of accelerating inflation at bay (S)

headline: Time to Call a Sears Repairman; A Turnaround Is Sidetracked by Its Own Oversell
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co stumbles in 1997 after significant improvements bolstered its sales and stock price in year before; problems included costly scandal that exposed unethical tactics aimed at collecting debts from bankrupt customers; other troubles are result of company's very efforts at improvement; company has given power to its rank and file, stripped away many old rules and become obsessed with staff training; result is more vibrant company, but also more distracted one; store managers and even sales staff complain about being bombarded with memos and e-mail from top management about most mundane matters; managers themselves announced new programs, seemingly every week; Arthur C Martinez, Sears' chief executive, hopes to get company back on track by pushing his management team to focus on five basic pillars he put in place after taking helm of Sears; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Japan Property Concern To Liquidate Subsidiary
abstract: Mitsui Fudosan Co says it will take charge of 57 billion yen ($456 million) for year ending on March 31 to liquidate its money-losing financial subsidiary, Mitsui Fudosan Finance Ltd; company lowers its full-year earnings forecast to net profit of 5 billion yen ($40 million) (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar falls again on reports that Japan plans moves to stimulate its economy; graphs; table (S)

headline: Sweetened Bid for Energy Group of Britain
abstract: Energy Group of Britain receives sweetened $6.6 billion takeover proposal from Pacificorp of US, touching off sharp rise in Energy Group's stock on speculation other bidders will increase price further in fight to buy one of Europe's biggest power companies; total value of proposal, with assumption of $4.1 billion of debt, is $10.7 billion (L)

headline: Toledo Journal; After 5 Centuries, a Mecca for Translators Again
abstract: Toledo School of Translators in Toledo, Spain, brings together writers and translators from around the Mediterranean in the hope of making Europe better acquainted with cultures of immigrant people, many of them Muslims from North Africa; harks back to Toledo School of 13th and 14th centuries, where scholars translated Hebrew and Arabic writings on medicine, philosophy, matematics, astronomy and botany into Latin and the languages of Europe; new school focuses for the moment on Arabic and Hebrew writing, but there are plans to include works of writers from Turkey and Albania; photo (M)

headline: 2 Ex-Baron Brokers Get Prison Terms
abstract: Glenn O'Hare and Joseph Scanni, former brokers at defunct brokerage firm A R Baron & Co, are sentenced to 3 1/2 to 10 years in prison for their role in stock-fraud scheme that cost investors $75 million, NYS Supreme Court, Manhattan (S)

headline: Some Applause for AT&T's Shake-Up
abstract: Many money managers are lauding AT&T Corp's drastic shake-up measures, including trimming of up to 18,000 jobs (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.50   5.40   5.18        3-month T-bills   5.09   5.02   5.02        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.03   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.66   3.25        10-yr. T-note   5.64   5.61   6.39        30-yr. T-bond   5.94   5.92   6.70        Telephone bd.   7.17   7.17   7.72        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.20   5.75          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Misunderstanding Sparked Indonesian Violence : Anatomy of a Price 'Riot'
abstract: PASURUAN, Indonesia—  Until a few weeks ago, this small provincial town was best known for its sugar mills. But following reports of wide-scale looting and frenzied anti-Chinese violence last month, Pasuruan became a symbol of Indonesia's explosive potential for racial strife and civil unrest.

headline: Maurice Schumann, 86, Dies; 'Voice of France' During War
abstract: Maurice Schumann, French aide to General de Gaulle in London during World War II who made moving broadcasts to Nazi-dominated France and later became Foreign Minister, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Military Gets Main Use of Big Computers
abstract: Civilian scientists say they are being forced into sometimes bitter competition with military researchers and with each other for resources they need to compute problems so complex that only world's fastest, most powerful computers can produce adequate solutions; Government pays for 19 percent of supercomputers built in United States each year and for 100 percent of top-end machines that break ground in speed and power; since cold war, Government has given civilian and military scientists rough parity in parceling out time on supercomputers; parity became 2-to-1 ratio in favor of military in 1996, and it will tilt to 5-to-1 ratio by 1999; tug-of-war between civilian and military scientists is result of disparities in budgets of National Science Foundation and Energy Dept (M)

headline: The President And the G.O.P. Diverge on Iraq
abstract: Sen Trent Lott, majority leader, and House Speaker Newt Gingrich call on Pres Clinton to use military to oust Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq as Administration officials try to play down expectations of what military strike might achieve; Clinton says he favors diplomatic end to intensifying dispute over weapons inspections; Defense Sec William S Cohen again urges Congress and public to focus on 'realistic' aims of military strike; planning for bombing attack nears completion; Cohen, national security adviser Samuel R Berger and Joint Chiefs of Staff head Gen Henry H Shelton again meet with lawmakers; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Is silver the glitter of yesterday? Or is it the new ingredient of the reasonably prudent portfolio?
abstract: Market Place column on price of silver, which rose when Warren Buffett bought 129.7 million ounces on Feb 3 and fell two days after Buffett's announcement; holds Buffett rally may have raised prices to a point where demand and supply balance; graphs (M)

headline: GE CAPITAL SAYS IT IS IN TALKS WITH JAPAN'S TOHO MUTUAL
abstract: GE Capital Corp is in talks with Toho Mutual Life Insurance Co about expanding into Japan's life insurance market (S)

headline: CURRENCIES
abstract: Indonesian currency, the rupiah, surges, bolstered by strong rallies in several Asian currencies and markets and by intervention by Indonesia's central bank (S)

headline: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN TO SPIN OFF MUTUAL FUND UNIT
abstract: Kansas City Southern Industries plans spinoff of its financial services business (S)

headline: NORTHWEST PIPE TO PAY $39 MILLION FOR 2 TUBE COMPANIES
abstract: Northwest Pipe Co plans to buy Southwestern Pipe Inc and P&H Tube Corp for $39 million (S)

headline: Mutual Fund Outflow Reported in Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong Investment Funds Association says mutual funds registered for sale in Hong Kong had net outflows of $1.65 million in November, second consecutive month that investors withdrew money; in October, investors pulled net $82 million from the funds; fund companies report $255.12 million in sales in November against $256.77 million in redemptions (S)

headline: CAMPBELL IN NEGOTIATIONS TO SELL CONTINENTAL SWEETS
abstract: Campbell Soup Co is negotiating to sell its European confectionery and distribution business, Continental Sweets, to Gilde Buy-Out Fund, a Dutch venture capital firm (S)

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Funds Watch column; 'private purpose' municipal bond issues explained (S)

headline: Leonard/Monahan In Providence Shuts
abstract: Leonard/Monahan, 20-year-old advertising agency in Providence, RI, has closed after losing important clients and top executives (S)

headline: Gingrich Calls for Hearings on I.M.F.'s Role
abstract: US House Speaker Newt Gingrich calls for series of Congressional hearings into International Monetary Fund to determine whether it is institution that has 'outlived its usefulness'; Clinton Administration has been pressing Congress to approve $18 billion for the world body to bolster its reserves in wake of Asia financial crisis (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SCHUFF STEEL CO., Phoenix, agreed to acquire the privately held Addison Structural Services Inc., Albany, Ga., another steel company, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rallies against Japanese yen and German mark; graph; chart (S)

headline: Ex-Chief Sues Federated: $16 Million Not Enough
abstract: Allen I Questrom, former chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores, sues retailer for $47 million more in bonus pay for taking retailer from bankruptcy to profitability in his seven-year stint; Questrom received $16 million thank-you from the board for a job well done; that bonus came on top of roughly $2 million he made in 1996 in straight pay; the previous year, Questrom received $13.2 million; photo (L)

headline: Soviet Defector Warns of Biological Weapons
abstract: Dr Kanatjan Alibekov, defector from former Soviet biological weapons program who is now known as Ken Alibek, says that Moscow's cold war plans for World War III included preparing 'hundreds of tons' of anthrax bacteria and scores of tons of smallpox and plague viruses; Alibek was second-in-command of branch of Soviet program and defected to US in 1992; he says Russian military was still running biological weapons program in 1991, year after Mikhail S Gorbachev ordered it halted; has written highly classified study of Soviet biological weapons program for US Government; says he believes a vestige of Moscow's cold war biological-weapons program is continuing in Russia under guise of defensive research; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans to invest $900 million at its plant in Genk, Belgium, in next three years for production of new-model Mondeo cars and Transit vans (S)

headline: Damascus Journal; Poking Fun Must Be Artfully Done
abstract: Interview with Ali Farzat, Syrian political cartoonist whose work routinely savages country's overzealous security forces and tryannical Government bureaucrats; he says he has learned to poke fun and criticize without being specific--in way that has made him most admired cartoonist in Arab world from country that lacks much of reputation for political humor; map; cartoon (M)

headline: Ramchandran Jaikumar, 53, Business Professor at Harvard
abstract: Ramchandran Jaikumar, professor at Harvard Business School, dies of heart attack at age 53 (S)

headline: U.S. LISTS OPTIONS ON USE OF FORCE IN IRAQ STANDOFF
abstract: Top Clinton foreign policy advisers meet to weigh military and political strategies against Iraq, including sustained attack on suspected biological and chemical weapons sites that Pres Saddam Hussein has hidden from UN inspectors; National Security Council official says there will be one final round of diplomacy, followed by ultimatum and action; White House officials say countdown to military strike could begin as soon as Ramadan, Muslim holy month that ends on January 30; Administration will devote coming week to convincing skeptical American allies and members of Congress that military action is only way to stop Iraq from building biological and chemical arsenal (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Canadian currency hits 12-year low against United States dollar on concerns that recent ice storms and Asian turmoil will slow growth; praph (M)

headline: United Natural Foods Deal
abstract: United Natural Foods Inc to acquire Hershey Import Co, Rahway, NJ, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: CALGON CARBON CHIEF RESIGNS AND COMPANY MAY BE SOLD
abstract: Calgon Carbon Corp says chief executive Colin Bailey has resigned and company might put itself up for sale (S)

headline: U.S. May Fight Satellite-TV License Sale
abstract: Justice Department reportedly leans toward challenging plan by American Sky Broadcasting, joint venture of MCI Communications Corp and News Corp, to sell satellite television license to Primestar Partners LP; deal would cut number of direct-broadcast players from four to three (M)

headline: Amid Layoffs, Wells BDDP Loses Two More Accounts
abstract: Wells BDDP, ailing New York advertising agency has lost two more accounts and has begun layoffs related to departure last month of third client; Heineken USA Inc will end its relationship with Wells, effective in 90 days; billings estimated at $30 million; US account of TAG Heuer watches, with billings estimated at $8 million, leaves Wells for New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi; loss of Procter & Gamble Co account last month, with billings estimated at $125 million, prompts layoffs; 40 employees will be dismissed; additional 60 people who worked on Procter & Gamble account have left for other jobs (M)

headline: Clinton Seeks A Partnership With Africans
abstract: Pres Clinton, escorted by Pres Nelson Mandela, appears before South African Parliament to describe 'common promise' in American and South African experiences with race and revolution; Clinton, first American President to visit South Africa, says US has 'profound and pragmatic stake' in country's new democracy; Clinton does not refer to long years in which US, through uneasy policy of constructive engagement, provided legitimacy to South Africa's white rule and apartheid; photo (M)

headline: INTERTAN SAYS IT WILL CLOSE 69 TANDY STORES IN BRITAIN
abstract: Intertan Inc says it will close 69 poorly performing Tandy electronics stores in Britain and dismiss 230 employees who work there as part of revamping of its British operations (S)

headline: Europe Refuses to Drop Ban on U.S. Beef
abstract: European Union refuses to drop ban on beef from cattle treated with growth hormones, holding World Trade Organization ruling against ban merely requires it to prepare new risk assessment and that it need not rely on mainstream scientific views; United States charges stand will undermine World Trade Organization authority; Amb Rita Hayes holds European Union has failed to prove scientific basis for ban; dispute tests treaty under which most industrial nations agreed that trade curbs based on health and safety concerns must be based on scientific evidence; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., bought the Atari video game division of JTS Corp. of San Jose, Calif., for $5 million in cash.

headline: Crispin Porter Gets Cunard Account
abstract: Cunard Line Ltd names Crispin Porter & Bogusky to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $11 million (S)

headline: Dow Continues Its Retreat as Profit Hopes Grow Dimmer
abstract: Treasury prices are mixed, with price of 30-year bond dropping 26/32 to 103 22/32 (S)

headline: The Year's Top Media Buys: Most Wanted 1997 -- The Annual Numbers
abstract: While Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and Paul McCartney -- music greyhairs all -- made brief appearances atop the charts when their albums were released, the world of rock, hip hop, country and pop adamantly belonged to youth last year. Hanson, Leann Rimes and Jewel, none older than 25, were among the leading artists.    In the last 13 days of 1997, ''Titanic,'' which is being distributed by Paramount, plowed into number 7 in the top 10 films, while Fox coasted in on revenue from its re-release of ''Star Wars'' in January.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUSS, MOLLY
abstract: YUSS-Molly. Age 95. Devoted mother of Marcia Grey, Irene Tuft and Shirley Elias. Loving grandmother of Michael, Mia, David, Carrie and Susan. Great grandmother of Zachary. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., ''Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel'', 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.

headline: Icahn Retracts Offer to Rescue Ailing Pan Am
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn withdraws his $43 million bid to bail out Pan Am Corp, leaving airline one step closer to closing its doors permanently; Icahn's lawyer, Thomas Lauria, says Icahn withdrew his offer in part because Pan Am employees and creditors attacked Icahn based on his troubled history in airline business; Icahn's reputation was sullied from his days at Trans World Airlines, when he sold off prized international routes and buried company under mountain of debt; Pan Am says there is still one potential suitor, Milan Mandaric, Silicon Valley investor who is still combing through Pan Am's records (M)

headline: Time to Bomb: Olympics Bad, No Moon Good
abstract: United States, in scheduling possible bombing attack on Iraq, considers wide range of factors, including intricacies of Muslim religious calendar, dates for moonless nights and Pres Clinton's travel plans; awaits political judgment on diplomatic efforts to end impasse; photo (M)

headline: SBC Emerging as a Bull in the F.C.C.'s China Shop
abstract: Analysis: SBC Communiations Inc, by persuading Federal judge to strike down vital elements of Telecommunications Act of 1996 last week and by agreeing to acquire Southern New England Telecommunications Corp for $4.4 billion, is clearly emerging as iconoclast of telecommunications industry; last week's court ruling, which could be bonanza for SBC and Baby Bells, will probably be stayed from going into effect soon and could end up in the Supreme Court; SBC's takeover of Southern New England could be rejected by regulators; SBC seems to be trying to remake communication law and to create revolution in how regulators think about local versus long-distance telephone companies (L)

headline: Russia Vows To Push Pact Cutting Arms
abstract: Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin says Russia will push to ratify second strategic arms reduction treaty in order to prepare way for Pres Clinton to visit Moscow for summit meeting by middle of year (M)

headline: People
abstract: -- Matthew W. Lake was named to the new position of executive vice president and new business director at Gotham Inc., New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been senior vice president and managing director at Hampel/Stefanides, New York.

headline: Notes From the Hearing Room
abstract: William H Gates, founder and chief executive of Microsoft Corp, wrote series of articles about his recent Congressional appearance for Slate, on-line magazine Microsoft owns; excerpts from Gates's accounts of events; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities column; late rally in silver comes on speculation that investor Warren Buffett, who has large silver holdings, foresees big use for metal in fuel-cell batteries; graph (S)

headline: Boyds Wheels to Cease All Manufacturing
abstract: Boyds Wheels Inc says it will cease all manufacturing operations and seek permission in Federal bankruptcy court to liquidate its assets; its Hot Rods unit will continue to operate and reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: Study Shows How World Banks Panicked Over Asian Troubles
abstract: New study data provide first concrete evidence of how powerful and mercurial flow of international money both propped up and then helped unravel Asian countries now in crisis; most economists believe crisis had its origins in irresponsible borrowing by Asian countries themselves, but study provides graphic picture of how eager foreign banks were to lend more money year after year and how surprised they seemed to be when currencies and stock markets collapsed; data collected by central banks as well as information from individual banks make clear that heaviest lenders to Asia have been in Japan, France and Germany, followed by American banks like Citibank and Chase Manhattan; graphs (M)

headline: Vladimir Prelog, 91, Is Dead; Swiss Chemist Won the Nobel
abstract: Vladimir Prelog, Swiss chemist whose pioneering insights into shape of complex biological molecules were honored with Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1975, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: Master Of Her Own Destiny
abstract: Article on the many professional faces of Martha Stewart, supreme queen of meticulous style and now master of her own corporate universe; Stewart, perhaps the pre-eminent female brand name in America, bought herself out from Time Inc umbrella last year and is rapidly expanding her realm; Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia LLC encompases her cooking and entertaining books, Living magazine, television and radio features, Kmart bedding, paints and Web site; photos; chart; calendar of her busy weekly schedule; Stewart says she is not worried about company's long-term prospects, despite close identification with one individual; company reportedly earned $20- to $25-million last year on revenue of $120 million (L)

headline: As More Traps Loom, 1997's High Scores for Banks May Be Hard to Repeat
abstract: Banking world was roiled in 1997 by huge domestic mergers and economic turmoil abroad, and landscape promises to be equally challenging in 1998, with more mergers, rising credit problems and slowing revenue growth; banks are under siege from host of new competitors as borders that once separated traditional banking from more exotic financial services continue to dissolve (M)

headline: A New Finalist For Little Caesars
abstract: Ad agency Fallon McElligott, finalist for account of Little Caesars pizza chain, withdraws; new finalist is team of McCann-Erickson Detroit and Kolon, Bittker & Desmond (S)

headline: A U.S. Judge Strikes Down Parts Of '96 Telecommunications Act
abstract: Federal Judge Joe Kendall strikes down major sections of 1996 Telecommunications Act on grounds that law unfairly keeps regional Bell companies out of long-distance; ruling, if it stands, would allow Bell companies nationwide to offer long-distance service for first time since AT&T was broken up in 1984; state regulators and Bell companies have been battling long-distance carriers which, along with FCC, want Bells to show that their networks are wide open to competitors before they can offer long-distance service; SBC, parent of Southwestern Bell, filed suit after being denied access to long-distance market in Oklahoma; other local operators are allowed to sell long-distance service without same restriction (S)

headline: No More Free Drinks: System Keeps Tabs on Bartenders
abstract: Mike Mogadam and his Barmate Corp offer electronic system designed to monitor liquor inventory, eliminating theft and waste in taverns and restaurants; photos (M)

headline: ARMS CONTRACTORS SPEND TO PROMOTE AN EXPANDED NATO
abstract: Six largest US military contractors who stand to gain billions of dollars in sales if Senate approves NATO expansion, have made enormous investments in lobbyists and campaign contributions to promote cause in Washington; have spent $51 billion on lobbying in past two years; their zeal, as well as extensive spadework by Clinton Administration and support by Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Jesse Helms, have made it virtually certain that Senate will approve treaty to admit Poles, Hungarians and Czechs; industry is also concentrating efforts abroad, setting up partnerships in Eastern Europe to give companies foothold (M)

headline: A West African Border With Back-to-Back Wars
abstract: Bo Waterside, border area between Liberia and Sierra Leone, has become training ground for force, aided by Nigerian peacekeepers, that is seeking to oust Sierra Leone's military rulers; Nigerians, ostensible peacekeepers in regional effort to end years of fighting in Liberia, are reportedly arming and training fighters in Sierra Leone in effort to restore democratically elected president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah; photos; map (M)

headline: QUEEN SAND TO BUY INTEREST IN OIL WELLS FROM MORGAN
abstract: Queen Sand Resources Inc agrees to buy oil and natural gas royalties and overriding royalty interests from Morgan Guaranty Trust Co of New York for $150 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   6.07   6.26        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.22   5.04        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.20   5.24   5.09        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.70   3.71   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.74   5.79   6.42        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   5.92   5.96   6.64        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.15   7.15   7.82        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.25   5.26   5.72          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Il Cortile: A Taste of Italy in the Middle of Paris
abstract: PARIS—  Despite a universal love affair with Italian cuisine, the very gastronomic Paris remains a wasteland for authentic pastas, breads, risottos and traditional Italian grilled fare. Leave it to Alain Ducasse, Michelin's new six-star chef and lover of all things Mediterranean, to bail us out here.

headline: Greg MacGregor Former Times Reporter, 85
abstract: Greg MacGregor, foreign correspondent who reported on Korean War as well as economic and political developments in Southeast Asia during 17-year career at The New York Times, dies at age 85 (S)

headline: GERBER SCIENTIFIC PLANS TO BUY SPANDEX FOR $183 MILLION
abstract: Gerber Scientific Inc agrees to acquire Spandex PLC of Britain for about 109 million pounds ($183 million) in cash (S)

headline: Hot Truck Sales Make Ford's and Chrysler's Day
abstract: Ford Motor Co says truck sales rose 2.1 percent, to 183,342 in December, a record for the month, compared with period a year ago; Ford's overall sales fell 3.6 percent, to 299,984 in December, pulled down by weak sales; Ford sold 116,642 cars, down 11.4 percent from year-earlier period; Chrysler Corp says sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks rose 8.2 percent, to 137,567, also setting record for month; car sales dropped 12.2 percent, to 52,624, compared with corresponding period a year ago; over all, Chrysler sales rose 1.7 percent, to 190,191 (L)

headline: Chief of Thompson Gets Additional Post
abstract: Christopher I M Jones, chief executive of J Walter Thompson, is named to additional position of chairman (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE ECONOMY  Corporate Profits Falter  Corporate profits fell 2.3 percent in the last quarter of 1997, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $483.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported, while the gross domestic product rose at a 3.7 percent annual rate -- less than the 3.9 percent reported earlier -- because consumer spending for services was less robust than first calculated. But numbers for February were far stronger. Sales of existing single-family homes rose 8.7 percent to a record annual rate of 4.75 million, and, excluding aircraft, orders for durable goods were up half a percentage point; over all, orders for big-ticket items fell 1.7 percent in February.

headline: Until Ed McMahon Calls, They Need to Slice Debt
abstract: Article in series Fresh Start, periodic look at crossroads of personal finance; focuses on heavy debt carried by Mark Nyman, lawyer, and his wife, Elizabeth Genel, who owns cosmetics shop; much of debt is from education loans; planner Karen Altfest suggests financial plan to cut expenses and debt; table; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDEN, STELLA GOLDBERGER
abstract: HEIDEN - Stella Goldberger. Passed away on March 22, 1998. Born June 21, 1903. Married to the late Dr. Lionel Heiden. Beloved ''Aunt'' Stella to dozens, piano and music teacher to hundreds, degrees from Damrosch-Juilliard and Columbia University. Taught at Horace Mann, Julia Richman, and Washington Irving. Avid sailor and swimmer. Board member of Bloomingdale House of Music, Secretary of the UFT Retired Teachers Chapter for 25 years. Funeral service at Gramercy Chapel, 1 PM on March 24th. Donations to Bloomingdale House of Music. We will miss her.

headline: Corel, a Rival Of Microsoft, Had a Bad Year
abstract: Corel Corp, Ottawa-based software company, reports loss of $231.8 million in 1997, worst performance since Corel was founded in 1985; company lost $67 million (US) in fourth quarter; Micrografx Inc accuses of Corel of violating copyright laws by copying calendar features of its Creata Card software program; Cindy McGann, corporate counsel for Corel, says she has reviewed programs and has not found any evidence of copyright infringement (M)

headline: GGT Group, battered by the loss of big accounts, has agreed to be brought into Omnicom's fold.
abstract: GGT Group PLC, battered by loss of big advertising accounts, including Procter & Gamble Co, agrees to be acquired by Omnicom Group for $234.2 million in cash (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rallies to end higher after traders conclude Cabinet shake-up in Russia could help economic relations with Germany; dollar costs 1.8256 marks in New York; graphs; chart (S)

headline: Mexico Wins Extradition of Two Defendants From U.S. for Drug-Killing Trial
abstract: Mexican prosecutors persuade California courts to send Alfredo Hodoyan Palacios and Emilio Valdez Mainero, alleged paid killers for a vicious drug ring based in Tijuana, back to Mexico to face murder and conspiracy charges; case has tested whether two very different justice systems can work together across the boarder to fight drugs (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise on the Big Board and Amex
abstract: Open positions of short sales increased on NYSE and American Stock Exchange in last month; data lists (S)

headline: Currency Is Devalued by Vietnam As Effects of Asian Crisis Spread
abstract: Vietnam becomes latest Southeast Asian country to devalue its currency, as Asia's financial turmoil shows signs of pummeling even most protected regional markets; Vietnamese central bank allows country's currency, the dong, to slip to new controlled rate of 11,800 to the dollar, a 5 percent devaluation; bank allows dong to trade within 10 percent band around target rate, and currency falls to floor of 12,980, an all-time low (M)

headline: Blacks Seek Focus on Africa Policy
abstract: Pres Clinton's coming trip to Africa reflects growing influence on foreign policy of African-Americans like Mayor Wellington E Webb of Denver, who wants US to put Africa at top of its foreign policy agenda (M)

headline: Treasury and Other Debt Issues This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and sales of a 52-week bill tomorrow and a 10-year inflation-indexed note on Thursday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on both the outstanding three-month and six-month bills was 5.17 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.16 percent, and the 10-year inflation-indexed note was priced to yield 3.70 percent.

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.87 percent and that on a six-month bill, 4.89 percent.

headline: CHART TO PAY $34 MILLION FOR AN IMI INDUSTRIAL DIVISION
abstract: Chart Industries agrees to buy Industrial Heat Exchanger division of IMI Marston, unit of IMI PLC for $34.6 million (US) in cash (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cablevision Official Offers To Buy a Stake in Yankees  George Steinbrenner, the controlling owner of the New York Yankees, acknowledged talking with Charles Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision Systems, about Mr. Dolan's buying a piece of the club.

headline: ATMEL AGREES TO BUY A TEMIC BUSINESS FROM VISHAY
abstract: Atmel Corp agrees to buy unit of chip maker Temic Telefunken Microelectronic GmbH from Vishay Intertechnology Inc for about $140 million in cash (S)

headline: AMERADA HESS TO SELL 50% OF VIRGIN ISLANDS REFINERY
abstract: Amerada Hess Corp sells 50 percent interest in its US Virgin Islands oil refinery to state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela SA for $625 million (S)

headline: U.S. Moves To Block Deal For Northrop
abstract: Justice Department files suit to block Lockheed Martin Corp's planned acquisition of Northrop Grumman Corp, contending that combination of two leading military contractors poses threat to nation's defense; US Attorney General Janet Reno and Defense Sec William S Cohen say they oppose merger (L)

headline: Cold Water For the Hot-Fund Strategy
abstract: Mutual fund newsletter editors Sheldon Jacobs and Daniel Wiener, who have produced above-average long-term results by investing in top-performing mutual funds of previous year, find strategy has not been successful recently; strategy hinges on premise that market trends that benefit particular fund do not necessarily stop at year-end; table (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; In Search Of A Foothold In Rocky Times
abstract: Mutual fund investors seeking safety sometimes face unexpected risks as managers of conservative-sounding funds maximize holdings in relatively volatile types of securities to boost yields; managers are under pressure because majority of funds have underperformed their indexes; drawing; tables (L)0

headline: Clinton Phones Suharto, Insisting on Commitment to I.M.F. Plan
abstract: Pres Clinton calls Indonesia's Pres Suharto to insist his country put in place commitments to overhaul his economy; Clinton stresses that International Monetary Fund program has to be followed (M)

headline: S.E.C. Sues 9 in an Insider Trading Case
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files suit against nine people, charging they made illegal profits of more than $200,000 by trading on insider information about Leisure Concepts Inc, Medco Containment Services Inc and Synetic Inc; Synetic says SEC complaint charges that one of its directors, Roger Licht, provided nonpublic information to friends in connection with transactions involving Synetic and Medco, its former parent company (S)

headline: Show Me the Mummy! Internet Offers a Home to Archeology
abstract: Archeologists are turning to Internet to announce their finds and findings, with many of their postings geared more toward generalist than specialist; journal articles follow later for colleagues and historical record; array of archeological Web sites discussed; photo (M)i

headline: Mutual Funds Report; There's Strength in Diversity
abstract: Article on mixing 401(k) retirement funds to help reduce risk; says most retirement plans that allow individuals to make their own investments have added to their menus; notes average plan offers seven choices, and most plans are continuing to fine-tune offerings; photos (L)

headline: A $4 Billion Global Issue by the World Bank Sells Quickly
abstract: World Bank prices its largest dollar-denominated global bond issue ever, $4 billion, as solid demand from investors insures quick sale and oversubscription; issue is priced to yield 5.703 percent for bond due 2003; Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, sells $3 billion in bonds backed by student loans in three parts through Merrill Lynch & Co; 30-year US Treasury bond rises 1/4, to 102 20.32; yield falls to 5.94 percent from 5.95 percent; graph; chart (L)

headline: 1997 Profit Fell 30% At Big Singapore Bank
abstract: United Overseas Bank Ltd, one of Singapore's four largest banks, says its profit fell 30 percent in 1997, to 502 million Singapore dollars ($303 million), as it set aside money for bad loans in Southeast Asia (S)

headline: Further Revamping Planned by DuPont
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co chief executive Charles O Holliday says company is starting new round of restructuring, including layoffs, aimed at shrinking corporate bureaucracy and making its business units more autonomous (S)

headline: First Test for Britain's Camelot: Welfare Reform
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair faces his hardest test over proposals to cut benefits in Britain's welfare state; contentious vote in Parliament on cuts in support for jobless single mothers and Government plans to submit benefits of sick and disabled people to means test have produced first significant opposition to what has been most popular new Government in British history; clash has produced response of missionary zeal from Blair, who says he will press ahead with reform of welfare state as centerpiece of 'radical' change for Britain; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSS, JOSEPH R.
abstract: POSS-Joseph R. Age seventy-one, of chronic leukemia on March 22nd, 1998. Former employee in the Accounting Department of Pepsico for 40 years, a graduate of NYU School of Commerce and an active member of St. Peter's Church in Citicorp. Survivors include brother Fred, niece Susan Rooney, nephews Fred and Paul Poss and Joe's companion William Gentz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 2-5, 7-9 P.M., with service Wednesday 11:30 AM. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Peter's, Wednesday, April 29 at 6 P.M. Memorials are suggested for various programs at St. Peter's Church.

headline: SUIZA FOODS ADDING LAND-O-SUN DAIRIES TO ITS NETWORK
abstract: Suiza Foods Corp to acquire Land-O-Sun Dairies LLC for about $224 million in cash and preferred stock and assumption of $63 million in debt (S)

headline: The Buttressing of Fortress Compaq; Deal for Digital Expands PC Leader's Footing in Computer Industry
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp's acquisition of Digital Equipment Corp is evidence of how much personal computer industry has grown up from its scrappy, free-wheeling origins only two decades ago; Compaq's chief executive, Eckhard Pfeiffer, is moving company well beyond its roots to compete in field of industrial-strength computing--long the unchallenged domain of mainframe and minicomputer companies; Pfeiffer is credited with leading Compaq from near-collapse in early 1990's to become world's leading PC maker, and model of efficient manufacturing, procurement and cost control; Digital purchase will make Compaq second-largest computer company in world, with combined revenues last year of $37 billion; Compaq sought to acquire Digital because much of corporate world will be replacing conventional minicomputers and mainframes in next several years; drawings; graphs (L)

headline: French Unemployed Turn Their Ire on the Socialists
abstract: France's Socialist Government, which was elected on pledge to alleviate stubborn 12.4 percent unemployment rate, has been unable to keep promise and has emerged from holiday season on defense against jobless themselves; some of 3.1 million unemployed have occupied more than dozen unemployment offices nationwide, demanding raises in unemployment benefits and New Year's bonuses, just like people with jobs (M)

headline: Hitachi Sets Cutbacks In Chip Production
abstract: Hitachi Ltd, Japan's largest electronics maker, will temporarily stop production of computer memory chips at eight factories in Japan to reduce inventories (S)

headline: Israeli Judges Put Security Above Rights
abstract: Three-judge panel of Israeli Supreme Court ends secrecy of four-month-old ruling in which it acknowledged and condoned fact that Israel is holding 21 Lebanese men, some for as long as decade, solely as 'bargaining card' (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Salmon eaters salute a victory against the protectionists.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says price of salmon in market is lower because of successful efforts of lobbies for wholesale fish distributors and restaurants in America to beat back efforts by domestic salmon industry to use nation's trade laws to bar foreign competition; says this might encourage other organized resistance to laws designed for protectionists, and consumers would be winners; drawing (M)

headline: Long Bond's Yield 5.72%, a New Low
abstract: Bond prices end higher for fourth straight session, pushing yields further into record-low territory; Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond closes up 9/32, to price of 105 25/32, while yield falls to 5.72 percent, beating record low of 5.74 percent set on Jan 5; graphs (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Profit Increases 7% in Quarter
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says earnings rose 7 percent in fourth quarter; net income rose to $817 million from $762 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose to $4.7 billion from $4.48 billion; for the year, company earned $41.3 billion, an 18 percent increase; sales increased slightly, to $18.87 billion from $18.67 billion; soda sales volume for year was up 9 percent; chart (L)

headline: Milken Settles S.E.C. Complaint for $47 Million
abstract: Michael R Milken, financier who used huge junk bond empire in 1980's to make or break a swath of big American companies, agrees to pay $47 million to settle SEC complaint that he had violated 1991 order barring him from securities industry for life; at same time, in apparently related deal, Federal prosecutors say they will not recommend new criminal charges against Milken for violating terms of his probation stemming from criminal securities fraud conviction in 1990; $47 million represents fees that Milken received for advising Bert C Roberts Jr, chmn of MCI Communications Corp, and Rupert Murdoch, chmn of News Corp, on 1995 accord in which MCI agreed to invest $1 billion to $2 billion in News Corp; in another transaction, Milken was paid fee for advising Ronald O Perelman, who controls Revlon Inc, on his acquisition of New World Communications; photo of Milken, Perelman and tennis player Jimmy Connors at Florida tournament (L)

headline: FRESH AMERICA TO BUY CLOSELY HELD ONTARIO TREE FRUITS
abstract: Fresh America Corp will buy Ontario Tree Fruits Ltd for undisclosed amount of stock (S)

headline: Surreys With Less Fringe: A Decline in Executive Perks
abstract: Corporate perks are trimmed back from their lavish levels of 1980's; for many executives, extras like corporate jets, chauffeur-driven luxury cars and memberships at exclusive country clubs have fallen by wayside; changes in tax laws wiped out or sharply reduced write-offs corporations could take for many of them, and companies feel further pressure to hold down costs to help deliver ever-improving earnings; Doug Geoga, president of Hyatt Hotels, comments; photo (M)

headline: Seven Possible Gems Amid the Asian Rubble
abstract: Article on seven Asian companies that may outperform Asian markets, which have encountered huge losses in recent weeks; companies discussed include Citic Pacific, Sime Darby, HSBC Holdings, Sun Hung Kai Properties, Advanced Info Service Public, Telecom Asia and Berjaya Sports Toto; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Wal-Mart Net Rises 17.3% in Quarter
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc reports net income rose 17.3 percent in fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan 31 to $1.29 billion, up from $1.10 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: Oxford Health Asks Rate Rise in New York
abstract: Oxford Health Plans asks New York State insurance department to allow it to raise premiums at least 50 percent on individual coverage it sells to 55,000 New Yorkers; increase, for someone who buys coverage directly, could amount to at least $100 more a month; group, known as New York County Medical Society, asks that arbitrator order Oxford to pay what they say is tens of millions of dollars owed to doctors in medical claims and that arbitrator require company to establish clearer payment guidelines (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Roster Belongs to Deutsch
abstract: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America says Deutsch Inc will be sole agency handling dealer accounts, with combined billings estimated at $65 million to $80 million (S)

headline: World News Briefs; Britain and Ireland Weigh Sinn Fein Ouster
abstract: Irish Republic and Britain say they will soon decide whether to expel Sinn Fein, Irish Republican Army's political wing, from Northern Ireland peace talks because of new violence attributed to IRA; Irish Prime Min Bertie Ahern and British Min Mo Mowlam comment (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar bounces back against the mark as outlook for Germany economy continues to look gloomy and Bundesbank official says interest rate increase is unlikely any time soon; charts (S)

headline: Bertelsmann Plans Website For Book Sales Via Internet
abstract: Bertelsmann AG announces plans for global electronic bookstore that has potential to become world's largest merchant of books; entry of Bertelsmann would challenge Internet pioneers that now reign in electronic bookselling (M)

headline: 'Dinosaur' Stirs Mexico's Old Guard
abstract: Gov Manuel Bartlett Diaz's outlines plan to seek ruling party's presidential nomination, interview; scores party leaders as timid bureacrats unwilling to stand up to opponents; bid to wrest control of troubled party from foreign-trained economists and technocrats and return it to old guard stirs enthusiasm in party and undermines Pres Ernesto Zedillo's authority; map; photo (M)

headline: TMB AFFILIATE TO BUY A BUSINESS FROM ITT INDUSTRIES
abstract: ITT Industries says it agreed to sell its precision die-casting business to Lester Precision Die Castings Inc, affiliate of privately held TMB Industries; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Korea's Other Big Problem: $300 Billion in Domestic Debt
abstract: Analysts worry that South Korea's $300 billion short-term domestic debt may be far messier problem than recently restructured $23.4 billion in short-term obligations owed to foreign banks; with interest rates soaring, liquidity fast evaporating and consumption all but coming to halt, dozens of companies are declaring bankruptcy, with potentially dire consequences both for local banks and global financial structure; whether country's battered financial system can absorb steady stream of bankruptcies is far from certain; graph (M)

headline: U.N.'s Long-Muddled 'Oil-for-Food' Program Makes Progress in Iraq
abstract: United Nations' long-muddled 'oil-for-food' program, plan allowing Iraq to sell some oil to meet urgent needs of its people, is finally beginning to make a difference, although problems and shortfalls remain, particularly in medicine and medical equipment; lack of medicine is caused not only by sanctions but also by Govt decisions to build palaces and monuments (M)

headline: BTR Shares Climb on Owens-Illinois Deal
abstract: Shares of BTR PLC climb 16 percent after company says it is selling its glass and packaging businesses to Owens-Illinois Inc for 2.2 billion pounds in cash and would return 2 billion pounds ($3.32 billion) to shareholders (M)

headline: Success in Failures
abstract: Two-year-old Divorce magazine is relatively new addition to market of niche magazines; it is published quarterly in four regional editions, with combined circulation of 83,000; it joins host of glossy magazines serving up self-help and inspiration in life styles format, catering to increasingly specialized groups; Dan Couvrette, publisher of Divorce, suspects that readers will remain with magazine for one or two years; photo (M)

headline: Equal Work, Less-Equal Perks; Microsoft Leads the Way in Filling Jobs With 'Permatemps'
abstract: High-tech corporations embrace use of long-term temps, employees doing high-prestige, high-technology jobs for year or more at same company, but without benefits or pay of company's permanent workers; Microsoft is leading practitioner of trend, employing 5,000 temps, including 1,500 long-term ones, to work beside its 17,000 permanent employees; some temps prefer flexibility and higher take-home pay that temp status affords, but many assail temping as backdoor way to create two-tier work force; Microsoft is locked in five-year-old legal battle with hundreds of independent contractors and temps who insist they should be considered regular employees and receive same benefits as regular employees; is appealing ruling of Appeals Court that it wrongly denied millions of dollars in benefits to hundreds of workers who were independent contractors; photo; graph (L)

headline: World News Briefs; Jew Stabbed to Death In East Jerusalem
abstract: Jew is stabbed to death in Orthodox Jewish enclave next to Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem, apparently by Palestinian militant (S)

headline: Washington Post Magazine Editor to Be Named Managing Editor
abstract: Steve Coll, editor and publisher of The Washington Post Sunday magazine, is expected to be named managing editor of The Washington Post; Coll will succeed Robert G Kaiser, who announced earlier this year that he will return to writing and reporting (M)

headline: Dow Climbs by 52.56 to Reach Its 6th Consecutive High
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 52.56, to close at record 8,451.06; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 9.30 points, to end at record 1,032.06; Nasdaq composite index gains 12.30 points, to 1,715.73; graph; chart (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Keep Climbing, Paced by Nike Shares  Stock prices rose again, sending the Dow industrials to their sixth consecutive record. While strong earnings at technology companies have supported the rally, merger activity -- and speculation about possible deals -- has also helped.    The most intriguing of the talk has centered on Nike, whose stock has risen 9 percent in two days amid market rumors that the investor Warren E. Buffett is adding to his 2 percent stake in the company. [Page D9.]

headline: Viacom Posts a Less-Than-Expected Loss
abstract: Viacom Inc's loss for continuing operations in fourth quarter was $102 million, compared with earnings of $17 million a year earlier; including pretax gain of $1.2 billion from sale of its share of USA Networks cable business, Viacom had profit from continuing operations of $597 million; net income was $573 million compared with loss of $227.4 milion a year earlier; revenue increased 5.9 percent, to $3.61 billion from $3.41 billion; chart (L)

headline: Illegal Trade in Homemade Computers Thrives : Beijing's 'Backyard' Industry
abstract: BEIJING—  Swinging their truncheons, a dozen "intellectual property police" strode into action along Beijing's Zhongguancun street. At the sight of them, the hawkers of pirated compact discs and CD-Roms hurriedly gathered their wares and decamped.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, JACK ROHE
abstract: HOWARD-Jack Rohe. On March 22, 1998. Husband of the late Barbara Balfe Howard and the late Eleanor Harris Howard. Father of Pamela Howard Gumprecht and Michael Balfe Howard. Brother of Jane Howard Perkins. Grandfather of Eliza Howard, Esme Howard, Matthew Beatty Howard, Cassie Mei Howard, Jack Rohe Howard-Potter, Ian Nicholas Gumprecht and Christopher Balfe Gumprecht. Contributions in his memory may be made to Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main St., Exeter, NH 03833-2460 and the Scripps Howard Foundation, 312 Walnut Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45212.

headline: Mazda's campaign aims to clarify its image and reverse a persistent slump in car and truck sales.
abstract: Advertising column on Mazda's glossy, energetic advertising campaign seeking to clarify fuzzy Mazda image as well as reverse persistent slump in sales of Mazda cars and trucks; campaign, with theme 'Get in. Be moved,' is first from W B Doner & Co since being selected as Mazda's new agency (M)

headline: Elephants Are Friends, China Tells Its Farmers
abstract: Local officials in southern China, after years of neglect, are getting serious about protecting elephants and other wildlife, punishing poachers severely; say elephant population has stabilized at over 200 (M)

headline: Kaiser H.M.O., Erring on Costs, Posts $270 Million Loss for '97
abstract: Kaiser Permanente, nation's largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, posts first-ever loss of $270 million for 1997; chief executive David M Lawrence says Kaiser weighs selling money-losing Dallas-Fort Worth health plan, other units; says it was far off in forecasting rising costs, especially in its big Southern California unit and added more new members than it could immediately handle (M)

headline: There's a Steady Rush To the Corporate Altar; Mergers and Acquisitions Continue At a Record Pace Across-the-Board
abstract: Corporate mergers and acquisitions continue at record pace across-the-board; Securities Data Co says so far this year, financial services industry--including banks, investment firms and insurance companies--is leading mergers pack with 119 announced bids worth $24.9 billion; telecommunications companies are not far behind, with 31 proposed transactions valued at $23.5 billion, followed by business-services sector, where $8.4 billion hostile bid by Computer Associates for Computer Sciences Corp drove total up to $13.5 billion; graphs; drawing (L)

headline: U.N. Leader Rebuts Critics Of His Pact With Baghdad
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan moves quickly to rebut criticism from Congress and elsewhere that he knuckled under to Saddam Hussein by creating special arrangement for inspecting eight presidential complexes that Iraqis hitherto put off limits (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co says profit fell 5 percent in fourth quarter; earnings declined to $366 million from $385 million a year earlier; sales rose 2.5 percent, to $3.71 billion from $3.62 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SABA PETROLEUM CO., Santa Maria, Calif., an energy company, said that it would hire an investment banker to help the company figure out how to increase its value.    UNISON HEALTHCARE CORP., Scottsdale, Ariz., a nursing home operator, said that three of its units had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

headline: Feeding the Next Generation; Food Industry Caters to Teen-Age Eating Habits
abstract: Supermarkets are increasingly stocking ready-to-eat meals that appeal to teen-age shoppers, who are helping to reshape way America eats; food companies, seeking to build brand image with next generation, have marketedly increased advertising in magazines aimed at teens and set up 'edutainment' sites on youth-saavy Web; graphs; photo (M)

headline: SMALL BANKS POSE POSSIBLE SETBACK IN KOREA BAILOUT
abstract: South Korea clears key hurdle in effort to stabilize economy, paying off or extending large portion of foreign bank debt; had to repay some debt because smaller banks are unwilling to extend loans; small banks could undermine international efforts to arrange repayment moratorium; Government appeals to citizens to donate jewelry and other gold to help ease crisis; Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung warns of 'unimaginable hardships' (M)

headline: Hampshire Securities Sued Over Acquisition
abstract: Executive Monetary Management Inc, minority shareholder in Hampshire Securities Corp, has sued Hampshire Securities and its controlling shareholders, contending investment bank's agreement to be acquired by Gruntal & Co disproportionately benefits controlling shareholders (S)

headline: UNITRODE TO ACQUIRE BENCHMARQ, ANOTHER CHIP MAKER
abstract: Unitrode Corp to buy Benchmarq Microelectronics Inc for $135 million in stock (S)

headline: SARA LEE TO BUY INTIMATE APPAREL UNIT FROM ARISTOTLE
abstract: Aristotle Corp to sell its Strouse, Adler Co women's intimate apparel unit to Sara Lee Corp for $21.5 million (S)

headline: Ethnic Chinese Try to Keep Out of Harm's Way
abstract: JAKARTA—  Amid the puddles and crumbling walls of Jakarta's morning market is the city's Chinatown, a labyrinth of shops, warehouses and narrow alleys navigated by stooped old women.

headline: U.S.-Led Arms Inspectors, Rebuffed by Iraq, Pull Out
abstract: William Scott Ritter Jr, American weapons inspector at center of latest confrontation between Iraq and United Nations, leaves Baghdad with his inspection team, whose movements have been blocked since Jan 13 by Government of Pres Saddam Hussein; two other teams were allowed to carry out inspections; Britain sends aircraft carrier Invincible to Persian Gulf to join large US force; photo (M)

headline: Kmart Profits Rose by 14% In 4th Quarter
abstract: Kmart Corp says earnings before charge rose 14 percent in latest quarter; says earnings before charge in its fiscal fourth quarter rose to $267 million, from $235 million in period year ago; says per share earnings in latest quarter, which ended Jan 30, exceeded analysts' expectations of 46 cents; Kmart shares rise $1.25, to $14.6875; another small retailer, Saks Holdings Inc, says profit before charge grew 39 percent; says profit before gain in fourth quarter rose to $38.6 million, or 58 cents a diluted share, from $27.7 million, or 42 cents a share, year ago (M)

headline: Stocks Rebound in Hong Kong and Tokyo
abstract: Stocks rise in Tokyo on expectations that Japanese Government will offer further measures to stimulate nation's economy; benchmark 225-issue Nikkei stock average jumps 924.47 points, or 6.11 percent, to close at 16,046.45; stocks also rise in Hong Kong, with benchmark Hang Seng index up 261.04 points, or 3.04 percent, to 8,840.42, following decline of 7 percent the day before (M)

headline: Harper's Bazaar is moving to increase ad pages with a new Web site and television campaign.
abstract: Harper's Bazaar, in effort to stimulate advertising sales and promote itself and its advertisers, puts up new World Wide Web site and starts its first television campaign since Elizabeth Tilberis was appointed editor in 1992; campaign is budgeted at $1 million and is timed to begin with publication of magazine's March fashion issue (Advertising column) (M)

headline: The Steep Price Of Climbing To the Top Of the World
abstract: Demand remains strong for commercial guided expeditions to climb Mount Everest despite dozen deaths on Everest during 1996 climbing season; advice on choosing expedition; photos (M)

headline: 4th-Quarter Net Soared 52% at Dell Computer
abstract: Dell Computer Corp reports earnings of $285 million in fiscal fourth quarter, up 52 percent from $188 million in year-earlier period; revenue rise 55 percent, to $3.74 billion, from $2.41 billion in fourth quarter of 1997 fiscal year (M)

headline: Workers Expect Layoffs At Hoechst Drug Unit
abstract: Hoechst Marion Roussel, pharmaceutical unit of Hoechst AG, will announce several hundred job cuts in research and development; employees are planning to demonstrate on Jan 16 to protest cuts, though they do not plan to strike (S)

headline: Malaysian Deficit Narrows in Quarter
abstract: Malaysia's current account deficit narrowed to 1.9 billion ringgit ($410 million) in third quarter of 1997, from 5.7 billion ringgit in preceding quarter; merchandise exports expanded 15.6 percent, or 7.6 billion ringgit, to 56.3 billion ringgit in third quarter, while merchandise imports grew 3.2 percent, to 52.2 billion ringgit (S)

headline: China's New Premier: Fast Riser Who Tamed Economy in Chaos
abstract: Deputy Prime Min Zhu Rongji, who will become China's new Prime Minister, is career Communist planner whose meteoric rise to power has been driven largely by sheer force of his achievements; he has steered economy over past five years, as chief economic planner, out of runaway inflation without stifling its growth and will become head of Cabinet at time when most populous country is emerging as economic and political heavyweight; faces daunting tasks, such as: remaking economy still rooted in thousands of money-losing companies owned by Government, salvaging banks that by outside standards are insolvent, reversing calamitous environmental pollution, finding work for tens of millions who once thought they had jobs for life and building new system of social welfare from scratch; will also have direct responsibility for pressing foreign policy issues, such as volatile relations with Taiwan and stand on human rights; faces ultimate issue of how Communist Party will maintain control over society that is becoming more complex and pluralistic each day; photos (L)

headline: Swiss Spy Identified 'Militants' For Algeria
abstract: Swiss police officer, Leon Jobe, is convicted and given 18-month suspended sentence for assembling list of Algerians in Switzerland and turning over hundreds of names to Algerian authorities; was ostensibly investigating possible arms smuggling by Islamic militants to Algeria in 1994; Algerian Government arrested, jailed and tortured at least 4 people on list when they returned to Algeria; with newspapers carrying daily reports of horrific killings in Algerian Government's battle with Islamic militants, list's disclosure has left many Algerians in Switzerland living in fear; among those Algerians on Jobe's list are people who say they are apolitical and have never sympathized with Islamic militants (M)

headline: DiTech Hires Kovel Kresser
abstract: DiTech Funding Corp names Kovel Kresser & Partners to handle its advertising account, which had been handled for two and half years by Ken Roberts Productions; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Public TV's 'Arthur' again cavorts with the commercial realm.
abstract: Promotion sponsored by Nestle USA Inc's Juicy Juice and TV Guide features Arthur, aardvark cartoon character from Public Broadcasting Service series; promotion appears with parent's guide in March 14-20 issue of magazine; critics are worried about blurring of lines between commercial and noncommercial enterprises--particularly those aimed at children; photo (L)

headline: Belfast Journal; The Chain This Catholic Wears Speaks Volumes
abstract: Interview with Alban Maginness, who became first Catholic mayor of Belfast, Northern Ireland, after Protestants lost their long control of city council last year; he cites efforts to reach out to Protestants; Sammy Wilson, Protestant councilman, says split between Protestant Unionists and Catholic Nationalists on council continues; photo (M)
