headline: Russia Arrests Ex-Colonel In '94 Killing Of Journalist
abstract: Russian officials announce they have arrested retired military intelligence official, Pavel Popovskikh, in connection with killing of investigative journalist three years ago; journalist, Dmitri Kholodov, had been investigating corruption in Russian military when he was killed by opening booby-trapped suitcase (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LIBERTY PROPERTY TRUST, Malvern, Pa., a real investment trust, said it  had bought, in separate transactions, 22 office and warehouse properties in Florida, Pennsylvania and the Detroit area for $106 million.

headline: 2 Strong Antagonists Hold Ulster's Fate
abstract: Article profiles Gerry Adams, leader of Irish Republican Army's political wing, and David Trimble, head of Ulster Unionist Party; skilled and powerful antagonists have starkly different ideas about how Northern Ireland should be ruled and success of peace negotiations to end 29 years of sectarian strife will depend on whether both are able to compromise in way that permits each to claim victory; photos (M)

headline: Low-Flying Jets a Common Sight in Vale of Death
abstract: Residents of Cavalese, Italy, where American military jet cut ski lift cable, say they complained repeatedly about planes, mostly Italian Air Force jets, using area as training ground for low-level flying; see Prime Min Romano Prodi's visit to blame American pilot as disingenuous; map; photos (M)

headline: Karpov Wins Game 4 and Leads Match
abstract: Anatoly Karpov wins fourth game of world chess championship against Viswanathan Anand in Lusanne, Switzerland; needs only two draws to win series and $1.3 million prize; diagrammed play (M)

headline: Mexico Playing Unfamiliar Role in World Oil Politics
abstract: Mexican officials are traveling in unfamiliar territory, side by side with Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, leading way in cutting oil exports to bolster world petroleum prices; analysts say never before has Mexico agreed to curb exports as part of cooperative effort to turn market around (L)

headline: A drugstore chain's campaign asserts that its pharmacists 'care about their customers.'
abstract: Advertising column examines $65 million corporate branding campaign for CVS, nation's largest drugstore chain in number of stores; says warmly emotional campaign, devised by Bates USA, seeks to develop image for CVS as devoted to more than just peddling pills (M)

headline: GIBSON GREETINGS CANCELS UNIT SALE TO PAPER WAREHOUSE
abstract: Gibson Greetings Inc says it ended accord to sell its party-goods unit, Paper Factory, to Paper Warehouse, after unit generated sales and earnings higher than expected and companies failed to agree on sale price (S)

headline: Japan Passes Bailout Plan
abstract: Japan's Parliament gives final approval to 30 trillion yen ($239 billion) plan to buy bank shares and protect bank depositors (S)

headline: Equity and Related Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: U.S. Stance Toward Nigeria And Its Ruler Seems to Shift
abstract: Pres Clinton appears to signal change in American policy toward Nigeria, saying that if Nigeria's military ruler, Gen Sani Abacha, stands for election, he hopes it will be as a civilian; previously, senior Americanofficials said US would find it unacceptable if Abacha ran as civilian candidate; Clinton is not visiting Nigeria on his current African trip, as sign of disapproval of Abacha's regime (M)

headline: CKE RAISES PRICE IT WILL PAY FOR 557 HARDEE'S OUTLETS
abstract: CKE Restaurants Inc will pay three percent more to buy 557 Hardee's fast-food restaurants from franchisee Advantica Restaurant Group; figure is now $381 million cash and assumption of $46 million in debt (S)

headline: Bell Canada in Phone Deal
abstract: Bell Canada International Inc acquires 68.4 percent stake in Colombian cellular phone operation Occidente y Caribe Cellular SA for about $302.2 million; Bell Canada says move will give it more than 50 percent of Colombia's cellular subscribers (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Corporate Intelligence: A Cloakhold On the Web
abstract: Gathering information on rivals, key to success in corporate world, can now be done through World Wide Web rather than by cloak-and-dagger techniques of old; organization charts, customer lists and executive biographies can all be plumbed to learn about state of most companies; corporate plans, mergers and strategic alliances can also be discovered if documents are properly analyzed (M)

headline: Reuters Profits Fell 22% in Last Half of '97
abstract: Reuters Holdings PLC says profit in last six months of 1997 fell 22 percent, to 160 million pounds ($260 million) from 206 million pounds a year earlier; full-year net income fell 12 percent, to 390 million pounds, from 442 million pounds in 1996 (S)

headline: F.C.C. Rule Review Assailed By a New Republican Member
abstract: Harold Furchtgott-Roth, new member of Federal Communications Commission's Republican minority, criticizes commission for failing to review its myriad telecommunications regulations adequately, as mandated in Telecommunications Act of 1996; William E Kennard, commission's chairman, claims FCC's review was most comprehensive one ever conducted by agency (M)

headline: Gulf Canada Chief Resigns and Stock Falls
abstract: Gulf Canada Resources president-chief executive J P Bryan resigns; he will be replaced by Richard Auchinleck (S)

headline: The da Vinci of Data
abstract: Edward R Tufte, professor of political science at Yale, is better known for his ideas and books on presenting information visually; his ability to present seas of information in easily readible form has attracted hundreds of people to his seminars and earned him millions of dollars; he rails about most World Wide Web sites, which he claims are crowded with worthless graphics, ignoring content; photos (M)

headline: A New Gandhi Hopes to End The Chaos of India's Politics
abstract: Sonia Gandhi, widow of Rajiv Gandhi and daughter-in-law of Indira Gandhi, enters Indian politics in Sriperunbudur, where her husband was slain, and although she does not say she will seek office herself, the crowd greets her as a future Prime Minister; there is also speculation that her daughter, Priyanka, and son, Rahul, might run for Parliament; Sonia Gandhi's entry into political fray upsets all calculations about outcome of national in February and March; Congress Party, long dominated by Nehru-Gandhi family, is electrified; yearning across India for charismatic leaderhip would favor Gandhi family's return to Government, but a there is also a countervailing trend toward splinter parties based on India's myriad distinctions of region, language, religion and caste; photo (M)

headline: Netanyahu Apologizes for Killing of 3 Palestinians by Soldiers
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, in unusually conciliatory gesture, goes on Arabic-language Israeli television to describe shooting of three Palestinians at Israeli roadblock as 'tragic mistake' and to express sympathy for their families (M)

headline: 3 Slain Palestinians Given Martyrs' Rites
abstract: Three Palestinian laborers killed by Israeli soldiers were buried as martyrs yesterday as violent protests spread through the West Bank. The killings at an army checkpoint on Tuesday ignited simmering anger among Palestinians over a long deadlock in peace negotiations. Israeli Army officers met with counterparts in the Palestinian police to keep the unrest from spinning out of control.    Article, page A3.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Ease Slightly But Bonds Rebound  The stock market took a break from setting records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 45.59 points, to 8,539.24. The market was led lower by Disney stock, which fell as analysts lowered their earnings outlooks. A plunge in Intel, the technology bellwether, in after-hours trading also raised concerns.    Treasuries rebounded slightly after a two-day slide, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 6.02 percent from 6.07. [Page D7.]

headline: Korea Opposes Plan by U.S. Banks to Repackage Loans
abstract: South Korean Government opposes debt refinancing plan devised by J P Morgan & Co to exchange private-sector loans for longer-term debt guaranteed by Government; at issue is how to repackage as much as $28 billion in short-term loans that are smothering beleaguered nation's economy; South Korea must now consider other refinancing options; its economy remains on life support with assistance from international lending agencies like International Monetary Fund; South Korean Government and corporations would be in default without such aid, and temporary loan-forgiveness from international banks; Government's hardened stance toward J P Morgan proposal may be nothing more than pre-negotiating ploy on eve of meeting of South Korean officials with international banks from Europe, Japan and United States (M)

headline: Large Charge Causes Major Loss at Waste Management
abstract: Waste Management Inc takes $1.5 billion fourth-quarter charge to reflect accounting changes taken to quiet investor skepticism about reliability of its financial reports; posts net loss of $1.41 billion for quarter, compared with restated loss of $394.8 million in 1996 period; had reported $138 net income for 1996 period; says similar recalculations will cut reported net income for years up through 1996 and first three quarters of 1997 by after-tax total of $1.32 billion (M)

headline: From Mandela, a Gentle Admonishment
abstract: South African Pres Nelson Mandela, meeting with Pres Clinton in Cape Town, says United States, as leader of world, should reach out to its enemies and seek talk of peace; Mandela praises some Clinton policies but stoutly defends South Africa's right to remain friendly with nations US considers rogues, like Libya, Iran and Cuba; Mandela gives Clinton emotion-drenched tour of Robben Island, where he spent 18 years as political prisoner, confined to tiny cell and forced to do backbreaking labor; Clinton notes that Mandela emerged from that confinement not in anger, but in hope and determination to put things right; Mandela expresses reservations about African trade bill passed by House of Representatives that would require African nations to privatize their economies and liberalize their political systems in order to attain free access to American markets; photos; map (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.25        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.50   5.54   5.33        3-month T-bills   4.98   5.00   5.03        6-month T-bills   4.99   4.98   5.11        10-yr. T-infl.   3.66   3.67   N.A.        10-yr. T-note   5.57   5.53   6.50        30-yr. T-bond   5.84   5.80   6.78        Telephone bd.   7.18   7.14   7.82        Municipal bds.   5.12   5.11   5.83          Sources: Salomon Brothers; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: U.S. Doesn't Dispute Italians Over 'Recklessness' in Crash
abstract: Defense Department says Marine Corps jet that sliced through cables of Cavalese, Italy, ski lift, killing 20 people, apparently was flying far below minimum authorized altitude for training missions; does not dispute Prime Min Romano Prodi's view that 'tragic recklessness' caused accident; Prodi visits scene with Defense Min Beniamino Andreatta and Justice Min Giovanni Maria Flick; says Pres Clinton has assured him that incident will never occur again; Andreatta demands pilot be prosecuted (M)

headline: World News Briefs; South Korea Eases Curbs On Investment in North
abstract: South Korea plans to let businesses invest in North Korea without controls or prior consultation; says it will allow business travel and visits by elderly to North Korea in bid to expand economic cooperation (S)

headline: Share Prices End Mixed, With the Dow Falling by 12.46
abstract: Stock prices end mixed for second straight session as prices dip again for many blue chips; Dow Jones industrial average drops 12.46 points, to 8,117.25; European and Asian stock markets have been soaring this week; in Japan, Nikkei 225 average is up 17 percent; in South Korea, main index is up 40 percent, in Malaysia 39 percent and in Thailand 14 percent; in Europe, London stock market is up 9 percent and German DAX is up 7 percent; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Exchanges Discuss Merger In a Challenge to Big Board
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers is discussing merger with American Stock Exchange that will create bigger and more formidable competitor to New York Stock Exchange; people close to talks say that NASD, which initiated them, hopes to offer companies choice of how their shares will be traded--either through its own electronic Nasdaq trading system or through Amex's auction system of central trading floor; say initially plan envisions creating holding company under which Amex and Nasdaq will continue to operate separately as subsidiaries (M)

headline: Where Immigrant Dreams Prosper, at a Profit
abstract: New York City taxi medallions, now selling for $237,000, are hot investment vehicle, with prices rising average of over 18 percent a year for 60 years; Freshstart Venture Capital Corp and five other companies formed under Federal small-business loan program that was later essentially privatized have enabled hundreds of immigrants to buy cabs; Freshstart is first of these companies, which offer tax advantages to investors, to go public; graphs; photos (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bertelsmann of Germany Buying Random House  Bertelsmann A.G. reached an agreement yesterday to buy the crown jewel of American publishing, Random House, in a transaction estimated to cost the German media conglomerate $1.4 billion.    The deal will make Bertelsmann the largest English language publisher of trade books and vastly increase its share of the $21 billion U.S. book market. But it also dismayed some authors and agents who worried about the possibility of reduced competition for books and less demand for literary works that lack best-seller potential. [Page A1.]

headline: Egypt's Leader Warns of Anti-U.S. Ire
abstract: Anti-American protests break out at Cairo university as top Egyptian officials warn United States policy toward Iraq undermines America's standing in Mideast (M)

headline: J. Scott Howard, Risk Management Expert, 53
abstract: J Scott Howard, risk management expert who was vice president of J P Morgan & Company in New York, dies at age 53 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Woolworth stock has been strong, but will Nike sales at the company's Foot Locker unit hurt?
abstract: Market Place column on outlook for Woolworth Corp focuses on future revenues from its Foot Locker division; graph (L)

headline: Saudis End Inquiry in Blast That Killed 19 U.S. Airmen
abstract: Saudi Arabia completes investigation into 1996 terrorist bombing of US military base in Dhahran, that left 19 airmen dead, but declines to immediately release results; announcement catches Clinton Administration by surprise and leads to new fears that culprits may never be caught; US officials say their probe into incident is far from over and that terrorists have not been identified with certainty (M)

headline: Intel Warning Touches Off Flight From Technology Shares
abstract: Intel Corp's announcement that earnings will not meet Wall Street expectations results in investors fleeing technology stocks; Dow Jones industrial average falls 94.91 pooints, or 1.11 percent, to 8,444.33; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 12.28 points, or 1.17 percent, to 1,035.05; Nasdaq composite index falls 47.78 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,711.92; charts; graph (L)

headline: Goldman, Sachs, the money manager of the wealthy, is contemplating a higher public profile.
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co, Wall Street's last big partnership, hires Ammirati Puris Lintas to conduct research of Goldman, Sachs brand; study will allow firm to decide whether to proceed with multimillion-dollar advertising campaign aimed at better promoting its image with public (L)

headline: Decision Deferred on Control of Key Bosnian Town
abstract: Arbiter postpones decision on which ethnic grouping will control strategically important Bosnian city of Brcko for al least nine months as tensions rise throughout region; Bosnian Serbs will retain control of city, which they captured during Balkan conflict in campaign of widespread killings and expulsion of almost all non-Serbs; map (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Some meaty stuff on monetary policy, from a former Fed hand.
abstract: Economic Scene column on former Federal Reserve Board vice chairman Alan S Blinder's upcoming book on workings of Federal Reserve titled Central Banking in Theory and Practice; drawing (L)

headline: Times Company Names New Vice President
abstract: Cynthia H Augustine is named senior vice president for human resources of The New York Times Co; she will be responsible for all human resources functions, including compensation, employee benefits and organizational development; photo (S)

headline: Peregrine Revising Deal With Zurich
abstract: Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd agrees to revise terms under which Zurich Insurance Co will buy stake in Peregrine; change comes two months after Zurich agreed to pay $200 million for 24.1 percent of Peregrine; since then, declines in Asian currencies and asset prices have eroded Peregrine's market capitalization (S)

headline: Roche Unit Genetic Deal
abstract: F Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd, subsidiary of Roche Holding AG, will invest $200 million over five years in Decode Genetics Inc of Iceland; Decode's research seeks gene mutations that predispose people to develop certain diseases; Decode has entire genealogy of Iceland in a data base (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISQUITH, MOSES
abstract: ISQUITH-Moses. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Rantch and Lenore. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and David. Brother of Santley, Murray and Jack. He was the recipient of The Purple Heart, African Campaign Ribbon with two Battle Stars, Good Conduct Ribbon, Combat Infantry Badge and Expert Marksmanship Medal during World War II. Services Tuesday March 24, 11 AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

headline: Crew of Jet That Sliced Ski Lift Cable Facing Criminal Inquiry
abstract: Military equivalent of grand jury hearing is ordered to determine whether crew of United States jet that sheared ski lift cables in Italy, killing 20 people, should be prosecuted on charges including involuntary manslaughter and negligent homicide; Major Gen Michael P DeLong, deputy commander of Marine Corps Atlantic command, blames accident on 'crew error'; says it was caused by way crew members 'aggressively maneuvered their aircraft' in steep Alpine valleys in northern Italy; head of plane's crew was Capt Richard J Ashby; case reviewed (M)

headline: Whittle's Schools Getting Investor Infusion
abstract: Edison Project, with its fledgling network of for-profit schools still at least three years away from turning profit, has secured infusion of $56 million from investors to help pay for continuing start-up costs; Christopher Whittle, founder and president of Whittle Communications, says two primary investors are J P Morgan Capital and Investor AB; both are contributing $20 million (S)

headline: U.N. Team Calls Iraq Sites Smaller Than Thought
abstract: UN team commissioned by Sec Gen Kofi Annan to map Iraq's 'sensitive sites' concludes after three days that total area is 12.2 square miles, including 3.9 square miles covered by lakes; says many of buildings are guest houses and only one is palace; UN special commission to disarm Iraq has estimated that over 27 miles and 1,500 buildings are in off-limits sites; UN official charges Iraqi shell game to divide commission and UN; commission chairman Richard Butler, who has not been included in Annan's Baghdad talks, says issue is access, not size of area (S)

headline: Czechs' New Day
abstract: Jane Perlez analysis of transition of Czech Government from Vaclav Klaus, who was forced to resign as Prime Minister over a campaign finance scandal, to Josef Tosovsky, a former governor of central bank; says that by changing Prime Ministers and facing political and economic uncertainties ahead, Czech Republic in effect becomes a normal Central European country; says privatization achieved under Klaus was largely illusory, since former state-owned companies remain unrestructured, with old managers and bloated staff, many of them controlled by investment funds that have become notorious for shady stock deals (M)

headline: I.B.M. and Digital Describe Entrants in Chip-Speed Race
abstract: IBM and Digital Equipment Corp will present technical papers at International Solid State Circuits Conference, San Francisco, describing experimental chips that operate at more than one billion cycles a second--or three times speed of today's most powerful personal-computer chips; though chips will not be available until after turn of century, race to so-called gigahertz speed has touched off battle for bragging rights between two companies, which each claiming title of developer of world's fastest general-purpose computing chip; graph (L)

headline: McCann-Erickson Shuffles Top Deck
abstract: Michael Sennott will take new position of vice chairman and client services director at McCann-Erickson World Group; James R Heekin wil succeed Sennott as regional director overseeing Europe, Africa and Mideast; Donald Dillon will succeed Heekin as president for McCann-Erickson North America (M)

headline: Park-Ohio to Spin Off Unit
abstract: park-ohio industries says it will spin off its logistics unit to shareholders through initial public offering of stock; unit will become separate public company called Integrated Logistic Solutions Inc (S)

headline: When a Smorgasbord Replaces a Diet Plate in a 401(k)
abstract: American Stores Co workers have mixed reaction to shift in 401 (k) pension plan offerings from mix of five investment funds to dizzying roster of 137 choices; some have begun studying stock market, while many are bewildered by array of choices; 90 percent of assets remain in original five funds; some investment professionals fear American Stores move is harbinger of alarming trend toward overloading people with investment decisions they are unprepared to make; employees comment; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Motorola Has Profits Below Expectations
abstract: Motorola Inc, hit by economic turmoil in Asia, reports that its profits for fourth quarter were slightly below expectations of Wall Street analysts; company earned $321 million, up 35 percent from $238 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 7.7 percent, to $8.3 billion, from $7.7 billion in 1996 fourth quarter (L)

headline: ROCHESTER GAS AND ELECTRIC TO SHUT 106-YEAR-OLD PLANT
abstract: Rochester Gas and Electric Corp says it will close its coal-burning Beebee Station power plant next year; plant, open since 1892, generates 80 megawatts of electricity (S)

headline: Has Vanguard Windsor's Shine Begun to Fade?
abstract: Recent disappointing performance of Vanguard's Windsor fund discussed; fund is managed for Vanguard by Charles Freeman of Wellington Management Co; Freeman has recently slashed some of fund's larger and more longstanding positions in stocks of cyclical companies; graph (M)

headline: U.N. Resolutions Allow Attack on the Likes of Iraq
abstract: Clinton Administration's stand that it has right to attack Iraq to force Saddam Hussein to open sites to weapons inspectors is based on succession of Security Council resolutions and statements and on United Nations Charter; American and other diplomats are pressing Security Council for new resolution declaring Iraq in 'material breach' of its commitments, move opposed by Russia (M)

headline: Silent Hotels / Building Boom Goes Bust : 5-Star Luxury at Bargain Prices
abstract: SURABAJA, Indonesia—  Welcome to the executive suite at the five-star Hotel Majapahit, a celebration of marble, Oriental rugs and gold plate.

headline: DIARY
abstract: WHEELS  All Very Swiftian  No need to be shipwrecked on an exotic island to have your sense of scale demolished: a modern Gulliver need go no farther than Detroit. At the auto show last week, Volkswagen rolled out its new Beetle, which returns to the Lilliputian end of the United States market after a 21-year absence, while just a few booths away Ford unveiled its Brobdingnagian new F-250, a pickup whose hood ornament is further off the ground than Dr. Ruth Westheimer's chin. Car makers and critics braced for a struggle over the Yahooish way light trucks have of mangling most any car they hit broadside; manufacturers are quietly pushing to have new side-impact standards set no higher than in Europe, where, unlike here, big light trucks are scarce. But the news on the environmental front might please the Houyhnhnms, Swift's race of selfless, sagacious horses: the Big Three and several Japanese companies are talking seriously about making new high-technology, high-mileage cars in the next few model years, and Ford says it will voluntarily upgrade its light trucks to meet the much tougher emissions standards imposed on cars.    PRICES  Won't Be Undersold  Wholesale prices fell two-tenths of a percent in December and 1.2 percent for all of 1997, the Labor Department announced, and the ''core'' rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy numbers, fell for the first time in memory last year. Analysts are calling the inflation outlook the best in a generation, with even the labor markets -- tight, by historical standards -- on good behavior. Among economists, fretting about inflation is beginning to give way to fretting about possible deflation and the economic harm that would come.    JOBS  Won't Be Idle  The latest evidence from the astrophysics lab says the universe will keep expanding forever, a characteristic that the American economy and labor force seem to share these days. An unexpectedly plentiful 370,000 new jobs were created in December, but unemployment actually ticked up slightly because an even greater number of new workers entered the labor force, the Labor Department reported. A record 64.1 percent of American adults are now in the labor force, but it wasn't a salary bidding war that drew them in: Real hourly wages rose just 0.1 percent last month.    BUDGETS  You Mean There's Extra?  President Clinton said he planned to submit a balanced budget to Congress for fiscal 1999, three years ahead of schedule, and predicted a comparatively trivial Federal deficit of about $22 billion for 1998. Wall Street yawned, having long since predicted that the strong economy would erase the deficit, but political leaders dived gleefully into an unaccustomed task: arguing over what to do with spare money. The President is expected to discuss new initiatives on child care and the environment in his State of the Union message later in the month; House Speaker Newt Gingrich is talking about tax cuts. Consumers are way ahead of Washington this time: They unexpectedly reversed a three-year borrowing binge in November, reducing their total indebtedness by $4.2 billion, according to Treasury Department figures released last week.    ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I  Rescues Needing Rescues  It turns out not to be quite as simple as tossing out a multibillion-dollar life preserver and hauling in the rope. Financial rescue plans sponsored by the International Monetary Fund for several Asian countries showed signs of unraveling last week, largely because of the reluctance of the recipients to swim along quietly in the specified direction. Indonesia announced a new budget that blithely ignored the I.M.F.'s fiscal advice, and when the rescuers' displeasure became known, the country's currency and its stock market sank like stones. Dire rumors, panic buying and fears of political instability swept the country. And in Thailand, which was the first Asian domino to fall, I.M.F.-required austerity measures are already pinching too hard for the Prime Minister, who asked for an easing of the terms.    ASIAN TURMOIL, PART II  Devil in the Details  Compared with Southeast Asia, South Korea seems calm. Its streets are quiet, and the stock market has stanched its bleeding. But the particulars of the debt restructuring the country badly needs are proving thorny. After a week of squabbling, creditor banks were near agreement on a plan to give the country a breather of 30 to 90 days on loan payments. Still to be sorted out is what happens next: who will buy a proposed bond issue and what kinds of government guarantees they will get.    COMPUTERS  New Year, New Prospects  January is the time of year Steven Jobs likes to spring surprises: He introduced the Macintosh computer with a stunning ''1984''-themed commercial that ran just once, during that year's Super Bowl; since then new products from Apple Computer have often been announced at the January MacWorld trade show. Mr. Jobs's show stopper this year was his announcement that Apple had managed a small profit in the first quarter of its 1998 fiscal year. The crisis is far from over for the company Mr. Jobs founded -- and is now trying to turn around after a three-year slide in other hands -- but Wall Street was delighted by the progress so far, pushing Apple's stock up 20 percent.    TELECOMMUNICATIONS  Buying Local  Why invent what you can buy instead? SBC Communications, which bought Pacific Telesis in 1996 in the first merger among the Baby Bells, has announced a deal to acquire Connecticut's phone company, Southern New England Telephone, one of the few remaining sizable independents, for $4.4 billion. One lure: S.N.E.T. has regulatory permission to sell long-distance service to its local customers, a privilege so far denied to SBC and its former Bell siblings. And AT&T was attracted by a 26-state local franchise when it agreed last week to buy Teleport Communications for $11.3 billion in stock. The deal would spare AT&T the aggravation and cost of building its own new local service from scratch, and had been expected for months.

headline: When Life After Death Is the Company's Lot
abstract: Article on how two companies have fared since April 1996, when their chief executives died in plane crash in Croatia, along with Commerce Sec Ronald Brown and executives from other companies; Barry L Conrad, 55, was so closely identified with his upstart hotel-management company, Barrington International Hospitality, that there were no plans for succession; his widow, Patricia, took charge and Paul J Sistare has since become chief executive; Robert E Donovan, 54, headed US unit of ABB Inc, part of Swedish-Swiss engineering conglomerate; colleagues have pursued his reorganization plan under leadership of Howard Pierce; photos; list of executives killed in crash (M)

headline: Argentine Officer Who Hailed '70's Is Cashiered
abstract: Pres Carlos Saul Menem expels from Argentine Navy a retired captain, Alfred Astiz, who caused an international outcry by defending torture and killing under military dictatorship of 1976 to 1983 (S)

headline: Video Rental Study Dispels Some Fears
abstract: Video Software Dealers Assn says survey it commissioned from Yankelovich Partners found that movies, theaters and Internet are not cutting seriously into video rental business (S)

headline: As Asia's Economic Turmoil Deepens, Pentagon Chief Reassures Indonesia
abstract: Secretary of Defense William S Cohen meets with Pres Suharto to discuss expanding security ties with Indonesian Government; American officials say meeting and Cohen's comments afterward were intended as gesture of support for Suharto, who recently faced rare calls from opponents to step down; say Cohen's statements were part of two-pronged strategy to press Suharto to make economic concessions that will insure international bailout of his country's economy, while trying to prevent crisis from sowing political instability (M)

headline: KLM to Complete Ownership of Martinair
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines NV says it agreed to buy 50 percent of charter airline Martinair Holland BV that it does not already own from Royal Nedlloyd NV; Nedlloyd says it expects to get $172.3 million in cash for its stake (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Giant Slaloms By Keyboard, If You Can't Get to Nagano
abstract: Olympic-related Web sites are proliferating, for those who cannot get to Nagano (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen extends is rally from five-and-a-half-year lows against dollar; graphs; table (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Jean Robaire, creative director, and Sally Hogshead, copywriter, at Martin Creative Los Angeles, which was closed by the Martin Agency unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., opened Robaire & Hogshead, Los Angeles, where each is a creative partner.

headline: Registry Changes Its Name
abstract: Registry Inc changes its name to Renaissance Worldwide Inc (S)

headline: NEWMONT MINING SAYS IT WILL CUT WORK FORCE BY 11%
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp will cut 500 jobs from its US work force as part of plan to reduce spending by $250 million (S)

headline: Stepping Out From Its Cubicle
abstract: Profile of office furniture company Steelcase Inc; says company will be making initial public offering of 12.15 million shares, at $23 to $26 each; holds investors may find Steelcase reasonably priced prospect in now-booming business; graph; chart; photo (L)

headline: Spot Gold Price Is Under $280 Briefly in London and New York
abstract: Spot price of gold drops below $280 an ounce in London and New York for first time in more than 18 years as feaer of sales by central banks and low inflation continue to undermine outlook for precious metal; spot price falls to $278.45, before rebounding to finish at $281.05; on Comex Division of New York Mercantile Exchange, February gold drops to $279 before closing at 18-year low of $281.80 (M)
