headline: NETWORK ASSOCIATES AGREES TO BUY A SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: Network Associates Inc agrees to acquire Magic Solutions, a privately held software company, for $110 million (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley's Income Increases 21% in Quarter
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co says net income for quarter ended Feb 28 increased 21 percent, to $691 million; chart (M)

headline: Well Versed in E-Mail Subject Lines
abstract: Article on imaginative subject lines on E-mail documents (M)

headline: Blair Aims to Rescue Worst-Performing Schools
abstract: LONDON—  It couldn't have been more timely. Just as Britain sets itself the task of trying to rescue some of its poorest schools from persistent failure, word has come that the malaise within the education system appears to reach to the very top — to Oxford University itself.

headline: Iraq Neighbors Fear a Burden If U.S. Strikes
abstract: Iraq's neighbors are worried about what Pentagon terms 'collateral damage,' euphemism for loss of civilian life and property, amid speculation about US military strike on Iraq; people express concern that Americans do not care about Arab lives, govts or economies; reaction in Amman, Jordan, country that suffered heavily during Persian Gulf war in 1991, described (M)

headline: F. Cecil Brenner, 79, Scientist Who Devised Tire Ratings
abstract: F Cecil Brenner, scientist who devised tire ratings, dies at age 79 (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Covering Asia With Cash; Banks Poured Money Into Region Despite Warning Signs
abstract: Many international banks were stepping up their lending to Asian companies and banks even as hints of trouble were emerging in Asian economies; Bank for International Settlements says by December 1996, international banks forked over $367 billion to borrowers in Asia, up 20 percent from previous year; adds six months later, borrowings swelled to $389.4 billion, excluding large amount of lending to Hong Kong and Singapore; among American banks, Chase Manhattan Corp, Citicorp, J P Morgan, BankAmerica and Bankers Trust have greatest exposure to most troubled Southeast Asian economies; graph; photo (L)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: List of major articles in Business section

headline: Annan to Go to Iraq to Seek a Solution to Arms Impasse
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan says he will visit Iraq to try to resolve crisis over Pres Saddam Hussein's refusal to allow unconditional inspection for proscribed weapons of mass destruction; Security Council backs plan; five permanent members, Britain, China, France, Russia and United States advise him not to stray from Council resolutions demanding unconditional inspection of all installations (M)

headline: More Americans Are Getting Away From It All This Winter
abstract: Recent survey by nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America, which has been tracking travel habits of Americans since 1992, finds that nearly 153 million Americans plan to spend at least one night 100 miles or more from home this winter--5 percent incease over last year; says this is highest volume of increased travel intentions ever measured; cites healthy economy, buoyant consumer confidence and low gasoline prices as major factors for increased travel (M)

headline: S.& P. 500 Jumps 2% as Bargain Buyers Fuel Trading
abstract: Stocks zoom, with Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 20.64 points, nearly 2 percent, to record 1,055.69, and Dow Jones industrial average up 125.06, nearly 1.5 percent, to 8,569.39; Nasdaq composite index closes at 1,753.49, up 41.57; charts; graph (L)

headline: CUBA ANNOUNCES IT WILL FREE 200 IN BOW TO POPE
abstract: Cuban Govt, in what Vatican officials describe as welcome response to Pope John Paul II's appeal last month for release of all 'prisoners of conscience' in Cuba, annnounces that it intends to free 'more than 200 inmates' held on political and other charges; Foreign Ministry spokesman says that Cuba will pardon 'several dozen' prisoners whose names were on list that Vatican Secretary of State gave to Cuban authorities during Pope's visit; spokesman says that Cuba also intends to release scores of other prisoners on 'humanitarian grounds' (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; A Bad Case of Index Anxiety
abstract: Only one actively managed equity mutual fund in 10 managed to beat Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in 1997; index, including reinvestment dividends, finished year up 33.4 percent; average diversified equity fund gained 23.7 percent; graph (L)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Fees For Rivals Are Set
abstract: Germany's regulator says Deutsche Telekom AG must charge rivals less than it wants for use of local phone lines, opening the way for competition in local service; former monopoly can charge no more than $11.30 (US) a month for connections to homes and businesses (S)

headline: Man in the News: Atal Bihari Vajpayee; Sworn In as India's Leader, Ambiguity in His Wake
abstract: Man in the News profile of Atal Bihari Vajpayee, new Hindu nationalist Prime Minister of India; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Blasts at Campaign Rally in India Kill 30
abstract: India's election campaign is rocked by series of bomb explosions that kill at least 30 peoplein southern city of Coimbatore as thousands gather for rally by Hindu nationalist leader Lal Kishinchand Advandi (S)a

headline: Earnings at Travelers Fall 35% As Asia Hurts Brokerage Unit
abstract: Travelers Group says operating earnings fell 13 percent in fourth quarter, to $728.7 million, and net income declined 35 percent, to $376.7 million including portfolio gains of $144 million and merger-related restructuring charges of $496 million; plunging financial markets in Asia cited (M)

headline: INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY GILLETTE'S JAFRA UNIT
abstract: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc, leveraged buyout firm, acquires Gillette Co's Jafra Cosmetics International; price undisclosed (S)

headline: Yugoslavs Try to Outwit Albright Over Sanctions
abstract: American and European officials say Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic may have made just enough concessions over conflict in Kosovo Province to confound State Sec Madeleine K Albright's efforts to intensify Western sanctions against him; Albright is set to leave for Europe to increase pressure on Milosevic to open serious talks on political autonomy with ethnic Albanians, who make up 90% of population in Serbian province; will meet, Bonn, with ministers of Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Russia, members of contact group that monitors events in former Yugoslavia (M)

headline: Owens Corning to Cut Staff and Shut Plants
abstract: Owens Corning says it will dismiss 2,200 people, 9 percent of its work force, close several plants and report 1997 earnings that are well below analysts' estimates; cites intense competition in building materials industry (M)

headline: Report Mandela Calls Hoax Links Ex-Guerrilla to Coup Plot
abstract: Mystery surounding arrest of Robert McBride, former South African anti-apartheid guerrilla who is Government official, deepens after Pres Nelson Mandela says army report linking McBride to coup plot is probably hoax and may be part of right-wing plot to undermine country's first black-led Government (M)

headline: 2 Agency Companies In Media-Firm Deals
abstract: Two large agency companies say they agreed to deals with leading media and research firms; Interpublic Group of Companies in New York and its media services unit, Western International Media, acquired Herbert Zeltner Inc; terms not disclosed; WPP Group says Paul Donato, its senior vice president for media and communications research, will join Kantar Media Research in new position of chief executive as part of joint venture to develop new system to measure magazine readership (S)

headline: Data Reaffirm Good News On Economy
abstract: Producer Price Index falls seven-tenths of 1 percent in January; construction of new homes and apartments falls slightly in January from December, but annual rate of construction is still healthy at 1.53 million units; graphs (M)

headline: GERBER SCIENTIFIC ACQUIRES COBURN OPTICAL INDUSTRIES
abstract: Gerber Scientific Inc says it bought Coburn Optical Industries for $41.5 million in cash and assumption of $21.5 million of debt (S)

headline: A Welter of Wireless Choices
abstract: Market for wireless communications includes scores of competitors hawking phones and rate plans that seem designed to befuddle consumer; welter of options are too numerous to mention, but there are several basic distinctions about wireless technology and services that consumer should understand before making choice; photo; chart (M)

headline: RISKING I.M.F. AID, SUHARTO DISMISSES CENTRAL BANKER
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto defies Pres Clinton and International Monetary Fund and dismisses Bank of Indonesia head Sudradjad Djiwandono; acts after central banker warned Suharto's risky effort to strengthen rupiah would subvert economic recovery plan; risks losing $40 billion rescue package, apparently gambling IMF will not abandon nation; resurrects Asian economic crisis as Clinton Administration priority; United States officials say Suharto is increasingly isolated and disregards own financial advisers; photo (M)

headline: New Means To Make Men Feel Younger
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies look to largely untapped market for satisfying male ailments like impotence; trend is seen in Government's recent approval of Pfizer's Viagra, one of nearly dozen new treatments for impotence that are on market or being developed; Viagra is first pill for malady, but three other products in advanced trials also promise to be less painful and invasive than existing methods, like implants and injections; estimated 30 million men suffer at one time or another from some degree of male erectile dysfunction, but only 2.76 million visited doctors last year with the complaint; since many men are embarrassed about impotence, Pfizer is considering aiming part of its sales pitch toward women; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat futures prices rise; wheat for Mar delivery rises 6 cents a bushel, to $3.275; graphs; table (S)

headline: Israel Urges U.S. to Keep Peace Plan Quiet, but It's Already Out
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu has begun intense campaign, deploying Israeli officials and lobbyists, to prevent Clinton Administration from announcing specific proposal for reviving peace talks with Palestinians (M)

headline: Random House Sale Shakes Up Literary World
abstract: Bertelsmann AG's announcement that it is purchasing Random House has shocked literary world; deal came as surprise even to most top executives of Random House and sent waves of uncertainty through publishing industry; consolidation of major publishing houses could result in reduction in advances to midlist authors who sell fewer books than brand-name authors with best-seller status; that result could make it more difficult for nonstars to earn literary living; chart (L)

headline: PHILIP MORRIS TO CUT 1,900 JOBS IN TOBACCO UNIT
abstract: Philip Morris Companies plans to cut 1,900 jobs, or 11 percent of its US tobacco unit's work force, through voluntary early retirement offer as it moves to trim costs amid decline in US smoking (S)

headline: Investors Step Up Purchases Of Stock and Bond Funds
abstract: Investment Company Institute says investors stepped up their purchases of shares of stock and bond mutual funds in January, compared with December; cash flows to stock funds failed to measure up to levels reached in January of previous two years; stock funds garnered estimated $18.5 billion in net investments in January; figure topped December's cash flow of $16.8 billion; bond funds took in estimated $11.5 billion in January, up from $5.6 billion in December and $3.6 billion in January 1997 (M)

headline: U.N. Discord Is Music to Iraq and a Threat To Security Council Credibility.
abstract: Barbara Crossette analysis contends that with United Nations' chief weapons inspector, Richard Butler, going to Iraq in two weeks for another round of negotiations over Baghdad's refusal to allow full access to suspect sites, Security Council appears to be more paralyzed than it has been on any other issue since end of cold war (M)

headline: First Union to Acquire Money Store for $2.1 Billion
abstract: First Union Corp says it will buy Money Store Inc in $2.1 billion stock swap that creates largest home-equity lender in the country; home-equity loans, which allow borrowers to tap into equity stakes they have built up in their homes, have grown quickly with lower interest rates and greater acceptance of debt by consumers; Federal Deposit Corp reports home-equity debt totaled about $96 billion at end of third-quarter last year, up from $85.3 billion for all of 1996; Money Store deal seen bringing measure of conservatism to lower end of consumer finance industry, which has been impacted over last year by earnings problems related to overly optimistic accounting practices; Money Store, which specializes in lending to people with troubled credit histories, is one of more visible lenders in so-called subprime market; until recently, subprime market has been enormously profitable, and large banks see subprime lending as growth opportunity; market analyst says acquisition makes strategic sense for First Union because of the fight for the consumer now taking place in banking; analysts expect further consolidation in consumer finance businesses; chart on leading bank home equity lenders and non-bank home equity lenders (L)

headline: 4th-Quarter Net Declined Sharply at Sprint
abstract: Sprint Corp says net income fell to $194.9 million in fourth quarter, from $246 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 7.6 percent, to $3.85 billion from $3.58 billion (S)

headline: No Frills, Just Service With a Screen
abstract: Corporations are showing interest in Internet chat rooms as a business tool; companies as big as Merrill Lynch and IBM are experimenting with chat as way to interact more intimately with customers over Internet; Chase Manhattan Bank is looking at chat as way to assist retail customers who run into difficulty while using its Web site; others see chat as promising new tool for training and education; recent study by Jupiter Communications suggests servicing customers with chat could cost as little as 25 cents a transaction, compared with $1.25 for each phone transaction; drawing (M)

headline: Charities Use For-Profit Units To Avoid Disclosing Finances
abstract: Focus on increasing use by charities of perfectly legal but easily abused for-profit subsidiaries to help them avoid financial disclosure usually required by donors; detecting which uses are legitimate and which are examples of abuse is especially hard since operations are allowed to proceed with considerable degree of privacy; critics say, unlike nonprofit organizations with which they are associated, for-profit offshoots can dance around how much they spend on salaries, whom they employ or who receives consulting contracts; say charities that have for-profit businesses at disposal can shuttle costs and income between two entities to mutual advantage; say donors, deprived of customary disclosures, may have little warning that abuses might be taking place; photo (M)

headline: MEDITRUST IN STOCK DEAL FOR GOLF-COURSE OWNER
abstract: Meditrust Companies agree to buy Cobblestone Holdings Inc, privately held owner of golf courses, for $241 million in stock (S)

headline: Fed Chief Sees Benefit to U.S. In Asia Crisis
abstract: Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, says Asia's financial crisis will soon cause slowdown in economic growth in United States, thus reducing any remaining risk of inflation derailing nation's seven-year expansion; Greenspan calls economy exceptionally healthy, with inflation so far remaining dormant despite strong growth, low unemployment and solid income gains; leaves analysts with impression that central bank will hold interest rates steady at its meeting next week and for months to come; Greenspan supports Pres Clinton's call to dedicate any budget surpluses first to shoring up ailing Social Security system, and Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for International Monetary Fund; Charlene Barshefsky, United States trade representative, goes public after months of goading Japanese diplomats in private about need for Japan to do more to deregulate industry, open up its economy to trade and spur domestic demand; says Japan must play more active role in helping to bring Asia out of its current economic crisis (M)

headline: Big New Risks For America's Insurance Plan
abstract: Whether American investors can maintain their optimism through prolonged Asian downturn has as much to do with market psychology as with monthly tally of American exports; photos (M)

headline: Nine West Puts An Account in Review
abstract: Nine West Group places in review account of its Easy Spirit brand of women's footwear, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million; creative portion has been handled by Lotas Minard Patton McIver, while Media That Works has handled media planning and buying (S)

headline: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS; Beware: A January Winner May Be Just a House of Cards
abstract: Article on five best-performing mutual funds by total return for January 1998; says only Rydex OTC has beaten Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over three years; chart (L)

headline: Sailing the High-End Seas; Luxury Craft Are Back and Prices Are Bigger Than Ever
abstract: Boating industry is rebounding vigorously, buoyed by appetite of the newly rich for yachts costing $3 million to $30 million; new yacht sales in 1997 roughly matched record $2 billion of 1988, reflecting smaller number of much more expensive boats; sales of smaller motor yachts, 35 to 50 feet, have only partly recovered; graphs; table; photos (L)

headline: Puzzling Over Productivity
abstract: Letter by Melvin J Gordon, chariman of Tootsie Roll Industries, comments on March 8 article on produtivity; warns that data for 1990's cannot be believed, as pointed out by Alan Greenspan (S)

headline: 2 Sit in Indian State's Chair as Music Stops
abstract: Political chaos reigns in Uttar Pradesh, India's largest state, where rival claimants for post of Chief Minister are encamped in Chief Minister's office in Lucknow, each appealing to police to throw the other out; many Indians fear such chaos will develop in New Delhi if current national election follows pattern of three since 1989 that failed to produce clear-cut winner; map (M)

headline: Indonesia Opposition Chief Calls on President to Resign
abstract: Indonesia's opposition leader Megawati Sukarnoputri calls on Pres Suharto to step down when his term ends in March and tells about 500 supporters that she is ready to succeed him; her declaration comes during period of growing public demands for end to Suharto's 32-year-rule as country's economy swirls in crisis; photo (M)

headline: What Becomes a Legend?; A New Executive Rethinks America's Lingerie Pioneer
abstract: Terry W Patterson, first woman to lead Frederick's of Hollywood in its 50-year history, must move retailer from wobbling, publicly traded family business into privately held company with hopes of reigniting strong growth after decade of running in place; Frederick's, which let Victoria's Secret run away with much of market it initially created, has lost touch with its customers; graph; photo (M)

headline: China to Prime Economic Pump With Mammoth Building Outlay
abstract: China's leaders plan to spend $1 trillion on huge range of public works projects in next three years, in effort to stop Asian financial crisis from derailing country's economic growth; spending plan adds $300 billion in spending to $700 billion already on drawing board; only after detailed list of projects is released will it become clear which sections are new and which are not; plan's broad scope is indication of how seriously threatened nation's leaders feel by Asian financial crisis and its potential to devastate an economy; Government official says money will come from domestic and foreign bonds and loans and direct allocations from central Government and contributions from provincial governments; current crisis is expected to slow modernization of China's financial system; China's leaders, fearful of power of international currency markets, have indefinitely delayed plans to make their own currency fully tradeable; photo (M)

headline: W. Wood Prince, 83, of Chicago; Businessman Adopted by Cousin
abstract: William Wood Prince, former president, chief executive and chairman of Armour & Co, dies at age of 83; Wood Prince was also prominent philanthropist; photo (M)

headline: For Oxford, Talks and a $100 Million Loan
abstract: Oxford Health Plans has obtained $100 million in short-term financing and will actively pursue other sources of capital; company is said to be talking wiht several potential sources of financing, including buyout firms Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, but such a deal does not appear to be imminent (S)

headline: 2d-Half Net Fell 73% at NatWest
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC's implied second-half net income fell 73 percent, to 139 million pounds ($228 million), down from 413 million pounds in 1996 period; bank reports 1997 net income rose to 627 million pounds, up 56 percent from from 402 million pounds in 1996; graph (S)

headline: GILLETTE PLANS TO SPLIT ITS STOCK AND INCREASE DIVIDEND
abstract: Gillette Co plans to split its stock 2 for 1 and increase its dividend by 19 percent (S)

headline: A New Model for Africa: Good Leaders Above All
abstract: James C McKinley Jr analysis contends that Pres Clinton's decision to hold conference in Uganda with East African leaders sends strong signal that US is embracing new generation of leaders in region who care less about establishing full-fledged democracies than they do about developing their countries; says unofficial standard-bearer for this group is Uganda Pres Yoweri K Museveni (M)

headline: Intimate Brands to Close Cacique Business
abstract: Intimate Brands Inc will close its Cacique lingerie business, resulting in pretax charge of $60 million to $70 million in 1998 fiscal year (S)

headline: Germans Cut Labor Costs With a Harsh Export: Jobs
abstract: Second of two articles Help Unwanted, on Europe's job drought, focuses on Germany; examines most striking economic feature in Germany: growth without jobs; notes that while Europe is enjoying its best economic growth in years, employers are not hiring many people; after years of layoffs and cost cutting, unemployment remains at record rates--11.6 percent in Germany and more than 10 percent across European Union; economists say that more and more, Europe's economies are growing without creating jobs; high labor costs and high payroll taxes discourage companies from adding workers; labor costs are pushing companies to invest elsewhere; last year German companies invested $25 billion abroad--10 times as much as foreign companies invested in Germany, biggest investment gap ever; political implications are potentially explosive; photo; charts (L)

headline: Earnings Reports Push Major Stock Market Indexes Down
abstract: Major stock market indexes post their first declines of week, as investors show uncertainty about outlook for corporate earnings; Dow Jones industrial average falls 92.92 points, or 1.2 percent, to 7,691.77; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index slips 7.21 points, to 950.73; graph (M)

headline: How Boyhood Friend Aided Pope With Israel
abstract: Jerzy Kluger, Jew who was boyhood friend of Pope John Paul II, comments on his role as Pope's informal intermediary between Israeli and Vatican officials in talks that eventually led to Vatican diplomatic recognition of Israel, phone interview; holds Pope is friend of Jewish people, having grown up with Jews in Wadowice, Poland; his role in talks was revealed in new book by Darcy O'Brien; photo (M)

headline: As Heir to Fidel, Raul Castro Assumes Bigger Role in Cuba
abstract: Cuban officials say that three months after Fidel Castro formally selected his younger brother, Raul, as his eventual successor, he appears to be assuming wider range of official duties and playing more prominent role in running of Government (M)

headline: New York Lottery Reviewing Account
abstract: New York State Lottery says it has begun mandated review on its account, which has been handled for last decade by DDB Needham New York; billings estimated at $50 million to $60 million (S)

headline: Serbs Bombed Ethnic Albanians; Many are Feared Dead
abstract: People fleeing area say Serbian police shell villages in central Kosovo, set fire to homes and appear to shoot at men indiscriminately in sweep to stamp out separatist movement of ethnic Albanians; attacks apparently leave many dead; ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of population in province, once autonomous region of Yugoslavia; police bar reporters from entering area; map; photo (M)

headline: ISRAEL ANNOUNCES STRINGENT TERMS FOR WITHDRAWAL
abstract: Israeli Cabinet says Israel will make no further withdrawal from West Bank unless Palestinians satisfy series of stringent conditions; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat's aides dismiss conditions as another attempt by Israel to avoid any further withdrawal; it appears that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu will go to Washington for meeting with Pres Clinton without any proposal that will enable stalled peace negotiations to resume; Clinton will meet with Netanyahu on Jan 20 and with Arafat on Jan 22; Israeli decision follows brief visit by US mediator Dennis Ross that was generally depicted as failure by Israelis and Palestinians (M)

headline: NBC Signs Deal to Keep 'Mad About You' for Another Season
abstract: NBC concludes deal that would bring hit comedy Mad About You back to network for another season; both of show's stars, Paul Reiser and Helen Hunt, agree to return to series for one more year; negotiations had been stalemated on stars' demands for salaries of $1 million each for an episode; though neither side will disclose terms of deal, executive close to deal says stars received amount they had demanded; NBC had been concerned that Hunt might opt to quit television for film career (L)

headline: Q&A/ Richard Stallman : Why Software Should Be Free and Shared
abstract: Richard Stallman developed the free software operating system called GNU, which is currently used by an estimated five million people. Principal author of several GNU programs, Mr. Stallman, 45, was awarded a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship in 1990, and received an honorary doctorate from the Royal Institute of Technology in Sweden. He is currently a researcher in residence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where he recently met with Ken Shulman.

headline: End Is Seen To Simmons Family Feud
abstract: Dallas businessman Harold C Simmons agrees in principle to settle suit by two daughters over control of his billion-dollar fortune; Simmons will give each of them about $50 million; in return, Simmons will retain control of the rest of his wealth, including five public companies; photo (L)

headline: CLINTON DESCRIBES GOALS FOR A STRIKE ON IRAQI ARSENALS
abstract: Pres Clinton, charging Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein lies and cheats to cling to chemical and biological arms, says he is prepared to order air strikes to 'seriously diminish' Iraqi threat to region and world, televised speech at Pentagon; seeks to rally public support for possible action; repeatedly says he hopes diplomats can persuade Hussein to comply with weapons inspections; says force cannot eliminate Iraq's ability to make such arms; appears with Defense Sec William S Cohen, Vice Pres Al Gore and Gen Henry Hugh Shelton after military briefing by Joint Chiefs of Staff; photo (M)

headline: Vornado Reported to Be in Talks for Barney's
abstract: Vornado Realty Trust is in talks with Barney's Inc; Vornado, should it consider a bid for Barney's, will be adding its name to list of potential investors that have considered taking retail company out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Pope vs. Embargo: Still a Sharp Divide in U.S.
abstract: Pope John Paul II is expected to denounce United States's economic embargo of Cuba during his Cuba visit; embargo opponents, including 600 business groups and 140 religious and human-rights organizations, hope visit will spur American political leaders to rethink effort to isolate Cuba; Clinton Administration says US will watch Cuba's policies after visit; anti-Castro members of Congress remain committed to embargo (M)

headline: Investment in Vietnam Dropped Sharply in 1997
abstract: Vietnam reports new foreign investment totaled $4.5 billion in 1997, about half of record $8.6 billion in new projects licensed year before (S)

headline: Waving Audit Flags
abstract: Although only one out of 100 personal income tax returns is audited, certain characteristics, known as audit flags, greatly increase your odds of attracting Internal Revenue Service scrutiny. Claim anything to which you are entitled on your return, tax professionals say, but if your action raises an audit flag, be sure you have the records to defend it. Ten such flags are:      * Discrepancies in the income you report and what payers have reported to the I.R.S. on forms W-2 and 1099. If the issuers have made a mistake, taxpayers should ask them to issue corrected forms.    * Married taxpayers filing separately. The I.R.S. has found that many such people do not report items consistently between the two returns.    * Regular returns with sizable items that often make taxpayers liable for the alternative minimum tax. Among them: deductions for state and local property and income taxes, the exercise of incentive stock options and big capital gains.    * Working in a business in which substantial cash payments are often made. The I.R.S. tends to look at doctors, lawyers, store owners and waiters in this regard, and it is particularly interested in self-employed taxpayers who report gross receipts of $100,000 or more on Schedule C.    * Being in a business that the I.R.S. sees as needing special attention. Among roughly 100 businesses that the I.R.S. is examining more closely are air charters, art dealers, bed and breakfasts, entertainment concerns, gas stations, liquor stores, mortuaries, pawn shops, restaurants and bars, taxi services and used-car dealers.    * Deductions or business expenses that seem large in proportion to reported income. The I.R.S. does not disclose its exact criteria.    * A return signed by an accountant or tax preparer who is on an I.R.S. list of ''problem preparers'' who have repeatedly violated the law.    * Complex business or investment transactions without clear explanations. Attach a separate statement if needed to explain an item on the return.    * Schedule F (farm) losses, particularly when the taxpayer has sizable salary income.    * Claiming the earned-income credit. The I.R.S. has found abuse in this area and tends to scrutinize claims.

headline: Brazil, Its Forests Besieged, Adds Teeth to Environmental Laws
abstract: Brazilian Congress votes to give federal environmental agency legal authority to enforce environmental protection laws, after Government figures show destruction of Amazon rain forest reached record levels in mid-1990's (M)

headline: CVS to Acquire Arbor Drugs For $1.48 Billion in Stock
abstract: CVS Corp to acquire Arbor Drugs Inc for $1.48 billion in stock, positioning it to become largest drugstore chain in the country; chart (M)

headline: Khmer Rouge Factions Battle Each Other in the Jungle
abstract: Remnants of Cambodia's Communist Khmer Rouge movement, riven by factional fighting, have reportedly turned guns against each other near jungle stronghold in northern Cambodia; mutineers have reportedly been joined by Government soldiers at base of Anlong Veng, and estimated 10,000 people are said to have fled into jungles; Cambodian officials say Government troops have taken control of part of Khmer Rouge territory along northern border with Thailand; map; photo (M)

headline: Isla de los Estados Journal; Dream Fulfilled at End of the World
abstract: Andre Bronner, French navigator, fulfills childhood dream by building lighthouse on Isla de los Estados, bleak island in Cape Horn off Argentine coast, that is replica of 1884 structure that inspired Jules Verne's last novel, The Lighthouse at the End of the World; maps; photo (M)

headline: Dow Closes Above 8,500 As Blue-Chip Issues Rally
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 55.05 points, to record 8,545.72; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rises 0.67 points, to record 1,049.34; graph; tables (M)

headline: Turks Fear an Oil Disaster as the Bosporus Gets Busier
abstract: Turkish officials say that tanker traffic in narrow Bosporus Strait could be reaching dangerous levels as huge amounts of oil and gas begin flowing from rich new fields in Caspian Sea basin; map; photo (M)

headline: Santa Fe to Add 4 Rigs
abstract: Santa Fe International Corp says it will add four rigs to its land rig fleet in Venezuela at cost of $75 million (S)

headline: Cristobal Martinez-Bordiu, 75, Surgeon Who Cared for Franco
abstract: Cristobal Martinez-Bordiu, surgeon who cared for Gen Francisco Franco and married Franco's only child, dies at age of 75 (M)

headline: TOYS 'R' US PLANS ANOTHER $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc will buy back $1 billion of its stock; company adopts 'poison pill' defense tactic intended to make hostile takeovers prohibitively expensive (S)

headline: A Warning About Sales By Compaq
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp says it will not make any profit in first quarter because of unexpected falloff in sales; Compaq attributes drop chiefly to sales to corporate customers in North America, its single biggest market; Compaq estimates its sales in first quarter will be about same as $5.3 billion it posted a year earlier; that would be 28 percent drop from fourth quarter of 1997 (L)

headline: Pact on Air Traffic By U.S. and Japan To Lift Restrictions
abstract: US and Japan end longstanding aviation dispute, agreeing to remove most restrictions on air traffic between two countries; framework agreement adds service between more cities in both countries, removesrestrictions on five carriers--United, Northwest, FDX Corp, Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways--and loosens restrictions on other American carriers; allows new American airlines into market and partner airlines involved in code sharing to jointly offer same flights; confirms rights of cargo carriers to transport freight through Japan to other destinations, but does not allow increase in number of landing slots for new flights at Narita International Airport outside Tokyo (M)

headline: What Patients Want From Their Hospitals
abstract: Robert J Salgado letter on J Philip Lathrop's Feb 1 article calling for pain-free, privacy-protected health care delivery (S)

headline: G.O.P. Pushes To Overhaul Finance Law
abstract: US House Republican leaders propose compromise to break long stalemate over how to update legislation governing financial services industry, offering bill that would eliminate many of barriers that separate banks, securities firms and insurers; proposal wins support from Wall Street and insurance industry; big banks say they want to study details before taking position (L)

headline: U.S. Sees New Villain in Asia Crisis: Tokyo's Leadership
abstract: Foreign ministers from world's leading industrialized countries, at opening of meeting in London, say Japan is undermining international effort to restore stability to rest of Asia by failing to stimulate its own economy; photo (M)

headline: Reed Elsevier Profit Rises Just 1.4%
abstract: Reed Elsevier's implied second-half profit before charges rose only 1.4 percent; profit rose to 296 million pounds ($488 million) before charges, from 292 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: A Big Merger In Health Care Is Called Off
abstract: Phycor Inc's $6.8 billion acquisition of Medpartners Inc, announced on Oct 29, 1997, is called off; proposed merger had been heralded as biggest in the industry (L)

headline: 2 Chinese Steelmakers Weighing Merger
abstract: China's two most profitable steel companies may merge as country strives to cut overlapping and increase efficiency; proposed merger, initiated by Wuhan Iron and Steel Works, or Wugang, has been accepted tentatively by Baoshan Iron and Steel Corp; China's steelmakers have been hurt by falling prices and overproduction (S)

headline: Top Coup Suspect in Nigeria Asserts 'a Setup' as Trial Begins
abstract: Nigerian military tribunal begins hearing cases of 26 people suspected of plotting Dec coup; Lt Gen Oladipo Diya, former top military leader, and others charge coup was fabricated as excuse for Gen Sani Abacha's regime to crack down on possible challengers (S)

headline: ASIAN MARKETS TUMBLE.
abstract: Most of Asia's stock markets, except for South Korea, have plunged in New Year, giving up gains made in December; Indonesia dropped 12 percent, Singapore 7.1 percent and Hong Kong 3 percent; South Korean stocks rose 3.6 percent; graphs (S)

headline: Club Med Discloses Plan for Reviving Its Resorts
abstract: Club Mediterranee plans to raise 1.2 billion French francs ($201 million) in new capital and set aside another 1.45 billion francs to finance overhaul of its financially troubled resort empire; chief executive Philippe Bourguignon comments (S)

headline: Record Big Board Seat Sale
abstract: Seat on New York Stock Exchange sells for record $1.8 million (S)

headline: Americans Abroad Learning Studies Now Offer a Bargain
abstract: Number of Americans studying abroad has jumped 84 percent over last decade; with average bill for private schools in US now more than $20,000 a year--and costs elsewhere in world much lower--growing number of American families are finding that experience that once was largely restricted to well-to-do is turning into something that middle class can no longer afford to ignore; number of students seeking bargain educations abroad has grown so quickly that backlash has been seen, both at American schools and those in foreign countries; University of Pennsylvania charges students going abroad same amount they would pay on Philadelphia campus; some countries that heavily subsidize higher education have taken to charging foreigners full price; graph (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SELL SOFTWARE LINE TO PLATINUM
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co will sell Intelligent Warehouse line of products to Platinum Technology Inc (S)

headline: Incentive of Sweden Seals Shift of Focus
abstract: Incentive AB will assume name of its dialysis equipment unit, Gambro, on July 1; company reports fourth-quarter profit rose to 1.740 billion kronor ($218 million) from 477 million kronor (S)

headline: Korea Steadies Itself on the Road to Recovery
abstract: South Korean stock market rises 2.37 percent for total increase of 26.55 percent so far this year; stock market gains underscore rare bit of good news from Asia these days: after near-death experience in December, South Korea may have stabilized for the moment; many investors, diplomats and government officials are far more positive about nation's prospects than they were just a couple of weeks ago (L)

headline: Prices Rise as Fears About Asia and Interest Rates Ebb
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 72.24 points, to 8,189.49; Standard & Poor's 500 index jumps 8.92 points, to record 1,012.46; bond prices rally; 30-year Treasury bond rises 5/32, to 102 29/32, to yield 5.92 percent; graph; tables (M)

headline: In California, a Distant Mirror on Korea
abstract: Bong Koo Cho, once one of wealthiest industrialists and biggest landowners in South Korea, and his family have filed lawsuit in state court in Los Angeles, Calif, demanding return of their fortune, which they say was illegally seized from them by military dictatorship of Chun Doo Hwan in 1984; Cho estimates assets would be worth $2 billion; lawsuit could cast light on corruption and political meddling in South Korea's economic system; case also shows that back in 1980's Korea was dealing with huge industrial expansion, backed by Government and fueled by heavy borrowing that left many companies on verge of bankruptcy and banks buried under bad debts; Cho's company, Sambo Group, one of largest conglomerates at the time, was transferred to rival company, Daelim Group, as part of Government program to merge, sell or liquidate companies deemed to be insolvent; Cho denies that Sambo was insolvent and says real reason was that he and his family failed to pay enough bribes to Pres Chun (L)

headline: Carat North America Has Acquired Freeman
abstract: Carat North America, media services agency owned by Aegis Group PLC, acquires Freeman Associates (S)

headline: German Ex-Monopoly Wants a Switching Fee
abstract: Deutsche Telekom says it wants to charge customers one-time fee if they switch to competing telephone company after its monopoly on voice service ends today; fee would apply only to what is called 'preselection service' under which all of a customer's long-distance calls are taken care of by another company (S)

headline: U.S. to Back Baltic Membership In NATO, but Not Anytime Soon
abstract: US and three Baltic nations will sign Charter of Partnership on January 16 in which US explicitly supports efforts by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to become members of NATO; document will not promise these countries NATO membership, but will be formal statement of common interests and common goals that future American administration will find difficult to dilute; does not pledge US to defense of Baltic countries, but embodies a moral and political commitment to their independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corrections of Feb 22 article and picture caption on workers suffering from multiple chemical sensitivity3

headline: U.S. Weighs Deal to Halt Missile-Gear Sales by China
abstract: US is weighing whether to allow American satellite manufacturers to buy launching services from China; senior US official says in exchange, China would have to create system to stop sales of Chinese missile technology to nations like Iran; move would waive sanctions imposed after 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre; it would allow Pres Clinton to take attractive proposal with him when he visits China in summer (M)

headline: World News Briefs; Peace Talks on Schedule Despite Killing in Ulster
abstract: British and Irish officials say outbreak of violence in Northern Ireland will not delay resumption of peace talks (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Land O'Lakes Inc., Arden Hills, Minn., to Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, owned by top management and the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its consumer promotion account, which had been handled by Rapp Collins Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $15 million. Campbell Mithun also handles consumer, trade and interactive advertising for Land O'Lakes as well as direct marketing.

headline: P.& G. Decision Prompts a Change
abstract: State Lawrence, executive vice president and managing partner at Wells BDDP, leaves to join Grey Advertising in new position of executive vice president and global account director for Pringles snack chips (S)

headline: REGIONS FINANCIAL WILL BUY ETOWAH BANK
abstract: Regions Financial Corp buys Etowah Bank of Canton, Ga, for $117.4 million (S)

headline: APOLLO MANAGEMENT BUYING 90% STAKE IN TANK TRUCKER
abstract: Sombrero Acquisition Corp, affiliate of Apollo Management LP, agrees to acquire Bangor, Me, tank-trucking company MTL Inc for $196 million plus assumption of $54 million in debt (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge's Ruling Could Allow Baby Bells to Expand   A Federal judge in Texas ruled yesterday that major sections of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 are unconstitutional, threatening the system created by Congress to deregulate the $200 billion telecommunications industry.    If the decision by Judge Joe Kendall of the United States District Court in Dallas is upheld, it could eliminate barriers that up until now have prevented regional Bell telephone companies from offering long-distance service. [Page A1.]

headline: Yeltsin Says He Won't Run For Another Term in 2000
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin says he will not run for re-election in 2000; refrains from endorsing any of potential candidates (M)

headline: U.S. WILL NOT ASK TO USE SAUDI BASES FOR A RAID ON IRAQ
abstract: US Defense Sec William S Cohen, amid deep reluctance by Saudi Arabia to support military strike against Iraq, says US will not seek permission to launch air strikes from Saudi bases; begins tour of Persian Gulf states; says very substantial attack can still be carried out even without use of aircraft based in Saudi Arabia; Saudi's tough stance undercuts Clinton Administration's efforts to build political support for punitive attack in confrontation over UN inspections of Iraq's chemical and biological weapons programs; photo (M)

headline: Suharto Aide Concedes Plan On Currency Is Impractical
abstract: Indonesia's Finance Min Fuad Bawazier acknowledges that plan favored by Pres Suharto to peg currency to dollar is not realistic; his statement appears to remove one of chief obstacles in discussions with International Monetary Fund over disagreements that have stalled release of $40 billion in economic assistance (M)

headline: The Fed Reports Slowdown In Industrial Production
abstract: Federal Reserve says industrial production unexpectedly stalled in January as utility output fell 4 percent; says output at factories, mines and utilities was unchanged in January to compared with December after having risen revised four-tenths of 1 percent in Decembed; plant-use rate, which measures amount of industrial capacity in use, fell to 83 percent in January from revised 83.3 percent in December; graphs (M)

headline: Prime Lending Rates Lowered in Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong banks cut their prime lending rates by one-quarter point, to 10 percent (S)

headline: Treasury Securities End Mixed After New Inflation Warning
abstract: Treasury securities end mixed, result of weakness in stock market, inflation warning from Federal Reserve official, new evidence of economic slowdown and glut of corporate bond offerings; 30-year bond falls 4/32, to price of 105 15/32; yield rises to 5.74 percent; graph (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Bob Chimbel was named to the vacant position of managing partner and chief creative officer at TLP, Dallas, a unit of Omnicom Group. He had been senior vice president and executive creative director at Bronner Slosberg Humphrey, Boston.

headline: IRI INTERNATIONAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR HITEC OF NORWAY
abstract: IRI International Corp says it agreed to acquire Hitec ASA of Norway for $280 million in stock; Hitec will retain 35 percent stake in combined company, which will be called IRI Hitec Inc (S)

headline: How Serial Refinancings Can Rob Equity
abstract: Regulators, consumer groups and Congressional investigators say poor and elderly have proved especially vulnerable topredatory lending practices by mortgage companies intent on generating big fees by constantly refinancing high-interest loans; say problem has grown in tandem with subprime lending industry--companies that make loans to people with little income or with checkered credit histories; according to Federal Trade Commission, industry has grown sharply in recent years, from tiny niche in consumer lending to 15.5 percent of total home equity lending in first half of 1997; photo(S)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of photo caption with March 15 article on resistance among owners of sport utility vehicles to higher liability rates

headline: Senate Urged To Approve Expansion Of NATO
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright begins Clinton Administration's final push for Senate approval of NATO expansion, warning Senate not to complicate effort by trying to delay possible second round of expansion for states, such as Romania and Slovenia; Pres Clinton is expected to submit documents for expansion on February 13 in move to secure major foreign policy goal; Senate is expected to approve in March addition of Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic in initial round of expansion (M)

headline: Balloon Sets One Record but Is Stymied by China
abstract: Three-man balloon Breitling Orbiter II sets flight duration record, but crew's hopes of being first balloonists to circle world nonstop are dashed by China's refusal to let craft enter Chinese airspace; craft, piloted by Dr Bertrand Piccard, cruises slowly over India (S)

headline: Hong Kong Donor to Tories Now Wants $1.7 Million Returned
abstract: Ma Ching-kwan, owner of The Oriental Daily, Hong Kong's largest-selling Chinese-language daily, is asking for return of $1.7 million allegedly paid to Britain's Conservative Party for certain commitments to family that have been unfulfilled; may have been trying to win influence so father Ma Sik-chun, allegedly one of Asia's biggest drug lords who fled former colony in 1978 after conviction in trafficking case, could return without arrest; Conservative Party spokesman categorically denies that donation was accepted conditional on performing any favors (M)

headline: Dow Rebounds After a Shock : Major Bankruptcy In Hong Kong Hits Asian Markets Hard
abstract: TAIPEI—  Stock markets and currencies around Asia took a dramatic dive to new lows on Monday — pushing down shares across Europe and shaking Wall Street — as one of Asia's largest investment banks, Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., went into liquidation.

headline: Chrysler Net Up But Higher Costs Raise Concerns
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that were better than expected, but the numbers, particularly a sharp increase in rebates and other incentives, set Wall Street to worrying about the auto industry's prospects for this year.    The cost of rebates and other incentives by Chrysler jumped 79.5 percent in the quarter, alarming analysts who expect other auto makers will also show increases in marketing costs.

headline: Commercial-time rates for last 'Seinfeld' should break records.
abstract: Advertising trade publications and USA Today report that NBC may charge up to record $2 million for 30-second commercial during series finale of sitcom Seinfeld; chart; photo (L)

headline: Allied Textile Ends Talks and Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of Allied Textile Companies fall as much as 15 percent after company says it ended takeover talks in absence of formal offer (S)

headline: Software Maker Seeks Services Concern in $8.4 Billion Bid
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc, leading maker of business software, makes uninvited $8.4 billion bid for Computer Sciences Corp, major provider of technology services, that would accelerate consolidation of industry in which size is now equated with survival; Compaq Computer Corp's purchase of Digital Equipment Corp and Computer Associates bid are driven by some common themes: challenge of resurgent IBM and primacy of computer services, a business that increasingly determines where corporations and Government agencies spend their technology budgets; computer services companies like Computer Sciences have graduated to become corporate consultants and gained access to top executives; chart lists Computer Associates' acquisitions since September 1991 (L)

headline: MARC to Acquire Agency in Dallas
abstract: MARC Advertising says it agreed to acquire Larkin, Meeder & Schweidel; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL AGREES TO BUY AMERUS BANK OF IOWA
abstract: Commercial Federal Corp agrees to buy Amerus Bank of Iowa for $200.9 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, VIOLA WERTHEIM, M.D.
abstract: BERNARD-Viola Wertheim, M.D. On March 21, 1998. Daughter of the late Jacob and Emma Wertheim. Beloved aunt of Joan Wofford and David Whittlesey. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.    BERNARD-Dr. Viola W. The Executive Committee, faculty, staff and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, express our deepest sorrow over the death of one of the Center's founders and our esteemed colleague, Viola Bernard. Dr. Bernard was a vital part of the Columbia Psychoanalytic Center for over fifty years. Bringing psychoanalytic understanding to important issues in the fields of social and child psychiatry, her work brought insights and approaches to the amelioration of emotional suffering of children and adults. Robert A. Glick, M.D., Director    BERNARD-Viola, M.D. The officers and members of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute express their profound sorrow at the death of their respected and beloved colleague Dr. Viola Bernard. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her family. Lester Schwartz, M.D., President/Society Edward Hartmann, M.D., President/Institute    BERNARD-Viola, M.D. Always the advocate for, and care giver to, those in need. Including victims of bigotry, poverty, abandonment and political oppression. She was also a renowned clinician, teacher and mentor and beloved friend. E. Gerald Dabbs, M.D.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: CINCINNATI STOCK EXCHANGE, an electronic stock exchange with headquarters in Chicago, named David Colker, its chief operating officer, to the additional position of president.    KELLY SERVICES INC., Detroit, gave Terence Adderley, president and chief executive of Kelly, the additional title of chairman, filling the position left vacant by William Russell Kelly, who died earlier this month.

headline: A Survivor Seeks to Stand Tall in Sandals
abstract: Article on Deckers Outdoor Corp, maker of Teva sandals and other footwear, which has battled heavy competition for years; some analysts say it may be poised for better times as survivor of an industry shakeout; graph (L)

headline: 4:43 A.M.: Do You Know Where Your Broker Is?
abstract: Increasing number of stock trades are being executed in after-hours transactions by computer; Texas investor Gerry Krayenhagen explains how he made $6,000 on overnight investment in Dell Computer; photo; graph (S)

headline: Scandals Can Hurt Bulls and Presidents
abstract: Market Place column on how Presidential scandals have hurt Wall Street; focuses on markets' reactions to Teapot Dome scandal of 1923 that might have led to impeachment of Pres Warren G Harding had he not died before new came out and Watergate Affair that led to resignation of Pres Richard Nixon in 1974; graph (L)

headline: LAZARD TO INVEST $220 MILLION IN RUBENSTEIN
abstract: Lazard Freres & Co's real estate unit, Prometheus Mid-Atlantic Investors Trust, agrees to invest $220 million in Rubenstein Co (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           Feb. 6   Jan. 30   Feb. 7       1998   1998   1997       Gasoline production, daily   7.9   7.6   7.0       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.4   3.1       Gasoline stocks   219.2   218.1   207.6       Distillate stocks   128.8   134.2   110.6       Crude imports, daily   8.4   6.8   7.9       Product imports, daily   1.6   1.8   1.9       Crude stocks   326.3   321.4   301.8       Crude production, daily   6.3   6.3   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   91.0   90.8   87.6          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Seagram Americas Reviews an Account
abstract: Seagram Americas says it has placed in review account of three brands handled for last decade by Ogilvy & Mather New York: Seagram's 7 Crown whisky, Seagram's Gin and Seagram's VO Canadian whisky; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Indonesian Reserves Fell 14% in February
abstract: Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves plunged 14 percent in February to $16.33 billion, their lowest point since at least 1993 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar retreats for third day against yen on further signals that Tokyo might use public funds to stimulate economy; graphs (S)

headline: Small Group Of Protestants Quits Talks On Ulster
abstract: Ulster Democratic Party, small Protestant party with links to paramilitary Ulster Freedom Fighters that admitted killing three Catholics earlier in month, quits Northern Ireland peace talks after pressure by other participants; departure is seen as another blow to already fragile peace effort (M)

headline: Detainees In Nigeria Pin Hopes On the Pope
abstract: Human rights campaigners express hope that Pope John Paul II will use his visit to Nigeria this month to seek clemency for Nigeria's political prisoners; they say issue has gained urgency with worsening health of one of country's best-known political detainees, Beko Ransome-Kuti, leader of Campaign for Democracy (M)

headline: U.S. Losing Battle on Control Of Data Encryption, Study Says
abstract: Electronic Privacy Information Center, independent research group, says Clinton Administration is losing its battle to increase international controls over how reliably computer data can be scrambled to insure privacy; group says its survey of 243 governments shows United States is virtually only democratic, industrialized nation seeking domestic regulation of strong encryption; Clinton Administration contends it has support of most nations on this issue (M)

headline: ENGELHARD TO BUY MALLINCKRODT'S CATALYST UNIT
abstract: Engelhard Corp will buy Mallinckrodt Inc's chemical-catalyst unit for $210 million cash (S)

headline: Industrial Production Is Unchanged; Housing Soars
abstract: Industrial production was unchanged in February even as nation's housing market boomed; Federal Reserve reports production at factories, mines and utilities stalled after rising one-tenth of 1 percent in January; manufacturing output also held steady; Commerce Department says housing starts rose 6 percent in February, well above January's increase of two-tenths of 1 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ernst & Young and KPMG Scrap Plan for Huge Merger  Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick called off their merger, which would have created the world's largest accounting and consulting firm. The leaders of the two firms cited growing opposition to the proposed deal from foreign regulators.

headline: W. Bradford Wiley, 87, Independent Publisher
abstract: W Bradford Wiley, publisher, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: Leftists Attack at a German Far-Right Rally
abstract: Right- and left-wing activists in Germany clash for second time in two weeks, as thousands of supporters of far-right political party congregate in Passau, town on Danube, to promote their cause before September's national election; photo (S)

headline: Choosing Between Phone and Cable for Internet Access
abstract: Stock market reacts to formation of consortium being formed to speed Internet access, which so far includes GTE, US West Communications, BellSouth, SBC Communications and Ameritech with Microsoft, Intel and Compaq Computer, hopes to develop new modems and software that will be up to 30 times faster than today's telephone modems; news helps to push up stock of Aware Inc, but stock of At Home Corp, which uses rival system to provide Internet access over cable lines, falls sharply (M)
